reviews.review: Serenity and tranquility. Leave the bustle behind and enjoy a relaxing leisurely stroll in this park. Beautifully maintained gardens and traditional style Chinese buildings. Well worth a visit.

Peaceful Garden. As a local people, I would also be there to enjoy the peace and quiet moment. Peaceful environment with a big garden, tourists were also nice to keep there quiet and clean. Convenient location which next to the diamond hill station. It is also free to entrance.

Man's creation is so incredible. I had visited the place 2 times with my overseas friends. Both times, we opt for the guided tours which starts from 5.00pm to 6.00 pm. The guide explained to us the design concepts and also the difficulties that the builder encountered. That made us more appreciative of what we have today. You would understand the long history of each...


More

Worth a Visit. Just visited Nan Lian Garden after having lived here for 8 years. It's surprisingly good, very peaceful and worth a visit if you're in HK. Not much to do for kids, but it's nice walk and some good photo ops

Serenity in the city!. We stayed withing walking distance of the gardens and nunnery when in Hong Kong. It doesn't take long to walk round the gardens and the nunnery but it is beautiful! Truly a bit of serenity in the city! Would recommend blocking out a morning and spending a bit of time walking round and taking it all in. Definitely worth putting...


More
Beauty!. Such a lovely place! It's a little bit far from the central of HK but it's worth it. Nice and quiet garden in that big noisy HK. Loved it!

Don't miss this gem. Beautifully manicured garden, once you are inside the garden, you hardly notice the bustling city around it. We were disappointed with the tea house experience, service was terrible. You have to order one serving of tea per person, & the quality of teas was mediocre. The snacks they offer were limited & ordinary, definitely not worth the money.

Serene and beautiful. This was one of the best experiences we had in Hong Kong. We were taken to the garden by our tour guide from Hong Kong Getaway Private Tours. The garden is very beautiful and peaceful - a perfect break from the hustle of Hong Kong. There were very few tourists. The walking path is easy and there are many spots...


More

Worth a visit. Go there via MTR. Interesting to see such a nice park in the middle of the city. Surrounded by highrises, you can enjoy a quite place and enjoy the architecture of a really nice garden as well as a temple.

Oasis of calmness in the middle of the city. This garden truly is an oasis in the middle of the city. Beautiful garden architecture and buildings. Also lots to learn about wooden buildings, garden stones etc. The cafetaria has some decent food and nice teas. Was a good stop before entering the nunnery.

Stunning. If you want to get some stunning photos and immerse yourself in a beautiful tranquil Chinese garden .. getting there is a breeze on the MTR - simply head to Diamond Hill stop.
There is a mall that used to have an excellent food court - sadly the food court has closed.

Urban oasis. I love this place. Easy to access from the MTR and after a short walk you are transported to a different time and place. The craftsmanship to build the wooden structures is amazing. The gentle sound of flowing water will help you to forget about any stresses.
Tranquility . Lovely garden in the heart of Hong Kong, very peaceful place with the contrast of the city all around. Highly recommended.

Bliss n paradise. Decided to go here after reading lot of good reviews and happy I did. It's like an oasis of peace in hustle n bustle of hongkong town. It is so well maintained and landscaping is amazing. Entry is free and I would suggest to visit during the evenings as one can enjoy the sunset. There is an amazing vegetarian restaurant nicely landscaped below a waterfall which is a must must try if you like Chinese cusine. Nice place to get amazing pics at almost every corner of the garden. A must visit in hongkong.

Don't miss the gardens . An easy trip on the MTR to Diamond Hill and a short walk to the gates and you enter a quiet, peaceful beautiful garden despite being in the middle of a city with a freeway running past it. Make sure you get an Octopus card to travel on public transport in Hong Kong. It is so efficient and cheaper than paying cash too. There are several buildings in the gardens and a walkway into the Chi Lin Nunnery that is also worth visiting. There is a fantastic display showing how the nunnery and temples were built, one displaying beautiful pottery and a lovely tea house in the middle. We had lunch in the vegetarian restaurant behind a waterfall.. a recommended experience. We didn't book but we're lucky to get seated at a share table. Like everywhere in Hong Kong it pays to go early. The restaurant opened at 12 and we were there at 12.10 and it filled fast.By the time we came out the gardens were also much busier while we had them much to ourselves at 11 when we got there.A must do.

Beautiful, rain or shine. Beautiful garden in the middle of the hong kong city. Loved the little temple thingy in the middle, and some of the small tidbits here or there. Overall, not a super intensive place, but great for an hour or so.

Beautiful and excellently executed. We visited this garden and temple and I feel we were lucky to have a manageable crowd. Looking at the size of the coach park this place could become unimaginably busy if you catch it at the wrong time.All of that said what a lovely place. The detailing of the Tang dynesty buildings is remarkable. There is an exhibition with model buildings showing the construction methods. My partner is an architect and was very excited. Also the large perfectly sculpted bonsai type trees are impressively kept, the rock garden is worth a look too and obviously the pagoda. We saw the tea building which seemed a little overpriced but I'm sure it was good at what it does. Nobody in there though.Gift shop filled with good pieces, if you want to spend good money you can. Little cage does drinks and very limited snacks. It seats about 20 max so if there's a crowd good luck!The temple itself is a place you just absorb and enjoy. Perfectly manicured water features and planting and the statues/displays are worth a few minutes of quiet reflection.

Beautiful gardens, koi pond. I loved the gardens, the Chinese architecture and the amazing koi fish they had here. When you take photos, you still see those high rise HK apartment buildings behind you, which reminds you you're in Hong Kong. Chi Lin Nunnery is right next door and actually follows the path from the garden. Amazing temple, and gives you some peace and quiet time. Easily accessible with a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR line.

Oasis!. This garden is so peaceful and well-maintained that you really need to go in her after a few hours at the nearby Holywood shopping centre! The grounds are very well looked after. There is a little souvenier shop and also a cafe that servers sandwiches etc. But if you want to really enjoy a good lunch, go in to the vegetarian restaurant - the setting is amazing! It is located under a waterfall and the view is quite good. The food is awesome too. These gardens are right next to the Chi Lin Nunnery so you can visit two great sites at the same time. Recommended!

Peaceful wanderings. After visiting the Nunnery across the road we ventured into this park. What a wonderful, peaceful oasis amongst some busy surroundings. It was wonderful to find a shady spot with seats and a table to rest. Great cafe serving a Summer Breeze crushed ice concoction my from lychee juice very reasonably priced and extremely refreshing on a very hot and humid day.

Stunning Oasis. Beautiful gardens surrounded by the sky rise of Hong Kong. We took the MTR to Diamond Hill subway station and it is about 5 minutes walk to the front entrance. Once inside, traffic noise is cut off and you can experience the tranquil, manicured gardens of Nan Lian in relative peace. What is more amazing is it is free! If you are interested in garden design this is a must see - we went during the day but they are open until late and it appeared a lot of the trees are lit for night viewing. There is a cafe inside if you need refreshments, and an interesting gift shop.

Relaxing and beautiful . The gardens are beautiful, the ambiance of the place is very relaxing, totally worth a visit. Especially with its close proximity to chi lin nunnery, and the fact that both places are free!
So Beautiful!. Definitely worth stopping by. Unfortunately it rained when we visited, still it was so peaceful and beautiful. A treasure within a city.

A quiet hidden oasis. You have to wonder how quiet it's going to be as the entrance is under a freeway- but once you're inside the noises, trials and bustling of the city soon fade away. This is certainly a retreat if only for a short while. The gardens aren't particularly big but if you take your time, enjoy the coolness of the misting sprays and maybe stop for some tea, you can easily loose a couple of hours here.
Nice spot . A good place to chill out for a bit. Some nice gardens and water features to take in. Its free and a short walk to the nunnery next door.

What a surprise--and not noted in our guidebooks. We had several plans for the day but the gardens at the Chi Lin Nunnery were so fantastic that we scrapped our list of plans and spent the day there! To get to the nunnery we had to walk through the Nan Lian garden -- a large traditional Chinese garden that is managed by the nunnery. What a surprise! We didn’t know there would be a garden and it was the most beautiful garden either one of us had ever seen. And we’ve been to England and other places to see gardens. It was magical seeing it in the rain and with not many people around. The bonsaied pines and other bonsaied trees, the many beautiful and strategically placed large rocks and pieces of petrified wood, the ponds, bridges, water wheels and traditional-style buildings, the many different types of trees with interesting bark and foliage including banyans, plus a variety shrubs and ground covers made for a calm and peaceful day right in the middle of Hong Kong city!! The garden also had some beautiful exhibits in traditional styled buildings including a showing of Marino glass pieces, bonsaied small trees, petrified woods, and an exhibit on how the nunnery was made without nails. It also had a restaurant plus a teahouse where we had tea (with assistance in the traditional way) and a light snack. It was a highlight of our trip to Honk Kong – it was truly stunning. We think the best to enter the gardens is by taking the metro to Diamond Hill.

“Nan” other than …. A Japanese style garden and pond with a wide varieties of trees and rocks plus a waterfall with a restaurant within.You can cross over to the Chi Lin Nunnery - Linked by an overhead bridge leading to a nunnery with water gardens and massive bonsai.DIRECTIONS:MTR Diamond Hill station, exit C2 and follow the signs.These are HK’s seldom ventured upon Gardens and Temples (at least for the hurried ignorant tourists) - You can visit all 4 sights (Nan Lian Garden, Chi Lin Nunnery, Sik Sik Yuen Temple, and Kowloon Walled City Park) by taking the metro or walking about 20 minutes between sights as they are linked by 3 adjacent MTR stations.
Zen garden. It's a gem in the concrete jungle. Good place to sit down and take a break from the hustling and bustling of the city. Very zen style

Quiet walk with sounds of birds.. Very peaceful place among the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, we enjoyed a quiet walk around the gardens and visited the Buddhist temple at the top of the hill. Recommended visit from the Diamond Hill train station.
Serene and peaceful place..... loved this place, easy mrt access you could easily spend couple of hours in this place. Good for cool mornings or evenings..

Just okay. After reading good reviews on TA, I made this trip a top priority and had high hopes of enjoying my visit to the Garden. Alas, all I saw was a manicured and artificial garden with a grotesquely coloured pagoda. I would give it a miss.
Quiet place and good break from the city. Right beside Chi Lin Nunnery. It's a simple garden, really. There's not much to do but stroll (better on weekdays where there would be fewer people here).

What a gem!. We were so into the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong with all the noise and the traffic that we never imagined a place like this could exist. It was really beautiful, quiet and very peaceful. The day was extremely hot and we enjoyed the "summer ice beverage" ($20 HK) at the small snack shop next to the souvenir store. It was like a tall slurpy from 7-11 but so much better.

Nice day out. We travelled to Lantau Island by MTR, and spent half a day there including a bus ride to see the Big Buddah, as everyone seems to call it. The day was dull, so we didn't see it at its best, but it was pretty, and well worth seeing as a contrast to the high-rise of Hong Kong itself. If you want to carry on shopping, there are lots of shops close to the Buddah.
Beautiful!. We took a taxi to get to Nan Lian Garden. It was such as beautiful place! We spent a whole hour walking around. Will definitely recommend to my loved ones!

Beautiful garden. We strolled through the garden on a sunny Sunday afternoon and thought it was very beautiful, surely it must be even more so on a cloudy day! The walk through the nunnery was a great experience and the idols were excellent.

Gorgeous gardens, worth a visit! . These gardens are so pretty. The trees are incredible! A must for any Bonsai fans. So green and lush! The Pavilion of Absolute Perfection is stunning! The man at the information counter gave us a map and was very helpful. Also enjoyed the Bonsai display next to the Rockery! The Chi Lin Nunnery is attached to you can visit at the same time, also very beautiful grounds. Its not massive so you don't need hours here but definitely worth a walk around, theres a picnic area with tables in the shade but otherwise you are not allowed food in the gardens. We had a great summer iced drink at the little cafe. So glad we went here, should be a top destination in my opinion!

Beautiful gardens. Well worth a visit, very well maintained gardens that occasionally feature art exhibitions in their exhibition hall. Coffee shop and souvenir shop located here along with a vegetarian restaurant situated behind a waterfall.

Beautiful - definitely worth a visit!. The gardens were absolutely stunning. I spent about three hours here, just wondering around. Feels very peaceful, despite the skyscrapers in the background. Make sure you go to the lotus ponds - there are loads of quotes from famous emperors, philosophers and buddhists placed around which I enjoyed reading.

manicured little oasis with a long list of restrictions. This is a wonderful park, but it seems they are going over the top with the rules. There are quite a few paths that are blocked off and no visitors are allowed to go closer. You should follow the path in one direction, but I broke that rule and it was Ok. If you have 2-3 hours to kill, it's worth visiting.
Oasis of rest in this busy town.. What an amazing place in this city where everybody is shopping, running, etc. Suddenly it's quiet and green. Absolutely worth a visit.

Stunningly beautiful. Strolled into this beautiful garden on a weekday morning to find it essentially deserted. How is a place this beautiful not crawling with people? It was peaceful, quiet, and just beautifully arranged. The golden pagoda and bridge are juxtaposed with lush scenery and modern HK apartment buildings in the background. They have the largest Koi pond I've seen in my life (upwards of 200 beautiful fish I would think) which was amazing to see. There's a lovely waterfall with a supposedly quite good vegetarian restaurant under the fall. Take a look folks, this a place you won't want to miss. Did I mention it was free? Take the MTR to diamond hill and follow the signs for the gardens. It's only a 2 minute walk from the station exit. Wonderful!

Peaceful. We came here twice during our visit to Hong Kong. The first time is was very very wet, so most of the time here was spent at the very pleasant restaurant behind the waterfall. We needed to go a second time so that we could enjoy the gardens properly and so made the easy trip using the MRT (MTR Diamond Hill Station Exit C2, follow the signs and walk for around five minutes). This time the rain held off long enough for us to thoroughly enjoy this magnificent garden, complete with paths, lakes, bonsai trees, interesting rock formations and Chinese architecture. There is also a very nice display of Murano glass that you can pay a small entrance fee to enjoy. Such a peaceful place, uncrowded but surrounded by skyscapers in the background.
Peaceful and beautiful. Neat place to visit if you're staying close or you have lots of time in Hong Kong. Peaceful and beautiful

Finally a place that isn't busy! . Coming from the countryside in the UK I find HK very busy and hectic at the best of times! The Nan Lian gardens and the nunnery are joined and less than 5 minutes walk from C2 exit of Diamond Hill MTR station so super easy to get to. It's one of the quietest places I've been in HK and was lovely and peaceful!The gardens weren't anything special but very peaceful and the nunnery was beautiful! Only a short trip required around an hour but well worth it!

Simply Beautiful. The HK Tourist people at Kowloon, recommended I take my mom (because she's "old") to this garden. It was lovely! Very beautiful, even in the rain. The temple itself was very well kept and the quiet serenity of the place was totally worth the long bus trip to it. Recommend taking the subway to this place. They do have some vegetarian food luncheon that they do, we didn't stick around for that.
Wonderful garden. Wonderful garden where one can come to rest, away from (most of) the hustle and bustle of the city.Worth a detour and shouldn't be overlooked when visiting the nearby nunnery.
Great Garden. It is a garden but there is a nunnery as well. Perfect combination of ancient in a modern country ! Free entry, no selfie stick allowed.
Beautiful and peaceful garden . It is a real beauty with many picture worthy spots. Far from city center. A mix of trees and stones.

Serenity in the city . Definitely a slice of serenity in the bustling city. Well worth a visit, especially if you need to recenter. Very zen. The coffee/snack shop was a perfect place to enjoy a cool summer drink.

Nice tranquil few hours getaway. If temples are new for you, and you're looking for a few hours getaway it can be a nice option. notice climbing up can be a bit challenging in the summer when it's super hot

Beautiful Garden. This garden was bigger than I expected since it was in the middle of the city. When you walk in, you feel like you're in a whole different place or time. When we were there, it wasn't really crowded and found ourselves really enjoying our time. The environment and music made us slow our pace and feel peaceful. The gift shop was small but adequate.

Just WOW!! . While it was raining when went there, couldn't help but be amaze with the serenity and beauty of the place. A Relaxing and peaceful sanctuary that can be found in the middle of a busy city. Very easy to find. It's just a few minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR Station. Marvel with chinese architecture and rock gallery. Don't forget to visit Chi Lin Nunnery as well. Worth your time!

Must see in Hong Kong. Such a peaceful and beautiful garden nestled by a transit station - I was stunningly surprised at how authentic and secluded the place felt. The place was very clean and free from any obvious tourist traps, nobody once tried to sell me anything and instead we got a fun lesson on how some of the ancient temples are built.The nunnery is essentially connected to the garden, making this even more convenient of a place to stop by on your trip to Hong Kong.

Pretty. It's a pretty garden, well kept. Insanely hot with few places for shade. I understand the negative feedback it has received - if you're looking for a park to have a picnic or lay on the grass for a bit, this isn't it. I wouldn't say it's all the peaceful either. I like it though. The modern feel of it doesn't bother me. We need to be allowed to make landmarks now too, so that in 500 years there are new things to visit.

Peace within the hectic city. This garden is so peaceful, it is hard to believe you are still technically in a city! It is a beautiful place for pictures. Add the Chi Lin Nunnery for a pleasant morning or afternoon. Take Ext C2 from Diamond Hill MTR station. There are signs to direct you. Hong Kong is a very tourist friendly city. If you get lost, just ask or look for a sign!

Very pretty. Nan Lian is a lovely garden attraction, free for the public. Firstly, it is not like a garden in the UK or Europe, don't take food into there thinking you can have a nice picnic like I thought! To create a garden in China you must have water, rocks and plants.. This really embraces all of these things and you can really tell that they have gone all out to make this place a lovely garden for everyone. Nan Lian is really a serene place in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the city of Hong Kong. If you are looking for some peace then take your time to visit.

Love it!. What i love from this garden in the collection of their building miniature that was made from wood. Very detail and beautiful. But i personaly think that visiting this garden in summer time is not a really good idea. It was really hot, even sitting under the trees not really helping. The other thing is, is garden is mext to a big mall. So if you plan to do some picnic in this garden, you could buy all the food and drink you need from the mall. This place is also easy to reach as near it near subway and bus station.
GOOD VIEW. Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden are an easy 5 minute walk from the Diamond Hill Station of the MTR (exit C2). Must to go there.

One of my favorite places in Kowloon. I've visited the Nan Lian Garden (and the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery) on several trips to Kowloon. It's a beautiful, serene, clean garden and temple with a great vegetarian restaurant. A definite must see in Hong Kong.

A tranquil garden in the midst of chaotic Kowloon.. Easy to find and a pleasant visit. It makes for a great rest amongst the chaos of Hong Kong. The gardens are well maintained and there is a small cafe where you can grab a bite to eat and something to drink.
Wonderfully Serene Environment. Great spot to visit and unwind from the hustle and bustle that is most of Hong Kong. The gardens and temples provide a sense of relaxation and inner peace.
A beautiful garden in the middle of the city. If you want to have a feast for your eyes you need to walk this garden when you visit Hong Kong. You would not regret it!!!

My new favorite spot. Amid a very bustling noisy city this is a place of quietude, beauty, and serenity. The pace of the world slows and one can think. All the elements- hills and rocks, water, venerable trees and wooden structures- of a classical landscape garden are here worked together into a cohesive 8 acre garden. Each scene has its purpose and theme and works well. Although you can walk through in 30-40 minutes it is a place that invites you to linger and ponder, although the security forces will deter you from wandering off the designated paths! The adjacent Chi Lin nunnery is similarly peaceful and elegant in every respect. This is not a highly colorful garden with flowers though there are some but the shades of green, the flashes of colorful Koi in the water and the detailed wooden buildings will delight your eyes. The gold Perfection Pavillion tied to the garden by the Zi Wu bridges will draw your eyes and entice your camera almost making you forget the high rises and freeways just a short distance away.
Beautiful. We had a lovely trip to Nan Lian Gardens via the MTR. What an incredible place in the middle of this crazy city. Doesn't take very long to walk around (< 1 hr) but well worth the trip!

Gardens next to Chi Lin Nunnery. These gardens are an extension of the Chi Lin Nunnery, take the time to walk around the gardens fully, has a coffee shop, souvenir shop, and Central to the gardens is a Chinese Tea House, well worth the effort to stop slow down and enjoy.

Ditto!. My title says it all. I can only reiterate what everyone else has said. Every tree in this garden has been bonsai (not sure of the verb for this) to some point and that, in itself, is amazing. Such a superb example of the Chinese culture.

A Green Garden. If you like seeing old trees, wood, and greens, this garden is suitable for taking a walk around. It is free of charge and near the Diamond Hill MTR Station. You can taste vegetarian dishes and try Chinese tea if you do not mind to pay at the designated locations inside.

Nice for a walk. This place is a nice escape from the busy city.. definitely good for leisure walks. There is a vegetarian restaurant inside, as well as a stone museum. The architecture looks more Japanese with beautifully maintained bonsai trees.

Heavenly haven in the New Territories. Having lived in HK and visited all the main sightseeing spots, this garden and the adjoining Chin Lin Nunnery were a welcome change. There‘s a real Japanese quality about this garden – unlike the garish red and gold of Chinese temples. A real haven amongst the bustle of city life …. And both are free – what’s not to like?! Diamond Hill MTR (Exit C2, 5 minute walk)

Calm Oasis. My first visit here and what a surprise. These perfectly laid-out and manicured Chinese gardens are a perfect spot to discover peace and quiet contemplation when you've had it with the hullaballoo of the city and its constant churn. Gardens, trees, rock gardens, pagodas, ponds as well as a tea house, a café and restaurant. A real oasis of calm to replenish your spiritual system. So quiet yet only a stone's throw from the commercial district.

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful Asian gardens, well-designed & landscaped. Beautiful stroll, constantly changing and surprising with different areas. Was very humid when we went because of the water features, but definitely worth it.
Beautiful temple. The temple is really beautiful and peaceful and not as busy as other attractions. Definitely worth the visit.

A moment of tranquility. When Hong Kong is driving you insane you need to get out and this garden is a great first stop. An oasis of calm with a neat little coffee shop and wonderful vegetarian restaurant behind a waterfall!
Peaceful. Nice trip out of the main city, don't need to spend long here though as not much to do but it is free of charge. Interesting to see the influence of the Japanese here

Gorgeous and sprawling oasis in the middle of the city. A beautiful place to escape from the city whilst staying in the city. Not many people there the few times that we have been there, which makes it even more peaceful. Extremely well-maintained - looks almost flawless. Always visit when in Hong Kong.

Amazing gardens. A real oasis in Hong Kong. Stunning gardens which are beautifully maintained. Lots of cloud pruned trees and different pagodas. The restaurant is expensive but they is also a separate tea house (in a beautiful wooden building) in the grounds. It was quiet when we went and a pleasure to wander around. It links directly to the nunnery across the road which is also very interesting.

Serene, Little Park in a Very Busy City. This park is tucked away yet easy to access by MTR subway off Hollywood Station. It is a lovely landscaped park. We were glad to have gone there. There is also attached a temple.

Peace within the City. This garden is amazing! It is such a peaceful respite among the hustle and bustle in the city. Soft music plays while you wander on the paths. It's interesting to see the traditional pagoda architecture with skyscrapers in the background. You are not allowed to eat or drink (except water) while in the garden, so plan accordingly.

Simply stunning. Beautiful park with lots of different things to see. Make sure you see the rocks in the rock room - also ac so a great place to cool down. So nice to be invited to take a seat. No food or drink allowed - I had a nice but firm reprimand for eating a pear !

Nan Lian Garden - Beautiful place to roam around and sit / relax. We went to diamond hill to meet a friend, and when heading back we decided to visit the nan lian garden- a chinesse classical garden, It is designed in the Tang dynasty style with hills, water features, trees, rocks and elegant wooden structures architectures. This place is highly recommended must visit ! very quiet, gorgeous place, tranquil among the busy streets and free entry to everyone.
Mix of Japan & China. Feel the positive energy at this place. its quite big place and have nunnery nearby. HAs a temple like building inside with golden structure.

Japanese Garden in the Middle of the City. This was a great quick stop. It reminded me of being in Japan. It was quiet, it was clean, it was very cool. This is worth the stop and great for stretching your legs

Hot hot hot. Went here since we didn't know anywhere else to go in hong kong.There's no fee to visit nan lian garden and nan lian garden is a very beautiful place. Truly a serene jewel in the bustling life of the city.I went here at the end of august and it was so hot that I was sweating all over. Better to bring portable fan and a hat or shades.

Imressive. A very pretty garden with soft relaxing music. My enjoyment was marred slightly by all the people posing for photos against every picturesque backdrop. I mean, do you really need 10 pictures of different shots in front of a bridge over a lake?

One of the best gardens in the world!. This garden is fabulous. I've been here multiple times and highly encourage people to go to it. I love the lakes in the park and the architecture. Plan on spending about one hour to enjoy the whole experience. It is a little far away since its in Diamond Hill but you can get to it somewhat easily from the mtr.
Nan Lian Garden. Nice garden with Japanese style and love this place, there is a sound and music for garden and beautiful tree inside.

Nice. Very beautiful park. Forget your trypod as they will not let you use it. ...at all. There was all of 20 people here but they would not let me use it. A very special place I really loved the landscaping. Unfortunately they are working on renovations to the bridge. ..it would be nice if tripadvisor would have a place for showing it different venue's are under construction. Thanks to some reviewers I was able to learn this for other places we visited in Hong Kong this week. But this was a nice place and worth the trip from causeway bay.
Heaven on earth. It is amazing to have this wonderful sanctuary in the middle of buzzing neighbourhood. If you want calmness even for a bit, visit this place.

Back to Tang Dynasty. The garden is small, but it is an enjoyable visit to see all the lovely trees and lotus flowers. You cannot imagine that the tall buildings and traffic are at arm's length and yet the garden is so quiet. The orange pagoda looks a bit odd, but it is the colour of the Tang Dynasty. The colour was taken up by Japan and they still keep the orange colour for their temples. The small museum on wooden structures was marvellous if you wonder how Chinese built the houses without nails! The vegetarian restaurant inside the garden is one the best I have ever tried. Lunch is around HK$120 to 140 per head. A must for vegetarian. After visiting the Garden, the temple is just opposite to it. It is built according to the Tang Dynasty style. Walk around to feel the tranquility of a temple in the middle of the city.

Enjoyed this peaceful spot.. Although it started to rain a bit, I enjoyed my time wandering around the gardens, appreciating their beauty and the peaceful aura that they reflected. So close the the MTR too, easy to get too.

Beautiful, calm space.. According to a leaflet I picked up, this garden was completed in 2006, so it does have a slight 'Theme Park'-feel to it. However, I'm not in the least bothered by that because it's a wonderful place. This is a beautiful oasis of calm in a city that often seems...etc., etc. but it really is! Walking round this garden is a rewarding, relaxing experience, away from...oh dear, doing it again. Anyway, just go...it's truly lovely. And make sure to look at the (not so-)miniature recreations of wooden buildings around China, they're stunning!

Beautiful Grarden in the middle of skylines. This place is best visited during the cooler months to be able to enjoy the walking around in the garden. It is so tranquil and relaxing. Be sure to visit both sides, one side is the garden area, the other side is the temple area (across the street-but you cross from a bridge within the garden. I've been here several times and enjoy it (in winter) It is an easy, marked walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station (drinks are not allowed if in your hands)

Peaceful and relaxing spot in a busy city. A peaceful, relaxing and tranquil escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The garden is beautiful and well-kept opposite of Chi Lin nunnery. It's easily accessed from the MTR and free admission. We spent couple of hours walking around, sitting and admiring the peace and beauty of the garden. Well worth a visit.
A calm oasis in a busy city. Clean and well laid out gardens, with a variety of interesting plants and features. A good place for a quiet and peaceful walk

Amazing if you like peaceful places, especially at night. Loved going here at night, after a hectic day walking around the markets in Mong Kok. It's a bit of a trek, especially if you're staying on the main Hong Kong island instead of the New Territories. But I'd definitely say it's worth a visit, in conjunction with the Kowloon Walled City Park. This place is just so beautiful and serene. It wasn't very crowded when I went (around 7pm, just after sunset). I was actually one of a few people there, so it was really great to be alone and just walk through the very well taken care of greenery in the garden.

A must-place to visit. Nan Lian Garden is a must-place to visit when you are in Hong Kong. It is located in Diamond Hill and is just a walking distance from the MTR station. It is a place of peace and serenity. The garden view is stunning. And if you visit on a Wednesday you can go inside the glass museum for free. Inside you can see the porcelain and glass handicrafts in different colors and designs. Just beside the garden is the very beautiful Chi Lin Nunnery. The temple is worth a visit and it is so calming just walking around and looking at those Buddhas.

Beautiful Gardens. We visited here having looked around the Nunnery which adjoins. Thoroughly enjoyed the beauty of it all and watching the people was almost as much fun! Very well cared for and set out.Nice vegetarian restaurant to visit too with some very unusual items on the menu.

A quiet escape. This garden is very beautiful and is a lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. It seems a little fake and tourist-aimed, hence the 4 stars, but is nonetheless a nice place to go.
Beauitful. Wow. What an absolutely beautiful place, so quaint and quite and just absolutely gorgeous. Really nice on a summers day and free entry.

A great place to visit. I remembered when Diamond Hill was known for its large squatter area that regularly caught fire, now it has a delightful garden. It is easy to get to being next door to Diamond Hill MTR and easy to walk around. The design is beautiful with fantastic detail, every tree and rock is there for a reason. The garden has a very tasteful souvenir shop and cafe but is famous for its vegetarian restaurant. Immaculately clean, polite and efficient service and a varied menu. I enjoyed my lunch very much but glad that I booked.Slightly off the normal tourist trail but worth the effort.

Impressive!. I am not a regiligous person, but I love nature, making this a remarkable. Really beautiful and peaceful, I would recomend you DON'T go there as I don't like busy places ;-) This is a must go in HK, no question.
Beautiful and relaxing. A nice relaxing and tranquil place in the middle of a concrete jungle. Beautiful gardens and a great place to un-wind.

A lovely place to spend an hour or 2. This garden is very close to DIamond Hill MTR. The gardens are very well kept with small bridges, temples and water features. You could easily spend a couple of hours walking around taking photos. There are small places to get a bite to eat inside if you're hungry. The nunnery is right next door as well. Take an umbrella as in the summer when I went it was quite hot.

Just Lovely. Right beside diamond hill mtr. Free in. Connects to the nunnery via bridge. Exhibitions on show at the moment are wood architecture of China, rockery, and Venetian glass (this one was $20HKD). There's a restaraunt, a cafe, and nice not tacky souvenir shop. Great place for photos of nature v city.

Really beautiful garden with skyscrapers as its backdrop. This garden is really lovely, with a miniature Pagoda exhibition and really beautiful plants, bridges and temples. Furthermore next door there is the nunnery which is equally incredible - I'd recommend this to anyone who's got even just a few hours in Hong Kong since it combines the traditions and natural beauty of the place with the modernity of the surrounding buildings.

An idyllic, peaceful location in the city. Visited the gardens and associated Chi Lin Nunnery and was astounded by the beauty and peacefulness of the gardens. The gardens are easily accessed from the MTR, you may have to change lines depending on where you are staying but that should not put you off making this trip. Highly recommended.

Very beautiful . We had a lovely morning at this stunning, tranquil garden. We enjoyed walking around as there was lots to see - plants, waterfalls, bright colours, and the amazing city skyline in the background. The garden is very well-kept. There is a souvenir shop and some places to eat too. We didn't eat here but the places looked nice. Definitely worth visiting.

Quiet place in a center. This is must be. Amazing place to quiet down after speed life in HK. Great Garden. Not that big but really worth to speed there an hr or two. Temple was closed but outside wiev great too

We liked it.. This is a great wee garden to wander around and get some snaps. You can get some excellent photgraphs with the gardens and tower blocks in the background. The garden is a pretty new build and diligently patrolled by security and the " do not do this" sign is rather amusing.i expected nothing less from Hong Kong really.If you have an interest in gardening and plants you will really like it there are some great bonsai trees too. We didnt go to the restaurant just wandered about. Some poo poo the garden and have a moan, but it is what it is really a rather pretyy garden now or not with excellent botanical stuff, plenty of shade some nice bird life and a good place to take stunning photographs. The cafe there is nice for a sit down and they do a vegan ice cream too. . If you moan because it's new and "sterile" you are probably that person who stood by the newly constructed pyramids and said "not as good as the old ones"..

Lovely tranquil day out. Do the garden at the same time as the Nunnery, see my other review - enjoy dim sum & tea in the garden - very relaxing day out when you need a break from the hustle & bustle. Easy to get to.

Worth a visit. Went with my family on a weekend and it wasn't overly crowded, a nicely kept garden making for some gorgeous photos. Just across the road from the Chi Lin Nunnery (you can access it via a bridge from within the garden).Thought the vegetarian restaurant was a little overpriced so found some cheaper local food in the nearby Rhythm Garden area (it's a small residential complex with supermarket and a few places to eat- need to speak canto though)

Gorgeous garden, so worth the visit. I adore Japanese gardens so when I heard about this Chinese garden I just had to visit. And I'm so glad I did! It was wonderful to see the similarities and differences between this and the classic Japanese gardens. Even in the boiling hot summer weather I tried to take my time to enjoy it. It also has a lovely gift shop so don't miss that (also because it's air conditioned!)

Nice looking park. Right next to the Chi Lin Nunnery, this park is worth a visit. It's not old. But the scenery is beautiful and makes for good pictures. There is a small exhibition of chinese architecture and some explanation on local culture. And it's free. Check it out.

Beautiful!. Next door to the nunnery are the stunning Nan Lian Gardens. The care that is taken to look after the gardens pis a joy, a truly beautiful place. What I love about this is amongst the crazy hustle and bustle of Hong Kong is the tranquility, it's so peaceful and relaxing, I could walk around here for hours. Our young kids really enjoyed it here to, that are now in love with Bonsai trees
Beautiful.... An "old" place in the modern world. The buildings are spectacular in the Tang Dynasty era. Perfect for cooler days. We there at midday in the summer, so it's rather warm.

Lovely formal gardens and unique exhibits. This is a beautiful and extensive garden. The Pavilion of Absolute Perfection is a good description of the vibrantly yellow octagonal pavilion with 2 red bridges leading from it. It is an ideal spot for postcard perfect photos. There is also a Chinese timber architecture gallery that shows miniature replicas of famous wooden Chinese buildings and displays in detail how some of the intricate corner fittings work. We also went through the Rockery that has various types of unique rocks on display. There is an attractive koi fish pond. Throughout the gardens, the trees and rocks are an artistic tableau.

Tranquil and peaceful in a very busy city. Very easy to get to on the MTR and a short walk from Diamond Hill station, we weren't expecting it to be so quiet and tranquil inside the gardens.The gardens with the sculptured plants, the landscaping and buildings are fabulous and are a great photo opportunity.We spent a couple of hours wandering around enjoying watching the carp in the pond and marvelling at the vibrant colours of the Garden Pavilion of Absolute Perfection. The Chi Lin Nunnery courtyard was also peaceful with lots of interesting architecture and ponds with lotus leaves/flowers.A must see in Hong Kong

Beautiful Gardens and Temple. We came for the temple and then visited the gardens. We were very pleasantly surprised, and had a very good stay. There is a lot to see and walk, and they are very well cared for. Overall people were very nice. Though this was perhaps the only place in HK that my kids were bothered for photos (I really don't like when this happens in China). I recommend a visit, even if it is a bit out of the way. Use the MTR instead of a taxi.

Tranquility in the city. Stunning place! Beautiful gardens, immaculately kept. Great landscaping, awesome juxtaposition of gardens to the skyscrapers surrounding it. The snack shop was great. Peaceful music accompanies you as you walk through the gardens. Very scenic. We were there on a rainy day and there were plenty of places to shelter between the fronts.

Best place in HK. This is the best place from out pov to visit in HK. Make sure to check when it is a free entrance to make the best of your money (either Wed or Thu cannot recall for a fact). The garden is absolutely amazing to walk around. It is exceptionally well maintained and the trees, flowers everything is prefect. Note that you cannot eat inside a sandwich or grab a bite from something you brought with you (don't know why). If not on a budget, one can try the restaurant behind the waterfall - from outside it looked very romantic. As you walk around you can also reach Chi Lin Nunnery for an totally amazing complete experience.

Beautiful Garden in the City. This is a traditional Chinese garden located just off the Diamond Hill MTR. There are wonderfully shaped bonsai trees, a golden temple called the Garden Pavilion of Absolute Perfection (and a lovely red wood bridge that leads to it), ponds, rare and unusual rocks, a waterfall, waterwheel, and a couple of exhibit halls. It's a perfect place to enjoy peace and tranquility in the city, and the grounds are perfectly maintained. There were very few people visiting when we were there - it was easy to find a quiet park bench and contemplate the view over the lotus pond. The Chi Linh Nunnery is right in the same area, so you can see both (but the nunnery closes at 4:30 PM). No admission charge to either the nunnery or the gardens. There is also a tea-house and vegetarian restaurant in the garden, but we didn't go to either one. Take a few hours and check it out - we sure enjoyed it.

Garden in the City. As a tourist, this should be a must visit to escape the bustling crowd of the city. The place is serene, quiet, well-maintained, picturesque and free. Prepare your camera and find the perfect spot to capture that is not too Hongkong.
Very nice park. Great views and worth visit. Some time you feel surprised about the location of the park and the beauty it has..

A good stop. We visited this garden in 2014. We enjoyed this Chinese garden. It was quiet and peaceful. It was laid out in a very organized manner and well maintained. This visit was a nice break from the hustle and bustle around it. Combination photos of the old with the new skyscrapers was interesting. There are many seats where you can sit and meditate and soak up the peace and tranquility.

A nice chinese garden.. Nan Lian is a nice Chinese garden well kept and clean with a backdrop of major skyscrapers on the Hong Kong side of the island. It is a good place for a stroll or rest. it has a nice clean park and a good place for pictures.

Serenity & peace amongst the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. These gardens are spectacular, immaculate and showcases natural beautiful scenes in miniature, although still very majestic. It is adorned with springs, hillocks, trees (pruned mostly in a bonsai look) flowers, plants pavilions, winding paths and bridges to different areas (although these were all closed when we were there). I was in awe of its beauty, serenity and peace whilst outside its walls is the hustle and bustle of HongKong and towering apartment buildings. A walkway will take you over to the beautifulChi Lin Nunnery.
Beautiful garden. Well worth a visit - beautiful garden with seats for resting and contemplation, quiet, includes display of bonsai tress and shrubs
Formudastic. A nice small chinese garden next to the nunnery on diamond hill with some interesting wooden buildings built in traditional style

Peaceful and amazing. This place isn't mentioned in must do top tens very often but it would definitely be in mine. The place is amazing. It's like a small central park. Peaceful nature in the centre of the cities hustle and bustle. Easy to get to on the subway and a complete delight!
Peaceful. A beautiful garden that is easily accessible from the Diamond Hill MTR. Go in the morning (before 11) to avoid the crowds and combine with a visit to the Buddhist temple across the road.
A delightful garden. After a short underground ride we enjoyed wandering through this peaceful respite for about an hour. This and the adjoining Chi Lin Nunnery were beautiful.

Peaceful amid the bustle.. Give your self a delightful break. It's a photographer's paradise. There is a restaurant undernieth the waterfall at the back. If you appreciate unusual rocks and bonsai you'll love it here.
great garden!. the garden is one of the most beautiful places to see in HK. The nunnery inside and the highrises on the background compose a an interesting picture.
Peace haven in centre of town!. Its amazing how peaceful a stroll is in this park right in the centre of kowloon and near major roads/axes.. worth it, if you have long enough time here.
Beautiful gardens. Really pretty gardens to wander around in and spend a bit of time out of the busy HK streets. Although not really ancient, it's still impressive.

A moment back in time. I was gobsmacked at the vast and well-kept gardens, massive centuries old rocks (carted from China) and plants for the beautiful garden layouts smack in the middle of the hustle and bustle of a busy city with all its noises. Here however there is a peace and quiet which I would assuredly want to come back to again. Absolutely worth a few more visits.

Unexpected but lovely detour. In visiting Diamond Hill, we had only planned on visiting the nunnery temple. However, these gardens are only across the road and there is a bridge linking the two; so we decided to take a detour to explore the nice looking park.The entrance facing Diamond Hill MTR station and shopping complex is odd, having had a motorway bypass constructed over it. That being said, it is the cleanest underside to a bypass I have ever seen, and once one enters the gate of the garden the sunlight will be shining down again. The timber museum is interesting; it mainly contains miniature timber reconstructions of famous old Chinese buildings from the mainland, including the imperial palace in Beijing. Little snippets of architectural information on the buildings can be found, including a huge fixation on hidden floors that are invisible to the outside - a quirk of traditional Chinese architecture.Outside again, there are numerous rare plant species mingling around the lake and fountains, and the trail provides a relaxing walk. The only part I didn't enjoy is that the golden pagoda island in the middle of the lake, despite having bridges over to it, was entirely closed off. They could also have signposted the nunnery better; one does not need to leave the gardens and cross the main road to access it, as we did, for there is a bridge connecting the two.

Dont miss it.. We loved the garden. It is free of charge. It offers a great brochure with all the features of the gardens. It is one of the best maintained gardens I ve seen. They pulverise the plants during the afternoon heat! The golden pavillion is such a beauty and there are plenty of resting spots to enjoy the sights. The waterfall comes round the corner unexpected and the many big stones makes this garden a joy. The koi dont get to be fed. But no one stops you getting yourself prepared with something for them. A must see in my eyes.
Nice to visit . We was on the garden nice place to start the day it was very nice garden it definitely worth to visit this garden

Beautiful place to spend a morning. . The Nan Lian Garden is a wonderful place. Very beautiful and serene. It is an oasis in the middle of chaotic Hong Kong. Easy to get to via the MTR and adjacent to the Chi Lin Nunnery, this is a must visit for any Hong Kong tourist.
And it is free!

Do it, it's beautiful. . Wow, what a beautiful place. Absolutely worth the time to visit. And take your time once there to appreciate it. Getting there is easy. Catch the MTR to Diamond Hill station. This is located under a large shopping center which is a bonus. Once out in the street, just follow the signs, you can't get lost. We discovered that you can't just take a break and sit anywhere here as there is staff there to make sure you don't. There is ample seating around the park anyway, and lots to see when there. There is a small cafe/restaurant at one end and under a waterfall which was very nice. Right across the main road is a Nunnery, which is an absolute must do whilst in the area. Both won't disappoint.
Magnificient. Next to Diamond Hill MTR and Hollywood Plaza. I first saw these gardens about 5 years ago. Stunningly beautiful and immaculately maintained and free to visit!

Wrong dish served at almost double the price. Food was so so but we arrested a deep fried mushroom dish me got served a fried mushroom dish at almost double the price and when we paid the bill and pointed out the mistake the only thing they could say you have eaten it already so you need to pay it. Most awful experience ever and spoiled the whole dinner.
A serene spot to escape from the bustle. This is a quiet and beautifully laid out garden filled with shrubs and trees. There is a pond filled with koi as well as artfully arranged stones.

Beautiful, peaceful sanctuary. If you like gardens, you'll enjoy spending a couple hours walking around Nan Lian. We thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere and appreciated the meticulous work of the landscapers. It was an overcast, misty day - just perfect for spending time here. And there were no crowds of tourist groups taking selfies!!!!
Pretty and well maintained gardens. The gardens were lovely and the nunnery over the road is gorgeous.Well worth a visit for a piece of serentiy away from the hustle and bustle of the city!

Beautiful oasis amongst the towers and peaks of Hong Kong. Beautiful, peaceful and interesting gardens. A great escape for an hour or two with great views inside the gardens and outside with the surrounding towers and mountains. Easily accessible via Diamond Hill MTR on the Kowloon side of Hong Kong.

Small Garden. This is a small garden and park compared to Hong Kong Park. However, there are also great sites and features to it as well. Next to it, there is a great shopping mall, and in all, very easily accessible by MTR Diamond Hill stations.

Not worth seeking out. This is a lovely garden but it is not worth traveling a long distance to see. It is underwhelming compared to other botanical gardens around the world and is far from other attractions.Due to the high ratings for this attraction we made a point of seeking it out for a change of pace from the crowded city. Trouble is, it is so far away that you must spend a lot of energy to get there. It took us well over an hour to reach by bus from other central areas (Star Ferry terminal area and Kowloon station) through slow-moving traffic. (Google had estimated about 45 minutes for both metro and bus). So it was exhausting just getting there.We arrived around 2pm on a Saturday and found it hotter, slightly busier, and louder than we expected. There weren't a ton of people there but a lot were rushing to take photos and clogging up the entire walking path, making it seem more crowded than it was. At that time of day there was also minimal shade along the walkways (especially while navigating between people). It was surprisingly loud inside from the nearby roads and highways. So after a not-quite relaxing walk through the park we left to endure yet another hour-plus trek back.It is certainly a lovely park but nothing exceptional. If you're in the area stop by (it's free). If not, don't add it to your must-see itinerary-you'll be more exhausted than rejuvenated for your efforts.

Beautiful garden. By boyfriend took me here, and it was a lovely garden. A wonderful green scene that you can enjoy a walk in.... except... perhaps you might want to avoid going there in the peak of summer when it's incredibly hot and the sun is just GLARING at you. Nevertheless, this place is great and lovely and well kept. Would definitely come here again next time.

Peaceful place inside the city. The Nan Lian Garden is accessible by MTR Diamond Hill. It's an incredible Chinese classical garden with hills, water features, trees, rocks and wooden structures. One of the most picturesque buildings is the golden Pavilion of Absolute Perfection! Highly recommended to walk around and enjoy nature :)
A favorite attraction. This place is absolutely beautiful. Lush, well manicured gardens and temples. Very peaceful to just walk around and take it all in.

Peaceful among the kaos . The Nan Lian Garden is right next door to the mtr station Diamond Hill, it's a nice place to see some old architecture with the surrounding apartment buildings and office buildings. Is good for half a day.

Good if you want break from the city. nice place for a short walk around.nice veggie restaurant in the gardens with good dim sum.we went when it was really hot so the restaurant was a welcomed break from the heat!I reckon a leisurely walk and lunch took a couple of hours maybe 3

Stunning Garden. Stunningly Beautiful Garden. With Hong Kong’s very fine weather, it soothing to take a walk and be amazed with the extra ordinary landscapes it offers. Walking Distance to MTR, it has a tea shop and restaurant. Definitely worth the visit.
Great Vegetarian restaurant. The gardens are an oasis from the chaos of traffic and people in the city. Beautifully maintained and a place of serenity.

Beautiful garden. Visited for the second time and was happy to be there again. Although the first visit in March was considerably colder than the second one now in July. Still - beauty. How the Chinese masters handle every single plant to bring it to absolute beauty. The mastery of bonsai is just amazing. And the composition of the whole garden as well. Just a little disturbing is the background of surrounding high rise blocks. But this is Hong Kong. Well worth to visit in any time of the year.
Beautiful . A Beautiful garden the real chinese way. A bit messy to get there from wan chai. Had to change the mtr 3 times. But a Great break from the noisy areas. Really recommended :)

Gorgeous gardens - serene, peaceful and so much to do. I actually wish we'd had longer in the gardens. They were superb and there's also a tea house, a restaurant and other things to do within. Definitely worth a visit even if it's a little bit of a way on the MTR. Loved it.
Peace and Serinity. Just a way to see how a country's own tourists view their history and way of life. Well kept and loved place of worship.

Peaceful and zen . Took a 45 minute stroll through the gardens with my family. While it was extremely hot outside, the visit was still worthwhile. A very quiet oasis amidst the bustling city. Certainly worth a brief visit.
Do not miss !. Nan Lian Garden and the adjacent nunnery are hidden gems of Hong Kong. Hard to believe places of such peace and beauty can exist in the concrete jungle. Go. Go, now!

Zen Garden delight, top 10 places.. I went to this garden to fill in some spare time in Hong Kong, what a delight. The Zen gardens are perfect and very well presented. I liked the presentation of polished rock formations and was fortunate to get an explanation of their meaning to zen Buddhists by a friendly park guide. Adjacent to the park is a zen Nunnery, which is built in traditional style, again this is a great visit. both places are free and 2 mins walk from the MTR. Would visit every day if I could, this place should be on your to 10 places to visit whilst in HK.

Well maintained Japanese gardens. Within Kwaloon island, this is very nice garden with Japanese monastery and plantation around. Quick ride by MTR takes you near this place. Very pleasant walk around this place, also provided a restaurant with flowing water around the glass windows.Overall its nice place, but definitely not a must go in Hong Kong.

Great place to relax and enjoy a little peace in the middle of the city. We really enjoyed the garden and the nunnery - beautiful peaceful place- it wasn't too crowded, very pleasant and worth experiencing.

Beautiful Zen Garden. This is a beautiful in the midst of the city. We loved strolling around this gorgeous place. No need to pay for an expensive tour or bus trip to visit here as it is less than two minutes stroll from Diamond Hill MTR station and very well signed posted. The wild life we saw in the garden is just inspiring and that is why we return again and again when we have visitors and to enjoy the awesome vegetarian food in the restaurant. A steep minimum charge of $120 per head to eat there but worth it.

It's the nicest zen garden I have ever been to.. Beautiful area in Diamond Hill few minutes from the Diamond Hill MTR exit. Too bad its in the middle of a city and not on the side. Recommended by my mom as well as other guides online, its a place to visit in HK.The buildings kind of kill the entire feeling of the place. Nan Lian Garden was built years later after the Chi Lin Nunnery was established. Free entry ! A mild escape from the "city" Upon entry of the garden, there is a huge wooden sign with the name of the garden in chinese. As you follow the pathway, theres a small building to the left which features many very intricate and detailed wooden structure models of larger/older buildings. Continuing along the path, you'll see a large golden structure surrounded by a pong. Very nice visual except for the modern high rises behind :( Its quite a nice walk (too bad it was a little hot that day and of course humid). The garden has a tea garden and a restaurant but very pricey. I heard its good to try the vegetarian meals there too but my friends were highly uninterested in that fact. You can check out the "rock museum" and gift shop that also showcases these high valued tea sets that my friends and I can't but wonder why they are so expensive. Lol The garden is connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery which has an extensive temple area which i will review individually from this. Great place to check out on a day of temples. Close to the popular and widely known Wong Tai Sin Temple (few stops away)

A quiet oasis in Hong Kong. Went to the gardens on one of the first days of my visit and it is still one of the best places I've been in HK!It is a wonderfully laid-out garden with many good views, bonsai trees and probably the most serene place in one of the world's busiest cities. It only takes a couple of hours to see most of the garden and the nunnery.

Classic HK garden - a little oasis in a a busy city.. I was lucky and timed my visit before the bus loads of tourists arrived, so was a very quiet place. Well designed and maintained garden, hides the bustle of the city well.

Beautiful oasis. Go see this. Beautiful gardens. Free entry. Perfect for an afternoon stroll. Everything you want in a Japanese style garden.ponds, pagodas, bonsai type plants.Eating is not permitted except in the café. Tea and a toasted cheese sambo is about 35HK. Go see the neighbouring Nunnery.

Calm and beautiful. A wonderful place to go, even when the weather is poor. The calm, soothing but quiet music complements the feeling of peace. Combine it with a visit to the Chi Lin nunnery over the road.

Gorgeous Garden. A bit of a way out of the main Hong along highlights, but well worth the MTR trip out to Diamond Hill. This Classical Chinese Garden is just across the road from the Hollywood Plaza mall you arrive in. Quite a contrast itself between the two landmarks. The garden is easy to walk around and is spectacular in its beauty and peacefulness. Much loved and carefully manicured plants. The bonsai (large versions) are fantastic. A great day out with the Chi Lin Nunnery just across the road.
Great for a first visit. This is my first time visiting this place and the adjacent nunnery, the garden was OK but the nunnery was nice.
A peaceful haven in HK. A great garden to visit wonderful photo opportunities and links to the monastery. Not old but an attractive reproduction of old china.
Beautiful garden. Good place to visit. Can take photographs. Also its very close to MTR just 10 mins walking distance.

The best place in Hongkong!. We found that little paradise in Hongkong and we loved it. So quiet and peaceful. Really nice are with little waterfalls, a lot of trees, chineese buildings...we really enjoyed it there ;)
An oasis of quite and calm in a bustling city. My favourite spot in Hong Kong. It is photogenic, has great vegetarian food close by and is iconic Hong Kong.

Beautiful serene garden. My husband and I discovered this place unintentionally, as we had a few hours to fill in, in Kowloon, and didn't want to race around too much. The Garden was directly opposite the Hollywood Plaza where our cruise ship's shuttle dropped us off. What a wonderful find! The gardens are incredibly peaceful and beautiful - gentle music playing, elegant topiary and bonsai, waterfalls, ponds, temples, even an amazing art exhibit. All with the Hong Kong skyline behind it. You can just feel your BP drop as you stroll around. Don't rush it - this place is special and deserves to be enjoyed at a gentle pace.
Peace and tranquility. These gardens are beautiful, tranquil and free!! It is hard to believe these gardens are minutes away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Well worth a visit.
Oasis. This is a serene oasis in a hectic city. Very beautiful park, with nunnery. Excellent vegetarian dinner in the nunnery's restaurant.
Nice and relaxing walking through the gardens. Nice and relaxing walking through the gardens. Hong kong is so busy so it was great to take a time out. Beautiful gardens

Peaceful garden in the concrete jungle. Beautifully manicured gardens, wooden pagodas with the main pagoda covered in gold leaf as central attraction. There is also a lovely restaurant and shop as well as a small museum with replicas of wooden buildings in China.
Garden Peace..... Great way to spend the afternoon away from the hustle and bustle of HK. Has all the richness of history and green space. Relaxing and picturesque...
Great place, beautiful garden in the city. Went here last week, i like it very much.. the view was superb. The garden was extraordinary... love the trees...

Relaxing break . I really like the garden and enjoyed the ' time out ' from the city. Great place to take photos.however my teenager thought it was all too artificial with no heart - a bit too Disney !
A piece of paradise in the busy city. I loved it here. It was incredibly relaxing, pretty and informative. Perfect for a nice stroll and to get out of the business of the city life.

fed up with walking in the dust and noises and heat, this is a good place to escape for a bit.... I don't like the name and its meaning although it is quite Buddhist-ish, the design of stucking bowls forming pillors for catching the rain from the roof is quite clever, a tiny falls of water is the only noise, it is quite cool as a place to escape the rubbish busy city life. I heard someone fell on the step of toilet, I discover the floor was specially design for something which I have forgotten, but at least it is waiting for some one to sue for compensation for broken bone medicine... compare with China's many garden this is rubbish.
Most beautiful garden in HK. Easy to get to via MTR Diamond Hill. Beautiful garden with manicured trees and some bonsai. definitely worth an hour or 2 of your time.
Simply wonderful!. Great garden with amazing architecture and great exhibitions. A real oasis - so calm and pretty, very relaxing. A great place to be and to enjoy nature surrounded by skyscrapers.

Beautiful, tranquil classical garden amidst the hustle and bustle of HK's cosmopolitan life. This Zen Garden is situated at Diamond Hill in Kowloon, HK and can be accessed easily by MTR's Green Line. Upon alighting the MTR ask staff to point you to the exit gate for Chi Lin Nunnery or Nan Lian Garden. From the exit which comes out of a shopping arcade, just turn left and head up a slight incline and there you will see sign post pointing to Nan Lian Garden just across the street. Entrance is free and the guide post hands out a pamplet of the garden which is shaped in a half moon. The garden is beautifully landscaped in the Tang style and there is a building gallery depicting the Tang architecture where joints are not nailed but interesting interlocked. A quarter of a way there are steps leading to the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery - a buddhist monastery. There are temples of Buddha's for Buddhist devotees. Along the corridor are displayed beautiful stone sculptures with Buddhist quotes for life! The central focal point is a lotus pond with beautiful lotus flowers around it. Back to the Garden: There is a running stream - the water from a nearby fountain that runs into two ponds in Nam LIan Garden where there are beautiful carps, a Pavilion with two bridges. There is a souvenir and snack shop and further down behind a cascade of water falls hides the Vegetarian Restaurant where simple vegetarian fare is served. Piped buddhist-styled chants can be heard softly as one meanders through the garden giving a surreal feeling of tranquility and serenity even though the weather was a bit hot when I visited at 11.30 am. I did not finish the tour and promised myself to return on another visit to go earlier before the sun gets too hot for my eczema skin. The garden opens from 9.30 am to 4.30 pm.

Beautiful. It's really beautiful here! It only takes about an hour to walk round but the gardens are stunning!It's very peaceful and nice just to be able to take in some greenery in the concrete jungle!Also it's free so great for anyone on a budget

Paradise in the city. What a wonderful surprise this wee gem is. Beautiful tranquil grounds with little paths winding around a pond sorrunded by trees. great photo shots of the golden temple and cute orange bridges. The vegetarian lunch and Tea ceremony are great options with a short hop across to the nunnery. serene and peaceful. definitely get there.
Nice place . Not a half day activity by any means but it is a nice place to see. 1 or 2 hours should be enough for the garden and nunnery. It's easy to walk from Diamond Hill MTR station.

Peaceful location and easy to get to. Used the mtr and got off at Diamond Hill, as you exit the station just follow the pink tourist signs that direct you to the gardens that are less than five minutes walk away.Take your time to walk around and appreciate the well maintained variety of plants and folliage. There are some buildings that contain interesting scaled down versions of ornate classic Chinese structures.While here you could visit Nunnery and shopping mall that are all located in the area.
Oasis of peace and silence. Beautiful place to walk around and come to peace if you are stressed out by the bustle of the big city. Ideal place to read a book if you have time.

Short Walk From Diamond Hill MTR Station. If you happen to be at this area, it really worth a visit this garden, with many beautiful tree and flower plants, a small lake and pagoda, good spot to your photo, a vegetarian restaurant next to a water fall, worth a try, the food is pretty good, but on the expensive side, the garden is free, a museum and a gift shop sell tea and Chinese art piece, I bought a umbrella with Chinese calligraphy print, make special for Nan Lian garden, it's kind of unique piece.

Tranquillity and serenity in the middle of a hustling and bustling Kowloon.. A train ride away from Hong Kong Island to Diamond Hill on Kowloon brought us to these gardens. It was an amazing feeling stepping out of the traffic and masses of people into the quietness and serenity of these gardens. Its style is of the Tang Dynasty time. The Lotus Pond and the Blue Pond ,the beautifully sculpted pines, landscaped gardens and classical timber structures (bridges, pavilions, etc.) provide an area for rest, reflection and relaxation. While children are welcome, parents are urged to keep their children quiet so as not to disturb the tranquillity of the gardens.
worth a visit. the statue is definitely worth the visit. ok, it is commercialized but still, worth the money spend. if you have sufficient time, use the cable cars. the view is stunning

Fantastic garden in the heart of the city. The garden is butifull has a small lake, several museums one for old Chinese woof buildings, fantastic rocks collection, crystal collection and othersAlso there is small water fall and vegetarian restaurant

Artificially created but good for a change. This is one of the popular destinations for tourists in a highly congested country. This garden is part of a big buddhist monastery. I enjoyed the place as it was clam and beautiful

Rest under the banyan tree glade!. This location is an oasis of peace and tranquility compared to all that's going on around you. Take your time. The vegetarian restaurant and tea house are worth it. The gift shop offers excellent merchandise. Take your time. Sit and enjoy the views and sounds. A special exhibit of Italian glass from Murano was on display--great display and detail. Well worth the time and money. This is one of the most beautiful gardens I've ever seen--even the gardens at Versailles pale in comparison to this!

When it get to much. Take a trip to this beautiful, stunning oasis when Hong Kong gets to much,so quiet and peaceful just what you need to recharge.Excellent cup of tea in the café,also the restaurant is built underneath the waterfall worth a visit just to see .Then just has you thought it could not get better,just cross over the bridge into the Chi Lin nunnery simply the best.If you have had to much quiet just cross over the road into the Hollywood plaza shopping centre.

Very tranquil in the evening, can be crowded otherwise. I have been to Nan Lian garden several times and whenever guests come to Hong Kong it is a easy go-to place. The garden is right across the street from the Diamond Hill MTR station. The garden is lovely with uniquely shaped trees/bushes, decorative ponds and waterfalls. It is next to a large nunnery/temple which is worth exploring. Its a place that you can spend either a few hours or an afternoon. There is currently an excellent Venetian glass exhibit on display in the garden. Also quite a unique nature-polished rock showcase and a modestly priced gift shop are on site. Watch for special performances that are also presented in the garden studio

Do not miss this. What a fabulous place this is. So peaceful and beautifully laid out. The stones are magnificent and the bonsai beautiful. This is free to enter and opens at 7am. It turned put to be the highlight of our trip.
Bliss and Tranquility. Beautiful traditional chinese style gardening in the middle of Diamond Hill. Go there with a book in the evening and have some "me-time".

Small But Beautiful Garden in Hong Kong. The pictures of this garden don't do it justice. It's a very beautiful, very green garden in the middle of bustling Hong Kong. Lovely specimens of bonsai and ornamental rocks. Definitely pair a visit to this garden with a visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery next door.

Very nice (japanese style) park. This lovely park worth the visit. Next to Chi-Lin Nunnery (must see), it is a quiet place to relax, take pictures, draw or paint, enjoy ornemental trees, a small pagoda, a teahouse, and some exhibitions (buildings models through history, stones, golden fish pound,...).Just avoid excessive sunny day (very little shade).And note that it is not a park for kids: guardians will haunt you and your singing/moving/running/sitting child everywhere, transforming your peacefull walk into a nightmare.

Bonsai Bonanza. Wonderful experience. Such a beautiful place and so serene. I spent several hours here but you could spend all day. My visit was on a Sunday so sadly, several areas, along with the restaurant (under a waterfall) were closed. There is however a cafe serving excellent snacks. Throughout the gardens there are the most amazing examples of Bonsai to be seen.
Amazing. Brilliant, clean, lovely gardens, birds and butterflies, very peaceful , the smells are lovely and an experience to awl around. Well worth a visit and free,
Wondrous surprize !!. A very short walk from Diamond Hill MTR station you will discover on of Hong Kong's many hidden gems. The Garden is small but filled with wonderful plants and rock formations.

Lovely and unexpected. Just a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station, with many English signs pointing the way. You just don't expect to see this lovely, tranquil garden in the middle of a city. Entrance is free. Take your time and wander the paths, so peaceful and tranquil. Be sure to see the exhibit of the wooden temple replicas. There are a few restrooms available and several shaded areas to take a break from the heat. Would have loved to have tried the tea room but it wasn't open. Take the time to walk through the nunnery as well.
Great for reflection. Peaceful location, great change from the busy-ness of the city buzz. Lots of great little displays as well as a good variety of chinese architecture.
Tranquil . A lovely place to visit for a morning or afternoon, very relaxing. A great place to take kids to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Calming, serene gardens - antithisis to hustle and bustle of HK. Easy to find from Diamond Hill MTR station. Wonderful manicured gardens that make one feel as if orient (vs Starbucks/Prada/M&S!) Free. Look at the exhibit on wooden temples (think giant doll's houses - definitely not for children and absolutely must not touch), waterfalls, ponds, just magic. We went to the tea house - do not be put off by the price - it is expensive for a pot of tea but a wonderful experience. Again serenity is the key word - relax, take your time and enjoy sample the flavours. Highly recommend. Tea house is good if raining - park ? bring an umbrella, and note there is shaded areas/routes if avoiding the sun.

An oasis in the middle of chaos. On the second day of our stay in Hong Kong we asked our guide to take us somewhere green and peaceful. She took us to the Nan Lian Garden. It was so much more than we expected! Very peaceful, extremely beautiful, and a lovely shop benefitting the nuns who run the garden. It was one of our Hong Kong highlights!

Peaceful place. BEAUTIFUL garden! Definitely recommend everyone to go there. There is a wonderful pond with Koi fish and really peaceful garden. There is even a temple in the garden so i do a afternoon visit to this garden. It is also located near the MTR and Plaza Hollywood.
Stunning garden oasis in the city. The gardens here were beautiful. We spent a couple of hours enjoying the peace. It was easy to get to via MTR and well signposted from the station.

Place of Zen. The place was beautiful and clean, with a very tranquil atmosphere. Eating and the use of selfie sticks are prohibited! They take great effort to preserve its beauty and solemnity. There isn't much to do but to admire the place and to take pictures. There are mini museums and places to eat at though. Garden wasn't that big either. But even then, I enjoyed taking a leisurely stroll, it's soothing. So if you wanna get away from the hustle and bustle of the city, this would be a nice place to visit! :)Better to go when it's not raining.
Very pretty.. A very pretty area. Quite serene in the midst of the city. Not a top site but a good one if you're in HK for longer than a week.

Pleasant garden convenient location.. This is a nice traditional garden with a cafe, vegetarian restaurant and small museum. Although not the quirkiest garden I have seen it is worth a visit if you have not been to a traditional Chinese garden. It has a open feel and is conveniently located next to diamond hill metro station and connected to Chi Lin Nunnery via a foot bridge over the road. In addition both attractions are free so if you are going past pop in.

Chinese soul in a concrete frame.
