Fantastic garden reflecting Tao philosophy in all details where you can breath the soul dream of symbols and forms of humans inspired by the God knowledge and perfection research.This is an incredible example of deep cultural Chinese heritage, on the way houses are traditionally built without a single nail, to magnific vegetarian food proposals into a spiritual maze of paths fraimed by bonsai trees and water and stone balance scenography.Incredible is the contrast on the back with the HK skyscrapers which represent the other side of the coin of HK, more practical, business oriented and soul off.

Gardens. Such a beautiful, calm, peaceful paradise in the middle of the hectic city. It's amazing to have that peaceful area and you loo up to see the city buildings that surround it. (piece of advice if you use a selfie stick, don't use it there) There's also a cafe, although I didn't go in.

Peaceful. I lived in HK for almost 3 years, but I ended up visiting this place only towards the end - in my last month there. I am pretty sure had I known about this place earlier, it would have been on my monthly visits list.It's so quite and peaceful and beauitful. Must visit!

Beautiful! But quick... . The garden is a little haven of tranquility nestled in the craziness of Hong Kong, truly beautiful BUT it took me around 20 minutes to walk around and I was done. If you have been to China or any Chinese gardens before you could definitely skip it, but, it is beautiful!

Rockery, clipped trees and bird songs. Probably the most exquisite formal Chinese garden visible in Hong Kong, this large park (3.5 ha) is was open in 2006 and became an instant hit with both local and tourists. The golden pavilion and vermilion bridge over a pond lack some patina but are very pleasant. A lot of care has been put in the overall design, the selection of rockery, trees are artfully clipped and many birds have adopted the place. A vegetarian restaurant is hidden behind a waterfall, a tea pavilion overlooks another pond, temporary exhibitions are organized in yet another pavilion (beautiful Murano glass vases last time I visited) and the boutique proposes interesting, mostly tea-related crafts. The hall dedicated to the nail-free joinery used in the frames of classical Chinese temples and pagodas is fascinating. A must see for any visitor to Hong Kong and a repeat destination for residents. It’s free and less than 5 mn walk from the MTR Diamond Hill station.
Lovely but. you can't get anywhere near the red bridge, since access is gated off. Could barely get a good angle for photography. A gorgeous place anyway.
Relaxing. After visiting Chi Lin Nunnery, cross the bridge to Nan Lian Garden. Relaxing garden with waterfalls, fish pond, restaurant and gift shop.

Bird watching. Peaceful well maintained gardens, lovely to wander around and get over jet lag, Free. Best of all great birds to look at too - if you are not from the area really interesting and singing so lovely! Do recommend the restaurant in the grounds, also note plenty of public loos, all v clean

Bliss among tall buildings!. Nan Lian Garden is located among tall buildings in Diamond Hills, opposite to Chi Lin Nunnary. The garden is simply beautiful. One can relax besides a small artificial waterfall. The entry is free of charge. There is a vegetarian snacks shop, which serves excellent green tea. One can buy some food products as well from this shop. There is also a restaurant, located just behind the waterfall. A must visit in HK!

Beautifully designed and maintained. Lovely place to spend an hour or so, out of the direct hustle and bustle of the city. The Garden is very easy to find from the Diamond Hill MTR station, has a lovely gift shop and plenty of places to sit and have a chat.
Gorgeous. Absolutely beautiful. It is located across from the nunnery. This was one of my favorite things we did on our trip....best of all they are both free.
Well worth a visit. A lovely Asian-style garden that is well worth visiting. Impecably maintained and easily accessible from MTR diamond hill (although we to the bus to it)

Beautiful. Just a short walk from the MTR, this garden is just beautiful. Free entry. Calm, peaceful. Contrasting Chinese garden and architecture with high rises in the surrounding areas. Well worth checking out.

An oasis of tranquility. Nan Lian Garden is a green oasis among HK's many high-rise buildings. It's a little off-the-path for those staying in the island, but definitely worth visiting. Pair it with a visit to Chi Lin Nunnery just nearby and to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery to make the most out of your day.
peaceful. A quiet and peaceful garden in the city. Free entrance and many nice spots for photos. After that you can go shopping at Plaza Hollywood nearby.

Beautiful. Beautiful garden park, free to public, nice place to relax in the middle of skyscrapers, if you have time, definitely go walk around. Just take MTR to Diamond Hill station and you're right there

Breathtaking. This garden is breathtaking. We were there early on a Saturday morning, before any crowds. The landscaping does not look real! To me the trees looked like something you would find in a Dr. Seuss book. The painstaking detail was phenomenal and my photographs look unreal due to the bright beautiful colors. Worth a visit if you are in this part of town.
Love this place!!!!. A must see!!!! The vegetarian Resturant inside the park is really good. Loved their congee! The park is not big and great for small children.
Gorgeous. An unexpected oasis in the middle of the city, a place you have to see. The tea house is a definite plus, you must try the delicious pastries. Don't think about it, go!

Beautiful garden, interesting Buddhist temple. The walk through the garden to reach the Temple is very beautiful, flowers, pagoda, greenery. The temple itself is interesting, with many statues and some information about what you are viewing.

Beautiful. This is a really beautifully kept garden and as others have pointed out has a nice serenity to it. If you have an hour or so to burn and it's on your mtr route I would recommend visiting but it probably isn't worth going out of your way for and really isn't a whole day out. That said it is really close to diamond hill mtr station and can be combined with a visit to the nunnery and the mtr mall at diamond hill too.

Very beautiful garden. This is a very beautiful garden to visit.....unfortunately some of the entrance were close while we were there so we could not capture the beauty of this garden....and was disappointed.....entrance is free but it was so hot during our visit .....
I loved taking pictures. I really loved this place, Loved taking pictures there and just walking around wondering was enough to put you in a good peaceful mood

An amazing bonsai garden. A beautiful classical Chinese garden with hundreds of bonsai trees of various types and sizes.The garden is a very peaceful refuge in Hong Kong.There is a vegetarian restaurant which opens for lunch.Entrance is free.

Tranquility.. A beautiful oasis in the middle of Hong Kong, which is backed onto the breathtaking Chi Lin Nunnery. My girlfriend and I fitted this in on our last day in Hong Kong as an extra - and we are so glad we did as it was probably one of our favourite places we visited.

Beautiful and serene! . Beautifully well kept gardens! It was really easy to get here using the metro ( just a quick walk from diamond hill station) the gardens were unbelievably well kept and it was nice and quiet as we went on a Thursday morning. It's a must for anyone to have a visit. Such a nice break from the busy streets of Hong Kong. The little cafe within the garden was had surprisingly cheap drinks, and was a nice place to take a break from all that walking. Would 100% recommend to anyone visiting Hong Kong!

Tranquility and Peace. Nan Lian Garden is a garden (basically a small park) with a lake, pagodas, bridges and waterfalls. With many benches to sit and enjoy the scenery, it is a fantastic place to escape the concrete jungles of the city.The colorful bridges and pagodas create a nice contrast to the modern high-rise buildings in the neighborhood.

stunning garden. we visited this garden one hot afternoon and its was very beautiful. there were a number of rules in the garden we thought was a bit silly like not allowed to run or no frolicking and you are not allowed to use a selfie stick. pretty dumb things really but the garden it self was lovely and the staff looking after the place are pleasant. it was far too hot so suggest brining an umbrella to keep you cool from the blazing sun. a lot of the garden you were not allowed to walk in to the pagoda or walk in to some of the buildings it was very limited to what you could see up close. but what we did see even on the garden path was really quite beautiful

Peaceful garden. I visited Nan Lian at the suggestion of a local friend. It was easy to reach by MTR and was well worth the visit, as was the related Chi Lin Nunnery. Because both are surrounded by modern Hong Kong high rise buildings, they seem slightly incongruous, but are welcome oases of quiet in the midst of the bustling crowds. Only a few other people were strolling through the winding garden walks when I was there. The vistas were calming and lovely. I ate lunch at the vegan restaurant, located behind the (artificial) waterfall, choosing the set 5-course menu of the day. Not all the dishes appealed to me, but I had more than enough food to satisfy me for c. $20 US.
Quite 🌸. This garden is clean, quite and beautiful. You can sit and take pics, also you can go from there to the next side and you will found Chi Lin Nurnny

Peaceful, quiet, serene and beautiful garden!. Perfect spot if you want to escape from the busy metro. It's my favorite place in Hong Kong. I can stay there all day just reminiscing or just taking in the beauty of the place. I can just sit next to the man-made waterfall called the "Silver Strand". The water flowing from there is very relaxing. What I love the most in the garden is the "Blue Pond". It really amazing and beautiful. To think that when you look at the background you'll see the tall buildings surrounding the garden. It's like a reminder that it's possible to have a beautiful garden like this at the center of the city. That you don't have to go out of the city and travel far to see a classical beauty. It's located several minutes walk from Diamond Hill MRT Station. This is a must visit when you go to Hong Kong! Oh and don't forget to try the fresh orange juice at their Snack Shop. It's the best fresh orange juice I've ever had. It's really fresh with all the pulps, and it's not bitter at all.

Fantastic quiet location. Loads to see. There is a lots of things you cannot do, the staff will soon let you know the do's and the don'ts very quickly. That aside, it is well worth a visit. Take about 4 hours to enjoy it fully. Don't rush as you will lose the enjoyment.

Amazing clean garden near to diamond hill metro. It is a well kept garden and a must to see if you are nearby . It has wooden artistic monastery and pagodas which are built in detail . The garden is clean and kept tidy . However it was a hot and sunny afternoon and we ran towards the nearest restaurant for some cool air . It has a restaurant with a waterfall feature which is quite good . We were short of time otherwise would have stayed longer

A clasical chinese garden between the sky scrapers. I.ve got here my first mosquito bites in HK...:)Just because it was so beautiful, that I couldn't go away quickly. It is a nice and peaceful corner in the agitated HK and the visit was a way to connect with history, tradition and religion of the locals. Don.t miss the garden, you will enjoy it much.

Very nice and clean garden away from the crowd. Within walking distance from diamond hill station , this park is a place to visit. Not well known among tourists because it is not on the to visit list of most tour agencies. But a good place for those who love nature and peace. The garden is well maintained and cleaned. There is a short walking trail which will guide you round the garden and end at the chi lin nunnery right opposite it, The architecture of the building, pagoda, bridges and waterfall has rich chinese and japanese culture in it. Quite enjoyable slow trail away from the hustle and bustle of hongkong.

Calm and Peaceful Garden. Nan Lian Garden is a great place to spend a peaceful hour amongst the busy-ness of Hong Kong. It is easy to get to from Diamond Hill MTR, just walk underneath the road overpass. There is plenty of space to wander around - lakes, paths, beautiful trees and rock formations to admire. They have a quaint little shop and tea room as well as the vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall.Chi Lin Nunnery is also good to look at, just head over the steps on the north side of the garden, across the road and follow the path into the nunnery. Again, it is a very peaceful place to look around.Top tip! Food and drink is not allowed in the garden (I'm not sure about the nunnery). We took some snacks and carton drinks in for the children. We sat down in a few places and a 'guard' immediately came over and told us that we couldn't eat or drink. We even sat on a bench outside the park and someone came over! I guess they want to keep insects etc to a minimum!

Nan Lian Garden. IF you have the time and IF you have the energy to visit BOTH the Nan Lian Garden(s) AND the Chi Lin Nunnery DO SO. You can ride the Hong Kong MTR to Diamond Hill station and both are a short walk.

A beautiful oasis in Hong Kong. After spending several days exploring the city, the Nan Lian Garden was a welcome and relaxing break from the urban landscape. The winding paths amongst the trees and ponds were beautiful and relaxing. I wished we had time for tea but we got there to early. The gift shop has beautiful and unique souvenirs. Not to be missed.

A beautiful garden in the heart of Hong Kong, who would have thought!!. This is a very pretty, picturesque garden with a lovely temple, manicured gardens, waterfall and spinning wheel and a lovely veg cafe too. A must visit. The MTR is the way to travel here
Peaceful Oasis in the city. Nan Lian Garden is a little gem tucked in among the skyscrapers. It's absolutely beautiful, and they have lovely merchandise in the gift shop, too.

The most stunning gardens ever.. A beautiful tranquil place. A must see if you have time in HK. Stunning. Immaculate. Not a drop of litter. In the heart of the city and yet feels a million years away from the hustle and bustle of HK.

Beautiful serenity.. Found this online on a self guided walking tour. We could not believe how beautiful this garden was and how quiet it was considering it was in the middle of the city. A couple of nice shops to browse in and lots of phot ops. It is connected to a nunnery that was beautiful as well. Many beautiful altars with different buddhas and lovely lotus pools. Would highly recommend visiting for a break from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Sanctuary within a concrete jungle. This is an amazing tranquil and exquisite garden. A must see in Hong Kong. A place to spend a couple of hours, take a camera for beautiful photos.

The most peaceful place . This place is just so utterly peaceful. I went early so maybe that's why. Very Japanese in style. Beautiful well kept gardens. Lovely waterfall. Stunning pagoda. I absolutely loved it here! It links to chi lin nunnery. Free entry. Opens from 7am. Wifi at the park. Toilets excellent. Very expensive tea house which I avoided. Vegetarian restaurant also. Located at diamond hill mtr

A Chinese garden surrounded by the tower blocks of Hong Kong!. Beautiful gardens in Kowloon.Easy to travel to via MTR - Diamond Hill station. 5 minute walk to the entrance, clearly signposted.You can spend a very relaxed hour walking around this oasis of peace in an incredibly built up area of Hong Kong. Location of a wonderful vegetarian restaurant. There is also a good cafe serving good value snacks.Continue your walk into the Chi Lin Nunnery.

Free, peaceful, serenity in the city. A beautiful place to walk around, or sit and relax for a short time.Very peaceful and serene, and great escape from the city.As the attraction is free, you would expect it to be busier, but this is not the case. You can walk around, it doesn't take long, but it is very enjoyable. As it is connected to the nunnery it prolongs the visit.There is a little restaurant to eat behind the waterfall but I did not.I would return in the future as it is so peaceful.

Magnificent Formal Chinese Gardens. Plan to spend a few hours walking through these gorgeous gardens. They are right across the street from the Diamond Hill MTR stop. Diamond Hill has a food court in the top part of the mall, attached to the MTR station, which provides a convenient place to get a snack or drinks. The gardens are free and were on of my favorite gardens we visited on our trip to Asia.
Peaceful tranquility. We went to the nunnery across the road and then went for a walk in the gardens, very peaceful and relaxing to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong
Amazing gardens. This is really a great place to visit. Very calming away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Beautiful gardens and very peaceful.

Oasis in HK. Reading other TA reviews, and listening to our concierge who had a friend of a friend that visited the place, I got the impression this Nan Lian gardens was a random collection of trees and oddly shaped rocks. We went anyway since we were in the area.Both the oddly shaped rocks and trees are there, but so much more. A beautiful and pristine garden that must take an army of gardeners to maintain. There's also sublime pagodas, waterfalls and outlooks. It's a very peaceful oasis in the middle of busy Kowloon, and if I worked near there I know where I would be eating lunch every day. A bonus is the free exhibits on Chinese architecture with models of other temples, with special attention paid to the joinery on these old temples which is amazingly intricate given the era they were constructed. And the buildings hosting these exhibits were created in this style.There's also a couple of comfy cafe's and restaurants. If you're looking for a peaceful experience in the middle of HK, I recommend. And the attached Chi Lin nunnery is also an unmissable part of the experience.

Loved this place. Recommend a visit to Nan Liang gardens, the gardens are beautiful. There is an English guide lady who was very informative who patrols the park. The nunnery is worth a look, very interesting, even for kids.Surprised by their collection of bonzais..

Speechless! An absolutely beautiful and tranquil park in bustling Hong Kong!. First off! This destination is so easy to find! Located directly across from Diamond Hill MTR station, the beauty of this park came as a total surprise during my first visit. Amazing collection of rare plantations and rock structures. Don't miss out on the beautifully prepared vegetarian dishes by the in-house restaurant. The huge shopping mall across from the park is worth a visit too.

A bit out of the way but worth it.... If you have seen the major sights in Hong Kong, this garden and the attached nunnery is well worth a visit. Take a taxi from your hotel and plan on spending 2 hours walking around the garden and display of Chinese architecture and whatever the special exhibit is...we saw beautiful Murano glass. And I agree with previous writers...the restrooms are beautiful! We even saw a nun and enjoyed their temple. To get back you will need to go down the hill and up the street to the mall to get a taxi.
Escape from the city. This place is always empty. It's a lovely little spot. Bring a book, a flask of tea, and make yourself comfortable.

Old world vs new. This garden is absolutely tranquil. It's a great place to practice your photography and stroll around with you thoughts. The view of high rises in the background with traditional buildings in front is very special.

Relaxing garden . If you need to chill out and escape from the city center you can visit this beautiful garden. The access is free and you can enjoy the beauty of plants and the temple which resembles the Japanese original version. You are not allowed to eat in the park or walk on the grass.

Go there for the waterfall restaurant . It is a typical Chinese garden laid artistically with bridges and a beautiful lake with fish in it. The place is peaceful and just on the opposite side of the Buddhist halls Don't miss having lunch or dinner at the veg. Restaurant near the artificial waterfall.
Peaceful. Best way to relax and reflect on life! Not much to do or see but it's free. So really it's not like it matters.
Nice garden. Giant carps, very cool! Beautiful well maintained Chinese garden in the middle of the city next to Chi Linn Nunnery.

Easily My Favorite Place in Hong Kong. This garden is beautiful and well-kept and a nice way to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. It is nice to stop in for a walk around. Normally, I visit during the day but recently visited around 7 pm, and it was even more beautiful at night. I had the place to myself and spotlights were on the golden pavilion making it an excellent time to photograph. The gates shut at 9 pm. If you have time, also try the restaurant behind the waterfall; it is very interesting vegetarian food and the proceeds go to the nunnery. This is definitely a must see in Hong Kong.

Colourful and scenic place. A landscaped Chinese garden of classical elegance.Without so much gardening experience, I think it has some similarities with Japanese gardens I have visited.Fantastically well-run, No weeds in sight. No tree or stone is deployed without a thought.Provides a surreal feeling with all the skyscrapers in the background.Stylish souvenir shop on site.Combine the visit with Chi Lin Nunnery.

Gorgeous and peaceful!. Absolutely beautiful! Pitty it rained so much we weren't prepared. Didn't stay long. Would have loved to stroll around at a slower pace to take in the beautiful, lush green landscape. Bonsai like trees, lakes, waterfall breathtaking. Worth a visit.

A must see. These classical gardens are beautiful, well kept, with all features you would expect: lotus pond, pavilions, pines groves, banyan, wooden houses ... Just beautiful. Easily accessed by MRT Diamond Hill exit C2, 5 mn walk. Free entrance. Don't miss the Chi Li Nunnery across the street, a Buddhist perfection.

Lovely tranquility and beauty, nice break for a couple of hours. A nice respite from the city hustle and bustle. Beautiful gardens with a one way system with lots of lovely picture spots. Also connects up to the Chi Lin Monastery which is a great temple visit. Very peaceful and respectful environment. A very pleasant visit and well worth the visit. Easy to navigate on the MTR system and well signposted also. Good for family visits (no playgrounds or running arounds on the displays though!), or adults.
must see. A must visit when you are in hongkong. Very accessible and no entrance fee. If you to see temples and buddha, this is the place for you

Mind blowing beauty. the care and keeping of this garden in the middle of such a huge city is done meticulously. It is almost like being placed in another relm due to the smog and thick pollution of the city. The history and the people who are in this garden are fascinating and so very kind. We had the chance to walk and try to talk with the oldest elder in the Monastery across the walk way.
Pleasant couple of hours. Nice park to spend a couple of hours in the mad activity of Hong Kong. Relaxing wander round with photo opportunities

Absolutely beautiful and peaceful. Really easy to get to, take MTR green line to Diamond Hill and just follow the signs. The garden is free. The grounds are kept in immaculate shape. The place is so beautiful and peaceful. I love nature and keep several gardens at home, so I really appreciate gardens. There is restaurant inside as well. We also gave a donation to see the blown glass collection. Which I thought was so so. At the end of the garden, you can cross over to the nunnery and see the beautiful architecture and Buddha. Combined together, definitely worth the trip, and you feel really zen while you're there.

japanese arts in the heart of HK. this park is so fantastic. its magnificent golden pagoda, a nice bright orange color bridge, bonsai trees, decorated rocks, ...all these amazing stuff reminds me of japanese zen arts rather than chinese ones. if possible, visit the park on weekdays in late afternoon when there are less people so you can avoid the crowd and appreciate this peaceful and quiet garden of eden even more. note: admission is free. the park is friendly for parents with baby stroller or people on wheelchair.
Awesome!. Beautiful garden and experience in the middle of Kowloon. A must place to stop and stroll! Great place to enjoy a tea ceremony in the middle of such perfect landscapes and tranquility.

Escape the bustle of Hong Kong. A place to wind down and relax even though the garden is surrounded by high rise and roads. Created in 2006, it is full of amazing trees brought in from China and Japan. Most look like very large bonsai with dramatic shapes. Not a really flower garden, it's more about shape and form. You could walk round in 30 mins but absorb yourself in the tranquility you need at least 2 hours. The gift shop is very tasteful and not overpriced. The tea shop and restaurant are quite expensive. Please note you are not allowed to eat in the garden. The Chi Lin Nunnery is attached by a walkway

Quiet and very peaceful garden. This garden is always worth a visit, whether it is a sunny or a cloudy day. Always go there by MTR, Station Diamond Hill and once you are on street level (where the bus exchange square is) turn right in front of the escalator leading to the Shopping mall and head up the street under the flyovers and at the traffic lights you will see the garden on the opposite side. The garden has beautiful trees, and although in the middle of the bustling city it is always quiet here. The lovely japanese pagoda in the pond is not accessible but makes for beautiful pictures, whether there is sun or not. The exhibition with the big stones is also worth to see and the small shop is not the usual trashy gift shop, but has very nice items, which can be very expensive in terms of the porcelain there.Depends how fast you walk and how long you rest on one of the benches, you can spend there easily an hour, if not 2.I always make sure, that we visit the nunnery on the opposite site of the street.You find an expensive tea house in the garden and a restaurant which is hidden behind the waterfall. I have not been in them yet.

Lovely quiet and peaceful in the middle of the city. One of the staff in our hotel suggested we visit these gardens, we are so glad they did. The gardens are beautiful, it is a great walk, we got some amazing photographs.

Nan Lian Garden. A little gem in a busy city. With the MTR, the gardens were very easy to get to and well worth the trip. Manicured gardens/trees, paved walkways, ponds and the city skyline in the background reminding us of the presence of busy Kowloon.

Well worth a tour. Easily accessible on the metro this garden and nunnery are definitely worth a visit. The peaceful garden is set in an area surrounded by high rise which makes for some interesting photos. The garden itself merits many photoz

An oasis of tranquility. These is a nice little garden - it doesn't take long to go around. It is attached to the nunnery which also has a nice water lily pond garden. A nice break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Easy to find.

A pleasant oasis in a bustling city: excellent to visit in winter. My wife and I visited Nan Lian Gardens in December last year. This post is late because I went for an operation just after the return from the trip.The Gardens are easily accessible by the Hong Kong subway. We took the Kwun Tong line (from Mongkok) and alighted at the Diamond Hill station. We took the C2 exit and walked out of the Mall. Just turn right at the Uniqlo store and walk out into the street. The Gardens is just across the road but the access is through a traffic controlled junction. It is roughly a 5-minute walk.Entrance to the Gardens is free. Once you enter into the Garden premises you feel that you are being transported into a different world, peaceful, serene, and calm. There are the ubiquitous trees and plants typical of a Chinese garden, complete with pavilions and bridges. There are some galleries which are educational, examples being one that shows the timber architecture and construction of the temples, and another that houses rocks. We visited a cloisonne exhibition which happened to be on display.At the far end of the Gardens is a Chinese tea house built to replicate those common during the Song Dynasty. A beautiful pond is in front of it. There is also a mill replica nearby.We would recommend a visit during the cooler months as it will make a pleasant leisurely stroll. Give yourself about 2 hours for an unhurried visit.

Beautifully maintained - the koi carp are amazing. A beautiful garden and escape from city life. I really enjoyed wondering around for an hour or so. It is immaculately maintained and a real treat if you have not seen many formal oriental gardens!

Unexpectedly tranquil. What a nice surprise it is to be able to step out from a busy MTR stop and be greeted with such a well kept and tranquil place .... and free! Definitely worth a visit if you are on the Kowloon side.

Perfect Peace!. A wonderful find in the midst of a busy city! A possible future world heritage site entry! Tranquill gardens,peaceful lakes, Pagodas, bridges, tea houses, serene walks, working temple & Nunnery, Immaculate surroundngs to while away a day! Hong Kong.Adjacent to monastatic complex of Chi Lin Nunnery bult in Tang style.A Must see do not miss if tranquilty is your thing!

Tranquil. My husband and I visited the gardens 8 years ago and it was a pleasure to visit again. Still tranquil, pretty, interesting and lovely to walk around.Unfortunately the tea house was still closed, couldn't stay until it opened, but if you get a chance to have tea there, it's lovely.

Serenity. Awesome place to spend several hours just strolling the winding walkways of this traditional Chinese garden. It is designed to be taken slowly and being slow is the best way to admire it. Be sure to visit all the pavilions of the garden, they have beautiful expositions about traditional wooden architecture, rocks and stones and so on. Than - continue across the bridge to the Chi Lin Nunnery.
Next to the nunnery. Very pretty. Guarded. Changing exhibitions - when we went it was Venician glass vases. Sign posted from metro - not far.

Beautiful garden in Japanese style. Very nice well hold garden/park in the middle of sky tall buildings. Was much more fascinating then I have expected. Very quite and peaceful place for those who love nature or want a break from rushy city life.
An Oasis in Hong Kong. An amazing juxtaposition of the past with present history. The gardens are spectacular and peaceful. Worth visiting!

So Serene in Contrast. The place was so quiet and clean! I learned something from this place. It was sacred for some people. Who would think you could find something as calm and as peaceful in the heart of the buildings & offices.

Should not be missed. The place is amazing, in the middle of the populated area is this green oasis. A stroll around the garden then walk over a bridge and you are in the Chi Lin Nunnery.Just amazing.
Lovely oasis in crazy busy HK.. This place is beautiful. Highly recommend chilling here. The rocks at the nunnery make inspiring reading.
Beautiful Garden. I am not sure why many people dont know this place, but it can be a good thing since it makes this attraction not that crowded unlike other places in HK. Beautiful and Tranquil.
A meditative walk in the gardens . It took me nearly 2 hours to finish my walk in the Temple grounds. There was an exhibition on Murano vases and also a very good vegetarian restaurant.

A true hidden gem in Kowloon. Known to far too few Hong Kongers and even fewer outside the Territory, these gardens are a prime and sad example of what Hong Kong could have been with good modern sustainable and democratically elected governance and a professional civil service who know what they are doing.
Find peace. Wonderful place of peace. Don't think many tourists take time to come here. Plus there is no admission fee, bathrooms are clean. Vegetarian restaurant under a nice waterfall.

Peace and quiet in the hub-bub of Hong Kong. Use the excellent HK subway system, get to Diamond Hill and 2 minutes walk are these beautiful and peaceful gardens. Entry is free and you will be rewarded with a lovely walk mainly featuring beautiful trees but there are waterfalls, ponds and a pagoda too. It is not large and you can probably walk all the way around in 45 mins but combine it with a visit to the nunnery that is just next door and you'll have escaped the HK madness!

Serene.. The garden was built recently, but that does not detract from the garden. It is a mix of architecture and nature. There is a section with small wooden models of various traditional buildings and a pagoda in the center. It is free to enter and is great for a quick stroll or a more reflective walk. It is also connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery. For being such a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR stop, this is definitely a must see.
lovely place!. Amazing Place to visit! A must if you are in HK for a few days, it's really worth a visit.Easy to find at Diamond Hill Station and the entrance is free!

Nice. The garden is beautiful but if you have been to Japanese gardens before, you may be a tad disappointed. Chi Lin Nunnery is in the same complex and is lovely too. Both can be done within 2 hours.Located 5-7 minutes from Diamond Hill station (exit C2). You will see signage so easy to locate.
It is called Chi Lin Nunnery too. Some call this spot Nan Lian Garden some call Chi Lin Nunnery. The place is a "must visit" place in Hong Kong.
Oasis. Beautiful traditional garden, every scene is well considered. Nice gift shop & good tea houses too - visit after 12 to access tea house with a view of the carp pond

Peace and tranquility. Set amongst the skyscrapers and next to a main road, it is remarkably quiet and peaceful. Pick up a free guide at the entrance and you can find out more information on the gardens and how they were set up. There is a vegetarian restaurant within the grounds. Go across the walkway and you can get to the Chi Lin Nunnery, worth combining the two

Lovely park. Beautiful park , next to the nunnery - it is tranquil if you can ignore the traffic that flies past in the main roads! It's well worth a look though - go to diamond hill MTR and loom for exit c2 - head right and follow the signs! The veggie restaurant is basic but nice :-)

Peace and quiet in a beautiful setting. Beautiful gardens and lovely old traditional buildings are the attraction here. Set in Kowloon not far from the hustle and bustle of the city the gardens provide a quiet and peaceful place, especially if you visit early in the morning. The gardens are very well tended and the wooden architecture is explained in an exhibition in one of the traditional buildings.

Just WaW. So much has been already said! Definitely a garden to check out. Easy to combine with Won Tai Sin Temple. Go to the Temple first and escape to the tranquillity of this Garden. Exposition is free on Wednesday. It is to experience. Eating is not allowed inside the park in way it is great they have this rule.

A must see expensive garden in Hong Kong. This is surely a must see garden. It was built in 2003, I think. The planning often garden is nice and the whole garden is so ZEN. You can also book a place to enjoy tea inside the trees, in Hong Kong city centre, this is a very luxury thing to do because there are hardly find trees. The veg restaurant is good and temple is also very nice. The whole area was built according to Tong Dynasty wood structure. I think all of the trees were imported from China and Japan and all are very very expensive trees.

Beautiful garden. This garden is worth seeing. I've been to this park several times and will definitely visit it again. Their plants, temple scale models, bonsai collection, stone formation and featured exhibits are wonderful. If not for the buildings around, you'll think you're not in the city. There is a bridge connecting the garden to Chi Lin Nunnery which is also a must visit.

An Island of Green. It's hard to imagine such a peaceful place exists inside such a populated city. While walking the paths through the garden, you can see the sky scrapers in the background that remind you where you are, however none of the noise finds its way inside. There is a colorful pagoda in the center of a lake with plenty of koi fish, and a tea room that opens later in the day. Dozens of picture opportunities and if going to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery, the gardens are connected so might as well see both. To get here from Hong Kong Island or Kowloon, take the red MTR line north and switch to the green line. Get off at Diamond Hill and take the C2 exit and follow the signs, very easy to find.

Magic and tranquility in the center of Hong Kong.. Incredible stillness amid the fabulous city of Hong Kong. Ideal to reflect, to be in touch with nature and learn more about the vast and enigmatic history of Buddhism. Temple that holds great works of art and magic place that teaches unparalleled and enriched.

Lovely gardens in the middle of a city. Easy to get to and a great place to wander aimlessly. Lots of traditional wooden buildings to visit. Disappointing that you don't seem to be able to access the bridges or the pagoda. My kids desperately wanted to visit them.

A relaxing stroll at the beautiful garden.. Add this into your itineraries because it is such a lovely walk for me and my husband in the garden. We spent about 2 hours in the garden, taking photos, learning the buddhist teaching at various spot of the nicely crafted buildings at the same time enjoying the plants and ponds. A feeling of calmness and serenity after the morning walk. It has a nice cafe and restaurant inside the garden.

Calming Atmosphere. Nan Lian is a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR stop. I found it much more calming and pleasant than the Hong Kong Garden. The rockery has some amazing rock shapes. There's a very nice gift shop, tea house, and vegetarian restaurant. I enjoyed a wonderful exhibit of Venetian glass in the hall.
Good place to see paired with Chi Lin Nunnery. It's a relaxing place for a stroll for those visiting Chi Lin nunnery. Not worth visiting in isolation, though.

A stunning garden. Hong Kong is full of parks and gardens, but this is the cream of the crop. An island of peace and beauty surrounded by high rise apartments and road flyovers. The standard of maintenance is superb, the lake has the largest collection of mature koi carp I have ever seen and there is an amazing collection of bonsai trees as well. This just cannot be faulted in any why.

A wonderful place to visit.serne,calm,inspiring.. This is amust, lovely gardens, stautues,a feeling of calmness,serene ,at sunst it looks lovely.far from town but once you go there you forget the hustle and bustle
Totally Unexpected. This is an oasis of peace and beauty. Trees like giant bonsai, tended by gardeners with scissors who groom them to perfection.

A little oasis in the city. Well worth a visit. So peaceful. Nice tearoom and a superb gift shop....we bought a number of lovely, quality souvenirs. Quite a way from the city centre...we took a taxi which is not too expensive...in my opinion.

A place of serenity & contemplation . These beautiful gardens are in Kowloon very near the Diamond Hill MTR station. They are adjacent to the Chi Lin nunnery, containing beautiful Buddhist temples built of wood in the ancient Chinese style. We spent a wonderful morning in the calm of this place which nestles in among the skyscrapers & flyovers. It has veggie Chinese restaurant, an ideal way to finish the morning.

Peaceful place. It's the kind of place where you find yourself. The garden is managed very well, most of the tres are pruned in a bonsai form. Although there are authentic bonsai trees centuries old. It's surely worth a visit, after visiting the Nunnery.

Beautiful park with the nunnery, free of charge, nice with kids as well. We went to the garden on a very rainy day. We were well prepared so the rain was not a problem. The garden was a nice oasis from the busy city streets. Very beautiful views and the building (nunnery) was interesting as well. Would recommend this garden for families with kids also.

Beautifully laid out. For a relatively new gardens it has the feel it had been there for ever. It can be very quite as long as you do not arrive at the same time a tourist buses. It is very well laid out with many features of interest.We can also recommend the café for its excellent coffee.

Our Favorite Place in Hong Kong. We went on a weekday morning and probably spend three times as much time as we had expected to. Our photos are on instagram #meandhetravel This garden is a treasure and all the more remarkable for being surrounded by skyscrapers. We took the subway to the Diamond Hill station and it was a quick walk to the garden which is connected to the Nunnery - also remarkable and unforgettable. As both are easily accessed by public transportation (both in terms of distance and time) we hope you will add Nan Lian Garden to your must-see list!!!

An oasis of serenity. If you want to escape the hustle and bustle of the city without having to hike up the hills, Nan Lian is a great option. Very accessible. We were in Tsim Sha Tsui and we could take either the MTR or buses #5 or #9. A spaghetti of flyovers surrounds it - a casualty of development, I guess - but the garden itself is idyllic. Built across multiple levels, with ponds and waterfalls, the landscaping blends in stones and trees and wooden structures beautifully. Not sprawling. But enough to give you a sense of insulation from the busy thoroughfares.We picked up some pure silk scarves and stoles from the boutique store inside. They are authentic and have fixed price labels.
Beautiful gardens.. We went to this garden and were impressed by the beautiful landscape. It is a quiet place in a large city. We took many photos of some beautiful trees, flowers, plants and rocks.

Visit Chi Lin Nunnery across the street first, then linger in Nan Lian Garden. After getting out of the Diamond Hill MTR station on the Green Line, you should visit the Chi Lin Nunnery first then spend more time in Nan Lian Garden.The landscaping shows great attention to detail, variety and harmony.This is one of the best gardens I have visited. It has benches and tables so you can take your time soaking in the beauty.
Nice peaceful place. A beautiful garden, clean and quiet. It's a nice stroll with the family. There is a good quality tea house and a vegetarian restaurant. Food is good.

Beautiful!!. Worth seeing beautiful garden and walking paths amidst the huzzle buzzle of HK.There is no entrance fee.There is a vegetarian restaurant and snack bar which are not that highly priced.worth a visit

Peaceful Break in a Classic Chinese Garden. We had combined the visit to the Nan Lian Garden with a visit to the nearby Chi Lin Nunnery. It’s free entry to the Garden. Do pick up the helpful free pamphlet for the Garden which has a map and description of the Garden. There is a gift shop, tea house, and an eatery inside the Garden.Some of the highlights include a rockery, a waterfall and five large wooden structures. The Garden is definitely worth a visit to experience a classic Chinese garden.

Beautiful. Free.. Absolutely wonderful Asian garden in Hong Kong. Easy walking paths through beautifully designed trees, waterfalls and rockscapes. Multiple special areas. There was as Murano glass exhibition when we visited - stunning artwork. There is special area for architecture (learn about how temples are put together), rock art design and a top-notch gift shop. Take MTR to get there - a 2 minute walk with easy signs to follow. The garden is free!
Beautiful garden. Definitely worth going to see the gardens together with Chi Lin Nunnery. Close to Diamond Hill MTR and no entrance fees. Really nice

A pocket of tranquility in a bustling city.. Located next to the Chi Lin nunnery the gardens are beautiful and surprisingly tranquil even though they are surrounded by busy roads. The gardens are easy to walk round with trees, ponds, waterfall & bonsai. There is a vegetarian restaurant which we didn't go in, and a snack bar which served well priced toasted sandwiches, coffee and soft drinks. The souvenir shop had some nice stuff. Just a few minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR station, no charge for entry, definitely worth a visit. Chi Lin nunnery located adjacent to the gardens is also worth a visit at the same time

Beautiful garden. I loved it here! As well as being right next to the stunning Chi Lin Nunnery, the garden is peaceful and beautiful; a true green gem inside the busy city life of Hong Kong. I especially loved the large lake filled with hundreds of fat, rainbow-coloured koi carp. Such a pretty place, a great spot for old and young alike; free of charge too!

My favorite place um Hong Kong. This is my second time in town and I've visited absinthe garden, so clean, so well maintained and so beautiful behind the Garden there are some incredible Buddhist temples they will surprise you again even if you already thought you had seen enough from the Garden.

Beautiful garden. You will find peace and relaxing stroll at this not so small but beautiful garden. You will see ponds, small houses by the ponds, various natural stones and plantations. Not a touristy place - as locals also use this garden to chill themselves. And this garden is very close to Chi Lin Nunnery - another must visit destination. So you must go to this garden and experience the tranquility moment in Chi Lin Nunnery as well.

Pretty garden. Quite a large garden which is well planted, with bonsai, a pagoda and lakes. It doesn't take as long to walk around as the initial information suggests so don't be put off. It's also very close to an overhead road but seems very peaceful inside. There's a gift shop, toilets, a cafe and a restaurant as well as some picnic tables which were popular with local workers at lunch time. The restaurant was vegetarian and very popular so we had a snack in the cafe.Close to the nunnery, so easy to do on the same trip.

An Oasis in the Concrete Jungle. A place to relax, escape, meditate, or to recharge oneself within the ever-active Hong Kong surrounding. The location of Nan Lian Garden is slightly off from the tourist district. However with proper mass transit, the place is easily assessable from all major hotels' location. The Garden is very well maintain throughout the whole complex. Beside its beauty, there are various educational value built-in the different museums and displays within the garden. This venue is worth the UNESCO World Heritage consideration.

Had one of our best dishes here!. The gardens are just one photo op after another. So meticulously maintained and magically designed. We had lunch at the Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant and the truffle mushroom noodles were extraordinary. Careful with the other dishes, we weren't impressed with anything else we ordered from the soup to dessert. The waterfall flowing over the picture windows look better from the outside than sitting in the restaurant, but still fun.
Lovely garden!. Quite a way out of central but worth a visit for garden lovers. It is free too! We took about an hour here to see it all. Not a top attraction but pleasant if you have time to fill

Peaceful and relaxing park in the middle of the city. This nice little park located near the Diamond Hill subway station is very relaxing and provide some cool background for photo-taking lovers. There's also a delicious vegetarian restaurant in the middle of the park.
Beautiful Garden. It's a hidden gem in the concrete jungle. This beautiful and tranquil garden is so contrast with the surrounding

“Quiet, scenic and memorable”. Along with Chi Lin Nunnery, this is perhaps one of the best places I visited in my recent trips. It's close to nature and entire scene is beautiful! One can get around the monastery in about half an hour and will still choose to stay because of the scene and its quietness. It's also a good experience to learn about Buddhism.The place is very accessible and is only a few minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR station near Hollywood Plaza.This is the perfect getaway if you're looking for a place to escape from the city's bright lights and busy streets.
Quite park in a city.. Get off at Diamond Hill MTR station and take a 10 minute walk. Close by is a big shopping centre. Great place for relaxation and enjoyment of the nature.

Very well kept. The gardens are located just outside the Chi Lin Nunnery so that is worth a visit after here. The gardens itself are very well kept. It wasn't very busy when i visited during the week. Obviously, it is best to visit when it is not raining as it is all open air. There is a nice little tearoom/cafe where you can have a quiet sit down and just admire the views.

Silence place inside the city. Just 5 minutes walk from the MTR station, you are surrounded by a beautiful garden. It is linked with the Chi Lin Nunnery and free! Stay here for a bit longer and feel the Dhyana culture.

beautifully maintained garden. The atmosphere was very peaceful and calm. we went early morning during a week day, so not too many other tourists besides us. My kids loved watching the koi swim around. The rock exhibit was beautiful.

Beautiful Gardens. We visited here on a whim really because we had done everything we wanted to in Hong Kong already and had some spare time, and we didn't regret it. The grounds are truly beautiful, and its located in a quieter part of Hong Kong that seems much more lived in with locals. I would go here if this is your sort of thing and you have time to do so, it really is a very pretty place and great for pictures!

Lovely to walk around but nothing breathtaking!. Don't expect me to be in absolute awe when visiting as if you have spent time in China, Japan etc it is quite similar to other sites I would say nevertheless it is welcoming considering how busy HK can be. There is also cafes and a vegetarian restaurant within the grounds too that do a set lunchtime meal for 120 dollars per person

Wonderful Haven. Wow-- such care in designing and maintaining this lovely garden. Not even the cold, gray weather could distract one from the serenity of the place. The added bonus was the temporary Murano exhibit at the multi-purpose hall. Luckily for me, there weren't many tourists at the time I went, although I missed the dining hours at the vegetarian restaurant inside.

Quiet and peaceful. A nice contrast to the rest of HK. Well worth the visit to this Garden and the attached nunnery. Hardly any visitors and so quiet inside the walls of the garden you wouldn't know there were motorways right outside.

Beautiful gardens close to MTR station. We visited at the weekend so it was busy with locals enjoying these wonderful gardens. This time we also could cross over the bridge to go into the temple, amazing experience. Only a small area so you could rush round and see everything very quickly. But it is great to slow down and enjoy the peace and marvel at these emaculate gardens, the rockery is not what you would expect it to be!
Must see. This is not readily advertised on the do list, but the gardens are beautifully maintained and just a peaceful and majestic place so close to the city.

The Highlight of our Hong Kong Trip. This really is a hidden gem, not a lot of people seem to know about it including many of the locals but it is not to be missed. I loved the contrast between the old traditional gardens with the back drop of skyscrapers. A must see.

Natural park in the big city!. Nan Lian Garden is really amazing park, this park look like vintage china style that make me surprised! There was really beautiful with the big trees, stones and vintage cottage. I can deep breath, slow down and get fresh. Especially there is no entrance free!
A must. What an amazing garden. Full of Bonsai and wonderful walkways. Attached to a monastery which is also wonderful

Whaaaaaaaatttttttttttttttttt!!!!!!!!!!!. Free, fabulous, then you get to the temple areas and it becomes even better. And then you have to check yourself - you are in a tiny park on what is in effect a traffic island.

Beautiful place - but not much to do there.. Its a really nice garden, well done and very preserved, with some temples and expositions. You can go there ant take a few pictures. No selfie stick is allowed, and you also can not sit on the stairs and floors lol no restaurantes or snacks shops, but still a good place to visit.

Nice afternoon at Nan Lian. We caught a taxi to these gardens and we found them so beautiful. Its amazing to have such a peaceful, quite place in amongst the skyscrapers. The birds were singing and the place was immaculate, with lovely trees and all sorts of bonsais. There is a café and some restaurants as well and lovely souvenirs to purchase. Free to get in as well.

Beautiful Place. Nestled in-between the hustle and bustle of HK lies the most beautiful gardens. Definitely recommend visiting if in Hong Kong. We also went to the vegetarian cafe here which was great as well.
Tranquil!. Get away from the hustle and bustle of the city life in the middle of the city. The gardens were simply gorgeous, and the coy fish were so majestic and big!

Immaculate and spectacular traditional garden. Connected to the nunnery which is also a top visit. If you visit in the morning, consider going straight to the vegetarian restaurant in the park and reserving a table for a lunch later, as it gets very busy, and is in a spectacular location.

Extremely beautiful. Extremely beautiful and restful park in the center of Hong Kong. Beautiful plant and stone compositions! We sat and enjoyed the beauty and tranquility that is very bizarre in the center of Hong Kong.
Peaceful. Go here to escape the frenzy of Hong Kong. If you like gardens this place is excellent and you go straight through to the nunnery which gives you a taste of China.

Amazing Garden. I skipped the free city tour I got from my travel agent to visit this place and I was not disappointed. The place is really amazing! Full of beautiful bonsai, flowers, trees, and lake! This is a must place to visit in HK. This is a great escape from the busy streets of HK.The garden is accessible via MTR. Just alight at Diamond Hill station. Check the map for the nearest exit. I forgot the exact exit but it is in front of a mall. You will not get lost because of the street signs and it is just 5 minute walk from the MTR. Nan Lian garden is connected to Chi Lin nunnery which is another wonderful place to visit. Please note, selfie sticks are not allowed here.

Beautiful Gardens to wander around and enjoy nature and history. Nan Lian Garden is quite easy to get to, especially by taxi and well worth it. They are beautifully kept and stunning. It's so nice to just wander around and appreciate nature against the high rise backdrop of Hong Kong. The Nunnery is just across the road so makes it even more worthwhile.

Amazing. I read about this garden on this site otherwise would probably have missed it. It is beautiful and I just wish I had more time. It is one of those gardens where one wants to linger. It is just over the road from a train station.

Surprise gem hidden in busy city. Easy access as described by previous review. A little walk takes you to the Chi Lin Nunnery, also worth a visit. Locals who live around here are really lucky to have such wonderful quiet place to visit year round.Exhibit includes very old house "support brackets". There are signs displayed around the exhibits. However, it would have been nice to have a tour guide to explain.I heard that the vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall serves good food. However you pay for it though. I was not willing to pay Hong Kong $198 per person. In Hong Kong you can get food as inexpensive or as expensive as you want. Expensive does not mean the food is always good. Inexpensive does not mean the food is not tasty.

Oasis in the busy city. Beautiful gardens full of bonsai and other trees, a lovely golden pagoda and koi lake, a peaceful place of contemplation and super photo opportunities next to Chi Lin Nunnery, don't miss that either. Also a vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall.

Nice change of pace. RECOMMENDED: As a long time Hong Kong resident, I seem to have missed this attraction until recently and while not a "must see" it's clearly a nice surprise. Easily reached from the Diamond Hill MTR station, walk underneath the overpass highway and cross the street. At first glance, it doesn't seem all that inviting. Busy highway, what can be down this walk. The surprise is a nice view, some interesting exhibits and beautiful scenery. At the end is also a nice restaurant that's not overly touristy. All well maintained and clean. You can easily MTR or bus to to this location.So happy to have discovered and clearly a place to take any HK visitor for a bit of new appeal and right in the city as well.
wonderful garden and buddhist place. nice place to walk around, see some green and a very well maintained garden. great design. in the middle of the city, but still a relax place

Love this garden. Go in early morning or a weekday. It's amazingly quiet and full of birds singing. The landscape is very well looked after, the wooden architectural display hall is worth checking out. The Rockery and its bonsai displays are enjoyable and it is a place to cool down by sitting on the large cool rocks placed in the centre of the room. Visit the little gift shop for reasonably priced and high quality food and gift items. All profit made are used for the maintenance of the garden. My favourite place is the Gragon's Gate Mansion vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall. The food is well prepared and cooked with no msg and reduced oil and salt. The complimentary Pu Er tea served in the restaurant is 15 years old and of good quality. Lunch starts at 12 and afternoon tea starts at 3:30 pm. There is set menu for both to choose from. The Tea Pavilion is a place to try some of the most exquisite teas. Walk around the pond in the middle of the garden. One one side is the carp pond. Some carps weight 30-40kg easily. In all, the place is a quiet escape from the hussel and bustle of Hong Kong.

Hong Kong Oasis. The garden is across the street from the Chi Lin Nunnery, and are worth taking some time to explore. Personally I would never go to a garden as an attraction in itself, but the Nan Lian Garden was an excellent addition to my trip to the nunnery. Other gardens/parks in Hong Kong would be easier to get to for a picnic lunch, but Nan Lian would make a good choice if you want to get away from the larger crowds or excessive crowding of some of the more central areas.

Fabulous. Spent a sunny afternoon here - well worth the trip. Beautiful and artistic layout and, as others have noted, a peaceful break from the HK bustle. That said, it was busy!Engineers, woodworkers and architects will find the traditional chinese timber construction models fascinating and inspiring.
Peaceful Gardens. Opposite Chi Lin Nunnery; definitely worth visiting both. Typical oriental gardens. Photo opportunities.

Sanctuary. A piece of calm and solitude in the middle of bustling Hong Kong.Quite incredible the gardens and magnificent ancient bonsai trees and water features...a must see free attraction when in hongkong.

So peaceful and beautiful. It's amazing there exists a place so restful and basil amongst so much noise! The gardens are immaculate and stunning to behold... Come here for a break... Come here regardless!

Peaceful and beautiful. Lovely garden beside the nunnery.
Very peaceful place. You can take a rest there and relax!
You may not allowed to eat inside the garden, and inside the garden also had some museum which you need to pay. And there's another free museum also
Peaceful Oasis. Lovely garden beside the nunnery. Peaceful and beautiful. A nice museum as well. Unexpected delight amongst the skyscrapers.
Very beautiful and calm. To be done, it's relaxing and beautiful! Veey Chinese, you'll get some presents at the end of our walk there.

Lovely garden in the midst of a bustling city. It's a very peaceful place. The temples and pagodas were beautiful and the people working there are very sweet and accommodating. They have a souvenir shop with beautiful Buddhism-related items. It's a nice place to relax. There aren't many people as well. Most I've seen are locals just enjoying some fresh air.
What a view. Such a beautiful place to take some rest even its surrounded by many buildings. This place is next to Chi Lin Nunnery. Recommended for low budget traveler cause its free entrance

Beautiful garden; only worth if in the area. I wouldn't go out my way just to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery and accompanying Nan Lian Gardens. Despite the large bonsai collection (Hong Kong's largest, if i'm not mistaken), and that it's a tranquil & pretty park, I wouldn't head all the way to the region just to see it. The nunnery is not really open to the public, though the park does have a few pavilions with exhibits explaining its construction (built to Tang Dynasty specifications, without the use of nails). If visiting nearby Wong Tai Sin Temple too (less tranquil, very busy, but authentic in the sense it is used by locals for worship), then it could be nice to swing by the Nan Lian Gardens too. Keep in mind that this garden is managed by the temple, so relatively strict rules apply to protect the religious sanctity of the area. Beverages (particularly coffee & alcohol) are not allowed, and there are glaring eyes at your every move there! Mornings can be a nice time to visit as you'll catch locals practicing Tai Chi.

Beautiful garden in the middle of the city. It is great place to visit - to relax and to see great garden with small architecture. Even if the weather is not great it is still woth to go there. There is also very nice shop with souvenirs - f. ex. small paintings

Nan Lian trip by students. . We American students had the chance to venture through this stunning garden, taking in the sights and smells and most importantly, the stunning feeling of realism as the visceral experience grasped the very essence of our being.

Peaceful and quiet. I had no plans to visit the Garden, but stumbled upon it after visiting Chi Lin Nunnery. They are both close to Diamond Hill MTR, but of those two I preferred Nan Lian Garden. Chi Lin Nunnery is closing relatively early (around 5), while the Nan Lian Garden is still open. It also seemed larger, there are beautiful pavillons, pagodas, gorgeous plants and flowers, some sort of a mini-waterfall and a windmill wheel. I thought it was absolutely lovely. The entrance is free.

Awesome even for the kids. Spend an hour or so wondering around the gardens. Lot's to see even if it is not 'Old'. It is attached to the "nunnery" which by the way has nothing to do with what westerners call nunsFYI - The tea house is very cool but VERY expensive.My children loved to see all the different trees and stones that are all arranged in very Feng Shui inspired ways

Pretty area with history and vegetarian food. The Nan Lian Garden neighbour's the Chi Lin Nunnery, both of which are an integral part of HK history providing a cultural insight into the history of a nun and allowing you to try authentic Chinese style vegetarian food.

A beautiful oasis in the heart of Kowloon. The Nan Lian Garden offers an oasis of greenery and calm in the hustle bustle of Kowloon. The rich density of plants and rocks are amazing. High marks to the gardeners and cleaners who keep the vegetation lush and the grounds clean. The vegetarian restaurant is fine too - the food is tasty and comes in many varieties. The gift shop is worth a visit, stocking a rich collection of porcelain, scarves, bags, organic snacks and souvenirs. My favourite is their chocolates which come in many interesting flavours and are better value than the pralines in fancy chocolatiers around town. One must not leave without visiting the Nunnery at the back of the garden. The temple reincarnates Tang Dynasty architecture, which is truly impressive. Situated right next to the MTR Diamond Hill station and a big shopping plaza, the place is easy to get to. All in all a gem of a place although not well publicised.

Garden in the city. A classy quint garden in the middle of the city.It has variety of bonsai plants. Who would have thought this haven exists right in the center of the hustles and bustles of the city. Definitely a good spot for taking rest after a busy afternoon.

A pice of quiet in a bustling city. A peaceful place in a bustling city. And it's free. The walk though the garden let's you see the high rise skylines but experience a quiet walk through a beautiful garden. Then take a walk through the Nunnery. A nice way to spend an hour and a half.

A bit out of the way for tourist. I've been here many times and I would suggest only coming here in winter. If you happen to come in summer then you'll meet one of the most humid place in Hong Kong. A few of my friends have been here and they didn't know there is a temple here, so please don't forget to go there. There isn't a lot of history to the temple since this park is quite new, but nevertheless it's still beautiful. The park has a building that showcase Chinese architecture and adjacent to this place is an rest area with marble and other mineral rocks that you can sit on. It's a relaxing park but quite out of the way for tourists and there isn't much to do in Diamond Hill. In this park you'll find more locals hanging out.

A very quite & relax garden in the middle of a hussel & bussel city area. Beautiful & technical architecture inside Chi Lin Garden. Close to MTR station. Quite & relaxing place in the middle of a busy area. A wonderful place for a leisure walk. Don't expect too much on food inside the garden. They do have a vegetarian restaurant inside the garden. Better check their serving schedule before you visit, especially during the weekdays.

Tranquility in the heart of bustling Hong Kong.. These monastery grounds, laid out to strict Feng Shuei principles, offer a lovely contrast to the all-enveloping vitality that is Hong Kong. Ponds, waterfalls and hillocks offer charming vistas. The temple itself houses stunning statues. Unmissable!

Beautiful garden. If you have extra time in Hong Kong, a visit to Nan Lian Garden would be a good time to spend, approximately an hour and half would suffice. The garden is beautiful decorated with trees. It has a Buddhist theme. It's a great place to relax and enjoy Chinese tea. There is also a vegetarian restaurant. The food, however, is fusion. To get here, get off at Diamond Hill MTR Station Exit C3, about 5 minutes walk.

When we returned to HK. for 1 more night, we decided to explore this wonderful gardens.The subway station is just 2 minutes walk to the gardens , which are free. Beautiful and serene. One pavilion had an exhibit of Moreno glass - exquisite. What a bonus.

Pretty landscaped garden next to Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautiful Chinese style garden to walk around with interesting wooden architecture exhibition. Can visit the Chi Lin Nunnery garden next to the Garden. There is a good Chinese vegetarian restaurant inside the park. Quite popular so get there early to get a table. A little expensive with minimum charge per head.

Beautiful Oasis on the middle of the city. If you want to retreat from the masses and the main tourist Spots, this is the perfect place. You can still see interesting things and capture some photos but you can also just relax. There are some nice souvenir shops around which have really interesting and affordable things.

I go back again and again!. Simply stunning any time of the year! although it isn't the most convenient place to get to it is well worth the trip- lovely gardens and traditional buildings in the midst of the urban HK

So serene. Once you get off the MTR @ Diamond Hill, just look for signs to the right exit to Nan Lian garden. A short walk away, cross the road & you enter this beautiful garden. There's even a vegetarian restaurant & small cafe. A great place to unwind.

An Amazingly Beautiful Haven in the Hectic City. This is a must see place for anyone interested in Chinese culture, history, art, or gardening. The artfully cultivated trees are a wonder to behold. Everywhere you turn there is a beautiful picture to take. A classic Chinese garden in "spades"!

Must visit. We stumbled onto these gardens on our way to Chi Lin Nunnery but glad we did! It is far from tourist areas which I loved! Not crowded (even during Chinese New Year NOT CROWDED), very serene and relaxing. So beautifully landscaped you can have a wonderful stroll with family, friends and your significant other.

Oasis in bustle of city. Beautiful and serene - a must see.We had a nice walk around and visited the monastery, closed at 4:15 when we were there so make sure to visit early if you want to go in.Excellent photo opportunities.
Beautiful Garden in a crowded City. One of the cleanest and beautiful Garden's in Hong Kong,not too far from Diamond Hill MTR station Nan Lian Garden is worth visiting if you have some time to spare.

A wonderful park with interesting architecture. I stumbled across this place on TripAdvisor whilst researching the nunnery. I'm glad I took a detour,as its very beautiful and actually is a nice build up to the nunnery. I went during CNY, so it was a bit busy. But I will definitely go back in summer to enjoy the water Lilly's in full bloom!

Spectacular. This is a must see. Very easy to get to on the MTR and only just across the road from Diamond Hill Station. The gardens offer an wonderful contrast to the hustle and bustle of HK and the high rise buildings in the background.

Very Pretty. This garden is fairly small but also very nice. I enjoyed my time here. I found the gift shop to have some of the best values in Hong Kong. Garden is very peaceful. Nunnery is directly across the street and should not be missed!!

An isle of tranquility. Situated in the New Territories, this magnificent garden and associated Buddhist nunnery and temple is worth the long MRT ride. Nestled between hi-rises, it's an amazing garden of bonsai trees with a pond and attached nunnery, temple and small museum. It is a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and a wonderful way to spend a sunny morning or afternoon relaxing.

Looks too plastic. Not really worth going: it looks too plastic and unreal in a bad way. So if you don't have any other purpose to go nearby Diamond Hill, better skip it. Although, we checked the mall just above the nearest metrostation (Diamond hill) and on the third floor was really good place to eat (called food -- something): it's like a canteen where you can pick up the food from which ever stall you want - they have western, local, chinese (sichuan, yunnan, shanghainese, you name it!) food - just choose your favorites and eat!

A hidden gem. An easy trip on the MTR to this amazing oasis amongst all the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Access to the adjacent nunnery is gained via an overhead walkway and this is a definite "do not miss".
Great!'. It's a great trip i've ever been. My dad&mom love this garden so much ! And easy to get there. Many templa style and huge tree that u never seen before

Beautiful. This is a stunning garden in the middle of the city. It is right next door to the Chi Lin Nunnery and both are really worth seeing. Seeing both will take you about an hour if you are like me or 2 if you really want to read every piece of information. Its a must do!
Best garden in Hong Kong. We were were really impressed by this garden. It is really so beautiful. As you walk around the curving paths, there is just one beautiful tree after another. Very peaceful.

Peaceful garden in middle of high rise. Catch the MTR to Diamond Hill and the garden is adjacent to the station. Could not believe how quite the gardens were with high rise properties all around. Monastery next door also worthwhile.

Beautiful gardens. This was a bit of unexpected find and we had a very pleasant stroll around.Word of warning though - no eating is allowed within the gardens. We had picked up some lunch at the shopping centre and had to eat it at the side of the road, so get something before you get there or eat at the cafe onsite.
Highlight of HK trip. A must see. Excellence in all aspects: beauty, tranquility, architecture, horticulture. This was the unexpected highlight of my trip to HK.

Garden in the City. This place is amazing. I didn't imagine I could see a garden this big in Hong Kong. You could see traditional Chinese plants and structures. There's no entrance fee and there are restaurants inside. It's very easy to go to since it is accross an MTR station and plaza hollywood mall. The view during evening is even more beautiful.
Hidden Gem in the City. Peaceful and serene garden in the heart of busy city. A classical Chinese garden, with beautiful natural elements. Found near Diamond Hill MTR, northern Kowloon.
Tranquil of Serenity among concrete jungle . Very peaceful place, easy to find just exit c from diamond hill mtr station.. Can spend a good couple of hours..
Beautiful. Just a beautiful quiet garden tucked away in amongst the tall buildings.Feels very serene and the car taken with the gardens and buildings is very evident.

The ultimate garden. Every time we go to Hong Kong we go to these gardens twice (day and night, closes 9.00 pm) we have never seen more beautiful gardens and features of it's type anywhere in the world and it's free.

Nice park in the middle of dense residential area. I came to this park after quite a long walk from nearby temple and was surprised by how serene this place was. The garden itself is very well taken care of, the trees are meticulously trimmed - actually, by small scissors, no less... There are stones exhibition, Venetian glass exhibition (well worth 20hkd admission fee) and a lot of nice spots to sit down and relax. All this tranquility is surrounded by densely populated residential areas. My only grievance in this case is that park guards do not allow to take pictures using tripod, which prevented me from being able to take a descent selfie...

Quaint Garden in the heart of Kowloon. Enjoyed walking around the gardens and seeing the unique vegetation. Truly a beautiful place in the midst of the city! We did not realize at the time that the nunnery was right inside the gardens, which was a pleasant surprise since we planned to go there as well. It was a rainy, windy day so I am sure it is even more beautiful when the weather is more pleasant. Definitely worth checking out while visiting HK!
Amazing. This place is one of the best garden i've ever visited. Perfect place to visit during your stay in Hong Kong. Too bad the rain was pouring hard when we came.
Beautiful . Beautiful garden and we visited it in the winter, I can only imagine how pretty it is in the summer! Worth the visit

Amazing - You must not miss this!. A wonderful, peaceful oasis in the middle of a busy area.
The design and colours have been so well planned it has a calm and relaxed feeling all around. This was recommended by friends and I can't thank them enough. We absolutely loved this place.

Shang Gri La in midst of city!. Nan Lian gardens are a must-see within Hong Kong - they are a stunningly lovely time-out from the hustle & bustle that is so Hong Kong! Initially, I was a little resistant - a garden is a garden - right? WRONG! As I stood on the steps of the nunnery (within the gardens) & surveyed the immediate surroundings, I was in awe at this oasis of total peace - especially as I viewed/considered the enormous high-rises that encompassed the idyll that is Nan Lian Garden. A goods shop was the only obvious 21stC intrusion ... But I did buy some beautiful memorabilia. Just don't do a currency conversion? Mama G of Canberra

Tranquil escape from the city - loved it!. We found Nan Lian Garden upon our visit to the Chin Lin Nunnery (also recommended). It was a magical park with sculpted trees and bushes, colorful pagodas/bridge, and pretty fountains and fish ponds. It’s a nice place to escape the city. I even liked it better than Hong Kong Park.

Glad we did this. We came here on the last day of our trip and I'm glad we did. Finding a bit of tranquility in Hong Kong is tough but this place provides all you need. The gardens are beautiful and it is a great way to spend a couple of hours of your trip.

A Peaceful Haven in Bustling Hong Kong. We are so glad we decided to go to this bonsai garden based on Trip Advisor reviews. We took the MRT to Diamondhead stop, exited the building based on the red circles on the map that told us which exit to use, walked across the street and into a peaceful, beautiful scene. It's free too. The lovely woman in the information stand gave us a brochure written in English that we used as reference throughout our visit. The water lillies and fish swimming in the lake are calming and lovely. Go here - you won't be disappointed

Peaceful oasis - A must when in Hong Kong. We thought to pass by for 20 minutes when we where occasionally in the area. Our visit then transformed in a half-day visit. The garden is simply amazing and the attached monastery reminded me of the peaceful and modest Japanese temples. It's also worth to take lunch at the Vegetarian Restaurant at Nan-Lian Garden, although it can be difficult to get a table as this restaurant seems to be very popular with locals as well.
Serene place in HK. It is located across the Diamond Hill MTR station. The garden and the pond are such a relaxing place.
Feel the atmosphere. Really vast, an oasis of peace in traffic congested Kowloon. Beautiful garden with ponds, a colourful pagoda, restaurants, gorgeous vegetation

such a different side of HK!. The palce is very close to Diamond Hill MTR.We went on a weekend, spent around 2hrs here. It has got a very serene ambience. The place is full of natural beauty and one feels soo calm. There is a veg snack shop which serves vegeterian snacks.
A pretty night time stroll. A nice place to wander through on a calm evening. Nice sculptured garden with dramatic skyline peeks through the trees.
A great afternoon. Spent an afternoon there and thoroughly enjoyed my visit. Peaceful and well maintained park with lots to see
Beauty in the midst of chaos. Who would have thought this gem was here right in the middle of all the chaos. Well worth the short excursiom.

Nice, scenic, and peaceful. Amidst the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong lies the peaceful Nan Lian Gardens. To get there, travel to Diamond Hill MTR station, and signs will guide you to the garden, which is a short walk away.
