You slowly walk through the gardens taking in the sights and appreciating the beauty of the gardens.The garden is connected with Chi Lin Nunnery, and you can walk there from the gardens. Inside the nunnery, you can hear the hum of Bhuddist chants. There is also a rockery (where there are pieces of beautiful rocks) to see, and a big pond with many koi fishes.Take time out and recharge your soul with a walk through the gardens.
The nunnert. The gardens are beautiful. This is the largest lotus flower garden I have every seen. There's lots of large Koi fish in the pond.

Very Refreshing!. A sight to behold. Very calm and serene. Full of greenery. You will enjoy walking around the garden. It helps relieve stress through the sight and smell of the trees and flowers. There are ornamental rocks, water features like waterfalls, and timber structures. It is very clean and well-maintained. They also have a shop where you could buy stuff like organic tea, coffee, cereals, and lots of nice souvenirs. I enjoyed taking pictures of almost everything beautiful you see inside. This is worth visiting.
A great place to visit. The garden is very beautiful and extremely well mantained. Definetely a must see while in Hong Kong. There's also a temple, a gift shop and a restaurant inside the garden.
Nice!. Peaceful, beautiful and well taken care off. The fact that the garden is directly besides the subway doesn't make it less good.

Off the beaten track. Out of the main tourist area this beautiful gardens are easily accessed by mtr, Diamond Hill station. From there you enter them just across the big mall.Being Nr 7 on TA I find it little bit overrated. This was my third time in HK and first time in the garden. That imposes there are far many better and more interesting things to do.The gardens are really beautiful, with lush greenery, small lakes, bonsai trees and awesome golden pavilion on the lake with red bridge leading to it.Easily covered within an hour the gardens are open until 9 PM. Very beautiful at night also when they're all lit up.

Peaceful sanctuary in bustle of HKG. These gardens are a wonderful sanctuary to go and visit the gardens to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Most tourists do not get out of the Kowloon or Hong Kong Island. This garden is an amazing array of trees, plants and shows the natural way of life through their gardens.

Cozy Garden. If you wanna escape crowds in Hong Kong that's the place to go. It's not very big garden but feels nice to be there, especially during sunny days. Green tries look very good with skyscrapers in a background. It's something you don't see every day.

Cute Garden in the middle of the city. Wanted to kill time before our flight so we decided to stop by this garden. The temple was pretty with many different Buddha statues. It was peaceful, which was weird when you see skyscrapers surround the garden. Not a must see, but if you have extra time and like to visit gardens, then come here.

Surprisingly beautiful and tranquility within a busy city. The pine trees, rocks, ponds, pavilions and architecture are beautiful, well maintained and bring you back to ancient China in Tang Dynasty 2,000 years ago. The restaurant serving vegetarian food is of very high standard. The tea house is quite with very relax atmosphere but a bit expensive. The coffee shop serves good coffee as well. The Garden can be easily accessed by MTR (underground train), the Diamond Hill Station.

A Nice escape marred by overzealous security. This is a great locatyion to combine with Chi Lin Nunnery over the road. The two are interconnected and well worth a trip. But from the relative peace and informality of the nunnery, entering the garden and doing something such as touching or accidentally straying of track can lead to a stern rebuke by the rather overzealous jobsworthy security guards. I was even told off for putting my toddler onto my shoulders. I understand why they need to keep control of visitors but I found this overstepping their remit. There were certainly no signs saying I couldn't carry him on my shoulders. But all-in-all a nice visit with some beautiful foliage and stonework to look at.

An oasis in the middle of bustling Diamond Hill area!. Must visit! Not usually recommended in most websites and books, which from a selfish point of view is good, as otherwise it will also become crowded!I have taken friends and family and always found being there a very refreshing and exhilarating experience. Well connected by public transport and also has a very good vegetarian Chinese restaurant in the adjoining nunnery (also a must do)

Most beautiful park I have ever seen. The park is trapped in the middle of the highway exchange and with a nearbay subway stop it is really easily accesible. Everything in the park is meticulously maintained. The bridge over the lake was closed but the "water" mill was operating. There is a restaurant behind a water fall and another cafe where you can get a good capuccino. They also have an exhibition room which at the time had a good collection of Venetian Murano glass vases and for which you have to pay entrance fee.

You have the time to see 1 thing in HK - definitely go there!. It does not matter if you are planning a long stay in HK, or you are simply passing through and have half a day there - the Nan Lian garden is an absolute must-see, the most beautiful place in the whole HK. It is a stunningly wonderful chinese garden located in between skyscrapers - the contrast between the green scenery and the surrounding buildings is unique. The garden contains also several petrified trees, a mini-museum of architecture, bonsai trees and stone. And it joined by Cho Lin Nunnery (look it up), which is a beautiful temple with a collection of bonsai trees and lotus pond. And its all completely free.Believe me - it will be worth your while to visit it.

Beautiful hidden gem. I read about the garden here on Trip Advisor. We were in Hong Kong to embark on a cruise, and it was very easy to get here from the Kai Tak Terminal. We just took the free shuttle to Diamond Hill and walked across the street to the garden. It was very peaceful and not crowded. It's definitely a nice place to get away from the crowds and see some beautiful landscapes.

Beautiful park. This is a great place to spend 1-2 hours admiring the landscaping and architecture. The place is well kept and beautiful. It's a quick walk from the Diamond Hill station (which is also connected to Plaza Hollywood mall, a good place to visit as well) with directions leading to the Garden.There are tea houses and cafes inside. No convenience store so bring your own bottle of water. Best to visit during the colder months.

So beautiful, so peaceful. Wow. Absolutely awesome garden, very relaxing, just great. Big enough to pass a few hours or to just walk through and see everything in about an hour. Try the chocolates at the souvenir shop.

Absolutely fantastic escape from crowded city. It's a must in HK as it offers something totally different than the rest of the city. Quiet and peaceful. Beautiful place for a walk.
Also try a vegetarian restaurant situated in a garden.

A little serenity. A lovely quiet spot on the Kowloon side of Hong Kong. The nunnery is so well maintained and it is very peaceful. You can't take photos once inside the walls. Entry is free. There were quite a few people praying which always adds a nice atmosphere.

Contrast between nature and the city beyond . Another little gem which is free and worth a quick visit. It's immaculately presented and my favourite part was enjoying the contrast between the beautiful trees and gardens and the high rise apartments in background. Great for those seeking peace in the busy city.

Stunning. We visited today (2 adults, 2 kids and a baby) the gardens are immaculately maintained and we thoroughly enjoyed wandering around. Very close to major shopping mall and MTR station Diamond Hill.

beautiful rocks and garden. The place is located within one of the busy Kowloon districtIt can be reached by taking the MTR to Diamond Hill exitIt is within walking distance, you just have to cross the road from the huge shopping centre when you come up from the subwayWe also went into the exhibit by Murano Glass collection which was an attraction by itselfWe met with a volunteer who also explains to us about the rocks,which were all brought from Chinathis is also linked to the monastery next door,there are a few steps to climbOne has to be there to appreciate the lay out, the orange bridge which links to the only colored structure which represent the heart...reflection of Buddhism with a clear mind and spirit

An oasis of serenity. I had not heard about Nan Lian until I read all of the glowing reports on Trip Advisor,so made time for a visit and was very pleased that I made the effort. Although the gardens are a little way out of the centre of Kowlook, they are easy and cheap to reach via the MTR green line to Diamond Hill. They are well signed from the station and only a short walk.Although totally free, we were given an explanatory leaflet, with a map, when we arrived and followed the signed all the way round. The gardens were first opened to the public in 2006 and contain lots of well manicured trees interspersed with large rocks, in the style of the Tang Dynasty. There are five large wooden pavilions and pagodas and also an indoor rockery with ancient polished rocks. The cafe sells food at a very reasonable price and there is also a vegetarian restaurant (which we did not sample). Altogether a very well set out garden which gives a sense of tranquility and serenity in an otherwise hectic city.After touring the gardens, we went to the nearby Chi Lin Nunnery and the Walled City park - see separate reports.

Simply Breathtaking! Extremely Peaceful in midst of busy City!. We went there with very lousy mood, however upon reaching the Temple, we were awestruck! Its so quiet and calm and the positivity and freshness in the air around brings millions of smile on face. Its divine experience. The Garden though man-made, but is very very beautifully designed with lot of photo taking opportunities. If one wants to feel absolutely fresh, forget everything behind, this is the place to be at!!!

Wonderful experience!. Our son took us to Nan Lian Garden and the Chi Lin Nunnery on our second day in Hong Kong and we were extremely impressed. Being hobby photographers, we were spoilt for choice with photo opportunities. The gardens are kept immaculately, the buildings most impressive as were the exhibitions in each of them and the gift shop very low key with absolutely no pressure to buy - but I did! The Nunnery was serene and, although no photography is allowed in the shrines, the koi ponds and interior garden area were still memorable. A must see!

tranquillity in the city. Easy to find from Diamond Hill MTR and I'm very glad I spent a few hours in the calming and beautiful Nan Lian Garden and attached nunnery. It was surprisingly quiet considering the roads running outside it.
A definite MUST!. Tranquility and absolutely beautiful a must go and see. Beautiful bonsai, peaceful music and relaxing.

A beautiful Chinese Garden oasis . I knew from TAs reviews it would be good, it was superb, what a wonderful experience. It may be relatively new along with the Chi Lin nunnery but it is wonderful. What makes it more so is it is split over a major dual carriageway and you just don't know. If the restaurant is coded beneath the Waterfall there is a wonderful Cafe next to it. I won't try to explain all of the sites of this garden save to say it exemplified exactly what I thought a Chinese formal garden would be. The Rockery literally the rockery ;) is wonderful. TIP until June make sure not to miss the wonderful exhibition of Venetian glass. 20HKD in gallery behind the Lunar Pool.

Beautiful, peaceful oasis in Hong Kong...not to be missed!. An itinerary in Hong Kong has to include this place. I visited several attractions there, and the buddhist complex formed by the Nan Lian Gardens and the Chi Lin Nunnery is definitely among the Top 3 Sights I've been to. Note that the Chi Lin Nunnery closed at 16:30!

A great peaceful retreat in the city. This is a great little retreat, although not in the heart of the city, is still surrounded by built up areas. It's free to enter, but make the most of it and spend a good hour or so walking around the gardens. If you fancy a break from the hustle and bustle of the city, this is your place.

Must visit!. A garden so well maintained!. Offers some great spots to take pictures and have a good walk. There is a vegetarian restaurant inside amidst the waterfall but it has a minimum 400 $ or so charge per person. There is also a small tea place, where we stopped by and had refreshing tea and sandwiches.

A quiet haven. This is a wonderful place to go to. Peaceful and beautiful and FREE. Great for food..vegetarian..great fro quality souvenirs. Just a beautiful spot , easy to get to from Diamond Hill MTR. Right beside the Nunnery so you can walk across and enjoy that too.

Worth the visit. If you want a quiet time away from the hustle of the city, then this garden is the perfect place to see. It provides a beautiful walk around, beautiful view of modern with traditional and nature view. it is also easy to get to through MTR. A lot of people do not know what they are missing out. Highly recommended for all ages.
Peaceful and serene. Very scenic and very tranquil. The scenic garden is beautiful with the hills and rocks and water features and the ornamental trees.

Special. This is a beautiful, quiet and peaceful place. We enjoyed watching the fish being fed - they are huge and very hungry! There was also a display of model Chinese buildings that was superb - interesting and educational. The gardens themselves were totally stunning - rocks, trees, plants and flowers.

Stunning Gardens. As this is not in the middle of the tourist areas many people dont know what they are missing out on. This and the Chi Lin Nunnery make the extra few stops on the MTR well worth it. When its raining the gardens are still stunning.
Worth half a day. Away from the hustle and bustle of the city- this garden is a perfect place just for a stroll & relax. Beautiful especially the koi pond.
Small but beautiful. If you have an hour or two to spend, why not spend it here? The park provides a beautiful walk, nice small views, and quiet in a busy city. Easy to get to from the MTR.
Absolutely stunning temple complex. Definitely worth the journey out to Diamond Hill. Can relax in the park and grab some shopping from the Commercial Centre on the way back to the Metro.
Lovely place. Well worth the vist...peaceful serene place...the nunnery is very nice....busy but not frantic...beautifully manicured garden and a credit to all

A Delight. A tranquil bit of paradise away from the noise of HK. This garden exhibits some of the best attention to detail I have seen - from the rocks and stones to the benches and tree cuttings. Even the pathways are beautifully displayed with granite edgings. We stayed here for 2 hrs observing three horticulturists just trimming a tree with scissors, admiring the lakes and taking in the peacefulness.
In the top 10 in HK. This is the most beautiful garden in HKThere is a pagoda, a lake, a house of the tea, a stone garden, bonsaiIt's a peaceful place

A little piece of heaven on earth. Lovely Chinese/Japanese garden. Free entry. Easy walk from Diamond Hill station. Amazingly tranquil considering location near to road network. Beautiful features and sounds of bird song. Souvenir shop has some really high quality porcelain etc. Nice toasted sandwiches in cafe. Don't miss this wonderful place.

Such an amazing garden. The gardens are beautiful. Also, try and visit the halls they have in there. I took special interest in one where they have small replicas of famous monuments and they explain the architechture. Also, I found it amazing that you can be surrounded by a booming city and still feel such peace and quite. They have soundproof barriers as I understand and it makes for such a quiet place in the midst of a city like Hong Kong. It hosts a great souvenir shop as well.

Beautiful and relaxing. This is a very calm and beautiful garden. I would suggest visiting Nan Lian Garden before visiting the Chi Lin Nunnery in order to really appreciate and understand the architecture. There is a building that houses replicas of famous buildings in China and shows how the buildings were built. Great for architecture buffs and people interested in wood craftsmanship.
Beautiful garden. . You don't need to pay to visit Nan Lian Garden. Easy to find the place. Really beautiful. Nice place to spend a couple of hours.
A port in a consumerism storm. This was a great way to spend a few hours out of the hustle and bustle. Visit the nunnery too and the temple. The nearby shopping mall has a useful budget foot court.

Stunning & Impressive. Really worth a visit at a few minutes walk from a MTR station. Garden is absolutely stunning, and the pagoda is highly picturesque. The Chinese style buildings go well with the greenery. So impressive. Its lovely to see locals and tourists alike enjoying what is a must see

Stunning tranquil and free!. Beautiful place to simply sit and relax. Gorgeous trees and shrubbery all groomed impeccably. Water features, coy carp and temples. Just stunning, great spot to get away from the crazy hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Completely free entry which is a great bonus. Take the green MTR line to diamond hill and it's a 2 minute walk from there. Signs point the way. Well worth the $14hk on the mtr to get there. The nunnery is just next door and also free. Enjoy

A beautiful paradise. One of the best gardens I have visited. A beautiful place full of trees, ponds... And you can enjoy the contrasting images of a serene garden and the modern Hong Kong architecture. Best to combine with a visit to the nunnery nearby.

Immaculately maintained garden . The garden is stunning!! So well maintained. It is lush and green with lots of interesting features such as the wood work exhibit and the temple. It's not really big, so you only need an hour or so, but for a free thing to do- it's worth the easy train ride there

Like a japanese zen garden. The trip is worthwhile as you can also see the buddhist temple and of course the lovely gardens. It is said that the wooden temple is put together wirhout a single nail, check it out yourself. There are lotus ponds as well in the temple and bonsai-like trees.

Awesome garden. One of the best gardens we have seen in Hong Kong. It's a lovely quiet haven in a very busy and noisy city.You can access the Chi Lin Nunnery at the same time, it's worth doing them both. The park is well-maintained and perfect for meditating. Entrance is free.
Great sight of HK. Recommended by friends and did not disappoint. A nice, tranquil and beautiful garden in the middle of a busy city. Worth the visit.

Possibly THE BEST garden in all of China. We have traveled throughout China visiting gardens, and found this to be the best anywhere. We took the MTR to the Chi Lin Nunnery (exit station and follow the signs past the Hollywood Mall), and afterwards walked across the bridge to the gardens. Somehow, we missed having to pay an entrance fee, which we had read was $1 HKD. There is an illustrated pamphlet available showing where certain features and vistas are in the garden: waterfall, lookout, banyon tree grove, etc. No eating or drinking is allowed in the garden, itself. It seems there is a restaurant behind the big waterfall, but it was crowded, so we passed it by. When we were there (Dec. 2015), there was an exhibit of Murano, Italy, glass ($20 HKD for general public; $10 HKD for students and seniors). The woman in charge said we could take pictures, then popped in a few times while we were looking at the glass pieces to remind us to take pictures! It really was a special place. When we visit Hong Kong again, it will be the first place we visit.
Oasis of green and calm. Lovely landscaping, nice little exhibitions and a cafe and restaurant that are reasonable quality. Nice.

Serene space in the crowded city. This is certainly a breather from the bustling city of Hong Kong. Its not a popular place among travellers alike which I do prefer as the places will lose its charm if it's too crowded. Its a good place to relax and clear your mind.

Perfect place for stress relief . As you walk into the main entrance, you can feel a sense of peace to your mind. Even my jolly mind, I felt, was under control when I saw the beautifully decorated foot steps, the greenery, the statues of Lord Buddha and the sound from priest reading the mantras inside. It feels like a SMALL HEAVEN. People who have stress and agitated mind must visit there to boost up your mind.

A peaceful place. An excellent place, and quite pleasant to walk around. With it's numerous bonsai's it's a wonder such a beatiful place exists besides one of the most busy malls in Honk Kong. And to be connected right to the Buddha temples makes it even better.

Amazing. What an amazing garden, peaceful and clean. The gardens are carefully managed, with amazing displays and a lovely cafe. I'd recommend visiting in late afternoon when the light is fading. It is amazing.
Must visit !. Nice garden , surrounded by tall skyscrapers . Not so many visitors , so a relaxed time there . In combination with monastery nearby .

Peaceful and Beautiful. We toured Shanghai and Hong Kong during our trip and visited numerous parks, temples and gardens. This was by far the most beautiful and peaceful garden that we saw. I would have enjoyed more time here.

Outstanding . Exceptionally clean , quiet and well crafted in every aspects.The display are very well maintained . Enjoy the architectural display , the colourful fishes in the pond, the various shape of bonsai , the unusual rock that is older than you and me . Your hear waterfall , birds . Please check out pictures that I posted .The number of volunteers kept this place exceptionally clean , nicely crafted and dust free .I saw a team of 5 volunteers wrapping the wire , I guess to protect winter frost or delay rusting .Been to Japan and many gardens , this is one of the 2 that I am majorimpressed.Set aside 2 hours and bring your camera .If you like my review , please vote for me .

The highlight of our trip. Just WOW! We went in the late afternoon so got to experience the gardens in the last bits of sunlight and then as the sun set we also walked them during the night and it was beautiful in both settings! This really was the highlight of our trip. It's a small oasis in the middle of the busy city. I almost don't want to write this review because it's not widely advertised in the city and it's not on the tourist bus routes - we had to get a taxi to take us there and even they needed directions.

Very pleasant surprise in a busy city.. The garden is very well done and perfect for an afternoon walk. If you go on a Wednesday the museum display inside is free to visit. We got to see some very cool venetian glass that was on display during our visit.
Wow.. What a fabulous place!. This really is a hidden gem. Such a beautiful garden away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. It was lovely, so peaceful and tranquil. Would recommend going here!

Nice and relaxing place in the city. The Japanese style garden with stone garden, big trees and ponds worth a visit if you have time to enjoy the beauty of nature and relaxing your mind.Food and beverages are not allowed in this area, if you want to have some coffee, tea or care for the refreshment, there's the cafe and restaurant inside.

A hidden gem. Not to be missed . Calm. Serene. A beautiful landscaped hidden gem in the hustle and bustle of HK . Surprisingly, many HK residents do not know about it. Get down at Diamond Hill MTR and just follow the signage, it is just a 5 min walk. No words to describe the beauty of the place, you just have to feel it. Do visit the small wood museum near the entrance. Great photo opportunities for the camera buffs. The only minus is the exorbitant restaurants/ cafe and the curio shops. The visit to the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery is a must.The garden is connected to the nunnery y a pathway and giant wooden doors, but check it's timings beforehand because the timings are different from that of the garden.

Nice peacefull. The garden is relaxing. You can take the subway to diamond hill. From there, exit on the road side. Signs will lead you to the garden. Don't forget to go to the monestary over the bridge

Beautiful Garden and Perfect Place For a Walk. Nan Lian Garden is one of the most beautiful gardens in Hong Kong. The peaceful and well kept area is perfect for walks and taking pictures. We really enjoyed how it was just steps away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong yet tranquil enough to make you forget where you were.

Impeccably tended garden in the Ming Dynasty style. Nan Lian is a beautiful garden maintained in the Ming Dynasty style with more than the landscape to recommend it. First, it's a 5-minute walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station and across the street from the elegant Chi Lin Nunnery, a spectacular complex on its own. Second, on its grounds are several buildings that house interesting attractions: one on the wood joinery used in constructing temples with scale models of such buildings as the Imperial Palace in Beijing and explanations of the meaning of architectural details, another is home to a very good vegetarian restaurant, a third is a tea house with expensive teas. Botanical fans will admire the variety of plants and the pruning art that shapes bougainvilleas into large bonsais. I almost forgot the cool gift shop.

Serene..... This Garden is easily accessed from Diamond Hill Metro stop. The signage is good and from the metro, takes about 5 mins. Although the flora in November is limited, the rocks, trees and pathways were serenely beautiful. The Gift Shop is also worth a visit.The Google Map can be deceiving as it looks like a long walk but I easily found the entrance (under the highways). The map also makes Chi Lin Nunnery look far away but there is direct access from the garden. Head toward the Yellow Pagoda and go up the steps. At the top you will come to a walkway/bridge that takes you right into the nunnery...not to be missed!The Garden offers many spots for great photos of the ponds, the rocks, the waterfalls and (almost) secret pathways. There are also many great bonzai near the gift shop.

Most tranquil place in the middle of Hong Kong. The Gardens are easy to get to via the MTR. The gardens are always busy, but there seems to be a reverent attitude, so always tranquil and peaceful. If you have a half day and just want to get out and do something that isn't too taxing, then this is a perfect place.

Step out of the hustle and bustle. Ann Lian Gardens are nothing short of spectacular. They are so well tended. The trees and flowers are breath taking and seems as if not a leaf is out of place. After spending time in the built up areas of Hong Kong take yourself off here for a truly refreshing afternoon. Take time to sit and enjoy the surroundings and unwind. Complete your relaxation by taking a short walk across the road to Chi Lin Nunnery. This amazing complex of wooden buildings compliments the time you have spent at the gardens and you cannot fail to be amazed at the skills that would have been needed to build such complicated buildings with a single nail.

Amazing park. This is really a relaxing escape in the city, with a lot of different pavillions. One is showcasing the art of wooden building, another held an exhibition of Murano glass and another was showcasing special "rocks" . Once you have walk through the garden you can also discover a very nice temple. Easy access from MTR. You can have a snack in the garden and there is also a tea lounge (expensive).
so nice. It is a beautiful place to visit. Love the walk, contrast views with traditional park and modern on the background. IT IS A MUST VISIT PLACE!

Best free attraction in HK. This is a garden that is next to Chi Lin Nunnery. Together, it is the best free attraction in HK. The garden is very well maintained. The golden pavilion is awesome for photography. The challenge is to catch it without any of the apartment as part of the background. This in fact is a difficult task as there are lots of high rise apartments around the area. These does not create any disturbance to the garden which is very beautifully landscaped. I like to go there whenever I am in HK. It give me an escape from bustling HK.

Beautiful Garden. Beautiful garden and seeing is believing. By name one may omit it from list, but it is a place not to be missed. Lovely garden with varieties of plants and trees. Very well maintained with beautiful paths. Fantastic collection of bonsai trees. There is a beautiful artificial waterfall and building near the water body. One can spend good time here walking in peace. There is a bonsai shop too but it was closed as we had reached early. This garden also has nice collection of rocks. An ideal place for photography.

Beautiful Green in busy Hong Kong. The Nan Lian Garden was easy to find (via public transport). Although located between highway bridges and busy roads, it was clean and quiet. There is no entry fee which is quite normal for visiting Asian temples and gardens. I enjoyed my stay there. There are a few gardens in Hong Kong but this one is my absolute favourite. You can relax, read a book and enjoy the fantastic view of the garden. It is also attached to the Chi Lin Nunnery which is a Buddhist temple accessible via a bridge. The Nan Lian Garden right in front of you and the concrete jungle of Hong Kong in the background showed the astonishing contrast between nature and human civilisation. Don't miss out on this site. I highly recommend visiting the Garden.

Very surprised. . Not sure what I was expecting but was thoroughly impressed with this fantastic garden next to the nunnery. A very fine example of a Chinese garden and absolutely immaculate. I really enjoyed all of the petrified wood.
Great spot for some relaxation!. We stopped by here in the afternoon, great place to take a moment from the rush of Hong Kong and appreciate some good architecture and well maintained gardens.

Hidden Gem. Visit the tourist information office by the pier and they will offer good suggestions. They advised that we visited the Chi Lin Nunnery which was about 20 minutes away on the subway train, it was a Buddhist nunnery with beautiful gardens and opposite it was a Japanese botanical garden spread over several acres; a tranquil oasis in a very busy city
Immaculate Chinese Garden. Beautiful, well kept garden in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong City. A peaceful and tranquil place with beautiful Chinese temples - worth a look.
A quiet place in the busy city. Located close to Diamond Hill station, the garden is so pretty! Well maintained and the golden temple looks stunning.

Amazing gardens in the city. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill and it's just a short walk across to these peaceful gardens. It's free to get in but there is a restaurant and shop within the well maintained grounds. Well worth the visit.
Peaceful Place. Very beautiful place to relax, clean and no noise! Good places to sit, some expensive, some not. Even on sundays they water the plants and clean the place.No entrance fee

Nan lush green garden is great! . Beautiful respite from the hustle and bustle of the city and it can be found right in the centre. The backdrop of the skyscrapers os spectacular. Very peaceful place to pass a pm.

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful garden! Wonderful for a family or solo stroll.
Lots of other tourists but at times very peaceful. Beautiful setting. Easy to get to.

Stunning. A beautiful place and a must see for anyone interested in gardens. I hought it was like a Chelsea exhibit it was so perfect with exquiste planting and not a leaf out of place. . The various buildings in the garden are very interesting as are the rock arrangements. An incredible contrast to the busy shopping centre, main roads and soaring tower blocks that surround it.

Serene place!. Not advertised enough, this is a must do for folks to do. The place offers a chance to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city and offers a view into the Buddhist architecture of temples and nice green areas (including lotus ponds)
Quiet and peaceful. Very quite and peaceful, also near the MTR station. no eating or drinking. Not very large but makes an hour of relaxation.
moern and old. this place is beautiful, it has the best of the old, traditional culture but its surrounded by modern buildings and constructions.

Beautiful oasis in the bustling city. This is the third time I've visited now and I'm sure I'll return as it's such a beautiful place, worth visiting for the wonderful vegetarian restaurant alone, I'm not a vegetarian but love to visit as the food is wonderful
Nan Lian gardens. Very tranquil, in the middle of Hong Kong, you catch mrt and visit the nunnery also. Very beautiful, and spectacular wood architecture on display.
Well worth it. Easy to get to (MTR to Diamond Hill), the gardens are well maintained and the mill and waterfall are lovely, a welcome oasis.
Very nice garden. Very nice garden....so zen..went there a morning and was very quiet. The temples are very nice.A must do in HK

A hidden jewel of the fragrant harbour. We went to the Nanlian garden with some Taiwanese friends. Getting there was quite easy. Catch the MTR to Diamond Hill station, walk past the Hollywood plaza and across the road is the entrance to the gardens. We were worried that we arrived a bit late (it was nearly 5 pm) but the entrance sign said that it close at around 10 pm. The garden is really a hidden jewel. Outside, you hear the hustle and bustle of the city with lots of car noise and pollution, but once inside the garden, you are immersed in serene and tranquil silence. I will let the pictures speak for themselves but it is truly worth exploring!

Beautiful garden. The location of the garden is in urban Kowloon this is a truly beautiful, colourful and scenic place with a tranquil and serene atmosphere.Whilst there are plenty of high-rise buildings in the vicinity of the garden the distant backdrop to the north is of the scenic mountain ranges of Lion Rock, Tate’s Cairn, Temple Hill and Kowloon Peak. I went there on a February evening with a friend and enjoyed the surroundings.

Quiet and peace, surrounded by skyscrapers. This garden showcases the exquisite Chinese sensibility and love of nature. It is surprisingly large, so much so that if you don't look up you'd think you were in the country, and you can even get temporarily lost. Despite the huge city surrounding the garden it is quiet, with the loudest noises usually being the cries of birds. There is enough greenery so that the air even smells fresher than the surrounding Hong Kong air, as if the bonsai-ed trees are filtering out the smoke and coal dust blowing in from mainland China. This is a formal Chinese garden, with wide, easily walkable paths; lots and LOTS of bonsai-ed trees, most of them nicely labeled; perhaps a few too many wonderful large rocks; several water features, including a huge pond with huge koi (try to catch feeding time in the middle of the day); a few walking bridges over the water, often closed to the public, however; several buildings including a museum of miniatures of some of the buildings that inspired the wonderful nunnery temple just a few minutes' walk away. Nice ground covers, but not many flowers -- the scale is just too large and the design generally not well suited to flowers. An excellent and reasonably priced vegetarian restaurant can be found in a corner of the garden. Be sure to read the whole menu as there are lots of interesting dishes in addition to the set menu.
Beautiful to walk through to Chi Lin Nunnery for Lunch. Beautiful Garden with chinese architecture. We found the Chinese Timber Architecture Gallery very interesting.
A nice break. A nice break to all the skyscrapers and bustling city centre. Easy access with the MTR and it´s good to combine with Chi Lin.

Peaceful oasis. Very quiet formal, manicured gardens with amazing backdrop of huge sky scrapers. Reading other reviews it is not to everyone's taste but if you like a nice formal garden this cannot be bettered. Free admission. Lots of rules, but they add rather than detract from the expernece. A few more seating areas would be nice..At Diamond Hill MTR Station

Breath of fresh air . A great place to come and visit when you just want to have a walk away from the shopping centres and all the people! beautiful quiet little place (take about 1 hour to go around). There are also little cafes and restaurants to eat at too!
Gem in the centre of Hong Kong. The gardens and the associated Nunnery are an oasis in the city. Free admission. Beautiful gardens, plants, shrubs and ponds.

Classical Chinese garden in the city background. A few minutes walk from a MTR station but really worth a visit. The garden is very beautiful and highly maintained. The Chinese style buildings go well with the greenery. So impressive.
An average quality visit. There are beauty sights but it is obvious that they are made recently. It is also very hot in the garden.

Stunning. I visited in the peak of summer, and despite the intense heat I had a wonderful visit. The gardens are absolutely stunning, and the pagoda is highly picturesque. I took some of my best photos in Hong Kong here. I visited during the week and it wasn't too busy either, which is a pleasant change from the city. Very convenient to get to from Kowloon side in particular! Only a few stops up the green line.

Beautiful. We loved it here. The city and motorways have built up around these gardens but when inside you only hear a low rumble of traffic. Its lovely to see locals and tourists alike enjoying what is a must see

Very tranquil. My second visit here. Last time I was here, I don't believe the shop or stone room was open.The nunnery is very clean, quiet, peaceful, and safe.I think there were five guards at the nunnery watching to make sure no one disobeyed the rules.The garden is beautiful. The public washrooms were immaculate. The store has a very tasteful array of products. My companions bought some beautiful items.
Aus traveler. U had a wonderful day at the gardens but the taxi fare was a joke thry charge u double the fare aswell as loading it up the scumbags
Very nice garden. It's very nice garden, free entry, easy accessible from Diamond hill subway station, less crowded than most of HK attractions.
Nice green pocket in a bustling city!. This is a very new place. Not a great historical site, but it offers nice views and a calm place to walk about to escape the rushing people everywhere.

Best Gardens in HK. This is a must visit! Very restful and beautiful. MTR bus easily will get you to Diamond Hill. It really is an amazingly serene old Chinese garden with ponds, waterfalls, bridges and manicured topiary shrubs.Don't forget to visit the Chi Lin Buddhist Nunnery across the road which is equally beautiful.

Nicely manicured. Beautiful garden in the middle of the city. Free of charge. Easily accessible from MTR. For all ages. A leisurely stroll for any time of day. Did early it in morning, then went to Nunnery next door.
Garden of Bonsai. Nan Lian Garden in Diamond hill is free of entrance, the place was so peaceful and the bonsai are well maintained. Easy to go there by MTR.

HONG KONG'S MOST IMPRESSIVE GARDEN. This is without a doubt, Hong Kong's most impressive garden, my jaw just dropped!!This place is so peaceful and serene. The Bonsai's are perfectly groomed, we even got to see the master gardeners at work clipping the trees.Everywhere I looked was so picture perfect, postcard material.The main Koi Pond was beautiful and full of huge fish.The Lotus Ponds of the main temple were simply beautiful, I couldn't believe that such an equisite garden could exist in such a busy metropolis.* Don't whatever you do miss this amazing garden !!!!!Take the MTR to Diamond Hill and follow the signs upon exiting, everything is well signposted here, so easy to find.The garden is basically opposite the MTR as you exit, a short 5 minute walk.

Must See!. Beautiful gardens are easy to access by MTR and are really a must see while in Hong Kong! Peaceful atmosphere and everyone we ran into was friendly and willing to take our photos. Great morning!

An Oasis in the bustling city. My wife and I were pleasantly surprised when we visited Nan Lian Garden. It is a perfectly maintained and gorgeous garden setting with ponds, temples and exotic trees and plants. Close to MTR and major mall - please cross the road to visit the elaborate temples at the Chi Lin Nunnery.
Serenity in the middle of bustling city. If you're looking for place to relax, this is the place. Go early in the morning to feel the freshness of this garden.

An oasis of peace. Easy to reach by metro, you can enjoy the beauty of the Gardens and the exquisite plants and trees. We enjoyed the vegetarian restaurant in the Gardens. Various set menus or free choices but with a minimum spend of hkd 120.
Recommend a visit, but choose a sunny day.

Zen amongst the Skyscrappers. A peaceful zen haven in the heart of the city. Beautifully designed and tendered. The water ponds with turtles was a bonus as where the butterflies. It was like a Chinese fairyland.

A beautiful oasis in bustling HongKong. With skyscrapers all around you suddenly find yourself in a quiet, beautiful garden with traditional historic buildings, lakes, ornate bridges, waterfalls, goldfish and plenty of walks around well kept gardens.
It was quiet and peaceful when we visited in October, so a good time to go.

A quiet refuge in Hong Kong. Dont miss this - we went and its beautiful . We had two hours there and its an amazing and beautiful place. So quiet and tranquil. Nice little cafe to have a drink and its free.to visit.

A Gem of a Garden!. We got to the garden early in the morning at 9 am and we were glad to do so. There was no crowd and we got to enjoy each little nook and cranny of the garden. It is a gem as it is ensconced in the middle of a busy city. It was peaceful and relaxing!
Garden Scenery. Such a beautiful restful place to visit in a hectic city. Wander around this Park - look at waterfall & glassware display.

Wonderfull Nan Lian Vegetarian Food. It is a wonderfull restaurant with superb service and amazing vegetarian food! Should not be missed! And it is situated inside a beautiful Chi Lin Nunnery, a large temple complex of elegant wooden architecture. Before having the meals there, must visit the Chi Lin Nunnery.
beautiful. It is beautiful in a Chinese style. Quite unique in HK. I just think it is a bit hard to access there even the MTR station isn't too far away.

Beautiful gardens. I would definitely recommend coming to the gardens. They were very well appointed, and there are many places within the gardens to eat lunch, have tea or even just snacks. Feels very serene despite being in the city.
Will definitely be back to try the vegetarian restaurant.
Lovely gardens. I did expect these gardens to be quite ancient, but they are reasonably modern gardens. They are spectacular just the same. An oasis in the business of HK life.

Breathtaking . This is a must visit! It is like something out of a painting. The gardens are so fresh and well maintained and the koi fish pond looking over the temple is just stunning. It is free to enter and is right outside Diamond hill train station.
Wonderful and peaceful garden in big city Hong Kong. Beautiful garden next to the Diamond Hill MTR station. Very peaceful and wonderfully landscaped. Near the Chi Lin Nunnery.
Beautiful. Very clean and great for pictures. The temple is especially nice. Might be a bit touristy but nevertheless, I enjoyed it.
Japanese style.... Really good. Seems like a painting. Do visit it. Free to enter. Right outside diamond hill metro station.

Relaxing space in Hong Kong. This is physically connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery, so you'd visit both in the same trip. It's a pleasant break for an hour or two from the noise and bustle of Kowloon. It's a tranquil garden in the midst of a Hong Kong suburbs...slight surreal to wander along a walkway within a carefully manicured, calm oasis of water and trees, to see Hong Kong's skyscrapers on the horizon. It also very easy to reach, being only a few minutes for the Diamond Hill MTR (about 25mins from downtown Kowloon). And when you are calm and relaxed, you can walk back to the MTR, and shop in the high-end mall that's build over the station.
Beautiful Garden. A well maintained garden in Hong Kong. Take a walk in the garden and enjoy its beauty. Located near Diamond Hill Metro and can be clubbed along with Chi Lin Nunnery.Worth a visit
Going back in time. The Nan Lian Garden is a place where u can find the old Chinese style meeting the modern city of hong kong. A good place to spend the evening
Peaceful walk. I had a wonderful afternoon here alone, strolling around the gardens. I stopped off at a tea shop to have a cheese toasty. Very clean, polite staff and a relaxing attraction.

A must see!. We loved these beautifully kept gardens - they are an oasis of calm & offer an intriguing contrast of old/nature against new/buildings. You can take water in with you, but not other drinks or food. There is a cafe & a restaurant under the waterfall if you want to stop.The gardens also lead to the Chi Lin Nunnery - amazing!When we were there there was (slightly bizarrely in the middle of HK) an amazing exhibition of Venetian Murano Glass.Get off the MTR at Diamond Hill, walk over the road & you're there. It's free, & for me it was an essential breath of peace & calm in a mad place.

Tranquil oasis. What a gem this place is! We visited on a weekday, and the place was not packed at all - making it seem more tranquil and peaceful. Very nicely done gardens replicating the Tang Dynasty. Beautifully trained bonsai and other trees spread throughout the garden grounds. Waterfalls. Service personnel comb the grounds to make sure visitors are behaving properly and keeping the place very clean. Gift shop offers unique and quality items. Tea pavilion was closed during our visit - or else I would have liked to try. It's such a pleasant surprise to find a peaceful place like this among the hustle and bustle of a busy city. Diamond Hill MTR station.
Beautiful.. A pleasant place to visit and so peaceful just over the road from Hollywood Plaza MTR stop Diamond hill.

Nice garden, rushed dinner. We had a group of 12 people coming for dinner. Apparently there are two settings for dinner. We were informed at our 6:00 pm reservation that we would have to vacate the table by 7:15 pm for the next seating at 7:30. At first a lot of the items we asked for off the menu they stated were sold out! A lot of beverages also were not available. I am not sure if they were holding back menu items for the next seating or if they had sold out the food from lunch earlier in the day. Even though we managed to order food we felt rushed the whole time, and got frustrated looks when we ordered more dishes. By the time we got out of dinner it was difficult to see the park in the manner to be appreciated. Next time I will make a point of going at lunch so that it is easier to see the surroundings. There is a gift shop which sells a nice variety of souvenirs and food items. The park is easily assessable from the subway, getting off at the Diamond Hill stop, and walking across the street.

Peace of mind and great vegeterian. Hong Kong always amazes me in how she manages to fit in superb public parks amidst the suffocating concrete jungles. Once you get into the garden (a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station), you immediately relaxes everything and just take in the greenery, bird chirps and the careful landscape. Lunch reservation is recommended as it's a pretty popular spot. The restaurant is behind the waterfall next to the water wheel!

Afternoon in the garden. Spent my last afternoon in Hong Kong at the garden and nunnery. Take the MRT to Diamond Hill and it's round the corner. Free entry and a little oasis in the busy streets surrounding it. Beautiful topiary and the art of Bonsi trees at its best and a huge Koi fish pond. All linked to the Nunnery. The Buddist Hall closes at 4.30! Small cafe there serving tea and soft drinks.

One Of The Highlights Of Our HK Trip. It is beautiful, adjacent to Chi Lin Nunnery that we had planned a visit to, this we just stumbled across.Free entry, but the pride the gardeners have in its presentation is exceptional, it is immaculate, an oasis from the noise of the city, staggering high rise towers surround this little bit of paradise. The mist machines watering the many plants giving an ethereal feel to the lake, the bridges, waterfall, temples, all exquisite. It is free, do not miss out it should be on everyones to do list.

No beatific description could have prepared me for the sight of the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection!. This is the most stunning garden I have encountered in Hong Kong. Every square inch of this sanctuary is immaculately maintained. The artistry that went into the design of this classic Chinese garden is breathtaking. The goldleaf pavilion with bright orange footbridges is unforgettable. Great display of eroded rock too.
Very relaxing and scenic. Beuatiful garden, not an easily accessible location and not massive. You can cover it all in about an hour, worth a visit for sure (if you're into gardens).

An ideal place to spend an afternoon. With time to spare before our flight home we took the MTR to Diamond Hill. A short walk later and we were in the gardens enjoying a pleasant stroll amongst stunning scenery. The adjacent Chi Lin nunnery houses a spectacular Buddhist temple that made the trip all the more worthwhile.

A hidden treasure. So glad we didn't miss this beautiful garden located close to Hollywood Plaza Shopping Centre. Its an Oasis in the Centre of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Close to Diamond Hill MTR station. you must pay a visit.
Very Beautiful and peaceful. The garden is very colourful and beautiful, another good point is that the garden is inside the city, and you can easly go with 1 or 2h.

a haven of peace in a crazy city. We visited Nan Lian Garden and the temple after reading about it in a travel book. It is definitely worth visiting instead of trailing around the city looking at more Knock-off goods than I care to remember in the markets.A 25 minute cab ride but do it, its beautiful.

Zen in the City. When you simply just want to get away from the city, Nan Lian offfers great views, Chinese architecture, a rock garden and a vegetarian restaurant. Entrance is free, get off Diamond Hill MTR exit and walk a few minutes. Chilin Nunnery and a mall is nearby.
Nice Place. Was in the same area for years to visit the nunnery and at taht time this garden was not here. It is a very clean area and you felt relax to be here as it is not crowed

Quiet place. Nice place to get away from the busy streets of Hong Kong. Would love to go back and spend whole day at the place, probably read there too! It is serene and they also sell postcards for 2hkd there of good quality.

Amazingly peaceful spot in the middle of the city. I really loved this garden - it was worth coming to. I wish I'd eaten in the restaurant too. The walk is lovely and the temple is peaceful. I hope to return.
Great day out. I have visited Hong Kong several times but just discovered this lovely, lovely garden at Diamond Hill. What a treasure it is..

Beautiful!!. Such a stunning garden to escape the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, really east to get here, quick MTR ride and only a few minutes walk from the Diamond Hill Station (also Plaza Hollywood shopping mall is here, worth a look!) The gardens are free to access and there is also a vegetarian restaurant here as well as the nunnery. Such a peaceful place, could have spent hours here getting lost among the serenity of it all! Worth a visit !

Nothing special. We saw pictures of the gardens online before going and thought they looked worth a visit. Upon arriving, however, we soon realised that they were in a built up area surrounded by busy roads with lots of traffic noise. Some of the pathways in the gardens appeared to be blocked off for no apparent reason, which we thought odd for a weekend when there could be lots of visitors and we were disappointed that we couldn't explore those areas. Sadly not what we expected. Try Kowloon Walled City Park instead for some interesting history and a less manufactured feel.

Peaceful gardens. Close to the centre of kowloon side Hong Kong these gardens are well worth the visit set against and in the midst of a bustling city.
Don't miss the tea house.

Beautiful. Calm. Picturesque.. This very beautiful garden is conveniently near the MTR and connects to Chi Lin Nunnery. This attraction is so majestic, I would come back if only I had time (visited it on a Saturday, so there were a lot of people)! It has a vegetarian restaurant in it, a souvenir shop, an exhibit of wooden scale models of famous traditional structures in China, a display of bonsai, a rock "garden", and an exclusive tea experience in one of the bigger pavilions (like, 200 HKD exclusive).But there's no need to spend a single cent to enjoy this sight.Best for solo, couple and elderly traveller.

An example of what makes Hong Kong a world class urban environment. We wouldn't have missed this. I guess this is free, but well worth a generous donation. There is a restaurant on the grounds, but hours are limited. I would like to learn more about the nunnery.

A calm oasis. In the middle of the city is the Nan Lian Garden, an oasis of tranquillity in the midst of all the chaos of Hong Kong. Take your time to stroll at a leisurely pace and enjoy the calmness.

A suburban treasure..... Located near Diamond Hill MTR so combine the gardens with the Nunnery and shopping close by. Take C2 out of the station, cross the road and your nearly there. The gardens themselves open early before the different exhibitions and you will beat the crowds for a little extra serenity. Features include the magnificent red arched bridge, the Golden Pavilion the garden's articulated plants, trees and augmented grounds.A tea room and gift shop are in the grounds plus a few seats looking out onto various postcard scenes. The bridge and Pavilions are not accessible allowing the charm to flow though this 'picturesque' oasis. It's always a pleasure visiting this garden for some tranquil time away from the 'big smoke' that's Hong Kong.Enjoy your experience!

Fantastic!. This was a treat. It was really an oasis in the middle of the city. The garden is beautiful as well as the traditional buildings inside it. There is also a popular restaurant in the garden and it is located behind a (man-made) waterfall.

Tranquility. You would not necessary think of visiting here as a must but it is so worth while. The gardens are beautiful and so peaceful. You can access the Chi Lin Nunnery at the same time it's worth doing them both. There is a resturant and a coffee shop for something to eat and drink. A lovely tourist shop with less tacky gifts to buy plus they sell the most gorgeous unusual chocolates there.

Serenity in frantic city. Visited this ripper peaceful little garden on a personal tour with our guide Bill Sievers.Took the subway here from TST.Very impressed with fact that this type of place can exist within such a busy frantic city. Surrounded by high rise buildings and the nine dragon mountains. Worth while visiting this serene price of honk Kong

Quiet and solitude, for nature and garden lovers. If you want to get away from the busyness of the city and want to find a place of quiet & solitude, visit this place. Though it was a bit far from our hostel at TST, It was worth visiting.  For nature and garden lovers like me, you will definitely enjoy this place. The landscaping and bonsai trees are so impressive. You will be surrounded by green trees, still ponds, view of colorful koi fishes, chirping birds, running waterfalls etc. Simply beautiful nature! Plus, for some taste of their culture, you get to witness locals worship as you visit the Chi Lin Nunnery, a temple that houses their gods.Personally, we opted to spend time here after a day from theme parks to cool down and relax ourselves. I wanted our daughter not only to experience fun and thrill but also to enjoy nature, quietness and stillness of a place. One tip, visit this garden on a wednesday where its museum located inside is free. During our visit, we got to view murano vases - such exquisite works of art. Bring umbrellas or raincoat for rainy days. If you are in the mood of sipping a cup of tea in this beautiful ambiance, they have a vegetarian restaurant and tea cafe. Be prepared to spend however. Prices are terribly expensive. Anyway, cheaper reasonably priced food is always available at the food republic inside the mall, just a five minute walk away from the garden. Getting here was convenient. Get off from MTR diamond hill station. You will find yourself near a mall. Simply walk and cross the street to Nan Lian Garden entrance gate. Best of all, the entire garden is free for public.
Nan Lian. One of the best garden I have seen in Hong Kong although we went there it's a little hot but restaurants and food booths are available along the way
giorgeous gardens. This was a lovely quiet haven in a very busy and noisy city. And, its free! Loved the temples and monastery. Great facilities and cooling and relaxing to wander in.

Amazing oasis in the middle of the city. I've been here with my family. The scenery is breathtaking, after a while the people forget where they are. 60 different trees make it the best park in Hong Kong. It is included in the tentative list of China's world heritage sites. Don't miss the vegetarian restaurant under the waterfall, it's a must!

Peaceful place. Excellent and serene atmosphere in the middle of the city. The garden is well maintained. Can spent an hour in the garden just relaxing. The nunnery is uphill and needs a bit of walking to reach.
Theme Park. Silence, peace and old Chinese Style garden. Easy to go. Artificial water pool. Good relaxing place to see small plants.

Nothing amazing about this place. OK to see.. Nothing absolutely amazing about this place. But if you are in the area and want to see something interesting it's worth a visit. Unless of course you are a Buddhist and want to go there for worshiping.
an oasis. good place to spend an hour or two. beautiful landscape. not too crowded. interesting architecture. a couple of restaurants, but I didn't try.

Tranquil oasis minutes from HK chaos. Kids enjoy looking at the different carp in the ponds and can stretch their legs running over the bridges. Wonderful sense of peace just minutes away from the bustle of the city. The restaurant had a gorgeous view of the gardens and the food was fine, but pricy.
waterfalls. such a peaceful place and beautiful place just minutes away from all the hustle and bustle of the streets

An idyll of tranquility. Slap-bang next to Diamond Hill and bracketed by busy roads you would expect this to be a noisy place.But it isn't.Instead this beautiful Chinese garden provides a place of calm and tranquillity. A meandering path makes the garden seem much larger than you might expect. Along the way, you can find stunning examples of traditional wooden construction techniques.Enjoy a tea ceremony. Find a vegetarian restaurant hidden behind an artificial waterfall. And do make sure to visit the gift shop - not the usual Hong Kong souvenirs. Enjoy the carefully selected ornamental rocks.Exiting the garden, you go up steps to enter a stunning temple. Camera is a must!!! Yes, you can take your smart phone camera but trust me, you will want a better camera if you have one.
Hidden in the city. Quite a nice garden in the middle of this concrete jungle. It is worth a visit to Diamond Hill. Easily accessible via MTR, exit thru the mall and cross the street.

Nice Garden. Very nice garden, well kept, beautifully scenery. It is very quiet and peaceful, clean. Worth a visit and spend two hours there. Have a cup of tea or coffee in one of the café and enjoy the peaceful moment there.
peaceful. its free! its really nice to get a FB profile pic here. hahah. at the same time checking out the Chinese culture how peaceful and rich there culture is.
Great experience. Nice quiet place in a busy city, love the gardens. Literally across the street form the MTR station. Dont forget t go the the nunnery, also amazing

A little bit of calm and serenity in the middle of a busy city. The gardens are meticulously kept and beautiful. There are sculptured trees and well-planned gardens are stunning. In places the mist not only waters the plants but cools the visitors! The calming music playing in the background adds to the overall serenity. It was delightful to spend some time walking around the gardens enjoying the plants and the waterfalls too.
Most see. Maybe the best Chinese garden in Hong Kong, not too big but very peaceful and enjoyable. There is close to the main temple of Hong Kong ( I cant remember its name )
Beautiful & Quiet. This place was recommended by my colleague from states. We walked for about 25 mins from Wong Dai Sin. The place was calm and peaceful.

Such a wonderful garden in the midst of a busy city. I've been here a few times and I absolutely love it. It is so calming and peaceful. The gardens are well maintained and clean. However, please note that you are not allowed to use a selfie stick within the gardens. The security personnel will run up to you to stop you as soon as you pose with one. I guess it is for the safety of others.

Tranquility in the heart of HK. Peaceful with lovely walk through the gardens and combine it with a visit to the Nunery.Hundreds of large Koi carp, vegetarian restaurant and tasteful gift shop combine to make this a worthwhile and free visit in the year of HK.Tip take the MTR to Mong Gok and then walk across to platform to get another train to Diamond Hill. Follow the signs for exit B and then the padestrian sign posts.
Beautiful. The Nan Lian Gardens were never on my 'to do' list but I'm so glad we went went! They were absolutely beautiful, and so tranquil too

Lovely. I was not originally planning on going to Nan Lian Garden. I was told that it was new tourist area with very little local history. A friend encouraged me to go though and I am so glad I listened. It may be new, but it's still a beautiful garden and was relatively quite for being in the middle of Hong Kong. It was actually one of the least crowded areas I went to in my entire trip. It was a great way to decompress, see some beautiful gardens, and escape from the crowds for a bit.

Nice outing-If main spots are covered. The garden fulfills all its promises: its Peaceful and beautiful, very well kept and makes for some great pics. The Garden and the Nunnery are both perfect. Just get off diamond hill station and you can follow the signs-no google map required! Covering the ground is time taking specially as you would like to sit in and take the views...Definitely cover this place if you are done with the usual of HK. There is a "veg" restaurant avialable however it provides mostly snacks and sweets ...Later you could also head off to the mall near the station to grab something to eat.

Tranquil gardens. Fantastic gardens which are also connected with the Chi Lin Nunnery. Very easy to get to on the MTR and only a couple of minutes wander from the station. The gardens aren't enormous but they are large, incredibly tranquil and detailed. Lots of water features and pavilions and fantastic for a gentle stroll.

Tranquil retreat with unusual bonsais. In the middle of high-rise apartments sits this tranquil garden quite unlike any other that I have visited. The temple buildings are fashioned after those in the Tang Dynasty of which the Japanese are highly influenced. Every tree, shrub and potted plant are bonsais. Don't forget to visit the marvelous rock museum of all shapes and sizes. It is clean and well-maintained. It would be a nice place to go to in the fall when the weather is much more pleasant.

Serene & calming . A must visit to get away from the hustle & bustle of the city. Free entrance into the gardens however there are a couple of museums within the area that charge a minimal fee to access. The garden is easy to navigate & definitely different than all other places in Hong Kong with beautiful scenery & relaxing music played throughout the garden. There is everything from gorgeous plants to beautifully manicured pathways to breathtaking wooden sculptures and polished rocks found inside. You can also walk into the nunnery & see beautifully cared for lily pad ponds & gorgeous statues.

Beautiful. Although we used to live in HK we had never been to these gardens, our friends suggested we go and we were so pleased we did. The tightly manicured shrubs and gardens are a sight to see. The feel of the place is peaceful & serene with not a leaf out of place anywhere. It's is free to enter and very easy to get to on the green line to Diamond hill. Make sure you go to the Nunnery across the road while your there.

A must visit. Although this garden and the buildings in it are not original, it has been recreated to a very standard. The location is amazing .... surounded by flyovers and high rise builfings, it is an oasis. Also vist Chi Lin nunnery which is next yo the garden. And by the way, the only charge is to enter a ceramic museum, about £2.
Quiet in bustling Hong Kong. Beautiful, pristine garden, an oasis. Great vegetarian restaurant on the premises. Tea house is a special experience .

How can you not adore this garden.. It is beautiful, adjacent to Chi Lin Nunnery, the pride the gardeners must have, it is immaculate, an oasis from the noise of the city, staggering high rise towers surround this little bit of paradise. The mist machines watering the many plants giving an ethereal feel to the lake, the bridges, waterfall, temples, all exquisite. It is free, do not miss. Out of this world.
Calm oasis. This is a beautiful oasis in the middle of a very busy city. The gardens are perfects, not a leaf out of place !

Delightful break from the city.. A friend recommended this to me. I visited the nunnery and then came through the garden. The central pagoda is beautiful. The models of famous buildings are certainly interesting, and I was tempted to buy many things in the gift store.

Beautiful. A tranquil and beautiful place to visit. I felt like I was walking in a giant bonsai pot. The Buddhas in the nunnery are the most beautiful I have ever seen - really stunning. An absolute must if you like gardens, peace and anything even slightly spiritual.

Really nice. Didn't realise it was attached to the nunery. What i expected plus more. Really nice tranquil gardens and structures. Not that big but makes great photos and free entry. Despite being surrounded by a mall and highway it felt old world and gave me that oriental buzz.
Just beautiful. I loved this beautiful compact garden with its colorful bridge and Pagoda. How amazing to achieve this effect in such a small area.

Stunning garden. Make sure you don't miss the Nan Lian Gardens. They were absolutely stunning, the gardeners are perfectionists and there's not a leaf out of place. Truly beautiful, and free of charge too.
Relaxing and beautiful place.. Very peaceful park with much reference to Japanese gardens. Well kept up and visiting can be combined with the Monestary on the oposite side of the road.

Beautiful gardens . Right next to the Chi Lin Buddhist Nunnery it is designed in the Tang Dynasty style with hills water features rocks and sculptures a beautiful and peaceful gardens nice for a stroll after visiting the nunnery. Beautifully manicured gardens

A quite and peaceful place. The opposite of Hong Kong: peaceful, green and relaxing place. In Nan Lian Garden, you will enjoy the peaceful and relaxing place, away from those CBD (Central Business Districts). Enjoy the greeneries and the pond with fishes swimming around. Listening to the waterfall nearby and have a nice tea inside the tea house will complete your day. If you want to, you can also enjoy the vegetarian meal offers in the restaurant. Plan a half day, when you go there. No entrance fee is required.
Peaceful. Very peaceful and well-maintained. Quite stunning to find in the middle of the city, surrounded by tall buildings.

So peaceful. Beautiful, peaceful and well maintained. It was an oasis amongst the hustle and bustle of the city outside! Definitely recommended the nunnery while you are there and the gift shop is full of beautiful gifts.
Relax and enjoy. A very relaxing experience in the city. Stroll through the garden and feel out of the busy environment of Hongkong.

Un jardin privilégié. Harmony between Humans and Nature
Recently connected to "Chi Li" Nunnery, this garden correspond with the Tang garden's style.
Each stone, plant, hill, pond or pavilion is placed according to a specific rule in order to reach a certain harmony between humans and nature.

Escape from the bustling city. This little park is really nice and relaxing. It's such a good place to chill out for a while after sightseeing or shopping in HK. So easy and fast to get there, and it's never that touristy in there. I always come back when I'm in HK.

A nice park. It is a very beautiful garden featuring old style buildings. The community has spent a huge amount of money in building this garden. There are interesting tower, lake, rocks, etc. in the park. Unfortunately, the park's management imposes a very tight and unfriendly rules in managing the park. For example, you will be interfered by the security guard if you use a tripod or if they think you are taking commercial pictures. A lot of Hong Kong people are unhappy about it. There are tea house and restaurant in the park. However, you will find something better at Hollywood Plaza nearby.To get there, beware of the Exit of MTR station. If you get to the wrong side of the MTR station, you will get loss.
Beautiful Garden. This garden is quite beautiful and picturesque. It's relatively easy to find and navigate. It's quiet and perfect for solo travelers.
Nice place in the middle of the city. Great place.Beautiful garden in the middle of the city. You can see bonsai, funny, you can not use tripod to take self pictures.

Peace and quiet from all the hustle bustle.. Lovely quiet retreat from the hectic sights and sounds of Hong Kong. Great examples of Chinese planting and bizarre rock formations. Huge lake in the middle with the biggest Koi you will ever see!

Tranquil but disappointing to see and not walk... Yes it is a beautiful garden, and very tranquil. It was also tremendously hot with no shade. You are allowed to look at, but not follow the paths among the trees or across the bridges. Lots of security and you cannot eat or drink in the gardens. A disappointment but i can say that i have been.

Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful Gardens only 20 minutes by MTR from the centre of Hong Kong. As you walk through the gardens it is amazing to see the different variety of plants, flowers, ponds and buildings. It is such a relaxing place to come to and there is so much to see especially as it leads you to the Nunnery. You can also eat in the on-site restaurant which lies behind a waterfall! A must-visit as a change from the busy streets of Hong Kong.

Relaxing piece of tranquility in HK. This small garden near Diamond Hill MTR is just across the street to Chi Lin Nunnery, making it a good combo trip. The gardens are well looked after with toilet facilities, gift shop and plenty of opportunities to sit down and relax.

Beautiful is the word!. i went in the middle of the day, really hot and humid weather...but the shade and the zero sound pollution is he turn on for this sight. the pagoda is just beautiful in the middle of the park with a water pond...the vegeterian restaurant is a bonus with fresh juice and sandwiches to offer...especially with such a humid weather.....there is a buildingmuseum at the entrance whihc is the highlisgh of this partk...it showcases a miniature versions of all the chinese temples that are centuries old...extremely well crafted! shouldnt take much time...give it a shot..may be evenings are better....something unique in hong kong to see greenery everywhere!

Nice garden but heavy security. A lot of parts were blocked off, no food or drink is allowed (although the tea house and the cafe behind the waterfall looked good) and guards are standing everywhere. It was also very noisy due to the main roads. Worth a visit along with the nunnery, since they're both easy to get to, but it doesn't present itself the best.
Best garden in Hong Kong. Just a stone throw away from the diamond hill station. This garden has a free entry. It's extremely beautiful and is a perfect place for photography. Don't miss it.

Beautiful Garden. This garden was very easy to spot, it's right across the Diamond Hill Station. No entrance fee, the place was quite peaceful, there were a few early morning joggers. The guards there are not allowed to take your pictures so be sure to bring a tripod or a selfie stick.

Tea House not to be missed. I combined the gardens with a visit to the Buddhist Nunnery Temple next door. All buildings in the gardens are built with ancient joinery techniques and do not use any metal fasteners of any kind. There is an exhibit explaining this ancient architecture. Very interesting to learn about and experience. The tea house is remarkable and I spent a pleasant hr enjoying the tea and surroundings. Had a very relaxing day.

One of the best gardens in Hong Kong!. This is one of the hidden gems of Hong Kong. The park is well-maintained and the place is so serene; perfect for meditating! A must-visit! Entrance is free. Going there: ride the MRT and get down at Diamond Hill (green line). From the station, exit at C2 and you'll see Hollywood Plaza Mall. The park is located just a few meters away from the mall.
Best thing near to nature in a concrete jungle!!. Super awesome garden. Amazingly manicured Bonsais and other trees. Calm serene and very peaceful. Must visit when in Hongkong

A nice and accessible retreat amid the forest of concrete in the city. If one has a few hours spare time, nearby an MTR station, wants to be wandering alone or with your companion without specific agenda, this place would suit the purpose perfectly. Get onto the MTR train and get off at Diamond Hill station, cross the street and you will be at the entrance of this wonderful Chinese Garden.Entrance is free and it will not be crowded during weekdays especially in the morning. The place is an example of excellent Chinese garden landscaping, and exquisite ancient Chinese wooded architecture if one is into these thighs. If not it is still one of the better garden-park with very nicely designed Chinese architecture and nice looking trees and rocks which together made for a beautiful garden landscape.It will take an hour or two to go around the place at a comfortable pace with some picture taking. Be reminded that tripods are not allowed to ensure smooth traffic and safety as I was told. More time is needed if one wants to study carefully every details of the beautiful garden. A small shop sells soft drinks, and there is a tea corner serving good Chinese tea but not always open for business. Overall setting is calm and peaceful where one can walking slowly while enjoying the scenery and admiring the architecture details etc.Worth a visit.

Impressive golden tower. Impressive is the golden tower in the middle of an artificial lake. Behind the complex are high rise buildings. This kind of scenes is common in China and Hong Kong, historical buildings surrounded by modern buildings. Economy prosperity has a higher priority.http://hkindependent-traveller-croatia.blogspot.hk/2015/04/chi-lin-nunnery-and-nan-lian-garden.html
Quite and soothing. Soothing area to relax after a hefty tour. Enjoy the scenery and eat at its local resto inside the garden.
If you are around, stop by!. Nice little garden which can be visited for free - it is nothing soooo special but its nice and for free, if you are around the area, stop by!

Serenity in the midst of a bustling city. It was exploring a classical garden in a modern city. There is a Chinese Timber Architecture Gallery located in the garden and free of charge. It was interesting and informative and showed structures of famous buildings in China. Selfie sticks are banned in the garden, and the locals are strict about it. There was construction going in in the garden when we visited in Oct 2014, a lot of areas were blocked and it was a pity, but I loved this garden!

It is not an ordinary recreational park. I like sitting under the trees and look at others taking photos or having their photos taken in front of the red pagoda of the Tang style. Having a pot of tea in the tea house may not be affordable for every one. Food is prohibited but a vegetarian restaurant and vegetarian snack stalls accommodate you when you want to eat or drink. I always eat before or after the visit and would rather sit down and relax in such a peaceful and well-maintained park. Models of spectacular temples or buildings are worth seeing.

Calm and beautiful. We really loved this garden. We got there early, at 9am when the nunnery opens (the garden opens before, but we wanted to see both together), so it was still quiet and empty and we could take lots of pictures and enjoy everything. By the time we left around 10am it was full of tourists, so get there early!

Well maintained garden. We visited this garden after Wong Tai Sin temple. The garden is quite picturesque and well cared for. There were a few displays to look at in addition to the foliage. Unfortunately during our visit, the golden pavilion and red bridge was closed off for renovation. There was a little vegan cafe next to the water wheel which we stopped by and had cheesecakes and smoothies.Great peaceful little garden towered all around by apartment sky-scrapers.

If you have to choose one temple - this is the one. It's beautiful and it is a tiny bit of nature in the middle of the city of skyscrapers. It's a really calm place, perfect for a rest during a day of sightseeing.

should go. It's a good place has alot of trees and awesome rocks and temple and people going there to pray. And also if you live ornaments item will find a good historical ornaments shapes just 20 HKD to entranceYou can get there by subway MTR it's close two metro station and entrance is free
Hong Kong . Loved nan Lian garden it was a lovely sanctuary from the hustle and bustle. You couldn't tell you were in The middle of a city. Would fully recommend it is worth a visit.

Beautiful,Serene & Free!. A visit here was an unexpected highlight of our time in Hong Kong. It is easy to get to being a 5 minute walk from Diamond Hill station. It is stunningly beautiful,and a virtual oasis in the middle of busy Hong Kong. We spent a couple of hours here and only saw a handful of other visitors. There is a restaurant there under a waterfall which looked like a wonderful place to eat but unfortunately we didn't have time.
