The Nunnery was closed when we got there but you can still visit the stunning surrounding gardens. It would be a good idea to check the closing time before you go so you don't miss out!If you are in Hong Kong for more than a couple of days,please include a visit to this stunning place.
Staff wanted you to enjoy. Nice and different on a wet day we were the only walkers in the gardens, the staff pointed out all the highlights a lovely way to spend a wet afternoon

Beautiful, calm oasis in the centre of the city. Came here on recommendation of tripadvisor reviews. Not a huge place at all, took about 20 mins to walk around, but stunningly beautiful and one of the few times we have felt calm after being in Hong Kong! 5 mins walk from Diamond Hill MTR station. I think this is a must for any visit to HK.

Run away from hectic Hong Kong. Very quite and pleasant place to visit. Being there three times and each time it was pretty calm and full of harmony and relaxation. Nice to visit just after opening in the morning. Make your day with gorgeous views....

Absolute Must See Oasis. What an Oasis in the middle of busy HK. The gardens are kept immaculate and so quiet. There are so many photo opportunities with a great selection of plants to see. The Nunnery is also great to look around.
Breathtaking. Words can't express about this absolutely stunning place and it is only a stop away from the Temple which makes it easier to visit two places within a short time
Escape from busy city. Lovely garden and a nice tranquil place away from the bustling city. Easily reached by Diamond Hill MTR. Shopping mall close by for relief from heat.

Zen experience. It was an utopia in the busy town centre.
love the vegetarian food here. worth the visit. one of the must go in hong kong.

Beautiful. The guidebooks tout Big Buddha, but we enjoyed Nan Lian so much more. Peaceful, beautiful oasis - no tourist hype. We were two adults looking for quiet and we found it here. The current special exhibit of cloissone was well worth a stop. We also found the Chi Lin Nunnery very reverential and moving.If you are an adult looking to avoid major over-touristed sites, I'd highly recommend this stop over Big Buddha. The location also makes for easy transportation. Another plus over standing in line for cable car or bus access.

Zenitude in town centre. I justed loved this place, When you enter make sure to pass at the little stand. There are some friendly staff who will give some more info and a little map about the gardens.The place is so well maintained and is just the perfect spot to relax in the middle of Hong Kongs urban jungle.To get there take the MTR to Diamond Hill then at the exit follow the signposts.Free entrance

Beautiful. Although I've been to Hong Kong many times I'd never visited this garden until this year. Wow, it's beautiful. Perfectly manicured gardens, very peaceful, well worth a visit.Very easy to get to, there's a car park and the MTR station opposite. Also, there's no entry fee.
nice nature corner. If you're looking for a nature corner amongst the concrete, this garden is the perfect place. You can take a really nice walk and enjoy the green and the traditional architecture

A place worth visiting!. A lot of tourists skip this place during their visit, however I would totally recommend visiting this gorgeous garden! Hong Kong MTR is super easy and fast and coming to this place is not difficult at all. MTR exit is very close to the entrance to the garden.

Free and a nice walk!. Its a very relaxing walk around to see the modern temples of HK. It is mainly free but you have to pay for some enteries. Get the metro to Diamond Hill and from there it is heavily signposted with a 2 minute walk to the clear entrance from the mall.

nice gardens, one stop from wan tai sin temple. the gardens are relaxing and well-kept.. although quite busy on weekends.. i would bring a hat or sunscreen if traveling in the summer as its really hot and not a lot of shade cover.. one stop from wan tai sin temple (although we walked)
Small, simple gardens across road fron Nunnery. Worth combing visit with Nunnery across road. Close to MTR station. Nice gift shop and Vegetarian restaurant. Recommend seeing.
Fantastic. A must for every Hkg traveller.just prove to yourself that Hkg is not the high rise buildings and all that shopping. It has this fantastic culture right in the middle of Kowloon.

Nan Lian Gardens - simply beautiful. Amidst the hustle and hectic buzz of this incredibly dinamic city, and hidden among the high rise that sprout from every square inch of available land.... is the stunningly beautiful Nan Lian Garden. Managed and cared for by the Chi Lin Nunnery, these gorgeous gardens will have your camera clicking and you mesmerized by their incredible beauty and tranquility. Sit a while in the shade of bonsai trees held in shape by intricate webs of wire and delicately placed cloth........ rest in one of the many gazebos and take in the peace..... be revitalised and gaze out over the Pond of Tranquility...... this really is hard to believe - in the middle of Kowloon peninsula's area of approximately 47 square kilometres (18 sq mi) with a population of over 2.8million people (2014). This accounts for over 50% of Hong Kong's total population (including new territories and HK Island). The gardens are located at 60 Fung Tak Rd, Kowloon, Hong Kong. An easy ride on the MRT Diamond Hill line. After viewing these gorgeous gardens.... go across the road to the huge Hollywood Plaza Shopping Centre for lunch and a refreshing drink....

Tranquility in the City. This is just one of the most beautiful places in HK. Easy to access from the Diamond Hill MTR. It's really a lovely place to visit as a change in pace from the sometime hectic HK. There is a nice little restaurant hidden behind a waterfall, which is just so peaceful. Take your time, don't come in a rush.

A little bit of paradise in the midst of a concrete jungle. A must visit for both tourists and locals. Literally surrounded by high-rises, the garden is the perfect place to go for some peace and quiet, with gorgeous surroundings.

Stunning garden and temple. Visited in March 2014.The gardens are beautiful and well maintained, (had been advised by a self proclaimed guru not to go as they weren't a good representation of a Chinese garden), very glad to have ignored that! Told others on our trip to go, so they, too, visited and were impressed. There were a lot of very good quality penjing (Chinese bonsai), in wonderful traditional southern Chinese pots. The planted gardens were also impressive with a variety of trees and shrubs. It is a tranquil place with not too many visitors the day we were there, even though it was a Saturday. Allow plenty of time as you can walk through to the Chi Lin Nunnery, also with many penjing. There is a very nice café to linger over dumplings and tea. It is easily accessed from Diamond Hill MRT, a 5 min walk.

Beautiful gardens. The Gardens present numerous photo opportunities - popular subjects are the pagoda, red bridge and banyan grove. I was there at about 2 or 3pm on a weekday afternoon. There were a few people taking selfies but it was nowhere near as crowded or touristy as say Ngong Ping.Definitely a recommended visit for anyone who likes taking garden pictures in a less crowded environment. It is also quite easy to get to - just follow the signs from Diamond Hill MTR. It's probably about less than 5 minutes' walk away. Chi Lin Nunnery - another recommended visit - is connected to the Garden via a bridge.

Peaceful and Beautiful. Worth the detour but actually quite quick to get to as it's 5 min away from the MTR station. Remember you are not able to take pictures of the Buddhas. The garden and the pagodas in the adjacent gardens to the temple are beautiful. Really worth taking some pictures and walking inside.

Nice free site in city. This is a very easily accessible site within the city, and it's free! There is a lot of nature all around with different flowers and trees. The yellow temple in the middle is great to photograph against the backdrop of large modern buildings. You can walk through the various trails to get away from the city feeling. This is a site which is close to the Chi Lin Nunnery so you can combine those two sites in around 3 hours.
Must visit. A quiet and great garden with a big nun monestry!Spend more time to visit and take pictures at every corner of the garden!

Hidden Gem in Hong Kong. Even many Hong Kongers do not know about this lavish temple/garden/museum complex, located conveniently outside of a MTR stop. One could drop in for a quick lunch or spend the whole day. The golden pagoda's of some of the buildings take on different hues as the sun sets. There are lovely museums which feature Chinese art forms, some of the exhibits are rotating. 'Tinkerers' will love the architecture museum which features famous historical buildings in miniature and displays the technology which allows them to endure without nails/steel. A vegetarian restaurant is located under a waterfall. The larger temple complex is amazing to tour, or just sit outside and relax, listening to the 'canned' chanting. Check events listing as concerts are often featured in the museum spaces. Although this place is located in the thick of the city, once inside, that city is all but invisible amid the lavish greenery and beautiful buildings.

A peaceful retreat for the busy hong kong tour. According to our tour guide the garden and the nunnery beside it is still new. It was very peaceful there it made us forget how crowded and rushing hong kong was during our tour.

Like a secret garden in the city.... As per reviews from tripadvisor, I especially allotted a day to this place and Chi Lin Nunnery and was happy to really do so... A totally different scenery in the middle of the city... Loved every part of it. Ate at Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant which serves superb good food... Worth the time! A definite must in Hong Kong!

A great place to unwind. It's one of the nicest gardens I have seen. It's a great respite from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong City life. Unfortunately, I could not say that this park is a juxtaposition of the old and the new since this park is also new. So I guess, the cultural significance of this garden can be put in to question. You can argue that it's just a tourist trap. But since you do not have to pay anything to visit it, I guess there is no point in complaining about it. All in all, I loved it here. It's a great place to unwind.

Boon for landscape connoisseurs. Visit the place only if you're not hard pressed on time and can spare half an hour drive from city to enjoy the quiet serene of landscaped garden.Its a nice park with waterfalls, flowers and surrounding Chinese architecture (of no historical value of course). Vegetarians can have tea and food in vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall. Get the directions from entrance and move into the serene greens. The lake is beautiful with bridges and many colored lotuses.

Serenity. We enjoyed this garden as a change of pace from the bustle of Hong Kong. We were greeted at the entrance and given an information map in English. We enjoyed the varying features of this garden.

a nice park in a modern city. It is a nice park consists of waterfall, different flowers surrounding classic Chinese architecture. Easily accessible.If you have time, remember to try the tea and food in that vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall!!!you can enjoy your nice Chinese tea and dim sum while you are watching the waterfall!!!so relaxing!!!

Nan Lian - a green treasure. The gardeners and landscapers have done a fantastic job for the garden. For a start, there is an info counter at the entrance where pamplets about the garden and direction are provided. Next, we were greeted by a wide array of greens - very healthy and well tended plants. The air is fresh . The lake is beautiful, framed by bridges and filled with multi-coloured lotus flowers. Definitely worth a visit! Do drop a generous donation for them to keep up the great work.

Nice garden, but not authentic at all.. The garden is nice, serene, beautifully decorated, and is a good place for people to relax. Yet, this place is so overrated, it is so new, it has little historical content, it has little to do with local culture and life of people in Hong Kong. It is waste of time for visitors to spend half an hour to leave the city and visit it. It is just another nicely built park in Hong Kong.

An oasis in busy Hong Kong. Go there for a nice wander during the afternoon. As soon as you walk through the gates of the Nan Lian gardens, it seems like all the other sounds from the city are erased! They play very subtle music and the gardens are just stunning. Very well taken care of and very peaceful. It does not seem to be a very touristy spot so there is not much hustle and bustle around making it even more relaxing. Bring a book, if you have a few hours to spare and enjoy the amazingly quiet atmosphere. It is really worth a trip

place for relaxation. Just next to Chi Lin Nunnery, there is no reason not to visit it if you go to nunnery. Unlike the nunnery, it is not of Buddhism theme, it is just of Tang's style. Sometimes there will be small exhibition about china culture of Buddhism. It is nice to have a walk here and if you have time try the vegen food there
Amazing. A really good place to visit with lovely scenery away from the busy streets, well worth going especially for taking pictures.
Perfection. Stunning cultural heritage, clean, tidy and free, great pictures and very tranquil, with the serenity of the garden contrasting to the busy city.
well laid out. a great place to visit that is not on the usual tourist map. lovely scenery and relax and enjoy the sights and smells

nan lian garden stroll. i love hongkong gardens, nan lian garden is so beautiful and so easy to find. Just exit diamond hill mtr and follow the signs. This garden is good for you who loves greenery. You will need sometime to sit down and enjoy the view, or else the whole garden is just one short stroll. For those of you who bring kids, make sure they were fed because you can't feed your kids inside this garden. And on the end of your stroll, if you see concrete stairs.. go up because it leads to the other garden (the chi lin nunnery). We missed that one.

A peaceful Chinese garden. A beautiful and very peaceful Chinese garden away from the crowds. I liked the calm atmosphere with quiet Chinese music playing in the background. Don't forget to visit the nunnery across the road.

Beautiful religious sight in Hong Kong. The place is in the middle of the city near an Mtr station so it is very convenient. However, it gets very hot in the summer so be prepare for a good clothing. My body was of sweat after walking around the whole garden.
Pretty Gardens. Not too much too it, but it is very beautiful It and the Chi Lin Nunnery are very close, and together they are well worth the trip and half a day

Easily accessible, no entry charge but nothing out of the world. Nothing too out of the world is my first reaction. I understand that you would be investing a lot of time and effort getting there, keeping that in mind I would say visit the place only if you are done with some of the other main attractions of HK.

Beautiful gardens. If you are visiting the Chi Lin Nunnery, then Nan Lian Garden is a must to visit as well (since they are located next to each other). Beautiful gardens to take a stroll in. Don't forget to check out the lake where there are lots of beautiful and big carps in there.

Very nice garden near Chi Lin. Very peaceful and nice garden near Chi Lin Nunnery
DO the same day Chi Lin, The Garden and Wong Tai Sin temple

We were impressed with the beauty of the well maintained gardens. After a busy day, we recharged with a wander through the gardens and monastery. The gardens is a small oasis in the hustle and bustle of a huge city, and provided welcome relief and a peaceful environment. We couldn't believe such a gem was nestled in the middle of the towers of apartment blocks.

A Tang dynasty style garden in modern Hong Kong. Take the one-way circular route to catch the best views of the Garden. Do not forget to stop and admire the uniquely landscaped rocks and trees. The restaurant serves some elegant vegetarian dishes.
A nice walk. The walk around the gardens is nice, but will probably only take 10-15 minutes. Good to combine with a trip to the nunnery.

Serene Place for kids and elders both. Enjoyed the break at this garden while touring the city.
This place depicts the culture of HongKong and Kids wanted to visit it as they heard Garden.
Nice silent place between the skyscrapers. ;)
Boring. Nan lian garden is similar to the parks in Singapore. There's nothing much to see. Same for chi Lin nunnery which is nearby. Hence, that area is not worth visiting.

Gorgeous. An oasis in the middle of the city. It has only been open a few years but is so worth a visit. Lovely landscaped gardens, lake and lovely traditional buildings. It has lots of visitors, but there are still a few quite places to sit and take in the lovelyness.

Beautiful, Peaceful, and Relaxing. Nan Lian Garden is a beautiful, peaceful, and relaxing oasis in the middle of the city. Walking the path around the pond and the pavilion is a blissful way to spend a few minutes away from the hustle of the city. The adjacent Nunnery is a stunning example of architecture and a breathtaking sight to see. We very much enjoyed our time here.

Serenity abounds!. Amid the backdrop of the public housing this garden is serene and beautiful. The bonsai trees, perfectly manicured gardens and wildlife are a joy to behold and a contrast to the hectic streets of Hong Kong. Not to be missed!

Get away from hustle and bustle for a minute. I went there for taking shots of hero trees, birds and th pavilions in this garden one weekend. Though the Chinese-sytled building and garden designs sound artificial, the garden is a gem right next to Diamondf Hill MTR station for very good after-meal walks and family photography. There are plenty of trees in this walled garden and the pavillions, air-condiitoned exhibition hall and clean environment make this a nice place to visit even in hot summer days. The shop selling Chinese tea leaves and souvenirs do not offer inexpensive goods in general, and the umbrellas are probably the only exceptions. The vegetarian eatery is a small and very decent place offering decent unique dishes including vegetarian dim-sum dishes for diners for lunch. The pond, waterfall and windmill outside the eatery also make a perfect scene for photographic shots.

Nan Liam. A welcome santuary in this otherwise bustling city! The colors of the plant and flowers, the statuary effect as from the plants being cultivated into certain shapes and forms is breath taking.
Supurb Gardens. A must see in the city. Beautifully maintained gardens and history on the architecture. Very peaceful even surrounded by the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong
A MUST VISIT. This garden is located across the road from Chi Lin Nunnery and is connected by an overbridge to it. It is extremely beautiful and has a very good vegetarian restaurant .

Great place to chill. The is a little oasis is a fast moving city. It is hard to believe the road and high rise flats are so close one could almost touch them. It great to wander around or just sit stil while the world rushes on

Very clinical and tidy. Although it is a very nice place to be, it seemed like all the places we wanted to be for a photo opportunity were barred off to the public.It only takes about an hour to see all of it and then you have a shopping mall next door to it.

Tranquility in the middle of HK. Though it is well visited bu tourists it still feels like a peaceful haven in the middle of Kowloon madness. Beautifully manicured with calming music piped alround to dull the sounds of the city.Beneath a waterfall is the excellent vegetrian restaurant. It is very well patronised so get in early for lunch. So worth making the trip.
Landscaped elegantly. At Diamond Hill, so MTR is very handy, or park at Plaza Hollywood and walk over.Landscaped for some photogenic shots just about everywhere. Nice stroll after lunch.
Best garden in HK. Worth the journey all the way to Diamond Hill.One of the most beautiful chinese garden I have seen, in the middle of the buildings of Kowloon

Beautiful. Beautiful & very nicely maintained.Very good photo ops. Good bonsai plants too.
Has a cafeteria but we did not like anything there.
Nov 12

Free and Great!. I went to Nan Lian Garden on my last day before I went to airport as I saw some good reviews of this garden! And yeah I didnt regret spending my last hour in this garden, I just regretted that I spent only short time in this garden. In this garden I felt different feeling compared to Hongkong outside of the garden. Outside, it was big city vibe! But in this garden you can feel amazed by temple, waterfall and by a little bit of peaceful feeling and relax from the garden.
Really nice. Really nice relaxing gardens, some space to have a break, though eating and drinking (except water) is not allowed. Closeby a shoppingmall.

A Beautiful Small Garden but No Selfie Stick Allowed. It's a beautifully well maintained garden that has clean toilets for its visitors.But we could not use our self stick. I understand that these selfie sticks can be a nuisance in a crowd. But when we arrived, it was in the middle of the day in the middle of the week meaning the sun was at its mid day heat and it was in the middle of the work week. Apart from us there were about only 4 other people. A grounds keeper from far away with hawk like vision saw us from the corner of her eye and told us no selfie stick. It would be great if they actually put up a sign at the entrance of the garden. At the time we visited the no selfie stick rule was not part of the list of NOT to do while in the garden but was just part of a hand held list of rules in laminated flash card form for non-Chinese speaking people.

A place of meditation and peace in a city of hustle and bustle. Absolutely the most magnificent gardens , temples and waterways. We watched the old ladies tending devotedly to the gardens while they chatted away together. The variety of plants, shrubs, trees and flowers is incredible. If you are a gardener, you will truly come away with heaps of inspiration..It is immaculately clean , even the bathroom facilities.

Beautiful garden with unhappy security. Hongkong really take good care for their Garden seriously, when i want to put on my tripod the security coming and said that is not allowed, what.....?? it's ok thenthis garden really clean, and beautiful

Beautiful, peaceful and interesting. What struck us about the Nan Lian Gardens initially was how beautifully manicured the gardens were. We soon saw why when we saw the many gardeners weeding and shaping the trees lovingly by hand. The walkways and paths lead you along and around a little lake and there is a vegetarian restaurant on site as well. A lovely way to spend a few peaceful hours.

Blissful. Easy to find but allow as much time as possible. I did not get to see all of it unfortunately due to bad timing so I shall return another time. The restaurant behind the waterfall is a MUST, great spot. The gardens are breathtaking.

what a lovely place. This truly was a haven amongst the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, lovely gardens/grounds with bonsai trees dotted around the place, a large lake area with huge fish in it, even a waterfall with a café by the look of it.They had an exhibition of Chinese and Japanese enamels (1886-1912) while we were there, this was simply stunning, the intricate work the colours were amazing, there was a step by step process In how they were made.

Tranquil Garden in Hong Kong. A short subway ride to Diamond Hill station brings you to a tranquil oasis in busy Hong Kong. The entrance is located under a highway overpass but once you are in the gate you forget all of that. It is a peaceful walk through precise landscaped trees. Do not miss the building with the wooden models of famous temples or the attached Chi Lin Nunnery.

The atmosphere of ancient China. Had a very nice walk here . Air feels very fresh . Nice place to take a pictures.And perfect to bring your children for a walk. Around 10 mintues walk from a metro station. I recommend to visit on the weekend

One of a kind!!. Second visit to the garden. Very gorgeous garden in the city, small compare with victoria park but this one has more to offer. Had lunch and learnt to make our tea in the restaurant. Tea was seved by weigh and favour, pricey but interesting to do the brewing the proper way. Limited choices of food prepared by kitchen each day. Visited the temples across the road as well :)

Must-see. The trip to this place was well worth it. We took the MTR to Diamond Hill and walked for a few minutes to get to this wonderful garden in the middle of busy Hong Kong. This is the perfect place to just marvel at nature and be quiet and at peace. It was a pleasant experience. I do recommend going at around late afternoon as it can get scorching hot in the middle of the day. :)

Don't miss this garden - a must see!. An unbelievably serene and beautiful garden in the heart of Kowloon, in the middle of busy highways, highrise buildings, and a backdrop of mountains. It was very easy to get to via the MRT – Diamond Hill stop and exit C2 – then only a short walk across the street. Although it is a relatively new garden, it opened in 2006, the plants are all mature looking, with rocks and beautiful Chinese architecture in the structures. A great way to enjoy some quiet time in Hong Kong!
a haven of peace. the diamond hill mtr station is where this is located. It is free entrance , and a perfect haven of peace an serenity. The gardens are lovely

Relaxing. Well manicured Chinese grade with magnificent lay out. Use of stones, bushes, trees and wooden buildings, plus evocative music. Makes a very pleasant stroll and ideal spot to meditate or read a book. Inspired backdrop of new Hong Kong. Also next to large shopping complex.
Beautiful park. The park not request ticket but it's so beautiful and quiet. I can saw a lot of birds in here. Guard staff are friendly.

Best Garden in HK. Nan Lian Garden is a Chinese garden with golden pavilion, beautiful ponds, waterfalls, a stone exhibit, and other attractions. It's well-manicured and offers great views on the garden itself and the surrounding HK high-rises with the garden in the background. The place is only 3 min walk from Chi Lin Nunnery and they really complement each other for a great visit.

Pretty and Peaceful. This is a lovely place to get away from the bustle and traffic. It's not huge, so an hour or two is all you need to take in the garden and the nunnery next door. The veggie restaurant in the garden does fantastically interesting food, and is well worth a lunch stop.

Garden Oasis. Was amazed that this oasis existed in bustling Hong Kong. A very beautiful and picturesque place with waterfalls, bridges and lovely buildings. The gift shop has a great variety of souvenirs. Well worth the visit.

My favorite spot in HK!. A beutiful and soothing place amidst the hustle and bustle of the city outside. I wish we could have stayed longer and sat in one of the pavilions and just take in the intricate garden and the elegant wooden architecture around it. This place is not your usual tourist trap and if you are in HK it's worth a visit. Entrance is free and is accessible as it's just a couple of minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR.Chi Lin Nunnery is adjacent to the garden it's a temple complex with beautiful lotus ponds, bonsai and temple halls with Buddhist artifacts display.
Lovely place. One of the best places to visit. Calm and serene and very beautiful. Don't miss this garden. It also has a vegetarian restaurant serving amazing food at reasonable prices.

Underrated Oasis - definitely well worth visiting. These beautiful gardens only got a passing mention in our UK guide book as being adjacent to the more publicised Nunnery, with which they do connect. But they certainly merit a visit in their own right. So peaceful especially by contrast with HK generally.As well as the lake, manicured trees, bushes and precision positioned rocks you would expect of oriental gardens, there was a building containing 1:30 scale models of significant wooden architecture - mainly ancient temples - and another called a "Rockery" which is in fact just that, a display of rocks - not quite sculptures, but very attractive. Sounds dull but really wasnt. A nice little gift shop had some smaller rocks for sale but quite expensive!There was also a very exclusive looking tea house overlooking the lake, but unless we misread the price list it was very expensive and presumably only for real tea connoisseurs.

Nan Lian Gradens. Beautiful. Manicured to perfection. Walking around the gardens one could think you were in Heaven. There are Pagodas, waterfalls and picturesque garden beds. Definitely, worth a visit.

Grand escape and wonderful food!. This garden and vegetarian restaurant are amazing. It was so peaceful and interesting. Go early before it gets hot, admission is free!The restaurant opens only at noon and the food is great mix of dim-sum, mushroom dishes and soups.
Hidden Gem. Very peaceful and only few tourist are visiting the place. The place is absolutely maintained well. Would love to comeback here with a love one. :)
beautiful. Beautiful and nice garden to visit and a good place for sightseeing but just the weather is too hot during my visit.

A beautiful horticultural garden in Hong Kong. You board the MRT cross harbour route from the Central Station and transfer at the Mongkok Station to the East Kowloon route, then alight at the Diamond Hill Station, Exit through C-2, and then cross the Sheung Yuen Road, you will reach the Nan Lian Garden. This is a very special garden with plenty of luxuriant topiary trees, flowers, and birds. It has a peaceful and quiet atmosphere, away from the busy life of Hong Kong. There are many photogenic views for taking photos and seats for people to rest. Also there is a garden restaurant nestled in offering foods and drinks. The Chi Lin Nunnery is only minutes away. This is a sacred quiet place for the Guan Yin Bodhisattva, full of serenity and tranquillity, good for buddhist worshippers, local visitors and tourists paying respects.

Temple of Heaven. Wonderful temple and a pure vegetarian Chinese restaurant nestled in the garden. A must visit and it is very popular amongst foreigners. Easy to reach here. Take the MTR towards Kwung Tong line and get off at Diamond Hill station exit C. Only3 mins walk from the station to this wonderful nunnery....

A very special garden with plenty of topiary trees and a very good vegetarian restaurant. This is a little gem by the Diamond Hill MTR station. Very special and a tranquil place to visit especially if you are interested in topiaries and rock gardens. The garden is designed with the principles by a famous Tang Dynasty poet "the design of the garden should suit the people who use it, taking into consideration the environment and to celebrate the beauty of nature." There are also ponds with many koi carps. The garden is part of the Chin Lin Nunnery and there is also a very nice vegetarian restaurant which is set behind a man-made waterfall. Very unusual setting but special. The menu is very simply but the dishes are delicious. Booking a table in advance is recommended as lunch finishes at 3 pm.

Peaceful. Just accross Diamond Hill metro station, free of charge, this garden is really beautiful. Not a huge place, an easy promenade to visit it entirely Although in the city, if you don't look behind the trees (high buildings) you can imagine yourself walking in some rural place. No need to be knowledgeable in chinese traditional architecture to appreciate the final effect of this place: it is peaceful, beautiful, relaxing. Birds shirping, sound of fountains, small bridges, typical pavilions and a large variety of banzai trees. I didn't try the tae house not the vegetarian restaurant. The souvenirs boutique worth a visit, I bought bookmarkers, beautifully done. A nice small gift, easy to transport. The nunnery is in the same place, just go upstairs behind the store. Being in this area, you can also take the MTR and go visit Sik Sik Yuen Wong Tai Sin temple (wong tai sin station exit B) for it's vibrant atmosphere where faith is noticeable.

Stunning Garden. We combined a visit to the Nan Lian Garden with the Chi Lin Nunnery. We found the garden to be absolutely stunning and surprising as when you look around the garden is surrounded by tower blocks and is tranquility in the middle of a busy city. Highlights were the pavilion of absolute perfection sat in the middle of a lotus pond, the rockery, the mill plus waterwheel, waterfall and lakes. We spent a couple of hours wandering around the garden, which was not crowded or busy, discovering the gems as we walked around. We stopped for a drink in the cafe, which was good and the souvenir shop was also good. If you visit over lunchtime the restaurant looks good as the waterfall flows out onto the restaurant building and you get a good view of the waterwheel. A really pleasant way to spend a couple of hours on a sunny day.

Simply stunning. The manicured gardens, and buildings make this a special place to visit.The views of the gardens with the high rise buildings of Hong Kong in the background are amazing.Its a ovely peaceful place to visit and a stark contrast to the rest of Hong Kong

Impressive. Impressive even on a rainy day! A secret garden in a bustling city! Never expected a golden treasure in the urban jungle of Hong Kong! How I wish we have the same attraction here in our country.

Refreshing , relaxing , and very near city shopping mall!. Love the small ponds with frogs and turtles in it! We love the lush plants and flowers in the garden! The entrance is already magical! And most of all the view of the city and it's tall buildings from this garden is awesome!

Feng Shui at its best. OK Three times I visit Hong Kong and each time for longer.It is not possible to talk of Nan Lian Gardens without the symbiotic relationship of Nunnery to which it joins.It is free but please donate.I have waited to do this review because when I went in November the Pagoda was covered in plastic for renovation. Now in May 2015 all is clear to view.This was very first place i ever visited in Hong Kong as I was using the Discover Hong Tourist Board's Walks brochure.So I give a plug to HKTB online travel kit for heaps of e booklets and mobile apps.Because if you go to these gardens and adjacent nunnery at Diamond Hill MTR (come out you see it to left) then you have to go to next MTR to see one of best temples in Hong Kong which I think is called Wong Tai Sin.These three are three off the closest, highest quality, sites in Hong Kong so take many camera batteries.The Gardens are beautiful from every angle, immaculately cared for they show water worn stratified jasperoid rocks interspersed with manicured gardens, bonsai trees, well pruned full trees,water running and still, fish life,routes through the gardens pass by features and some pay exhibitions.The only drawback for me was not minding to pay for exhibitions, but no photos.Sad about that.Photos elsewhere in gardens are OKPlaces to eat cater to all from those seeking experience of a true tea house treatment, a snack place or vegetarian restaurant plus others.This is a place to bring people to impress and for tranquility.To propose, meet with loved ones, walk hand in hand - escape the bustle and close amicable business deals.I do not ever include pictures of places so as not to spoil the visit.But I do include pictures that may help make decisions like menus, maps etc.There are plenty of images on Google if you want to spoil your personal experience first hand.I just visited the Gardens etc yesterday and one special thing I must say is that if looking to buy quality value for money presents that I think the small to medium sized shop in these Gardens is best option in Hong Kong followed by Stanley Market.At low end fridge magnets are exquisite ceramic copies of ink paintings, pictures of great quality and in lacks of 5 for around HK$38 they represent ideal presents in size, weight, quality and usefulness.At the high end is jewelry,ceramic works,silks etcThe exhibit of woodwork and models of buildings once again is no photos but free and very special.To sum up this park it is all about perfection and dedication in care and that fastidious asian artisan nature to spend time to make enduring works of visual beauty.Look I love Hong Kong Park to bits but the difference between there and Nan Lian I think is that the former is meant to be highly charged places always changing to provide weekend variabilty to those with days off.HK Park is meant to be a charged atmosphere where as Nan Lian is at other end of scale and I think visiting both may be explained better by others in their own way.I get a buzz from both but I like seeing the interaction of people at HK Gardens.Children get more enjoyment at HK gardens that is for sure it is a total family experience.

Beautiful garden to combine with the Chi Lin Nunnery. this is one of the places in Hong Kong where you come to get away from the hustling city. Only 5 minutes walk from the MTR station, you can enjoy this garden, very well maintained. After strolling around just cross the street and combine it with a visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery

Surprising !. Its surprising that such a place exists in a noisy city that is so full of people busy with their everyday life. Its really a place where one can meditate in HK. Very well kept place. V good variety of plants with all the explanations. Sky-scrapers in the background spoils the place a bit else it would have been a 5 star rating for me. still a 4 star and a must visit in HK !

Beautiful and tranquil - amazing place. Loved how quiet this place was in the middle of the hustle & bustle of Hong Kong - the sound barriers were very efficient in making you feel you were out in the countryside. The gardens are perfectly manicured with attractive Buddha Pines throughout and the traditional buildings (some dating back to medieval times).The gardens reminded me of the Chinese art you see so much of with the Pagodas and beautifully shaped trees, ponds and Koi Carp

Beautiful garden. The place is well maintained and once you enter the garden, read the rules at the entrance gate. Monopod or tripods are not allowed inside the garden. The place was full of plants and flowers. It was peaceful even it was situated in the city.

Must see. Loved these gardens. It rained the day we went but I'm so glad it didn't put us off. The bonus was the gardens were deserted. What a special place, a pure oasis in the middle of a sprawling city. Definitely the highlight of our trip. Amazing photographs with a sky scraper backdrop. Superb.

Absolutely beautitul. It rained and sort of 'spoilt' my visit. Still, as one of the workers whom I spoke to said, a rainy day has its own beauty. Such a profound wisdom! It gave a new meaning to the photos I took which were somewhat "downcast" (caused by the lack of sufficient light for my camera) but I suppose the word 'downcast' should be expunged from my vocabulary now and be replaced with "another depiction of nature's beauty".Nan Lian Garden is actually linked to Chi Lin Nunnery, so you can visit two places on one trip. It was not until I left the garden then I realised that the overhead bridge was actually the link between them. I had actually entered Chi Lin Nunnery on one side of the road, and came out from Nan Lian Garden on the other side of the road! LOL!The landscaping was simply beautiful and very well maintained. I would recommend spending an hour or so strolling around to wind down, if you have been doing too much shopping in downtown Hong Kong.

Peaceful. Such a beautiful peaceful place! It was nice to get away from the shopping malls and traffic of Hong Kong and into this garden. I would describe it as a typical oriental garden, a good place to take a breath of fresh air and a nice walk.

It's a gem!. We're happy to find Nan Lian garden. It's a breath of fresh air from amusement parks and shopping malls of Hong Kong. Nan Lian Garden is so picturesque. Visit here early in the morning or towards late afternoon, it was mid-day and the weather was so hot when we went there, which made us feel uncomfortable. Nevertheless, we still enjoyed our visit in Nan Lian.
beautiful. amazing and peaceful yet surrounded by flyovers and the hustle and bustle of the city,,, a must visit
lovely garden. the morning we visited Nan Lian Garden, we just came to early. Even though they welcome visitors at 7 am, but the main part is open to visitors at 10 am.

Combined with Chi Lin this is a beautiful half-day outing. It is surprising what you can find at Diamond Hill. When you leave the MTR you will come up at Hollywood Plaza - then just across the road you will find a stunning Buddhist monastery and a gorgeous park garden.The gardens are stunning and definitely worth a visit.There are also a couple halls in the gardens displaying beautiful stone and showing amazing architecture from the past and how it was constructed.A truly beautiful park.

Unexpected peace.... Nan Lian Garden & Chi Lin Nunnery are situated next to one another. When I viber-ed photos to friends who frequent Hongkong for shopping, their question was: "where are you???"If you take the MTR to Diamond Hill, follow the exit signs and you'll alight in a mall. As you exit, turn left (where there are public toilets) towards the intersection. Just cross the pedestrian lane and you'll be at one of the garden entrances.

A mystic green island in the city. Simply fantastic.If you spend a day in Hong Kong find one hour to visit this "mystic" garden.it's all very very treat. every stone, every tree are positioned in the "accurate position".to be see

Loved it. Tranquil place in the middle of a chaotic area. Take MTR to Diamond Hill and follow the signs. Keep at it because at first you think it has to be wrong, major road, overpass etc. But then after 5 minutes walk or so, you are here.Lovely setting, pagoda, water wheel and ponds as well as some beautiful landscaped areas. Just wander around and enjoy. Good for photos. One of the halls had a Japanese ceramics exhibition on - very interesting. No fee to enter.If you are anywhere near, worth a look.

PEACEFUL OASIS. Considering this garden in under one of the many HK flyovers, it is so quiet and peaceful and full of wildlife. Very well-cared for and beautifully manicured trees as well as the rockeries, topiary and watermill. Good cafe and shop as well. A great place away from the hustle of HK.

Serene place in Diamond hill. Went this May and loved the place, The Golden Pagoda was nice though you cant take picture in the bridge because it has barricade. There is a water mill, mini falls over a vegetarian restaurant. The plants was really interesting. If you like taking photos on your trip this place is recommended. PLUS if you are looking for hidden nature in the city. This might be what you are looking for. They also have a nice souvenir shop inside.
A complement to the temple. Serene surroundings, a restful place, with natural beauty and beautiful plants and trees. Loved by families and tourists alike.

Nice Visit for an Hour!. The garden is very pretty and awesomely stuck between high rises and a highway. The juxtaposition of the natural beauty and modern development is uniquely Chinese. It isn't a large garden and only requires an hour or so to visit. Considering it is right off the train and next to the the Nunnery and near Sik Sik Yuen, it is worth about stop for sure!

Well worth it. This is situated near the Diamond Hill MTR station on the Green line hence quite easy to find. The garden opens at about 7.00am and it is worth doing it early in the morning as it is not too hot and quite tranquil. The garden is divided into 5 key areas based on the horticulture and is a peaceful walk to start the day with. There is also a Rockery & another hall that holds miniature wooden architectural models that open at 10am. The garden is said to be a Tang dynasty style landscaped garden.The highlight is the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection which is a site to behold on its own and even in the setting o the garden and the sky scrapers not too far off.They seem to not like people using tripods for photographs hence better check before you do. Beautiful location to capture some nice clicks.A scenic location with a serene atmosphere that does not take too much time to cover is a must add to your itinerary. Can combine with the Chi Lin Nunnery.

Oasis in the middle of city. Tranquility oozes from each rock, pond and plant. The setting is peaceful and there are less visitors than other attractions. You can take time to admire how the buildings and the rocks are placed along the garden. The water mill and water fall provides the only noise in the garden. Even the gift shop sells interesting stuff. Stroll along and take your time to hear birds sing. Visit the temple across the street first, then walk around and see the lilies, the bridges, the kiosks and the gold fish. It would cleanse your soul.
Tranquility in Kowloon. Beautiful gardens in the city. Nice walks. Very quiet, especially for HK. Wonderful varieties of flora. Nice birds. Excellent respite from the hubbub

picturesque. near the MTR, get off at diamond hill and follow the pink signs. you can see the entire grounds in 1 or so, then go to the nunnery for more things to see. a must do while in hong kong. theres a restaurant, bathrooms, gift shop...etc inside.

Beautiful and large. It seems you could get lost in this garden. It's very beautiful, though there are not many flowers, it's not that type of garden. It was pretty crowded while we were there which was kind of a bummer, it's hard to feel peaceful when surrounded by a crowd. It's still worth a visit, and I hear that the vegetarian restaurant on premises is the best in Hong Kong.

Pretty gardens with many attractions. These gardens are right across the road fro the Chi Lin Nunnery and we visited them after the Nunnery. They are beautifully landscaped and have many features in them. There are many pretty vistas (lake, bridges, pavilions, pagoda), thus there are many people taking pictures with these backdrops. We were there Sunday and although busy was not annoying. There is a gift shop, a gallery (at the time showing a Chinese enamelware exhibition) which has a cover charge, clean public toilets, a small café and a restaurant. There is even an area of tables and chairs to sit out under the trees, not that plentiful in Hong Kong ! We ate lunch in the Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant which was average (see separate review). It was very popular and crowded. We got the last table at 11:30am and after that people were queuing.

Beautiful garden! Visit all the different pavilions. The golden pagoda is the centerpiece. Take your time to walk down all the winding paths and visit the various pavilions. There is a beautiful teahouse in the middle, however, it's extremely expensive (in my mind - $200 HKD for 5g serving!?). Though I hear their tea are high end. They enforce a minimum charge per visitor.Otherwise, enjoy the park for free. There is a restaurant on the grounds. Bring a bottle, there are water fountains to allow for refilling of your own bottle!

Great gardens in the middle of the city. Wow, what a gorgeous and quiet retreat in the middle of busy Kowloon. These gardens and their golden temple were gorgeous. Hoped to stop for tea but the prices for tea were VERY high. Too high for us to stop. Nice gift shop had plenty of wares, we took a few home with us.

great park to visit in tandem with chi lin nunnery, but no places to sit and enjoy. visited park and nunnery together. its a nice park, but not enough places to sit - i tried to find someplace to sit down and have lunch, but i couldnt find any. i think this is one way to keep the park clean. the gift shop was a bit expensive as well
A little oriental haven in Hong Kong. The gardens are full of beautifully manicured little trees and shrubs, with clear ponds full of colourful koi fish. And it's free! Worth a visit.

A must do. We were recommended this by the tourist information office in HongKong and we are so very pleased we we went. Its easy to negotiate the MTR to the Nan Lian Garden....it is truly beautiful....very quiet and tranquil...well worth a visit and its free

Scenic and Cultural Sightseeing Spot. The place is clean, beautiful and very green. There are guards checking up on visitors at all times. The artifacts are maintained in top conditions and the visitors are well behaved. Tranquility and pleasant atmosphere throughout the temple. Great job.

Peaceful and beautiful place. Place to be if you need rest from big city, very calm and pasific garden, few people. There we found the exhibition of Chinese and Japanese art on vases and plates. Highly recommend it
Nice garden and convienient for travellers, Next to MTR. Recommend to take night pictures using tripod, water features like the waterfall and the wheel projected by the lightings are great
This is not why you come to hk. If you are interested in geo stuff - just go to outside island, this is basically a complimentary plantation due to the guilt of property developers

Fantastic looking gardens. Exquisitely maintained gardens. Absolutely lovely. Not too crowed which allowed plenty of good photos. Easy to get to from Diamond Hill metro station. Well worth a visit. Definitely visit the Chi Lin Nunnery next door when you are finished here.
Beautiful gardens. The gardens are well kept and beautiful. You can see the skyline of HK within the gardens but once inside the grounds it is so peaceful and quiet.
Well worth a detour. A tranquil spot in the middle of a busy part of town. take the MTR to Diamond Hill and follow the signs. Peace amid the bustle, but shopping close by too!

excellent. Quiet and zen in the middle of the big city. Beautifull place.
Nothing bad, not so much tourist and easy to go and find.

Combine with Chi Lin Nunnery for a pleasant escape from the city. Both the gardens and the Nunnery are connected by an overhead bridge and we combined our visit to the Nunnery with the Nan Lian Garden. Like the Nunnery the gardens and meticulously manicured, with a stunning display of bonsai trees and neat landscaping. You can walk around the garden easily following a circular path which takes you past ponds, pavilions, ancient rockeries and bridges, all complimenting each other. Although there were quite a few people here, it is a peaceful and serene place and one where people respect this atmosphere. It is easy to reach the garden by MTR to Diamond Hill. The route to the garden is well sign-posted and you don't need to book a tour to go there.

Beautiful Oasis of gardens, water features and tea house. Loved the gardens, the meandering paths and falling waterfall outside the restaurant in the heart of the gardens. Easy to get to on public transportation, good facilities, a nice small museum and beautififul relaxing areas for travelers to rest and enjoy the beauty of the gardens. Visit the Chi Lin Nunnery next door!
Very beautiful and Tranquill. In the summer this is a great venue to visit with its well groomed japanese gardens and nunnery. not so good out of season

Wonderful escape from the busy city. I loved the peace that characterized this park. In addition the music that you could hear throughout the visit made the sightseeing even more special.I highly suggest a quick visit to this religious park!

Worth the time to check out. A short stroll across the road from the nunnery is this beautiful manicured garden. So the pagoda in the middle is a little ostentatious with the bright orange bridges, The rest of the gardens are just wonderful to wander through and relax especially considering the amount of traffic just a short walk in any direction you will find.
Nice visit. A nice stroll I had through these gardens. It was a rainy and cold day so I found solitude in a nice cafe and drank green tea. A little gem I found in HK
A nice experience.. Looks a bit synthetic but especially the garden is a very nice experience. A quiet oasis in Hong Kong. definitely worth a visit.
A beautiful oasis in the city. It's really easy and quick to get to this beautiful garden and it's plants, rocks and winding paths are perfect to relax the soul. We loved going here.

Loved, Loved, Loved this Garden!!. Loved loved loved this beautiful, peaceful gem in the midst of a hustle bustle great big city such as Hong Kong. It is romantic, perfectly coiffed and very very neat and clean. People enjoying it's wonderful lure, but not crowded for such a great place. What I enjoyed the most were two things. The many pictures that I loved taking were so classic asian backgrounds and they turned out to be some of the most beautiful photos from the whole trip. The other thing, I was just fascinated by the fact that it was free! They have a very lovely gift shop where I found a simply perfect special piece of jewelry which I just loved. The garden is just a few steps away from a large shopping mall. If you are on a cruise, the shuttle lets you off at that mall, so if you get off there, don't miss a visit to this near perfection of a garden. The garden is not too large, where you get too tired, I thought it was just the right size, especially to take that break from other activities. Don't miss it and don't forget your camera. You will love it too!

Excellent place to visit - Free entry. Brilliant place for visitors to lace around and enjoy the wonderful beautiful settings.Backdrop of old and new fused together with mountainous background and the Nunnery backdrop.Spectacular.Best - free entry and next to DiamondHill MTR

Don't miss this while you are visiting Hong Kong. This has quickly become our favorite walking park in Hong Kong. The Gardens are pristine. The smells are great, the scenery is great, the peacefulness is great. Don't miss it.Read more here: http://www.peanutsorpretzels.com/5-free-things-to-do-in-hong-kong/

Quite a Find! Something special in Hong Kong.. Something quite special in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong! Best time to visit would be before sunset and stay during and after.....the Gardens look lovely at night with all the lights! The nunnery provides for some great photos and there are some interesting historic buildings with historic items in them! Lovely for a nice afternoon stroll - no smoking in the Gardens so very clean!

A peaceful garden in the madness of Hong Kong. I really like that garden because of it's quiet and peaceful atmosphere. The monastery is attached to the garden so you can visit both at the same time. Be sure to go there early because part of the monastery closes at 4.30pm and after 5.30 you can only access the garden. The gift shop is also a stop to do when there, they have beautifull little things like silk scarf, bags… perfect for gift and the majority of the benefit goes to the nunnery and a plus prices are very reasonable.I haven't tried the vegetarian restaurant there but I heard it was ok.
Beautiful and serene. Such a busy city, such a lovely peaceful setting, easy to get to with historic temple right next door. Gardens a dream and so well looked after

Wonderful. This beautiful garden is just across the road from the Chi Lin Nunnery and is a calm and relaxing place to visit. There is a vegetarian restaurant and a great little cafe too. We went back to visit after dark as it's all lit up and there's music playing in the background. Very atmospheric and a photographer's dream.

Lovely garden amid all the bustle of Hong Kong. I was taken here as part of a tour of Kowloon and the garden and attached nunnery is one of the nicest things I've seen in Hong Kong. The nunnery is beautiful with lovely buildings and statues. The garden is very easy to see with a path going round the whole site - you can't miss anything. There are lovely ponds, bridges, and Chinese buildings to see with lovely views all over. There is also an architectural museum - quite small but fabulous, with large hand-crafted wooden models of many famous Chinese structures, built exactly as the originals - stunning workmanship to see and very beautiful. To top it all, the garden is free to visit!!

Quiet oasis in bustling Hong Kong. The 'noise' of Hong Kong stops as you walk through the entrance gate of this peaceful garden. Beautifully maintained with golden pagoda in centre. Well worth a visit.

Oustanding traditional Chinese garden. Loved this somewhat new garden that I discovered from TripAdvisor recommendations. The whole area is pristine with all of the plants neatly groomed. buildings polished, and grounds super clean. The placement throughout of rocks, structures, and other items showed how much care was taken to make the place. Many staff on hand to help with questions but to also make sure you don't do anything to disturb the serenity. A big recommend here as it's a one of a kind zen area that really lifts your spirits.
worth going to. lovely gardens near to a busy shopping plaza. spent an hour strolling around, feeling calm ad peaceful

So Beautiful. This is a beautiful, very well kept Chinese garden. Lot of trees, waterfalls, bonsai display and a Golden Pagoda in the middle. There is a vegetarian restaurant and a gift shop. We found them very tranquil and lovely to walk around. Very close to Diamond Hill MTR station and a few minutes by walk from there, following the signs. Entrance is free. It is worth a visit.

Wonderful Garden. I was initially worried that since this was a newer city garden, the atmosphere would feel sterile and forced. That was not the case. You can immediately tell that a lot of time, money, and positive energy was put into creating Nan Lian Garden. Everywhere you walked was absolutely beautiful. Everywhere you pointed your camera was a splendid picture opportunity. Even the high rise buildings in the background created a great juxtaposition between the old and new traditions. I highly recommend both Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden as a free afternoon Hong Kong excursion.
nan lian garden. very next to chi lin nunnery, very beautiful place to visit, right in the middle of the city, next to hollywood plaza
Make time to visit the vegetarian restaurant. A calm retreat in the city. The restaurant serves some delicious and interesting vegetarian dishes. The gardens are easily reached by the MTR.

Beautiful and peaceful. I spent just under an hour walking around with my four year old son, and it was beautiful and tranquil ... Despite me having to tell him every five minutes not to step on the grass or climb on the rocks (garden rules!). A great escape from the hustle and bustle.

If You Like Cloud Trees!. This is gem amongst all the hustle and bustle of Kowloon, you do not need to love trees to enjoy this beautifully kept garden, to call it a garden is an understatement, it contains wonderful cloud trees, a small Pagoda and lakes, completely free but you are not allowed to eat or drink although there are restaurants and cafes, also conveniences.To get here follow the recommendations of fellow TripAdvisor review under heading of Wonderful Golden Pagoda by SachseTX, or from Kowloon Ferry a taxi will only cost you less than £10 which you may find easier.However you decide please make the effort to find these gardens, truly amazing.

Rocks and Trees With a DIfference: Incredible. I finally discovered this incredible garden (and the attached Nunnery) on my 3rd trip to Hong Kong, thanks to a group of expat teachers we met in the Stanley Market. The gardens have become one of my favourite places in Hong Kong and I definitely recommend a visit to the gardens to future travellers. As others have said, they are very serene.Nevertheless, I was most fascinated by the "architecture" of the gardens. The trees have been perfectly sculptured and the rocks placed to create a long lasting images. Do not miss the incredible rocks from Dahua County and other regions of China. Words can not fully describe the beauty of this Garden. Perhaps, the best thing one can do for free in Hong Kong. There is also a great souvenir store with interesting artwork (handout paper, paintings, etc), tea cups, and rocks (yes rocks).

A sanctuary for the mind and soul. Our family greatly enjoyed the peaceful serenity of the Nan Lian garden, and the fact that it is free is even more amazing. One tip is to walk to the nearby mall to catch a taxi since it is difficult to catch one from the Garden.

Wonderful Golden Pagoda and Amazing Golden Buddha. We took the MTR train to Diamond Hill station and used the C2 exit to Plaza Hollywood. We walked about 5 minutes to the Nan Lian Garden garden. The golden pagoda is wonderful. The garden is beautiful. We walked uphill from the golden pagoda to Chi Lin Nunnery. The golden Buddha is amazing. We came back to complete the tour of Nan Lian garden.

An oasis of quiet in a city that never stops. These gardens provided a wonderful oasis of quiet after a week of busy touring. It was very well maintained and the facilities were good. It was a pity that the tea tasting was quite expensive and we opted for a very cheap cold drink at the snack shop. The architectural display was excellent and it is an easy walk around for all ages. A pleasant souvenir shop sold local and imported items.

A little gem. Like the neighbouring Chi Lin Nunnery, the Nan Lian Garden is an enclave of peace and quiet. Quite an achievement given it's proximity to the rest of bustling Kowloon. The garden layout is pretty traditional with water features, rock formations and sculpted trees. All very photogenic. We didn't get a chance to eat there, but the garden has a (vegetarian) restaurant. Diners looked out from behind a waterfall. Can't comment on the food, however. Definitely worth a visit.

Serene but surrounded by concrete jungle. You need to keep your view selective in order to enjoy this place. While the garden itself is very beautiful and worth spending the evening, do expect to catch partial view of the tall ugly buildings around it. Unless you can selectively ignore it. I could not. Thats why an average rating fir an otherwise excellent place.
Good to go~~. Nice place to visit from the daily routine life.Very peaceful inside. good to spend some time roaming inside the garden.

Nan Lian Garden. This garden-complex is situated across the street from Chi Lin Nunnery and can easily be reached from the nunnery by crossing a bridge.The gardens are well-kept with many exotic trees, plants and flowers. Little ponds , a bright red bride and yellow-golden pagoda's contrast with the geen of the garden.Their is also a museum where you can admire some antic fine woodwork;A beautifull place to relax from the hectic Hongkong life.
Worthwhile visit for an hour or so.. Lovely little gardens bringing a nice bit of peace and quiet amongst busy Hong Kong. No entrance fee, worthwhile visiting, will only need an hour.
Nan Lian Garden Hong Kong. Beautiful scenic garden nestled among modern buildings in Hong Kong.Soft Chinese lyrics were playing as you strolled through Banyon treed pathways

Tranquil. The Nan Lian Garden was very tranquil and beautiful. If you enjoy looking at beautiful gardens and bonsais this is it. Shame people are not allowed into some of the buildings but you understand and respect that. There's also a souvenir shop, a teahouse and a vegetarian restaurant there.

A charming garden in the city. Much of Hong Kong has greenery despite the soaring skyscrapers, but this is a very large, beautifully landscaped garden. It has waterfalls, a large pond, pagoda-like pavilions, interesting banyan-like trees, and curved bridges. We were there at night, after eating at Chi Lin restaurant. It's very romantic at night, but they close off certain sections, and you could probably see more in the daytime. An added attraction: flocks of white birds circling overhead.
Lovely, calm place. this garden adjecant to the chi lin nunnery is nice for a chill walk in this otherwise so hectic city. They also serve some snacks and lunch if you need a refill :D

Lush greenery among the concrete jungle. It is a place where the hustle and bustle of the city is relegated to the background. It is elegantly spread with beautiful Chinese architectural buildings, a small waterfall, a small pond with fishes(which my son loved).
So peaceful. Surrounded by the hustle and bustle of Kowloon, this garden is truly paradise. A must for any visitor to escape the skyscrapers and people.

Beautiful Chinese garden in the middle of the city. Go to Diamond Hill MTR station to visit this garden. Entrance is free.
There are interesting pavilions on stone, timber, and Chinese architecture.
Visit also adjacent Chi Lin nunnery.

Well worth visiting this beautiful little treasure of a garden. It is easy to find outside the Diamond Hill rail stn.. Many beautiful bonsai trees, perfect buildings with bridges, wonderful vegetarian café under a waterfall.

Hidden Gem. We had intended to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery and were surprised to find this beautiful gem of a garden across it. Feels like a set of a movie where actors would wire-fu to walk across the pond or leap from tree to tree. The other structures also have rock formations of semi-precious stones on display, I believe wood fossils and some calligraphy scrolls too. A definite must-visit, doesn't cost a thing and near an MTR station.

A Beautiful garden.. Another oasis in a busy city.Across an overpass from the nunnery is the beautifll Chinese garden,carefully laid out and easy to walk around, the bird life is alive and well too. there are two displays well worth going through, one on Chinese stone, the other miniture Chinese buildings dating back over a centuries and so well made it is breath taking, no photography there though.This is well woth a visit when in Hong Kong

Gorgeous garden even in the mist. We thoroughly enjoyed the lush landscape of this garden surrounded by the skyscrapers of suburban Hong Kong, however, our photos would have been more dramatic on a clear day. Worthwhile along with the Chi Lin Nunnery across the road. It was 7 stops on the Metro from Victoria Harbor in Kowloon but was easy on an early Sunday morning.

... plus the Chi Lin Nunnery, a must for nature fans. An unbelievably beautiful and silent place in the middle of this vibrant district of Hongkong. I especially recommend taking many many pictures of the lovely and thoroughly well-kept trees and rocks.
Beautiful. we managed to get there 9:30 and it was empty before the tourists pour in. worth the visit for sure.

Lovely Garden. Nan Lian Garden and the adjacent Hammer Hill Park were pleasantly landscaped with casually winding paths, lovely plants, complementary landforms, and so on. Depending on your level of interest in such things, it might be a very short visit. We spent about an hour and a half between these two and Chi Lin Nunnery. The beautiful red-whiskered bulbuls were all about; you could hear their remarkable song even if you didn't see them.

Beauty and Calm. By far, the calmest place I have ever visited in HK! It offers lush greens, manicured lawns and the most beautiful structures! It is nearby Diamond Hil station and Plaza Hollywood mall, you will never get lost finding the garden because of the abundance of street signs both in Chinese and English. It is also a few steps away from Chi Lin Nunnery, which also offers a quiet respite in the middle of a bustling city. It is best visited in the morning, because you can have the garden to yourself. :) I highly recommend HK tourists to spare some time in their itinerary to pay this place a visit!

A beautiful haven. Although it's a bit further away from the main areas of the city than say Kowloon or Hong Kong parks, the Diamond Hill MTR station is just across the road from the entrance, so it's easy to get there and well worth the extra journey time. The gardens are beautifully maintained and the pagodas and water features are stunning and provide a haven of calm relaxation among the high rise buildings. The food and drinks seemed a little expensive, but as it's free to get in, I suppose they have to recoup their running costs somehow and so I don't think you can complain. But if you're on a really tight budget it's probably cheaper to buy a drink or snack from the Hollywood Plaza next to the MTR station.w

Truly an oasis within the highrise jungle. Nan Lian Garden is true peace, with even the sounds of nearby freeways, high-rises and schools fading away. The garden areas are perfectly manicured, the golden pagoda stunning in the sunlight and the exhibits are beautiful (currently there is a ceramic & china exhibit). I take everyone that comes to visit Hong Kong to the garden as it is my favorite place in all of Hong Kong. If you are in town for more than 1-2 days and you want a moment to reflect, relax and see true beauty, please go to Nan Lian Garden. It is very easy to get to via MTR, taxi or bus an great to accompany a visit to nearby Chi Lin Nunnery.

Oasis among the towers. In loved the contrast between this beautiful garden and the surrounding tower blocks of flats. This made it seem very special. The trees were beautiful as were the water features.
Green paradise. It is hard to believe you are in the middle of bustling Hong Kong. The park is tranquil and very relaxing. Perfect for a picnic.

What a beautiful public park. What a great public park, really close to the Nunnery. In excellent condition with super views. Try out the little tea room, they provided a good cup of tea with milk. Sign language worked a treat! Vegetarian restaurant behind waterfall looked interesting and was full which is always a good sign. You can walk all round in a relatively short time. Would recommend doing this when you visit Chi Lin Nunnery, they are really close.

Absolutely wonderful. These gardens are an absolute credit to the government and people of Hong Kong. They are among the most beautiful Asian gardens you will ever see. The photos dont do it justice. You will feel a sense of peace descend as you enter the gardens and leave the madness of Hong Kong on the outside for a while. In conjunction with the adjacent Chi Lin nunnery, I would put this as one of the top 3 places to visit in Hong Kong. Very easy access from Diamond Hill MTR. You will not be disappointed.

Good combo if visiting Chin Lin Nunnery . I am not sure I would recommend the trip out here if you don't combine the visit with seeing Chi Lin Nunnery, unless you are a Garden aficionado of course. Both attractions are spitting distance from the Diamond Hill station. The trip out here from Tsim Sha Tsui station is about 20-25 minutes. The garden is quite nice and tranquil by all means and the Nunnery is next door.

Peace and Tranquility. Hong Kong is an exciting, noisy and Tiring place with not much surcease from the hurly burly. However catch the MTR to Diamond Hill and you can be in a peaceful and beautiful oasis in minutes. The gardens were created in the early nineties, but the wonderful planting of so many aged trees with carefully arranged naturally sculpted rocks makes this one of the most beautiful gardens I have ever visited. Surprisingly the traffic noise is very subdued in this calm and tranquil place. It's a pity you have to share it with so many other people !!If you like gardens then don't leave Hong Kong without visiting this. For me possibly the premier attraction in Hong Kong.

Peace and Beauty. Travelled here by train which is very easy to navigate. Signs are everywhere when you alight.The garden seems to be set in a valley and surrounded by residential towers and busy roads. Once inside the walls of the garden it is so peacefull and the gardens are spectacular.They have a gift shop inside as well as restaurant for coffee. Well worth a look if you are seeking tranquility and beauty.

Well cared for. Visited the gardens after leaving the Chi Lin Nunnery, they are close together and you would want to visit them both at the same time. This is a well kept garden again I a traditional Chinese style, with a pagoda, pond, water wheel, etc. it is very well maintained but can be busy there I should imagine. We were there on a relatively quiet day and it was not overexposed in terms of numbers. Again, take your camera for plenty of shots.

Wow Factor!. I never heard of this place until I seen the reviews in Tripadvisor. It was such a WOW place for me the first time I have seen it. I love everything about it. It's like finding a beautiful oasis amidst the city. The colorful backdrop against the tall buildings has made my fingers so itchy in taking lots of photos. Guaranteed you will enjoy walking around the place (1 hr at least). Never miss this when you visit HK. It's near Diamond Hill MTR exit and Chi Lin Nunnery.

Be sure to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery across the street.. We almost missed this place; we were on our way to the Chi Lin Nunnery when we walked by it. We usually don't include gardens on our itinerary. Anyway, we enjoyed the rock gardens, bonsai, the waterfalls and the pagodas and other buildings. Don't miss this one.
Nice Garden and resturant. I think this is the best thing to do in Hong Kong for free. Gardens are beautiful, lot of sitting place and veg restaurant is a must visit.

Nice gardens . Nice refuge from the bustling city life. There was a friendly welcome and the brochure have some explanations in English or Chinese. It looks rather new and clean, a bit like the way a Swiss or a Singaporean would organise a garden, nice though. Recommended. Walking distance from Diamond Hill station
Beautiful!. this garden is absolutely beautiful, a peaceful Calm area in the middle of the hustle and bustle. The gardens are so manicured and there is so much history

Oasis in a busy city. A great place to head to for a welcome time out from the busyness that can be HK. Really well set out gardens and exhibits and I felt an immediate sense of peace and calm. This was my second vist, the first back in 2011, and I loved just as much th second time around
Perfection. Spend some time here and at the gardens on the opposite side of the road. Shame the Big Bus doesn't service these wonderful places.

Serenity amidst activity!. This place defines the meaning of serenity. Located amidst skyscrapers , the nunnery is modeled on traditional Chinese architecture. One can find number of idols of Gods and Goddess from the Chinese literature, each with a description to aid in understanding the role of each figure. Th nunnery in itself is huge, with three prominent halls or 'aangans' as we call it in Hindi. Visit to the nunnery can provide a good mix of freshness and relaxation to the otherwise packed & hectic tour of Hong Kong.But if you are not the kind who likes visiting gardens and temples, then you should probably pass this place.
Oasis of Peace in the heart of Kowloon. Very peaceful and lovely gardens. Beautiful chinese architecture. A must for both local and visitors.

Beautiful landscaped gardens. This garden is easily accessible from Diamond Hill mtr, just follow the signs. It is very peaceful and has beautiful sculpted trees. A number of routes in the garden was closed for upgrading works. We wanted to go for afternoon tea but it is only served on Saturday and Sunday. Nice contrast between nature and skyscrapers in crowded Hong Kong.

Peaceful, rejuvenating, different. Different from the usual Hong Kong offerings of big shopping malls or nature hikes, Nan Lian Garden is a nicely-tended, Japanese-style manmade garden. The bonsai and petrified wood displays are fascinating as are the model-scale temple display. Bring a book or a Kindle and enjoy a quiet afternoon wandering and reading outside.

An easy add-on to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Was attracted to the gardens by the golden pagoda with a vermillion wooden bridge that was just so picturesque it deserved to be photographed. The gardens were also much quieter than at Chi Lin so well worth a quick detour to take in its sights given the proximity.
Great Landscape garden for photos. Easily accessible place by MTR, a true hidden gem as not a lot tourists. However, the garden is beautiful and you can spend a few hours here.

Lovely city garden in a buddhist nunnery. This garden, connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery at Diamond Hill MTR, is definitely worth a visit. We went on a cool, grey day and even then the beauty was apparent of the formal gardens. It would be fantastic on a hot, sunny day. Photo-ops abound with the juxtaposition of Japanese-style planting and buildings and the surrounding skyscrapers. An excellent gift shop and an outstanding vegetarian restaurant. Also a tea pavilion that we didn't manage to find (it could have been closed). There was also a display of interesting stones( really) to give a zen-like aspect to the visit. I enjoyed the gardens more than the Nunnery, but both are worth the trip and if you are veggie, GO and EAT

Serene zen garden in HK. Excellent place to spend a leisurely couple of hours strolling. Has a buddhist (veg) set menu restaurant. After enjoying this place, don't forget to visit Chi Lin Nunnery and Wong Tai Sin Temple, they are all near to each other.

Beautiful and tranquil garden. Quite easily spend at least an hour here admiring the beautiful and well kept garden and architecture. Above the garden lies the Chi Lin Nunnery which is definitely worth a visit to.Came during the Chinese New Year public holidays but fortunately it wasn't crowded.Very easy to get to by MTR - jump off at Diamond Hill station and signposts direct you across the road and straight into Nan Lian Gardens.

Tranquil garden. This is a wonderful and tranquil garden a short walk from the Diamond Hill metro. You can pick up an English map and follow the garden route. Immediately the thick groves of trees blocked out the traffic sound. We also struggled to see many high rise buildings so we felt far away from inside a major city.It was a pleasant half hour walk passing by numerous rock formations and trees that looked like giant bonsais. Even the grass was carefully tended and looked like tufted thick ground cover.After passing by the rockeries we came upon the Lotus pond which in its centre had the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection. It was a brilliant yellow pagoda but alas it was closed off so we could not cross the bridges to it. Still it was a lovely spot. We continued on to the Lunar Reflection terrace which overlooked the blue pond which had huge fish in there. There was also an old mill and a pleasant waterfall feature, and a small museum devoted to timber architecture which had some wonderful scale models of pagodas and other structures.Overall a wonderful and calming experience away from the mayhem of Hong Kong.
Beautiful garden. Very well kept ,located next to Plaza Hollywood mall.So peaceful and so relaxing Well worth a visit.Visited on 3/24/2014

A peaceful oasis.. This is such a peaceful place to visit. Beautifully kept - spotlessly clean. I loved the juxtaposition between the oriental intricately carved rooftops of the temples and the modernity of the skyline. Makes a great picture shot.
