beautiful park - great contrast between garden and high rise buildings around it. Makes a nice few hours of relaxing. Easy to get to (right next to Diamond hill MTR). Free entrance. Atleats whne I was there it was not too crowded.
Classic Chinese Garden. The park is beautiful. If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong this garden is a place to visit. It is beautifully landscaped.

A peaceful oasis. The Nan Lian Garden is a very peaceful oasis in the center of a very busy city. We enjoyed the flowers, the trees, the fall and the museum (opens at 10:00) that displays very fine miniature reproductions of various sacred buildings, convents and nunneries. We missed the Chi Lin Nunnery because we didn't know it was there.The gift shop offered very fine souvenirs and a large selection of excellent teas. At first, the prices seemed a bit too high, but the products were well worth what we payed.
A beautiful parc. After a visit to the Chi Lun Nunnery this parc is a must see. Visited for the 4th time and I will visit next time I will be in HK

Beautiful garden in modern Hong kong. This new relatively new garden is easy to get to on the MTR, get off a Diamond Hill station and take C2 exit then just up the hill. The garden is free to enter. The garden itself has been beautifully laid out in a traditional Chinese style with bonsai plants, rocks and water complimenting each other beautifully. Well worth spending a hour to view all the garden. It's then only a short MTR trip back to Mong Kok for some retail therapy.

Simply lovely. This lovely garden is situated very close to Diamond Hill MTR.Directions to the gardens were very clear.The gardens are well maintained (of course) with Bonsai trees, Pagodas & Koi Ponds, a really lovely place to visit for a little piece & quiet.

Not-so-hidden Gem. Being a relatively new garden, Nan Lian Garden and the nearby Chi Lin Nunnery are never too crowded, but tourists are starting to realize just how beautiful this garden--designed in classical Chinese style--really is. Sprawling around a central golden building, the trees, ponds, flowers and rock gardens offer a great bit of tranquility amongst the endless white high-rises surrounding.

Stunned by the beauty. Nan Lian Garden was not on our planning but we saw a piece of it on CNN while staying in HK. It surely is a beautiful garden and was the perfect ending of our vacation. A must for those who a appreciate some green in the city.

Lovely walk.. I was bored will all the tourists so I took myself to Nan Lian Gardens. I found them very tranquil and lovely to walk around. There were hardly any other people here and loved that around every corner there was something different to see.
A nice tranquil place with Bhudist temple across road. Smallish garden but worth a visit if you are lost for things to do. Very close to Diamond Hill MTR station
Under renovation at the time. I really like these gardens. I've been there before. But when half of everything is closed, it's hard to relax.
Beautiful. The gardens were well kept and all the trees and bushes were well manicure. Definitely a must see when you are in Hong Kong.
Serenity. This is one of the most beautifully serene and lovely gardens I have ever visited. Every direction had something of beauty to behold.
Just beautiful. The most amazing i ve ever been. In the middle of blocks with amazing and peaceful atmosphere. If u r in hongkong u should go there for sure

An oasis. easy to get to on the underground. A green oasis with a temple. We had a peaceful couple of hours there. We weren't at all hungry so didn't try the vegetarian restaurant behind a waterfall but it looked very good. open until 9.00

Nice garden. We spent a lot of time here having a lot of photographs of the garden. Very nice landscaping indeed. There was a display of different architectures in miniature pieces of course.
You can go here by bus and should be able to find this area.
Recommended because it's peaceful and relaxing.

So beautiful. I thought this the best place to visit in Hong Kong. Gorgeously laid out, the garden had a sense of serenity even though it was in the middle of the city. The wooden structures on it were impressive but the gardens and the water features were wonderful. Loved it.

Hidden treasure in Hong kong. Don't miss the serene gardens and lake that make up this Free attraction. Words can't really describe the oasis amongst the hustle and bustle of the city. Take your time and chill. It's an easy stroll from Diamond hill station and the mrt makes it easily accessible too.

Stunning place. Don't leave HK without visiting this place!It's simply amazing with the lovely groomed trees, amazing rocks and tranquility.You can completely relax in the midst of koi ponds, fragrant flowers and trees... It's very quiet and peaceful.Not many people there when we visited.On your way out, don't forget to visit the gift shop.Be mindful of their policy: no drinks/food outside of the restaurant/shop. No loud talking, no running around.

Breathtaking landscape in city. Super impressed with this garden right in the middle of Hong Kong. Every tree and bush is manicured, loved the Bonsai trees. The main building, which is part of the Nunnery, is astonishing.
Don't miss the Chi Lin Vegetarian Restaurant!!!! Very unique menu.

must see this. We spent hours walking the grounds of this peaceful, and meticulously groomed garden in the middle of the city. The koi pond was particularly beautiful and we took many photos to capture the beauty of the grounds. The gift shop also has beautiful silk scarves reasonably priced.

Worth a look. Its a Chinese garden thats beautifully kept and well worth a look . The little pagodas and bright red bridges , ponds with bright carp fish are lovely. Its a peaceful place among a very busy and towering city.

Beautiful and peaceful. Continuing the visit to the nunnery, you get to these beautiful gardens which hold as more power and peace as the temple. Everything is impeccable and symmetrical in order to give your sight an inner sense of beauty. I've also been here 3 times! I know.... I just kept wanting to go back :-)
Nan Lian Garden. a quick 6 stop ? or so subway ride from Langham Place hotel. Gardens were beautiful. temps in late January for 68-70. Perfect for strolling thru the garden

Beautiful small garden. We, a family with two kids visited this garden on a Sunday morning. We took MTR to the Diamond Hill station - Exit C2 it is an easy clearly sign posted 5 minutes walk. Entrance is free.Garden is small but very nicely maintained. Lot of trees, water features, rock arts, bonsai display and a Golden Pagoda in the middle. It is a very nice view to see lot of trees with tall modern buildings in the background. There are many ponds but we couldn't see any fish as we expected. Kids were bit disappointed. This may be due to the winter weather.We thought to have lunch at the vegetarian restaurant but it was full. Instead we had some snack at the small cafe next to the gift shop. Vegetarian noodles and mushroom sandwiches were very yummy. Service was great, friendly and helpful.After the garden we cross over the bridge to see the Chi Lin Nunnery.This is a must see garden in Hong Kong and will nicely fit in to a relaxing day between other activities.
Lovely!. The garden is a beautiful escape from the city. It was like stepping into another world! We definitely recommend this as a must do.

an oasis of quiet in Kowloon. This very nice little public garden is relatively new. It's adjacent to the Chi Lin nunnery and across the road from Hollywood Plaza shopping mall in Diamond Hill. You can easily walk around the park in 25-30 minutes, enjoy the quiet in the middle of Kowloon, the pond, the waterfall and the various small pavillions with permanent or temporary exhibits. There is a vegetarian restaurant in one corner of the Garden. The gift shop, also in the Garden, is recommended - it sells some very nice and tasteful local artefacts and souvenirs.

A lovely experience. I visited these gardens last week whilst in Hong Kong. A friend told me about them or I don't think I would have known they existed. What a peaceful, tranquil and serene place, surrounded by the bustle that is Hong Kong. Absolutely loved the gardens and will go back when next in Hong Kong in July 2015. Well worth a visit, highly recommended.
Very nice place.. The place is worth visit on Hong kong. The place is well maintained and very clean. Good to spend 1-2 hours.
Refreshing. Stepping out of Central Hong Kong's concrete jungle into a life-filled jungle of nature was refreshing. The gorillas "choir" was intriguing.

One of the best hidden treasures. We planned to go here before we got to Hong Kong however I forgot my list. It was only by chance that we spotted the signposts for this place and we were so glad we did, as it was beautiful.Its free to enter and it is so tranquil and gorgeous.Its set in the centre of the roads (almost like a freeway) and you would have though on arrival that it was tiny. On entering though you realise how surprisingly large it is.It is so nice to see the high rise back drop against the green trees, and waterfall and lake.This is a place to go and relax, maybe have a bite to eat at one of the restaurants/cafes and enjoy the quietness.I especially loved all of the little stones/signs dotted round which provided lovely photo opportunities.Although this is so highly rated, we found the garden to be very quiet and not busy at all.

Paradise in the city !!. This is a paradise in the centre of sky scrapers. The gardens are really easy to find, if you catch the mtr it is located at diamond hill and is only a 2 minute walk from there. When we first got to the gardens it was just after 9 and it was so peaceful and a place I could spend all day relaxing, it seems that it's not huge tourist attraction so you get to experience them as you should.Walking around the gardens there's a chance to learn and see the beauty of it as they are extremely well maintained and also some labeled so you can see the different type of plants they use, also there are lovely waterfalls and a lake with coy carp in which you are not allowed to feed. All in all I love that you can find peace and tranquility in a big city !

nice gardens; really thoughtful sightlines. compared to other gardens, the paths and plantings appear to have been planned to offer great views of the features within the gardens. also fun so look past the beautiful trees to the high rises of the residential areas beyond.

Beautifull. In my recent visit to Hong Kong, we had one free day to explore the city by ourself, we discovered from a magazine that these garden is near to our hotel in Kowloon like 30 mins walking distance hence we decided to go.As soon as we reached the garden and entered to look at the landscape, we all were stunned to look the beauty of the place. Its just amazing place to visit in Hong Kong. Its peaceful and beautiful garden ever seen by us. Fountains, Waterfalls, Pounds filled with fishes and loads of trees makes you feel fresh and energized.If you have time and want to spend some peaceful quality time with family or spouse, please visit the gardens.

Beautiful garden. I came across this garden by accident on my way to the Chi Lin Nunnery but it was a great find. The gardens are free, have bonsai trees, an amazing gold pagoda, ponds & a museum. It is a beautiful oasis of calm in a very busy city.
A Hidden Garden. Quiet, few tourists, nice place to escape the busy streets of Hongkong. Beside the Nan Lian Garden is the Nunnery. But there are some spots that photography is not allowed.
nice garden in a busy city. What a lovely garden to walk around and relax in a busy city! Would be great if there were signs about what you were looking at regarding pagodas/buildings, etc.
Beautiful garden. Wonderful place to take pictures, sight see, and generally enjoy Hong Kong. Good snacks available nearby if you are interested, also lots to buy if you are in the mood to shop!

Vegetarian Gem in Diamond Hill. Genuine vegetarian culinary delights. No MSG, carefully chosen ingredients, price ranges to fit all budgets. Good service, delicious chinese tea and one of the best coffees in town! Yes coffee. The head nun has personally seen to the menu development herself with her team. Visit the oasis of Nan Lian Garden an oasis in the middle of Kowloon. The imagery is truly what HK could be. Nestled beneath the mountains of Diamond Hill, next to Hollywood Plaza and tall buildings, attached to Chi Lin Temples - a quiet oasis and a garden conceived and run so well by the Chi Lin nuns and created so beautifully is a testament to what is possible in Hong Kong. 20 mins via MTR from Admiralty with one train change. 5 mins walk from Diamond Hill station. Definitely worth a visit to Nan Liang Garden, the restaurant and Chi Lin Temple Grounds. Tip:Restaurant opens early. Get your hotel to book a table.Weekends and public holidays busyAllow 3.5 hours minimum to visit garden, temple grounds and enjoy a leisurely lunch.

Chi Lin + Nan Lian Garden. Directly south from Chi Lin Nunnery it's worthwhile taking a 30 minute walk around the two ponds is this garden if you are visiting Chi Lin. In January 2015 certain sections of the Garden were closed for remodeling so there weren't many seats available to sit and relax with a view. Some of the areas that you'd like to get closer to were also blocked - not sure if that was from the remodeling or not, but more access would have made this a more enjoyable experience.

An oasis in the heart of bustling HK!. The garden has been built by modelling the architecture design of China's Tang Dyanasty. Time and money have been generously used in the process. Timber and stones were all carefully selected, sourced and built to reflect the actual style, skill and atmosphere of the ancient Tang Dynasty. It is therefore a unique piece of green in the heart of HK. The large lily pond is the higlight of the garden. The tea house next to it is in fact the best hideout in the garden where you can sample some famous style f tea from China while enjoying the serenity and tranquility of the surrounding Tang period setting.Go to Nam Lian Garden if you want to see a garden with a difference and a unique style here in HK. And, while you are there, don't miss the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery. Actually, it is the nuns of Chi Lian who planned, built and managed the Nan Lian Garden.

Lovely :). This is a small but beautiful garden located in bustling Hong Kong. It's a 5 minute walk from the underground station at Diamond Hill. There's a nice looking vegetarian restaurant which we didn't eat at, and a traditional tea house (minimum cost $160 HK per person) which was a highlight for me. I'm really glad we visited.

Absolutley stunning garden!. I must have spent a good half-day just strolling around this stunning place. There is a tea house in the middle in which one can experience a tea ceremony. There is also a really good vegetarian restaurant just behind the waterfall. The Chi Lin nunnery can be access from the gardens too.

Unique & Pretty . After reading that it would be out of the way, I was pleasantly surprised at how close to the MTR it is. Just follow the signs across the street. It's a beautiful garden, which is very unique in such a crazy city.

Intersting. Very nice and beautiful location. Very impressed with the design and decoration for a very modern building. The rock garden/museum makes some radical claims that we found interesting. The bonsai trees were amazing and very old. Another location in Hong Kong that needs an option to take a guided tour in English to truly appreciate the full attraction.

Beautiful but unfriendly. Having visited this place before, I was disappointed this time to find it unwelcoming. The gardens are a beautiful oasis in the middle of a noisy suburb of Hong Kong. However, the tranquility was spoilt by the feeling of being watched all the time. "Security" guards were everywhere, even lurking behind trees from which they would emerge to follow you. I saw several occasions on which they admonished people for apparently breaking one of the many rules advertised at the entrance. As the guards spoke no English, their arm waving and agitated behaviour was clearly confusing to all those who were admonished. Even entering the park was off putting as you had to pass a large sign with a list of over twenty behaviours which were forbidden in the park. Some of these were reasonable, however others seemed very trivial and unnecessary. This over-regulation ruined any sense of atmosphere and tranquility. I did not find my visit relaxing. This place definitely is not child friendly.

an ideal place to relax your mind... Visited Nan Lian Garden due to highly recommended in Tripadvisor, noticed that it is also been included and recommended in one of the brochures I obtained from the airport. The garden and Chi Lin Nunnery are just few minutes walk from Diamond Hill train station. It is a good place to relax your mind and enjoy the beautiful scenery. Everything seems very new, certain areas are blocked which are not allowed for visit (I wonder why!) I did not do research much about the place but I find it rather Japanese style/feel. Btw, there is a shopping mall right at C2 exit so don't miss it! Managed to buy few clothes from the H&M there :)

One of the loveliest gardens I have visited. So worthwhile. I would love to have the time to come here for the whole day to walk, meditate, and just take it in. They have meditative music piped around the garden. It is peaceful, and not overly crowded on the day we qvisited. Be sure to cross the bridge to the nunnery. Free entry, but they collect a small amount to visit the cloisonne exhibit that is completely worth it, what a gift to have this tranquil space available in the city.

More than we expected. We are young and like to keep busy, sitting in a park is not usually what we do but while were at the chi lin nunnery opposite (also connected by a bridge) i knew it was top on tripadvisor so we went over. It was more like a tour. We got given a map with numbered points of intres and we followed the map around, took some photos and went into the museums. Which are cheap, but happen to be free every wednesday. My lucky day. There are also a lot of chinese plants to be seen. There was a restuarant under a water fall but apart from that there is not really any sitting areas. But again its a must visit at the diamond hill stop on the MTR. then it is easily sign posted once you come out! Have a great time in Hong Kong :)

Worth a visit. Conbine this with the Chin Lin Nunnery. There is a gift shop which has quality goods. We did not try the vegetarian restaurent which appears expensive. There is also a cafetaria for a light snack. There is a small onsite museum with changing exhibits. The Garden is not large but there is meandering path so allocate about 2 hours (including visits to the gift shop and the small museum.)

Beautiful scenery and architecture. Went to this place based on Tripadvisor recommendations. It's not in the common tourist area but is a great place to visit if you want to see beautiful scenery and wooden architecture modeled from China's Tang dynasty. Several of the buildings are not open to the public so you can only admire the outside. However, the garden is quite serene and beautifully maintained as well as being free. The nunnery is also attached and worth a visit. It's less than 5 minute away from the Metro station which is located underneath a mall.
a great place to see while in HK. I found the garden really pleasant to walk. this is one place that made me feel good while visiting a mercantile city like HK

Gorgeous. Such a beautifully maintained garden. Right nextdoor to ChI Lin Nunnery. MTR to Diamond Hill and a few minutes walk. There is also a lovely new shopping centre as you exit the MTR. Well worth a visit, just to escape crowds and noise.

Peaceful and beautiful. Slightly out of the way from Hong Kong Island, these gardens are well worth a visit to. Easy to get to from Diamond Hill MTR just follow the directions (there are maps and wifi in every station if you get lost). The gardens are quite small so won't take too long to walk around but they were the best gardens I saw in Hong Kong, really unique with beautiful bonsai trees and water features. My friend and I went to the tea house in the centre which despite being very expensive was really good fun and the tea was a brilliant cure for a late night out! Highly recommended for a morning stroll.
little piece of paradise. directly across from the Chi Lin Nunnery, what a great place to wander and relax away from the busy city. Also next to Diamond Hill MTR.
Beautiful scenery. Free garden entry. Beautiful view with the buildings, the mountains, the temples and the water. Only 45 min to 1h from downtown Hong Kong.

A tranqil place amongst bustling Hong Kong. With Diamond Hill's highrise apartments in the background, this public park was built in the style of the Tang Dynasty. Surrounding its beautiful pagoda is a scenic garden with rocks, plants, fish ponds, water features and timber structures all placed using special rules and methods.Adjoining buildings house historic Chinese timber architecture and rock exhibitions. A vegetarian restaurant, cafe, souvenir shop and several toilet blocks are also available. Food is not to be consumed within the gardens.Arrive early to avoid the crowds - access via MTR Diamond Hill exit C2 and follow the signs. Be sure to visit Chi Lin Nunnery across the footbridge as well.

totally worth a visit. I'm so in love with this place. Plenty of directions coming from the MTR station. Lots of photo spots there,and it's so calming. You could just sit there and enjoy the atmosphere. The shop is also nice. Believe it or not, it's the first shop I visited in HK, where the shop assistants were all smiling, saying hello, and replying back to my 'thank you's

Oasis. It's self amazing beautiful garden in Asian country. I have been traveling by my solo the garden laid on well condition and can spend couple of hours without boring. There are many guides are asking to me to take around inside the garden but I don't think so necesaary for me.Mtr diamond hill station was fantastic.Wonderful scenic view. So nice hidden garden.
gorgeous garden. This garden is absolutely exquisite with its amazing trees and shapes and the pagoda, bridge and the tea rooms.
Wow. Loved this garden, it was the first place we visited after our 11 hour flight and it was beautiful, peaceful and restorative. Also has a nice little cafe.
Lovely!. Great gardens to walk in for 20 minutes or 2 hours. We visited after seeing Chi Lin Nunnery - also worth a visit! There is a restaurant in the gardens that seems popular but we didn't visit.

relax in the hectic of the city. take the MTR to Diamond Hill station, a few meters itno the phantastic garden, which is set up to reflect the area of the TANG dynasty : trees, landscaping, rock garden, Lotus Pond

Wonderful serene oasis. Put this on your list of things to see in Hong Kong. Easily accessed, get off the MTR station at Diamond Hill, no entry charge.These beautifully manicured and serene gardens are a lovely place to spend a few hours. Lovely quiet place which is quite a counterpoint to some of Hong Kong's busier areasHad a lovely morning here. The adjoining monastery is also a must see

Relaxing and different activity in Hong Kong. As my second time in Hong Kong, I was looking for something different from the obvious touristic areas. This place happened to be just like what I was looking for, something like an oasis in the middle of a concrete jungle.From the moment you enter, you can feel how peaceful the place is. Inside the garden you find lots of green area, a lake, and even a temple, where you can see some people worshiping and praying. The whole atmosphere was very peaceful, it doesn't even look like it is Hong Kong. Everything inside is very preserved and well maintained.I definitely recommend this place for everyone and I might dare say that this is a must see in the city.

Serene, special place. We moved here in July and this is still my favorite of the more "touristy" things we've done. You forget you're actually in the city for awhile! The golden pavilion in the middle has been under construction for some time, but it's still beautiful despite that.

Picturesque. Easy to get to. Come straight out of exit C2 at Diamond Hill MRT and it is well sign posted. Didn't take long to walk around (30-40 minutes) but got some beautiful photos. The gardens are beautifully maintained and the backdrop of modern buildings reminds you that you are in a huge city. The Nunnery is just across the road.

The Hidden Garden. What a beautiful little secret this garden is. A traditional Chinese garden filled with Pagodas, life size bonsai styled trees, paved pathways, authentic foot bridges and culture at every turn. This little oasis may be surrounded by a concrete jungle of high rise apartments but these giant monoliths fade away against the beauty and formality of the gardens. Hop across the road to the fascinating Nunnery to complete your cultural journey.

Lovely gardens. Only a 2minute walk from Diamond Hill MTR station and next to Chi Lin Nunnery. There was some construction work going on whilst we were there but there wasn't much disruption. It was really peaceful in the gardens as there weren't many people there even though it was a lovely sunny day. Really glad we went.

a peaceful garden in the middle of the city. I was impressed by the design, the waterfalls and the big bonsai plants. I enjoyed walking there, very serene ang calming place. Easy to find as it is in the middle of the city. Just go there early morning or during sunset as it was very hot on the afternoon that we visit. I highly reccommend this garden.

Beautiful Tang style garden beside a big shopping mall. The garden was built per Tang style, opposite to Chi Nin Nunnery. The garden was beautifully designed. All the building materials including the rocks, the plants and the small lake were carefully chosen and built to create a serene environment. Whether you come alone or with friends, you will feel peace and joy. You can sit quietly in the tea house by the lake, sipping good tea and vegetarian dim sums. If you have a bigger stomach to fill, try the Lung Mun Restaurant by the waterfall. The Garden is easy to access. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill Station. The directory inside the Station offers clear guide.
What a beautiful place to just sit and enjoy. It was great watching the waterfall and looking at the modern skyline in the background of this old peaceful place in a major city.

Just gorgeous!. We visited here with a bunch of hungry teenagers who forgot about their tummies and totally enjoyed the place. Everything was gorgeous and the temples and trees really were something to see. We can't recommend it enough

Beautiful and serene. We spent more than an hour from the other side of Hong Kong to get here. It's across the road from Diamond Hill MTR exit. You can definitely tell this place is not a historical site, only made to look like one. But it has the most bonsai trees and each tree in the park is sculpted to look like larger bonsai. It is extremely calm, given the hectic pace of surrounding Hong Kong. Kiddies loved it and the vegetarian cafe is extremely clean. There is also a vegetarian restaurant which sits underneath its own waterfall and a traditional tea serving segment, hidden inside of a large pagoda where you can sample the taste of ritualised tea service, overlooking koi carps and a large pond.Highly recommended. 8.5/10

Spectacular Chinese garden. 5 minutes walk out of Diamond Hill MTR station. A beautifully and tastefully laid out Chinese garden. Despite it being set amongst major roads it is very peaceful. Visited the Cloisonné exhibition and a very reasonably priced snack at the teashop. There's also a restaurant. Beautiful traditional Chinese architecture on the buildings.The Chi Lin Nunnery is accessible via a bridge across the highway. Together the two provide a must see 1/2 day experience.
Hidden Gem. Be sure to have a look at the miniature replicas of beautiful wood buildings made without nails. A lost art! Wonderful interesting rocks in the gardens.

Simply beautiful. You will find it hard to believe that you are in a very busy part of Hong Kong. The Nan Lian Gardens are just spectacular. Once you walk thru the gates, you are in another world of calm and beauty. They work so hard in the care and maintenance of the plants and landscape. If I lived in the area, I would certainly spend time relaxing and unwinding in these beautiful gardens and ponds.

Like Oasis in the Desert. This Garden is like an Oasis in the desert. It is hard to imagine presence of such a beautiful and nice garden within the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong City. The Wooden exhibit within the park is very nice and so are the other areas. There was some renovation work going on when we visited and a part of the garden was cordoned off to visitors, but we enjoyed nevertheless.
Park. It is good for everone ~~Good for photo ,and 呼吸新鮮空氣

Serenity within the city. The unique feature is having a garden of Asian architecture right in the middle of the town. unfortunately on the day of my visit, it was drizzling thus not able to enjoy in completely. Easy to access from diamond hill MTR. A mere 10 mins walk. The garden s well kept and serene.Perfect for nature lovers

Greeneries in the middle of the city. Nan Lian Garden is connected to Chi Lin Nunnery in Diamond Hill. We first went inside Nan Lian Garden and took hundreds of photos because of its beautiful sceneries. The place depicts the vibe of having 'history being surrounded by the future'. The garden was built in Tang style, representing the enactment of the timber structure and garden of the ancient Tang Dynasty. My favorite spot there was the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection situated at the center of the Lotus Pond. It gives you the feel of pretty much being in the Tang Dynasty.There is a must-try restaurant there at the middle of the attraction, but it was said to be pricey but good.The place can be easily located from Diamond Hill Station Exit C2. It's real hot there though during summer or mid-autumn.

A Lovely and Picturesque Garden. Chances of visiting this place if you are following a big tour group will be rare. If you are travelling in a small group or a private tour......ask to visit this garden. It's a very well kept gardens that is tranquil and lots of nice scenic nooks for some photos. Entering the garden is like going into a different world. Be prepared to do some walkingDo stop by for lunch at the vegetarian restaurant. Prices are a bit pricey but it is worthwhile as the dishes are really good. Go for the set meals. My parents totally enjoyed themselves

Wow!! . If you like Asian gardens and architecture then this should be on your 'must do' list! Absolutely gorgeous and very, very serene - which is strange considering the freeways all around it! Just catch the MTR to Diamond Hill station and follow the signs past Plaza Hollywood.

Beautiful garden - plan on going to the Nunnery too.. Easy to get to from the Diamond Hill metro stop. Go in the lower gate - check out the side rooms - make the loop, then go up the stairs to the nunnery.November was a great time to visit BTW

Good walk!. The gardens, english in style, are very luxurious and well kept. I wouldn´t say it´s must see, but it is a very good walk - one can always stay for almost 3 hours wandering around, getting to know all the trees and birds. I liked very much.
Absolutely Superb. This garden is absolutely beautiful and astonishing considering where it is. Now completely surrounded by housing. Really tranquil and certainly photogenic.

This isn't Hong Kong, but it's a nice break from reality. Visiting at 8am on an early winter Monday morning, enjoying a quiet hour strolling with friends made for a good start to our day. There was hardly anyone else about, and after a while the noise from the traffic all around us did fade away a bit. So for a short while taking in this fairly small oasis in such a hectic city is an enjoyable stroll. Especially the case if you enjoy the garden's structured beauty. But it isn't very big, and I doubt it would be anywhere near as much fun on a hot crowded summer day.

Loved the fresh air of Nan Lian. A little heaven in the busy Hong Kong. Easily accessible by MTR, it is a free activity to enjoy with the family when your bargaining skills are put to test at the markets...

Looks like an extension from Chi Lin Nunnery... If you have visited Chi Lin Nunnery, Nan Lian Garden is just across the road. The garden itself has an infusion of Japanese theme (Zen) with Chinese style pavilion and a large pond. Since it is free for all, wont hurt just taking a scroll through it.
Beautiful gardens ,bonsais and buildings. Nicer then Hong Kong Park.Lots of Bonsais and beautiful buildings.A quiet oasis in a busy hectic city.Well worth the visit.

Loved this place. I absolutely loved this place. It was easy to reach from Diamond Hill MTR station. Unlike other places in HK - there was no crowd here. The trees were beautifully done. The bonsai collection is extraordinary. The garden was serene and peaceful with beautiful frames to click your pics. A must visit. The hollywood plaza mall was nearby so you can end your trip with some shopping.

Fabulous and so relaxing. Friends had recommended these gardens. They were stunning. All round the gardens are high rise buildings and fly overs, very noisy roads. Once inside the gardens, you can't hear the traffic. A very peaceful and relaxing place. The trees are amazing. We went in the cafe and the gift shop. We didn't eat in the restaurant. We enjoyed the gardens so much that we visited a second time, just to chill out and relax.

Beautiful and contemplative. the gardens are just fantastic, great contemplative place with wonderful chinese music playing. Unfortunately some areas were closed including the golden pavilion which was under cover for maintenance.
Very nice.... Beautiful gardens, great place for photographers! These gardens altogether with Chi Lin nunnery gives you the best experience of the special and unique views of the East.
Absolutely beautiful garden. Well worth the visit, beautiful classic style garden. Make sure you check out the vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall.

A stunning Tang style Chinese garden oasis in busy Kowloon.. I lived in Hong Kong from Jan 2007 until August 2008 and despite this stunning garden having been first opened to the public in November 2006 up until my visit in December 2014 I had never even heard of it... I found it on Trip Advisor when looking for something new to see during a spare day I had during a business trip.Easy to reach from Exit C1 of the 'Diamond Hill' MTR Station (leave exit C1 then turn right and then left and you are there in a 2 minute walk, following the pink tourist information signs - See photos) this peaceful and stunning Chinese garden is well worth a visit. Just take a leisurely walk around, sit and reflect or go for something to eat in the Vegetarian Restaurant under the waterfall or take some traditional tea in the Song Cha Xie Tearoom there is every opportunity here to relax and unwind from the usual busy city bustle. The gardens are open daily from 7:00am until 9:00pm.There are also exhibits of traditional Tang building techniques in the Chinese Timber Architecture Gallery and a quality gift / souvenir shop to look around, and the Rockery is also interesting with it's artistic chunks of ancient rock formation. The Pavilion Bridge and the Zi-Wu Bridges are beautiful but sadly whilst I was there the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection was covered over for essential maintenance work (due open again in the New Year I believe).In summary this garden is certainly worth a visit as is the lovely Chi Lin Nunnery which connects to the garden in the North... And all Free of Charge entry for both attractions.

Such a treat. This beautifully kept garden in Kowloon is stunning. No expense has been spared in the design and management. The area is quite large and can accommodate many visitors, but it doesn't feel busy or crowded. The garden is located right next to Diamond Hill MTR station, so it's easy and inexpensive to get there. There are clear signs to the garden from the MTR station. The garden has good informative information. Lots to photograph and plenty of places to sit. Enjoy!
Place to rest. It was really peacefull and the Information was helpfull, free Information sheet was offered. Chinese garden with lots of blooming plants.

Beautiful gem in Hong Kong. After 4 days of sight seeing this was a welcome break from the relentless onslaught of humanity that is Hong Kong. It is a beautifully laid out garden with clear signage and wonderful areas to sit and just enjoy the view of the waterfall or the mill. It was free to get in and combined with the Nunnery it was a great way to while away a few hours.

Calm in the Chaos. Wow! This garden was absolutely stunning! My husband and I spent quite a bit of time in here relaxing and enjoying the scenery. There are workers up in the trees, in the bushes, taking such great care of such a serene place. It's so contradicting to see all the sky risers and busy building that surround the garden, but the peace of the garden still emits. This was one of our favorite spots, especially easy to get to and also connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery!

Amazing. As per the Chi Lin Nunnery, what an amazing place. The gardens are spectacular, with the biggest fish I've ever seen in a fish pond. A real secret in a hustle bustle location, but the peace and serenity is magical.
WOW..... Definitely enjoyed this place. Extremely relaxing and lots of interesting things to see here. Went with my wife and two teenage kids and we all enjoyed it.
Perfect urban oasis. Perfect conception and execution; a garden paradise in the midst of concrete. Nothing to dislike, it was surprisingly quiet on a weekend.

Nice get away from the city. This is a beautifull garden with great extra's such as typical chinese buildings, a fog effect and even some zen sounds. It's nice to go here to have a get away from the city. Make sure to combine this trip with something else in the neighbourhood or you will be spending a lot of time traveling because it's pretty far from the city centre.

In the minds eye. This garden is what I've always imagined a perfect zen garden would look like, and have always been disappointed. Go behind to waterfall to stop by the restaurant for filling, reasonably priced vegetarian cuisine!
Excellent garden. If you wanna escape the buzzling city of hongkong and would like serinity then this is the right place!!!!
Beautiful Garden. Next to Diamond Hill MTR , beautiful gardens with water feature and traditional architecture , spend a nice half day walking , also a vegetarian Restuarant under waterfall .
Gorgeous garden. Very well kept garden with water elements as well. Near Diamond Hill MTR station and Hollywood Plaza mall. There is a good and cheap food court on third floor called Food Republic.

New and huge. Somehow, as recently as 2002, Hong Kong found the space to building this huge, beautifully designed Chinese garden next to an old nunnery. Plus, it has a wonderful gift shop with local handicrafts in all price ranges.
Pretty. It is a very pretty garden, was quite busy the day I went. I wouldn't put it on the 'must see' but if you have a spare hour or two make the trip.
Amazing garden. The garden is peaceful and relaxing. Here you can see a golden temple and a hidden restaurant behind a waterfall! Absolutely a must go place.

A Veritable Oasis in Busy Diamond Hill. Located next to Plaza Hollywood mall and adjacent to the Chi Lin Nunnery, the Nan Lian Garden is a great way to introduce both local and foreign tourists to traditional Chinese garden styles. It is a well-maintained mini-park that features indigenous Chinese flora and rock gardens, as well as a couple of tranquil ponds in the center. To the east is a man-made waterfall along with a traditional water mill that mimics the countryside. It was a pity, though, that the centerpiece of the garden, the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection, was undergoing maintenance at the time we visited, so we did not see it in its full glory. Nevertheless, do check out this garden for a relaxing, leisurely stroll in the early morning or late afternoon.
Nice and relaxing. Lovely place with beautiful gardens. Still relaxing despite the crowds. Some good walks and well worth a visit.

A respite from the crowds. Signs leading to the garden makes it very easy to get there. However, because the garden is smack in the city, I did wonder if I was heading in the right direction.The garden is immaculate in its design and showcases traditional Chinese architecture with its various pavilions. What I enjoyed was walking around soaking up the landscape and sunshine. It is obvious that a lot of care goes into the maintenance of the garden.What disappointed me was that many of the 'attractions' there are blocked like the Thatched Pavilion and Xiang Hai Xuan (an exhibition hall). Except for the hall, there was no reason stated so I am not sure if these were meant to be seen from afar only or there were special reasons. Also, at the moment the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection and the Lotus Pond is under renovation so that's another two less attractions to enjoy.From here, you can also make your way to the Chi Lin Nunnery which is a tourist attraction in its own right.

Absolute Tranquility. If you have holidayed in HK and always wanted to visit Nan Lian Gardens but have run out of time, well make the effort, treat yourself and GO! Wow, what a beautiful place. So peaceful, tranquil and immaculate. The design is fantastic and the maintenance on the trees and gardens is second to none. We took our three kids but would probably leave them behind next time as they wanted to set a cracking pace and my wife and I would prefer to get lost in there. Will return there as a priority next visit to HK and get lost!

Stop and relax in an oasis of calm and stunning Gardens.... This is a place to see the vast differences between new and old Hong Kong, bustling/chaotic/concrete through to purposeful/meditative/stunning gardens..... Every inch is so well planned, loved and respected. Easy to access and something entire families will love. I felt more connected to this cultural experience than any other - every part of this Nunnery has been built without a single nail! Do some reading before you go as there is a lovely Vegetarian Restaurant and a Teahouse overlooking the water. Invest the time to see how a green space can be maintained within a bustling city.

Peace, perfect peace, and beauty!. Free to get in, and as you walk through the entrance, it's as if a veil has been drawn. The noise of the city drops away, and there is the peaceful sound of chinese meditative music. It is well ordered and the walk through the gardens takes you on immaculately clean paths. The trees and shrubs are also immaculately groomed. There is a lovely lake with a pagoda and carp. The first view of waterfall is with a backdrop of skyscrappers as if to remind you of where you are. The stones and boulders give a timeless serenity to the whole makeup of the place.I've been to gardens in the UK, Italy, the USA and Japan, and this is surely up there among the best of them, mainly because of its elegant simplicity and thoughtful design.If you are of a religious nature you would find spiritual content in this place.The restaurent gives a wonderful bonus that was a delightful surprise for my daughter - peanut butter and condensed milk toasties!!!

Lovely Park in the Middle of A City. This is a beautiful place, well thought out, in the middle of Kowloon next to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Once you enter the garden, you immediately hear a reduction in street noise. Very relaxing.
The gardens are pristine and gorgeous. To see a traditional garden like this was beautiful. I would recommend families with young children visit the gardens because they are well worth it.

Hidden little oasis in the middle of the concrete jungle!. The contrast of this little oasis of peace and quiet in the middle of the bustling concrete jungle is what strikes you the most when you visit Chin Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian garden. I was very glad I visited this - it is such a breath of fresh air from the usual touristy things you do and all the crowded places filled with hour long waiting periods that you face in Hong Kong. Loved the beautiful grounds with its stunning bonsais, the water wheel and the orange bridge, the koi ponds and the really peaceful and beautiful Nunnery. It is also really easy to access by public transport. A must do in my opinion.

Great garden most of the year...the best part (gold tower & orange bridge covered until Jan 31 '15). Both the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden are beautiful, peaceful and well worth a visit. Unfortunately, the most stunning part of the garden, the gold tower and orange bridge, are covered and being painted through Jan 31 2015. It is a bummer that they can't only cover a part and paint it so visitors can still see the beauty. The other amazing thing is that only steps away, there is an expressway and energetic city while in the Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden, it is so quiet and peaceful. I would definitely make sure the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden are both on your itinerary.

Beautiful scape. Easy access through public transport, beautiful grounds and fabulous spot for pictures. Take some time to seat around and quiet your mind in this busy but amazing city.The mall nearby has lots of food and beverage options - typical HK!

Beautiful. It's a beautiful place to visit, and you can walk over to Chi Lin Nunnery. The garden is well maintained and it's kind of surprising that my family and I were not stung by mosquitoes - not even once! Despite enjoying the nice view and all, I was deeply disappointed at the vegetarian restaurant. 1. The waitress aggressively told us that if we wish to have our lunch, we must spend at least HK$100/pax. 2. When we were clarifying certain food, to make a more informed choice, the waitress was frustrated, and said, "I don't care how your Singa-what-pore-whatever-China place prepare the food, this is HK" We merely wanted to clarify, so that we can decide if we wish to try that particular dish or not.... we meant no harm, neither are we trying to compare which country prepare the food better. We have no idea why she has to be so aggressive and defensive.
Oasis. An oasis of beautifully maintained gardens, a delightful place to wander through on way to the Nunnery.
A stunner of a garden. What a great garden to visit, even in the rain as my wife & i found outPeaceful, stunning,interesting & so enjoyable.Highly recommend you consider visiting this garden.

Peaceful Oasis. What a beautiful garden. You could almost forget for a second that you were in Hong Kong except that the skyscrapers are visible. Walk the entire garden, stop in the Rock museum and the Bonsai garden.

Hidden gems. Didn't know what to expect coming here, but I definitely not disapointed, has a zen like atmosphere and the plants were very well maintained, a good place if you want to relax and enjoy the view. The downside though the pagoda were under maintenance when I went there until next year.

So Peaceful!!!. After I visited The Nunnery, just across the way, I decided to go visit the Gardens as well. The place is so peaceful and so relaxing that you will have no idea you are still in Hong Kong. The area was somewhat under construction a few weeks ago, but besides that, this place is worth the detour. There is also a restaurant hidden behind the waterfall which is very neat and totally different. I definitely enjoyed just wondering around and disconnecting from the hectic city life that Hong Kong as to offer. A definite must do while in Hong Kong!

Fantastic. While I am not a fan of visiting gardens this one is the exception. Well maintained and themed. The pagoda was wrapped in plastic fro renovations and the lake it sits in drained. The main lake is full though and has some huge Koi in it. Combined with the nunnery the best place to visit in HK. Even with the traffic noise still remains peaceful

Tacky sculpted gardens, don't get it. Surprised that this is so highly rated in HK. It's a heavily sculpted garden in the middle of a nothing area. Doesn't really feel that special or seem to have any real historic value. Must better outdoor adventures to have in Hong Kong. Meh.

The best thing we did in Hong Kong. Beautiful, tranquil relaxing garden, a real oasis from the noise and bustle of the city. 1 min walk from MTR station Diamond Hill. Opposite is theBuddist nunnery that is also a haven of peace and quiet. I will not duplicate all the previous positive comments but would always go back if in Homg Kong again. A word of caution, the central bridges and pavilion are closed for mainteneace at present but still worth the visit.
Serene and peaceful place. One of my fave places in HK. A must-visit spot. A great place to getaway from the hustle and bustle.
beautiful!. the place is beautiful, very peaceful, the maintenance is impeccable! very nice, i recommend to send 1-2 hours there..

Worthy Of A Visit. Visited at the same time as the Chi Lin Nunnery which adjoins to these gardens.Beautiful serene and tranquil gardens which have been well planned out.The garden is host to many exciting trees and is a real escape from the busy city. Worth a visit as is the Chi Lin Nunnery.
the beuty. What a beautiful place, what I can say here is really not quit enough for describing the lovely time that we had in this amazing free entrance garden

Beautiful garden. I like this garden as it is beautiful and has variety of wood trees planted but there are restrictions to go to few attractions. They renovate few of them but yet you can still see the attractions. It is a beautiful, well designed garden and peaceful, apart from the some tour guide noises. It is a must go there, besides you can do shopping afterwards. The shopping mall is right in front of you.

Beautiful serene authentic gardens. FREE. Well worth a visit, soooooo peaceful and relaxing and great for photos!!! Loved it. Also images of the Buddha quite impressive, great to just mooch around it and chill.
Must do. Never seen such a nice park before. The main attraction is in renovation. But never mind go there. Its for free. And its great!!

A Beautiful Treasure!. Wow...one cannot believe what is amongst the towering buildings. The gardens are full of beautiful bonsai and Buddhist pine trees. Within the gardens is a nice waterfall feature that is partially incorporated into the vegetarian restaurant on the ground, lovely. The large main pond and pavilion were unfortunately under renovation and therefore closed, unfortunately. There were other ponds brimming with very large koi fish you could see. Take the time to visit this little oasis by the Chi Lin Nunnery.
Peaceful and beautiful. We walked around this after we had visited the Chi Lin nunnery and found it to be a lovely tranquil place to wander and sit.

An oasis of calm amongst the tower blocks. We visited this lovely garden, beautifully kept after our visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery.. Well worth a visit. Enjoyed visiting the Rockery with beautiful ancient stones, shapes & colours. Some fine examples of bonsai & natural shaped Buddhist Pine. Beautiful water features with waterfalls & large ponds with enormous koi fish swimming lazily by. We had lunch at the Long Men Lou vegetarian restaurant, & a delicious set menu for HK $120 for four courses. I recommend getting there before 12 noon to get a table or otherwise make a booking as it gets very crowded.
Building work going on until January 2015. Very nice garden and worth the trip out on the MTR. However, the main pond area in the centre is drained and the pavilion covered up.. But of a shame.

No Tripod. The temple in the center of the garden is red and eye catching. The wooden bridge nicely built but inaccesible. The chinese garden has lots of stones. But, what weird was the officer told me not to bring my tripod. I have to left it in the counter. Why? How am I supposed to take my own picture?

Stunning Garden and Architecture. My wife and I spent the morning between here and the Chi Lin Nunnery next door. Entry is free and one could easily spend a couple of hours here enjoying the gardens and buildings. It should be noted that one of the main attractions, the Lotus Pond & Pavilion of Absolute Perfection are currently (30/10/2014) undergoing major renovation, the pond has been drained and Pavilion is under covers. However, there is still plenty to enjoy, the Carp pond is particularly interesting. The gardens were commissioned in 2003 and completed in 2006. The design of the Garden is based on the Jiangshouju Garden of the Tang Dynasty, a traditional Chinese landscape garden in Shanxi Province, and as such look as if it's been there for centuries. There's a Vegetarian Restaurant and a café which sells light snacks and some of the best coffee I've tasted in Hong Kong. A really enjoyable experience. Highly Recommend.
Oasis in the City. It is a really nice garden in the City. Silent and not so crowded as the rest of the town.It is worth a walk trough it.

Beautiful. Make sure you go to the vegetarian restaurant there, great setting and tasty lunch options. It was a shame the pagoda in the middle was being renovated but other than that was a great trip!

Traqil and beauty with in a busy area of Hong Kong. The Nan Lian Gardens is a surprising and very beautiful garden located just a short train ride from Central Hong Kong. Like so many parks in and around Hong Kong the Lian Gardens is totally tranquil and the perfect place to spend a couple of hours. Situated opposite a large shopping mall and the Diamond Hill MTR station this is a great way to escape the city rush without having to journey very far away to do so. The Gardens are quiet comprehensive, so do not expect to be able to quickly whip around them. Take your time to enjoy the beauty and have a snack or a meal at one of the eateries located within. All food served is vegetarian possibly due to the garden also being situated within a Buddhist Nunnery. Wander through a Lotus Pool Garden, but take note that although photos are welcome around much of the garden there is no photography within the many alters and shrines that make up the temple.View large golden Buddha statues and take notice of the story attached to each. Look carefully and you may be rewarded with a close up of some of the naturals worlds small marvels as Dragonflies of different colours back around the Lotus Pool.Entry into the Gardens is free however there are two exhibition halls where special exhibits may have a small charge.

Under construction, not as much to see on 10/29/14.. I visited the Nan Lian Garden today before heading to the Chi Lin Nunnery. NOTE: the garden is under construction and you won't be able to see the beautiful pagoda within the water feature you've likely seen in guidebooks.The water feature has been drained for improvements. It is still a pretty garden, however, with a koi pond and nice views of the nunnery with tall buildings in the background. If you are pressed for time, I'd scratch this from your list for now. And, if you plan to go, I would suggest calling to see if consruction is completed.

Go when the weather is relatively cool. This garden, adjacent to the Chi Lin Nunnery, is a beautiful respite from the hustle and bustle of town, but is undergoing a lot of reconstruction. Try to time your visit for nice weather or a cooler time of the day as the garden can get very hot and humid. Unfortunately, when we visited, one of the best parts of the garden, the Pavilion of Absolute Perfection with its Golden Pagoda, was completely closed for refurbishment, including its ponds and bridges. Fortunately, there were a few interesting parts of the garden still open. There was a building devoted to an architectural display of the various techniques of elaborate wooden structure construction (not using nails), with models of existing Tang, Liao, and Jin dynasty structures. This was very interesting although it was difficult to see details since the room was quite dark and there was a lot of glare from the windows. There was also a special exhibition of cloissone art (extra charge) that was both fascinating and amazing. The art and various techniques of cloissone, using step-by-step demonstrations, were explained. It really made you appreciate the incredible detail and skill inherent in this ancient and breathtaking art form. In other sections of the garden, there is an curious display of unusual striated and glistening rocks gathered from all over China, and a serene waterfall sheltering a well-liked vegetarian restaurant. Located near Diamond Hill MTR, admission free, exhibit extra charge.

Peace and tranquility in Hong kong. Gardens are manicured to perfection and detail is to be hold, a great place to visit and nunnery is right next door. Well worth a few hrs visit. Easy access from Diamond Hill MTR station and is well signed. The pagoda was under repair but still well worth the visit.

Beautiful Gardens in the city. *) http://www.nanliangarden.org/home.php?eng*) Long Men Lou: Chi Lin Vegetarian CuisineOpening hours:Mon to FriLunch 12:00 to 15:00 hrDinner 18:00 to 21:00 hrSat, Sun, Public HolidaysLunch 11:30 to 15:00 hrAfternoon Tea 15:00 to 17:30 hrDinner 18:00 to 21:00 hr*) Nearest MTR Station: Diamond Hill MTR Station Exit C2 so that you land directly in front of the Hollywood Plaza Mall. From there follow the directions to Nan Lian Gardens. The gardens are about 100meters away. There is no entrance fee. The visit will take you about 2 hours, including the Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens, technically another attraction, by a bridge. Both can be visited without ever coming on the road.*) Entrance is free*) Pickup the brochure at the entrance. It has a map (helps you keep oriented) and some information about the history, architecture, and design of the garden. I learned things from the brochure that I probably would not have picked up just by observation.*) Its not allowed to eat on the benches in the garden.*) There is a Chi Lin Vegetarian Restaurant where you can have All Veg lunch for 120 HKD per person. This one is by the Waterfall*) There is another cheaper place where you can have snacks like Sandwiches, tea, coffee and cold drinks.For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://hongkongandmacauitinerary.blogspot.in/2014/10/hong-kong-macau-itinerary.html

Lovely. I fell in love with this place! The water sprinkled over the trees on a hot day creates a mist and it all looks totally magical. They are still renovating the Pavilion of Absolute perfection and the lotus pond, but even without them the garden has a lot of stunning views to offer (Pavilion Bridge and the Mill being my favourite)

not dissaponted. Came here after reading the recommendation from Tripadvisor. It was a pleasant trip. Easy to get to via MTR. Good to be away from the noise and the crowd. HK is never really a place to relax for holidays unless you idea of holiday is shopping. This is a good place to relax for a few hours. We also had a good lunch at the vegetarian restaurant.

Tranquil. Nan Lian Gardens are beautifully landscaped and tranquil. The gardens and buildings are all to traditional Chinesee design and feng shui rules. The juxtaposition between the gardens and the skyscraper surrounding them make for interesting photos. Visit in conjunction with the Chi Lin Nunnery next door, both easily visited by MTR. Take a short walk from C2 exit at Diamond Hill station.

Oasis in Hong Kong. Well maintained peaceful public garden with plenty of places to stop and enjoy the view. There was an enamel exhibition when I was there that was worth looking at. Didn't try the vegetarian restaurant but the shop had lots of quality souvenirs.

MUST GO!. I highly suggest seeing the Nan Lian Garden! Probably one of my favorite places in Kowloon. I was completely lost for words to see how beautiful the scene is. The surroundings of garden and backdrop of skyscrapers looks surreal. Very relaxing place, places to sit down, path to walk around, and a place to play chess too!
Beautiful garden.. Easy to access from MTR. Well worth a visit if you enjoy sculpture gardens with huge rocks and sculptured trees. Also lakes and huge gold fish.
Nice surprise. Central Park it is not, but after visiting the underwhelming nunnery across the street, we were pleasantly surprised with this park as a short respite from the city that surrounds it.

complete zen. this garden or park is a complete zen! Its a nice place to sit down relax, have a heart to heart talk with your friend or lover. Or just sit... sit there and enjoy the tranquility of the place.

One of my secret favourite places. Not well known but once you have been it will become a favourite. Walking through the garden you get to see & appreciate the Asian way of gardening, laying out plants & manipulating trees to make every space perfect. There is a beautiful golden pagoda & a small lake with the biggest carp fish I have ever seen. It offers a chance to slow right down & enjoy some fresh air & to just sit & be still. Access from Diamond Hill MTR is signposted & a 5 minute walk from Plaza Hollywood shopping mall. It joins into the Li Chin Monastery which is another beautiful space.

Fascinating and well laid out. Having read a poor review about these gardens, the balance needs to be redressed. At the time of our visit the pagoda was being refurbished and was covered in protective sheeting, and the surrounding lake had been drained. It will be finished in January 2015. But that is a very small part of these beautiful gardens, that are peaceful in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Kowloon. The surrounding hills provide a backdrop, and the high rise flats overlook, but this does not detract from the beauty of the place. Currently there is an exhibition of Chinese and Japanese enamelware on display, just beautiful, and showing how it is made, which was new to us. The plants, timber buildings, waterfalls and lakes all just add to an excellent ambience, enhanced by lovely background music. Do not be put off, this is a must visit!

Great place. We are here visiting a friend and he brought us here. What a beautiful place, very peaceful. We ate at the vegetarian restaurant also, tasty food. Including the nunnery, we were there for about 4 hours.

Plesant but not that impressive. The garden was lovely although there was not thing to be excited about as the golden pavilion, which is the main attraction in the middle of this garden and lotus ponds around it are under construction. Still, it is nice to walk around after visiting Chilin nunnery (if you are not hurry)
Quiet oasis. Bonsai tree oasis in the middle of a bustling city. Good option if you are looking for a quiet escape. Right outside subway station.

Lovely gardens. Beautiful gardens to wonder around and relax. Only some slight disappointment as main attraction was being renovated and some of the sections had been blocked off so couldn't explore the whole gardens. Otherwise it was lovely!

Weird rules But enjoyable place. This is a great thing to do in busy Hong Kong. The gardens aren't big, but are well designed and in addition to the nunnery next door, it's a worthwhile trip. Just catch MTR to Diamond Hill, it's just next door.I did the lunch at the vegetarian restaurant, which I have to say was pretty good. There is also a traditional tea house for those who want the experience.Whilst in the garden, I decided to sit down, take off my shoes and cross my legs and close my eyes and just enjoy the peace and quiet. In about 3 mins a security guy come over and told me I couldn't do 'that'. I'm not exactly sure what 'that' was, but it involved me having my shoes off. I thought this was weird and pointless as the whole garden is designed to relax in. Anyway, I had to 'move on' which I did, but thought that was really quite bizarre. Garden managers, maybe you might have a word to your over zealous security team. Anyway, I thought that was weird, but did not detract from my enjoyment.The gardens are free and I was here for 90 mins inc lunch.

Green Oasis in Hong Kong. These gardens are easy to get to from Diamond Hill MTR station. They provide a beautiful, gentle walk in the middle of Kowloon. The large pond containg Koi , a size I have never before seen, is a nice spot to sit down and spend a few moments contemplating.

Wonderful peaceful retreat. This attraction is attached to the nunnery, and was a wonderful oasis in the heat of the day. Try the lychee slushie in the cafe on site. It was so refreshing. The park offers different aspects to chinese culture with archiecture, landscaping and cuisine. There are areas to sit and watch the world go by or to take a sedate walk. This attraction is literally 100metres from the MTR, and is free. Worth a look for sure

A lot of things closed as being done up.. A nice garden with some big bonsai trees! A few of the building were closed off for refurbish. They have so many signs around the grounds advising you which way to go, what not too do as well as what type of trees. A good build up to the nunnery and a peaceful walk.

Lovely place to get peace and quite in the middle of the city. great place to enjoy tea in true style in the tea pavilion . Such a nice place to visit and enjoy the wonderful statues and shrines. A truly peaceful place.

Pretty nice, nothing special. You like city parks? Then visit this one, it's pretty nice. Chi Lin nunnery is a bonus. A bit out of the way from Central, but worth visiting once. I found no reason to come there again.

Fantastic Bonsai's. This garden has the most awesome bonsai-ed trees you will find anywhere. They are mainly Buddhists pines but there were others as well including some fantastic Bougainvilleas. Most of these bonsai trees are actually planted in the ground rather than pots which makes them all the more special

Under renovation - October 2014. Easy access from HK via MTR in about 30 minutes.
It was tough to enjoy or evaluate the gardens b/c the main feature was shrouded during renovations. Several other buildings were also closed the day I visited. Thankfully, the Chi Lin Nunnery is attached to the gardens and well worth the trip.

Beautiful Peaceful Stop. Well worth the MTR trip to get here. A beautiful and peaceful park that seems to shut out the city with well-manicured grounds, ponds, boulders, trees, and plants. The only downside during our visit was some major renovations on-going with the central pond area. Really one of the highlights of our visit to Hong Kong

If you like parks and quiet and soothing atmosphere. If you like parks and quiet and soothing atmosphere Nan Lian Garden is a must. It is a pretty small garden but it is so nice that you can spend hours in it and still not be satisfied. it is a Japanese garden with soothing Japanese music played all over the park so you can enjoy the greenery intermingled with Japanese style constructions. Surprisingly, it was not present in my Lonely Planet guide. Getting there is simple - get off on Diamond Hill MTR station and look for signs. It is literally 3 minutes walk from the station. Plus, there is no admission fee.othercontact: MTR to Diamond Hill
Great place to visit. The Structure of the building and the calm side of Hong Kong.

A Place of Contrast. Situated in urban Kowloon where the whole area is lush and hilly giving it a real nice setting.The garden is beautiful and scenic with lush trees, huge rocks, water features and in the back ground are tall hi rise buildings giving this quite the contrast. We visited on a Friday and it was surprisingly quiet compared to the rest of the places in the city. Its clean, fresh and a quiet oasis away from the bustle of the city.One should take the time to visit this garden as part of a visit to the Chin Lin Nunnery just next door and of course their vegetarian restaurant on the premises.Its located almost next to a metro stop thus its a must see place for visitors...allow several hrs or more for the whole visit including lunch and the nunnery.

silence and peace amid a bustling city. a must-visit for all travelers to HK. it's right next to MTR Diamond Hill station. It's not just the green but several attractions including the gallery on wooden architecture, the ponds and the colouful fishes. keep at least an hour for the garden. the souvenir shop sells expensive stuff but worth buying a piece or two.
Beautiful. Definitely worth a visit, so peaceful and beautiful. Chi Lin Nunnery and Hollywood Plaza Shopping Centre are in the same vicinity so it's worth the trip.
Peaceful haven in the middle of the great city. Great place to go for some relief from the crowds. The gardens are wonderful and the Buddhist Nunnery is a tranquil oasis.
I'm glad that I came here!. Enjoy the garden walk and you will be surprise this garden was in the middle of high rise buildings!

Oasis in the city. This garden is surrounded by buildings and bustle of HK. Yet, one does feel the peace. While a bit concocted, it does afford a nice walk. At the time of visit, there was a gorgeous cloisonné vase exhibition for free. I visited around 10 a.m. during a weekday and had the place almost all to myself--really the only time I can say this in HK. I would have loved to have tea in the lovely building but service was not available at the time. While this spot is not a must-do, it is certainly a nice spot to visit.
Beautiful. A beautiful oasis! Calm, quiet & a wonderful place to "wind down" from all the noise & crowds of the city. The tea house is also lovely.

Peace in a chaotic city. Beautiful getway from all the traffic and noise-so picturesque that you'll find yourself taking pictures constantly.A must visit to get a nice walk and see some great architecture. The little shop has sweet little bits in there too that are reasonably priced.
nice view there but not so friendly. will held some events inside the garden but with not much introduction. good garden but you cannot rest and enjoy there.

Truly peaceful. I found it amazing how a garden which sat amongst busy main roads was able to completely block out the bustle of the city. A place to find true tranquility amongst beautiful surroundings.

A RELAXING PLACE IN THE CITY CENTER. I couldn't believe that such a serene sanctuary exist in the middle of an urban jungle that is HK.It was literally a few steps away from an MTR Station so coming here was really convenient and fuss free.Luscious gardens, awesome sight and a relaxing feeling awaits would be visitors. Give this a Go!
This is a highlight. True gardening genius, beautifully landscaped, lots of interesting plants and a very good vegetarian restaurant on site.

Zen garden. It is a beautiful garden, lost in the urban jungle. When you get into the garden, as if immersed in the world of the past. The garden contains various trees and stones, quiet paths and pond, gazebo for meditation and contemplation of bonsai If you want to relax your mind - this is the place.

Tranquil, peaceful and greenery. The 3 words above represent my opinion toward this place. Sadly the Nan Lian Garden is under construction when i visited. However, i still enjoy the environment, get yourself out of the noisiness of city.
Worth the visit. Worth the effort to visit. Very quite and tranquil. Take the MTR to diamond hill also visit the big shopping centre for some great shopping.
peaceful, quiet garden. Saw lots of flowers and beautiful shrubs. Very shady on a hot day and the guides are helpful if you are 'lost' while walking around.
Oasis in the faced paced city. Wonderful garden concept - you can feel how you relax while visiting the place. It even seems that noice is significantly less there.

Great to see the old airport land being used for a garden.. Lovely peaceful gardens in traditional style with busy traffic all around. Would have liked to try the restaurant with the waterfall in front of the window.

relaxing. In a city that is so busy this garden is a welcome retreat.Very relaxing. There is also a great gift shop in here.Prices may be a little more than the markets but it is worth paying for some quality gifts and some proceeds go to charity.

the peace in the middle. You can find this peaceful place in the centre of HK, known as economic centre always running. Unfortunately some maintenances were undergoing and we cannot visit some part of the garden. The rockery was surprising. The topiary of the trees delighfull!

Oasis in a busy city!. As with the Chi Lin Nunnery, I was completely surprised at how relaxing stepping inside the nunnery and garden would be. I wanted to visit the picturesque tourist site for some great photos, but I ended up experiencing something on a completely different level. How lucky HK is to have this oasis in the middle of a busy city!

Serenity in the middle of the city. Nan Lian Garden is beautiful, serene, and elegant and is actually maintained by the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery. This has to be one of the most beautiful places in Hong Kong - it's on Diamond Hill in Kowloon. Every rock, piece of land, body of water is placed according to specific rules. The landscaping is meticulous. You'll see lotus ponds, trees, paths, bridges, and pagodas. It designed as a sort of walking path from which you can see the gardens and also the high-rise structures surrounding it. It's a lovely way to spend an afternoon.

Oasis in the city. An oasis in the middle of a bustling city! It was marvelous to see how manmade creations have created this garden to sample different views and natural sights of the Eastern world. A definite must see.

Gorgeous!. An oasis in the middle of HK. You can't hear any of the happenings of the city inside of the walls of this garden. Unfortunately the pagoda and a few other things were closed when we were there, but we still loved everything. Meticulous landscaping, elegant music, and beautiful trees are just some of the things that await you in Nan Lian Gardens.

Great traditional park in the middle of the city. Nan Lian Garden is a unique park: It is placed in the middle of the city, and surrounded by modern buildings while the park itself contains of many traditional buildings. Plus:1. There are many good spots to get photograph.2. There are trees everywhere, so it should not be too hot in the park.3. There are also quite a lot of seats for you to sit on when you're tired.Minus:Be careful when you're thirsty or hungry when you're in the park, because when you're eating or drinking something, the guards will surprisingly appear and command you to stop eating and drinking immediately.
Beautiful. Serene and worth a peaceful walk through the gardens, gift shop worth a visit and good to get some small easy to carry gifts home.

A HAVEN OF TRANQUILITY. Need a break from all the shopping and boozing? Nan Lian is a hidden gem, guaranteed to relax and impress. Looks like it's been there since time immemorial (though it's actually quite recent).

Wow garden not just for garden lovers. This small jewel set in the midst of bustling downtown was a major success in our overall visit. We were lucky enough to visit in a soft rain, which gave an extraordinary romantic atmosphere. I can only compare it favorably with the fabulous gardens of Kyoto. A golden pavilion, waterfall, stone arrangements, flowering vines and bushes and tiny water drops glistening on every pine needle. A little stroll inside and you're eager to see what is around the next curve in the path. First class, extensive gift store with authentic china, fabrics, music, accessories, books, wood items. A very different ethnic shopping experience than the myriad high profile international designer stores that proliferate in HK or the night and lady markets. Sorry not to have been able to try the restaurant.

Not a normal park. I enjoyed spending my time in this park. Not only a park but they also have some collection of different kinds of rocks and models of some impressive places of China. You can also walk across the bridge to Chi Lin Nunnery, another nice and calm place.

Beautiful Park. This park is just beautiful and we'll taken care. Thoroughly enjoyed it having greens around.There's a small cafe near the souvenir shop serving very good freshly brewed coffee. Try it. It's very good!It was unfortunate that the pagoda is in restoration stage. Otherwise my trip here would be complete :)

Different style, equally nice. Nan Lian Garden is right to the opposite of Chi Lin Nunnery. Despite Chi Lin's calming dark brown structure, Nan Lian has a million colors in it with it is eye catching golden tower in the middle of a lake.

Oasis in the storm. Like a mini Central Park but with much more tranquility and style. Their gift shop items are reasonable priced, and their vegetarian restaurant (behind a waterfall no less) is amazing! A favorite place to stop.

next to Chi Lin Nunnery. i loved the Chilin Nunnery. worth the visit. then i realized there is section 2 two which is the Nan Lian Gardens. both places complement each other and you won't want to leave!

The most beautiful garden I've visited. As someone who likes to think they have green fingers, I Have in my life visited a number of botanical and specially created gardens, but a visit to the Nan Lian gardens has superseded all of these as the most beautiful gardens I have had the fortune to visit. It is defiantly not the biggest and it has the unique Hong Kong landscape around it, with sky rise apartments seemingly set on the edge of the gardens, but the quality of the park, the attention to detail of the gardens and the cleanliness of the whole place was quite wonderful!A must see visit, especially as the nunnery is right next door, and the walk from the underground is minimal.Stunningly Beautiful

A true oasis right. The place is a surprise treat and one that you would not expect to be placed right in the middle of a busy city. You could reach the place by getting down at the Diamond Hill MTR station. The place is close to the Chi Lin nunnery and you could combine both these places on your visit. This botanical garden is filled with friends from the plant kingdom and that too in wide variety and is a true treat to watch. Also the place is the perfect spot to get away from the heat or taking a little stroll.

Tranquility in the midst of a city. The last thing you would expect in the middle of a huge city like Hong Kong, yet a peaceful garden lies quite in the middle of this bustling metropolis. This along, with the Chi Lin Nunnery right beside it, was the most unexpectedly wonderful experience during my trip to Hong Kong.

Worth a visit. We came across this lovely garden while visiting the nearby shopping mall at Diamond Hill. The 'garden' is a small botanical gardens in the Chinese style with everything trimmed to perfection. There are a number of pagoda type buildings that together with careful choice and positioning of plants and rocks create some beautiful views.
