beautiful gardens in the middle of a ctiy. We had an enjoyable afternoon stroll through the gardens. Unfortunately the pagoda is under construction. The trees are quite beautiful.

Beautiful, must visit. Absolutely stunning temple complex, highly recommend. Definitely worth the journey out to Diamond Hill. Can relax in the park and grab some shopping from the Commercial Centre on the way back to the Metro

Wonderfully relaxing, beautiful place. One of the must see places in Hong Kong. Across the road from the Chi Lin Nunnery (also very good). Winding paths around a ~2 acre lake filled with multicolored Koi carp. The paths are lined with different types of trees and shrubs (labeled) and the most incredible collection of large rocks and boulders set among them. A nice tea house, a restaurant and gift shop as well as an interesting rock museum, more like an art museum than anything else. If it wasn't for the skyscrapers on the horizon you would swear that you had left the city behind.
Just below the Nunnery. As an extension of the Chi Lin Nunnery this beautiful garden unfolded. Waterfalls, ponds, seating areas all designed to compliment the surrounding.A must see in HK.

Hidden Gem out of the Busy City of Hong Kong. Having located at quite far district from the Hong Kong city center, it is actually easier to get to this place by taking the MTR. Just get down from the Diamond Hill MTR, and you'll know where to go, coz there will be several singage to direct you to go to this place.The place is so beautiful. I love gardens, and this gigantic garden is so pleasing to my eyes!! They have a big fish pond at the center of the garden. They have as well a pagoda covered with gold with its red bright bridge for you to take pictures.The ambiance is just so lovely..

Breathtaking gardens. The scenery was breathtaking, especially the bonsai trees. We see some men working painstakingly with small cutters trimming and shaping the trees, each tree was cut to precision.Definitely worth a visit

OK, but much is closed off A/O Aug. 2014. Nice little park, but was difficult to find, as signage from MTR not easy to spot.
As of Aug 19, 2014 much of the park, including bridges and mini pagoda were closed off.

Peaceful and serene. Beautiful well kept gardens and the Chi Lin Nunnery was so calm and beautifully maintained. There were many small temples with statues of the various 'gods' with explanations in English.

Nice to get away from the noise. This garden is kept perfectly and a pleasure to stroll through.
We especially loved the numerous bonsai trees all over the garden.
Make sure you visit. Take the MTR and get off at Diamond Hill, follow the signs. It was weird for this gorgeous garden to be in the middle of the sky scrapers. Well maintained and very beautiful.

Nice walk in a green environment. We went here late afternoon just to look around and have a stroll in a green environment. Like everything in HK it is close to the MTR (and a shopping center) and it is not huge but good for a walk and kids can run free.

TRANQUILITY IN KOWLOON. I take all my friends and family here when they visit Hong Kong. This is a beautiful and stunning garden with the nunnery attached - eat at the vegetarian restaurant on site, lovely little tourist shop to add. Join this with the Wong Tai Sing Temple and Kowloon Park for a full day out and if you are brave finish off with the flower, bird and ladies market for the evening run

Disappointing place. After reading all the reviews here I decided to check out this garden. I was a little disappointed and I did not think this was such a great garden. Its really a small place with some parts of it roped off. There is some vegetation and a path but not too much other than that. This is not a place I will be visiting again.

Beautiful and quiet. Very pretty and worth the visit if you have the extra time. Small waterfalls, the grounds are well manicured and everything is picturesque. You don't need more than 20 minutes here. The Chi Lin Nunnery is easily accessible from here.

Amazing restaurant amidst serene garden. I visited the Nan Lian gardens 7 years ago and returned last week to find that it is still a serene and beautiful haven amidst the intensity of Hong Kong.The gardens are so peaceful and well tended, but the highlight is the vegetarian restaurant at the far end. We had the set menu for lunch which was delicious. Most items are based on different mushrooms. We returned later in the week for dinner ( booking highly recommended) and this experience was just as lovely and delicious! It is just a couple of minutes from Diamond Hill MTR and a terrific multi story shopping centre. Great combination for a day trip!

Wonderful Chinese Gardens. Take the Diamond Hill MTR to visit the Nan Lian gardens which then leads to the Chi Lin nunnery. Many people mistake the Nan Lian gardens for the Chi Lin Nunnery so make sure you see the gardens before proceeding to the nunnery. The Nan Lian gardens are expertly landscaped with bridges, water features, and appropriate temples and structures. The gift shop is very nice also. Plenty of non touristy authentic gifts. You could spend a good hour here but in the heat we were glad to get here at 10am.

A Wonderful 2 hours of nature. A wonderful walk to experience a Chinese style garden.
Currently there is a display of ceramics from China and Japan. Well worth the $30HK entry for this exhibition.
The display of ancient Chinese building techniques is amazing,

A nice escape. Nan Lian was a welcome escape from the urban landscape of Hong Kong. Tranquil gardens and a very interesting eastern architecture display which was a great insight into how temples and housing are constructed. I recommend visiting Nan Lian first and then making your way up to the Chi Lin Nunnery where you can see the architecture at its finest.

Absolute haven of tranquility and green peace!. This is a beautiful garden – green in all shades and varieties – and was one of our highlights this holiday in Hong Kong. There are so many kinds of trees and plants, shrubs and water ponds, tiny little landscaped areas and different places to just relax and let nature take your breath away. It is quick walk from the MTR station and is on the opposite side of the road from the (must visit) Chi Lin Nunnery.The landscaping is in the style of the famous Tang dynasty. There are a couple of exhibition halls and souvenir shops (great respite from the hot July morning sun). There are bits of information on the trees and plants, and everything is landscaped and managed and kept absolutely meticulously. For us this was the best day out. It was truly, a green day for the mind, body and soul.
Delightful gardens. Welcome respite from the urban jungle. Beautifully laid out. Interesting exhibition on building without nails (as in the neighbouring Chi Lin nunnery).

Enjoy the garden. The tranquil Nan Lian Garden is in front of the Chin Lin Nunnery (separate review) . The meticulous landscaping of the lovely gardens are influenced by the popular Tang Dynasty style. Surprisingly this calm and serene Park is right here in Hongkong, a busy and bustling city. The Park makes you forget the stress that the big city offers to travelers. There is a souvenir shop and a Tea House that serves veggie dishes. This garden Park is for free, so make the most of it - relax , take your time and enjoy the Nan Lian Garden. Include this lovely park in your itinerary,

Free to enter, meticulous maintenance.. Stark contrast to the massively tall buildings you're used to in Hong Kong. The gardens are free to enter, very beautiful and it is obvious that the landscaping is top class. Some souvenir shops (air conditioned, thank god!) a restaurant and other services to be found in the gardens. A caveat, not all of the gardens are accessible, the area around the lake, for instance. But you can go to Chi Lin Nunnery from the Garden which makes for a great connecting visit to two top attractions here on TripAdvisor in an afternoon!
Children will enjoy it!. Good walk early morning. I just like the place. My daugther and my son just enjoy walking inside the Garden and stayed there for longer.

Still continues to be a great experience. Despite the fact that there seemed to be three times the amount of people there since we last visited, it continues to be a place of serenity. Also, several parts seem to be in the process of restoration. However, it is definitely well worth the visit. Sit in the shade on a hot day and relax. Mind you, if you visit the nearby nunnery you're not allowed to sit down in most places in the shade! Still a must see for me for visitors to Hong Kong.
Gorgeous. This is SUCH a gem in a concrete jungle. The garden is beaultiful and the golden pavillion is gorgeous. It was such a nice break from the hussle and bussle of the city.

Wonderful hidden garden within the city. As others have said, you can visit this garden and Chi Lin Nunnery together in one go. This is a beautiful garden hidden away within the bustling city, be sure to take some great photos of the garden with the juxtaposing skyscrapers behind. We came in the morning so it was very nice and quiet and I would recommend the same to others as well. Very easy to access via the subway line and the walk from the station is very short.

Super. If you visit the must see nunnery you're already just about there....a beautiful and beautifully maintained garden that's truly an oasis in a place as packed with humanity as is HK. No reason not to go and spend some quiet time and reflect on how pleasant life can be.
Serence and beautiful. A Little off the beaten track in Hong Kong, get down at the Diamond Hill MTR and you can walk from there. Loved the Serene and quite nature of the place.
Peace in the City. Beautiful gardens in the city. Easy to get to by bus and worth the trip. Well maintained and laid out for a pleasant walk. Nice little cafe in the grounds for a cool drink.

Serenity in the city. These gardens are just gorgeous. Walking around the lush green surroundings, the only sign you are still in the city is a bit of traffic noise and some surrounding skyscrapers. It is just so peaceful and serene. The grounds are immaculate. It is well worth the visit. The Chi Lin Buddhist nunnery next door is so stunning. Easy to get to too- right at the Diamond Hill Metro stop.

A peaceful surprise inside Hong Kong. We visited this place with our tour guide Jessie from the nextstophongkong. Without her, we would never know that Hong Kong has such a special and unique place so different to this cosmopolitan city.It's so quiet that when you stepped in,all the noise and chaos from the city were gone. We just enjoyed our time there so much and we will definitely come back again.
A Gem. A very peaceful place in a busy city. Very easy to get to on the metro and free to enter. Also visit the Chi Lin Nunnery which is across the road and a stunning monastery.

Really nice souvenir shop. Usually I do not like souvenir shops because they just sell crap. Wonderful stuff. And you have to try the chocolate, it's way better than all the Belgium chocolate you get everywhere.But really worth to visit the Garden and next door the nunnery.
Brilliant. What a beautiful place, definitely worth the effort. The garden is kept in a superb condition. Bonsai trees every where. We really loved it.
Peaceful..!!!. Highly recommended for meditation, romance, or photographic pleasures. Really beautiful to wander around and take amazing photos.

Serenity. About 5 minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR exit, this garden was really beautiful, clean, serene, and peaceful. Two things amazed me : First, the location is just unique near high rise buildings and Second I wonder why only a few local visiting it? But the fewer people visiting it the more serene this place become. Highly Recommended to visit

Beautiful gardens in the middle of HK. The gardens are really well planned and planted and with HK in the background it is a nice oasis. I didn't see anywhere selling water but there is a souvenir shop and info centre. Can't eat or drink inside n security are hawkeyed.

An Oasis. Beautiful - hidden gem. really beautiful to wander around and take amazing photos which contrast the amazing pagodas and greenery to the high rise flats behind. Absolutely stunning and very peaceful. We teamed this up with catching the bus from outside and across the road to Sai Kung where we hired a boat around the Geo Park. The Gardens are free to enter and if you have time, truly gorgeous!

Beautiful gardens, quiet and serene park. The grounds are beautiful, with quiet ponds and meandering walks among the greenery. There are many great spots for photos, with traditional Chinese architecture sprinkled among foliage, ponds, and the Hong Kong skyline as your backdrop. The Nunnery is also worth the trip, which is right next door via a bridge.
Hidden Gem. You will never expect for a garden in the middle of hustling bustling city like HK! one word, it's just so BEAUTIFUL!!!Try to visit during spring to avoid hot weather...

Calm, quiet and gorgeous. This is a nature photographer's delight. Landscaping is beautiful, noise from nearby bus routes was minimal, there were not many tourists, and it's very peaceful. If you go in the early morning, the vegetarian restaurant is not open. There was an outstanding exhibition on cloisonne objects which had just opened, with an explanation of the process and included video.

Spectacular. I like to do a bit of research before visiting anywhere new and I had picked out Nan Lian Gardens for my wife and I to 'decompress' from the buzz of Hong Kong and Kowloon. Yes it may not be authentic but it is a little piece of paradise and calm right in the middle of residential tower blocks that surround it on all sides but which you hardly notice when you are inside. Beautifully kept gardens, lovely pond in the middle, some relaxing buildings dotted around the gardens. Bigger than you might expect, it has a tea room and restaurant, a very decent shop and attached is a monastery that is also well worth a visit. And it is incredibly photogenic. A great place to while away a couple of hours before you start shopping again!
Peaceful and Serene. We visited here on our second day in Hong Kong. I didn't realize how recent ally it was built in 2006. Still, it's a very peaceful place with beautiful gardens and architecture.

A nice escape from the city. Loved the tranquillity and the lake in the middle. The garden is not very old actually but looks like it has been there for a long time. Great place to walk around but you cannot meditate as you cant step on the grass!

Beautifully Serene Garden. Wow! A beautifully landscaped garden with pagodas and koi pond right smack in busy Hong Kong. Can't help snapping photos. Make sure you come prepared with a full battery for your camera. Very accessible using MTR Kwun Tong line, get off at Diamond Hill station and watch for signs pointing to Nan Lian Garden. A must visit place in Hong Kong!

Kitschy and overrated. Disneyfied version of a phony Chinese garden.Too clean neat and sterile.In REAL Chinese gardens you see kids playing and flying kites and grandmas with babies strolling and sitting on benches . Most parts of the gardens (the bridge and pagodas) are roped off and when you do finally find an area of little tables and chairs under the banyan trees you are not allowed to eat or drink there. You might as well go to the Hollywood Mall acrosd the street.

Next door neighbour of Chi Lin Nunnery, a great place to visit. I was sceptical at first, why would I visit a garden, but hey...once Im there, Im glad that I did. They won an award for a reason! Beautiful well kept garden...very calming in contrast to the busy, hectic HK. Just make sure you have a full battery camera with you.

Combine gardens and the monastry. Beautiful gardens, also a museum of rocks and a nice souvenir shop. There's a restaurant behind the waterfall. Unfortunately I got there too late for lunch (it closes at 15h), but it is a recommended restaurant. Gardens very well kept. Go see the monastry as well!

A peaceful place in the centre of a noisy city. Built by the nearby nunnery complex, this garden is a haven in a busy and noisy city. A path winds around beautiful vistas of shrubs, trees and a lake full of koi fish.
A bit of Natural Paradise in the midst of a BIG CITY. Beautiful place to unwind and slow down during a HECTIC Hong Kong visit. Highly recommended for meditation, romance, or photographic pleasures.

Paradise of Peace & Tranquility. Very beautiful garden with terrific landscape and meticulous maintenance. Its one of the most peaceful places I've ever been to. Scenic & photogenic fish ponds, fountain & so many more delights that can only be experienced by being there.
Visit it if you'd like to relax & soak in the ideal Chinese Feng Shui Tranquility!

Very nice contrast to busy city. Peaceful and very well maintained garden with nice oriental feeling. Waterfalls, goldfishes, bonsai trees etc. If you want to calm down in otherwise so hectic HK, this is a perfect spot. Was not even crowded on Sunday.

Probably the most peaceful place in Hong Kong. This garden is amazingly quiet and beautiful, although it is located inside the city, near a busy road. I loved the huge bonsais trimmed to perfection, the pond and the golden pavilion and red bridge, as well as the artificial waterfall and colourful flowers - there were a lot of pink and white lotuses. All these make for wonderful photos. Do take at least one hour to thoroughly enjoy this oasis of peace and quiet inside the bustling city of Hong Kong.
a peaceful chinese garden. great experience to visit this chinese garden coz the garden is so beautiful and peaceful with sound of chinese music and steam everywhere makes it a romantic place

Best landscaped garden in Hong Kong. Thoughtfully landscaped garden with quiet paths, ponds, a tea house, and a vegetarian restaurant. Check out the garden's website for a schedule of its cultural activities from Chinese musical appreciation to tea ceremony.

A good place to visit, rain or shine. The gardens are stunning and never cease to amaze. Well maintained and plenty of photo opportunities. Free to enter. Vegetarian restaurant in the gardens. You will also see the nunnery which is integrated into the gardens and is very much recommended.
Beautiful vegetarian park. This park is very nice and clean. Lots to see. And easy to access by mtr. There is a popular vegetarian restaurant in the park too.

Lovely Pagoda and Garden. The place is easily accessible via MTR (Diamond Hill Station) and if you're taking advantage of unlimited MTR ride for 3 days then it's should be part of your places to go while in Hong Kong. The garden offers a serene feeling with the pagoda on the background. At one angle you can have a east meet west shot with the pagoda plus the tall buildings at the background.
it's hong kong. this is hong kong and you will never know hong kong if u don't visit this place as it's one of the better place to be when u r there.

Will never set foot here again!!. We are visiting Hong Kong and specifically wanted to take pictures of my daughter in Traditional Chinese dresses in the garden. We were told the QiPao is a distracting costume and does not suit the "peaceful" ambience of the garden and therefore not allowed!! It is absolutely ridiculous!! I understand no wedding dresses and graduation gown, but Traditional Chinese Dresses are considered a costume?? On top of that, the other reviewers already mentioned, here're all the other reasons I will NEVER go to this garden:1. There are more guards than visitors and thru watch you like a hawk. It's not "peaceful", its "stressful"2. Everything in the garden is newly built, there's no historic value, its all artificial! Yet they are enforcing 20 some rules like its more precious than the Great Wall, give me a break!! The Kowloon Walled City Park is just as we'll done and is an interesting piece of HK history3. The one way path enforcement is another ridiculous rule, can't even go back for the bathroom! Sorry, I can't maintain peace of mind when my bladder is full. So no!! I will not waste my time here at all!!
Surprise find. A Good visit.. Was wondering around various MTR stations and stumbled across this quiet but very beautiful garden. Worth a special trip just to visit.
Super. Beautiful gardens with a temple to boot. Really a pleasant surprise to find this gem in the middle of a city.
An Oasis. Fabulous gardens by Chi Lin Nunnery, Its so quiet and peaceful, a real oasis in Kowloon, a place to rest and relax a bit

What I Expected a Chinese Garden to Look Like. Nan Lian Garden is right across from the Chi Lin Nunnery and they are often seen as one attraction. This is a bit misleading since as far as I know the garden doesn't have "opening hours", while the nunnery does.In any case, the garden is wonderful, it's really what I expected a Chinese garden to look like. First of all, it isn't crowded like most places in Hong Kong or famous Chinese gardens in Mainland China. Second of all, it's small so it's possible to maintain it to the highest standards and with the greatest attention to detail.All of the objects in the garden are beautifully painted, you will not see many spots with peeling paint despite the constant extreme humidity and marine winds (containing salt) in Hong Kong. The bushes and trees are perfectly cut and this seems to be constantly maintained. Even the layout of the stones is anything but random.The place includes a lake, stone garden, waterfall and an exhibition that to be honest I didn't quite understand. Steam comes out of the ground in certain places to create a mist. The only downside was that the park doesn't have many places to sit, probably on purpose so people don't linger. This is unfortunate.

Beautiful, bigger than expected. We combined this with a trip to the nunnery, totally worth the half day trip out to Diamond Hill MTR. Largish garden with many beautiful polished rocks, find the "cloud rock" . Also has a geocache:).Has a rockery and a pottery building as well as small gift shop with very expensive hand made chocolate. Can be very hot but gift shop is very air conditioned. Also has a banyan picnic area. We did not visit the restaurant.Beautiful and manicured oasis in the big city. Would totally recommend a visit.Go on a Wednesday and admission to the air conditioned pottery building is free.

Beautiful and tranquil. A lovely park with a large lake to visit and walk around. There are some great photo opportunities.There are also a number of exhibitions to see, including pottery and one on the design and techniques of Chinese wooden structures and buildings. This has some wooden models to illustrate this.The only thing is, don't eat anything. An over zealous security guard blew a whistle and waved and shouted at me for taking a packet of mints out of my pocket and putting one in my mouth. Ridiculous!!

Oasis amidst the city. A reviewer suggested visiting on Wednesday which we did. So the entrance to the pottery exhibition was free. Chi Lin Nunnery closes at 4.30pm so plan well. If you like landscaped gardens, this would be a good place to take pictures. Note that the golden pagoda & the red bridge are out of bounds to all visitors. The security watches like a hawk too. Lots of beautiful lotuses in pots, huge bonsai plants & stone sculptures to admire. Miniature buildings of prominent places are featured too, although phototaking is not allowed.Move on to Chi Lin Nunnery which is attached. Devotees & visitors enjoy the peace & tranquillity that it offers. The chanting on the loudspeaker sets your mind at ease. The residential buildings towering overhead sends a reminder that this oasis of calm is right smack in the busy city. Good to visit.

Beautiful gardens, peace and tranquility in the city. I enjoyed visiting both the gardens and the adjoining nunnery, a pleasant contrast to the busy city well worth a visit. Whether spiritually inclined or not no visitor could fail to be impressed by the beautiful architecture, waterfalls, flora and fauna.

A peaceful oasis!. This garden is a hidden jewel of tranquility tucked in a city that is congested in every way- we live in Canada! What a surprise to leave the subway station, walk across the street & find this oasis.The trail winds through gardens & beside ponds with lotus & fountains. There is a orange bridge & pagoda that will have photography buffs snapping with delight. You will feel like you have been a world away after spending a few hours here- we hated to leave!
Beautiful!. It's a amazing little garden and quite accessible by train. Combine the trip with Chin Lin Nunnery across the road to get your time's worth. A great location for photography

Hidden gem in the middle of the city. We came there very early in the morning so we were glad to found out that we were the only visitor at that time. I actually saw some monks doing their prayers and felt spiritual at that time. The place is very accessible and just a few walks from MTR. I just love the concept that there is actually like a hidden gem inside a busy city of Hong Kong. The garden is well taken care of and as what others keep on mentioning it was indeed very photogenic that you would surely take lots of your selfies in there. BTW, I think there is a nice vegan restaurant inside it; it’s just that we were not able to try it.

Serene Garden in Midst of Modern Hong Kong. Nan Lian is an amazingly serene respite and beautiful garden in the midst of Kowloon. Located near the Diamond Hill metro station, the garden is adjoins the Chi Lin Buddhist Nunnery. The garden is designed as a classical Tang period garden with trees and other garden elements that look like they have been there for 50 years or more. In reality, however, it is less than 10 years old. What struck me most was the contrast of the garden’s mature plantings and exceptional structures against the ‘borrowed’ backdrop of high-rise buildings and wooded hills. For anyone with an interest in landscape gardening, Nan Lian is a must see. There is also a very nice gift shop in the garden.Be sure to also visit the adjoining nunnery. We were there in March and thus were not able to see the lotus pools in bloom. However, we certainly enjoyed the gorgeous layout of the site and the architecture of the buildings.
Nice photogenic place. The place is photogenic and nice to spend an hour or less. Very easy to reach, the hollywood mall nearby is good time pass too !!Just avoid on a rainy day

An oasis. Amazing serenity in this garden. Let's you forget you are surrounded by high rise apartments. The water features, the amazing trees up to 1000 years old, the restaurant - wonderful place to visit

pretty little garden. A hidden gem at diamond hill. 5 minute walk from the MRT. quiet and pleasant place. Well taken care. Been there in the morning but a lot restricted area. hope can gain access to the golden building.

Peaceful and relaxing. This is a very peaceful and beautiful garden in the New Territories, across the road from the Chi Lin Nunnery. (Photos of the garden are often described as the nunnery in guide books) It is a short walk from Diamond Hill MTR station.It is a lovely place to rest and relax in the late afternoon.

a sanctuary in the middle of bustling city. nice garden, easy to locate,,,
we we're not disappointed.
though this garden is not frequented by travellers...
prepare your cameras, as the views are nice...though there are some gallery where you can't take pictures.

Excellent Garden and Nunnery. Fantastic garden that is a reprieve from the hustle and bustle of HK. The adjoining monastery and the vegetarian restaurant are great as well. Much nicer when the temperature is cooler.

A Visual Masterpiece.. An easy ride on the MTR to Diamond Hill gets you to the Gardens which are a short walk away from the station. The gardens are based on ones within the Tang Dynasty and occupy a significant 35,000 sq.m. There are numerous ponds, pagodas and pavilions amongst meticulously manicured trees, shrubs and grasses. The attention to detail is superlative and the walk around is relaxing and serene. These gardens are a must see and will not disappoint. As additional feature the adjacent buildings are the Chi Lin Nunnery.
A oasis of calm. Beautiful, serene gardens set within the chaos of the city. Some interesting exhibits and a great restaurant under a water fall are also there

Worth visiting. It is completely free to enter and is a beautiful space to calm down in the middle of the city. It's not a terribly large garden, so I wouldn't plan on spending more than an hour on it.

Garden & Nunnery- a nice morning. My 12 yo daughter and I visited the nunnery and garden on our first morning in HK, before our friends arrived from the UK to join us for a week. Both venues were enjoyable to visit. Easy to get to , lovely to wander around. Very peaceful in middle of busy HK.

Peace and tranquility. The garden is set amongst the high buildings but you'd never know it once you're inside. It's very quiet, very pretty and worth visiting just to see how the wooden buildings have been put together. No nails or screws just amazing joints!

Just gorgeous!. These gardens were a complete surprise. Nestled within the city, the garden is a pocket of tranquility and beauty, and a breath of fresh air after the chaos of Hong Kong's streets.It's a very easy walk from the closest MTR station, and it's worth a 2-ish hour visit (add an extra half hour if you also see the adjoining nunnery). And definitely bring your camera! We visited on a rainy day in May, and even the little snapshots on my camera phone are quite impressive. You do NOT need to be a gardening enthusiast to enjoy your visit. It's simply a beautiful place to catch your breath before heading back into the glorious rush of the city.

Simply superb! Breathtaking garden with a surprise in the end!. The Nan Lian garden is beautifully maintained with lovely fauna and fountains. But the best part is the Chinese vegetarian restaurant at the end which was a superb surprise with awesome authentic vegetarian Chinese cuisine!

A beautiful island of calm within Hong Kong. A short walk from the underground station brings you to this small island of peace within the energy of Hong Kong. Worth making the trip to get there. Nice to get some photos to contrast the modern tower blocks that surround it with the traditional buildings and gardens.
Magnificent garden. A stunningly beautiful and quiet space in the bustle of Hong Kong. Not just another garden. Nice little coffee shop too. Free entry.

loved the gardens. Nian Lian Gardens is across the street from the nunnery and is another beautiful gardens. We had an excellent meal at the vegetarian restaurant. The display of pottery being created by a leading potter and his apprentices with the backing of the nunnery is amazing.
Far away from the hustle of HK. A wonderful oasis of calm in a busy bustling city. Felt as if transported to a different time and place once there. If you enjoy gardens then well worth the visit.

Very relaxing gardens. Beautiful gardens, just as you see them in books. All the stress just falls off when you walk around. I would recommend it to anyone going to Hongkong to go there. If you are pressed for time, this is still a must see. Easy access from the MRT Diamond Hill, just across the road, as well as the Chi Lin nunnery

Gorgeous Respite, even in the rainy. Walked the Garden on a rainy Sunday. Quiet. Beautiful. Almost empty. Enjoyed the different structures, the koi pond and the landscaping. Easy to get to, easy to find.

Nice little garden amidst the concrete jungles of city living. The garden is within walking distance from the Diamond MRT station. We especially enjoyed the serenity and quiet from the Chi Lin Nunnery located just next to the gardens.
A very romantic place. Large green garden with creeks in the middle of megapolis. Must visit place. The entrance is free. If you a young couple, go there.

Such a Paradise in the City!. Nan Lian Garden is such a treat for visitors in Hong Kong.. It displays an array of pavilion and the impressive view of the ponds... The place is very convenient to walk from the nearest Train Station (Diamond Hill) and neighbouring another attraction spot which is the Chi Lin Nunnery on the other side of the road. Inside Nan Lian you can enjoy a siesta feel in their tea house they have variety of hot drinks and foods their. I tried their dumplings, it's good. I was surprised using tripod there is prohibited. So you can just ask the guards there to take photo of you if you are alone. To see more of the place, check: http://jlordalmighty.blogspot.sg/2014/05/asias-world-city-hong-kong-trip-14.html#.U3toB142nwI

Lovely experience. We spent a week in Hong Kong and this was definitely one of the highlights. Beautiful park in the middle of high rise buildings. We had tea and dumplings in the tea house. Expensive but worth it. Beautiful alters.

The way China used to be. It's a a very small garden but truly beautiful. There's a vegetarian restaurant behind the cascade. I didn't try that but the tea house instead. You get transported to another dimension. Mobiles must be switched off and the whole place is iconic of peace and reflection. The teas are absolutely amazing and this is an experience you may want to share but equally satisfying if solo. The service is impeccable and the pastry delicious. Is not on the cheap side but it helps to support the garden and is unique in Hong Kong. The small cups and pots are truly adorable and the sight so relaxing. Ask for a place looking towards the lake rather than an inner place. It's rarely crowded so is likely you may have your pick.

Oasis in Kowloon. Situated at Diamond Hill (the green line takes you there, exit at station with same name) offers this Tang Dynasty-style garden many characteristic timber structures, ponds, valuable trees. A dominant of this garden is the golden Garden Pavilion of Absolute Perfection.

Most visit with the Nunnery. My directions to Nan Lian Garden can be seen in my review of the Chi Lin Nunnery. It is very easy to reach and once inside the quiet, peaceful garden will be a contrast when you look up at the high rise buildings of the city. The entire garden is meticulous. The landscaped garden of trees, flowers, plants and rocks are place in perfect position, almost to perfect in our world, but a great sight to see to make us reflect on its beauty. The buildings both here and in the Nunnery next door reflect the dynasty style of over 1000 years ago. The garden and nunnery are a very must on your trip to Hong Kong. Nice to get away from the glass and concrete jungle for awhile. Stop at the mall on your way back to the subway for a chance to sit, have lunch or a cold drink (in summer of course). Hats necessary in summer as you will not find much protection from the sun.

Always A Lovely Time. Whenever I visit Hong Kong, I always make a stop at Nan Lian Garden. Easy to get to, just take the MTR and get off at Diamond Hill. Follow the way to the Garden inside/ at the mall. On the right is the way to the Garden. If you had extra time, visit Chi Lin Nunnery and take the bus to Sai Kung- a nice harbor area with calm vibe into it.

Peace and quiet.. After a trip out on the local train system which was easy to navigate. (such a pleasure after a recent fight with the Melbourne Australia train network) The arrival in the oasis that is Nan Lian was an absolute pleasure. Beautiful gardens, a peaceful place and a nice contrast to many of the busy busy tourist and shopping places you can spend lots of time in. What was really wonderful is that many of the plants were named so we now have a list of some plants we want to try to purchase back home. Wonderful spot with helpfult staff.

Beautiful!!. The garden is beautiful. The best part is the architecture of Chinese wooden houses showcased through model. The garden becomes more attractive because of the contrast provided by tall buildings nearby. Its very peaceful and calm.
City garden. Lovely garden,great spot for a quite morning with a beautiful little gift shop. A haven in a very busy city

Amazing Surprise in the City!. We were looking for Chi Lin Nunnery when we found this beautiful place! You walk through the (free) Nan Lian Gardens to get to the nunnery. As you walk through, I am sure you will find the botanicals, the waterfalls, ponds, pagodas, and the other scenery as beautiful as I did. Be sure to stop at the vegan restaurant within the park for lunch or dinner....the food is very unique, delicious, and beautifully presented. Chi Lin Nunnery is located within the park (reviewed under Chi Lin Nunnery). Both places highly recommended!!

Nan Lian, what a beautiful place!. Not many people talk about Nan Lian Garden when they reel off a list of highlights from the city state, yet I thought it was a nice little walk around amidst tranquil scenery, with the imposing backdrop of Hong Kong’s concrete jungle looming large over the manicured foliage.Just adjacent to Diamond Hill MTR Station, Nan Lian Garden is a public park built in the style of the Tang Dynasty. Among its 3.5 hectares, there is also a vegetarian restaurant and a traditional Chinese teahouse.Wherever you look there are water features, rocks, wooden bridges over koi ponds, and incredibly well-manicured plants and shrubbery all around you. I thought Nan Lian Garden was very photogenic, and it was hard to believe that despite it looking as though it had been around for centuries, the gardens were only designed and opened to the public as recently as 2006.The golden pagoda at the centre of the gardens was very impressive. It was hard for me to get some good pictures of the pagoda as there always seemed to be other tourists in the way of my camera, so it took a little patience and some clever positioning to get the shots I wanted. In fact, later during my visit to Nan Lian Garden, a coachload of Chinese tourists turned up and completely obscured the view, so I was glad I had some quiet time to reflect before they arrived.When I was researching Nan Lian Garden I didn’t really know there was a nunnery here too! It was a nice bonus and an unexpected surprise – although I didn’t see any nuns!
Oasis in the city. I found this garden to be amazing. It is in the middle of a bustling city yet when you are in the garden you forget the city and are in a tranquil place.

Serene Garden. Very easy to get to via the Diamond Hill Station. From there it is a 5-10 min walk. The street view on google maps is a great resource to familiarize yourself with what the walk will look like for you. Chi Lin Nunnery is right next door too. Entrance to both places is free. Bring your camera, it was cold and raining a little the day I went but I still got great photos Trip time can be from 1 hr to a couple hours, its really self paced and flexible to your schedule. opens at 7 am.
An oasis in the middle of Hong Kong.. Peaceful and beautiful garden with free entrance. What else is to add? The sharp contrast with Hong Kong skyline is definitely interesting.
Green Oasis in Grey City. When tired of the skyscrapers and the crowds in HK city, a short trip to Nan Lian Garden is a green treat.

Beautiful. Once a hidden gem, the Nan Lian Garden is now regularly visited by many tourists and is the most beautiful spot in all of Hong Kong. The gardens are beautiful and well maintained away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong; it is very tranquil here with all the greenery, pagoda, waterfalls and the vegetarian restaurants. Nan Lian Garden was created with the Chi Lin Nunnery, located beside the garden and the Hong Kong government.

Stunning. A beautiful garden in the middle of metropolis. We loved walking through the gardens, so serene and relaxing. well laid out with waterfalls, rocks and bonsai. There is a small café with drinks and snacks and a lovely souvenir shop. Well worth taking time from the rush and bustle. Easy to get to on MTR and shopping centre nearby.

Interesting.... To be honest, I was expiating more...But is a very nice garden in the middle of the city with a nice pagoda and a great size temple.Looks like everything in Hong Kong, new to me... doesn't have the feeling of an ancient site.

Chinese Garden of Beauty & Tranquility. Beautiful, serene and relaxing garden. Not a typical HK site of shopping & busy streets. Clean garden with peaceful environment that will make you feel close to nature, full of greens, with koi, and water falls. The temple with red bridge was really an attractive view ti look at. Even our 5y.o niece appreciate this place. You will surely enjoy taking some photos and will admire the garden's landscape even the bonsai plants forgetting that you are still in HK. It is worth to visit , away from hustle & bustle of the city. The garden is for FREE. It's open from 7am to 9pm. Take MTR alight at Diamond Hill Station and go to EXIT C2 then you will see the sign to the garden entrance. Worth to visit.

A must see site to escape the hustle and bustle of HK.... Combine a trip to the Nan Lian Gardens and Nunnery and it's an ideal way to spend a morning in a serene manner. Take a short trip on the Metro to the Diamond Hill Station, exit to the right and simply enhoy the gardens. Recommended.

Don't miss it. Beautiful space of green so badly needed in Hong Kong over in the Kowloon side. Lots of historical replications of previous chinese civilizations and also a delicious vegetarian restaurant there. We spent some hours there just enjoying taking photos, admiring the landscape and temples. For awhile, you feel away from HK.
Awesome attraction. Many different paths to choose from and take your time. Koi fish are amazing and waterfall is nice as well

Beautiful Gardens. We were impressed with the beauty of the well maintained gardens. The gardens is a small oasis in the hustle and bustle of a huge city, and provided welcome relief and a peaceful environment. Highly recommended!

Dim sum in the Gardens. After visiting the Chi Lin nunnery (see my review) we walked directly into the gardens were the peace and tranquility of the temple remained wrapped around us and gave a pleasing contrast to the skyscrapers all artound the gardens. The gardens themselves are beautifully arranged and maintained and scrupulously clean, as is all of Hong Kong. We eat at the vegetarian restaurant in the Gardens having one of the dim sum specials on offer, window seats are keenly sought after as the large plate glass windows are continually washed by a waterfall cascading silently from above. All the diners were oriental and the staff, surprisingly for HK, had very little English but the whole thing was a delight

Tea for two. After a busy day, we recharged with a wander through the gardens and monastery. We couldn't believe such a gem was nestled in the middle of the towers of apartment blocks. We finished our wander with a traditional tea for two and some almond cookies in the tea house.
Our favorite thing to do in Hong Kong. If you are remotely interested in gardening, you must go there. Everything is perfect. We had one of the best meals of our 14 days in Asia at their restaurant.

A picturesque garden in the busy city. A well-maintained picturesque garden in the city, it provides short getaway for both locals and tourists who may be tired of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. It is only a short walk away from Diamond Hill MTR Station. There are a lot of signages that will lead you to the garden. It will not be too difficult to locate. There are a few thematic settings in the design of the garden. Do take some time to appreciate the nuance of these themes. You will only need to set aside about 2 hours to visit the garden.

Average Park Experience. We visited the garden in the morning and the weather this time of the year is hot and humid. Dressing appropriately and making sure you take sunscreen and sunglasses is a must if you plan to go in the mornings during a sunny day. My advice would be to wait until the afternoon because the weather becomes a lot more pleasant then. Other than that, the garden itself is average. I expected to see a lot more flowers and koi ponds. It was a bit disappointing that access to the red bridge was restricted. Tips: (1) Get the brochure at the entrance. It has a map and some information about the history, architecture, and design of the garden. I learned things from the brochure that I probably would not have picked up just by observation. (2) If you plan to visit Chi Lin Vegetarian inside the garden for lunch, note that the wait for us on a Sunday was 40 minutes for a table on the ground floor. Even then, we did not have a view of the waterfall. You can manage to get a table on the first or second floor with minimal wait if the waterfall view is no big deal to you. Food at the restaurant was pretty average. They don't serve meat, animal products, or alcohol, but gluten was all over the place. (3) Photographing the statues in the nunnery is prohibited, but you can take as many pictures as you like of everything else. Also, some people actually worship there, so you need to be mindful of that.

Garden in the middle of concrete jungle. Have been told by our friend, Nan Lian Garden was built from donation money and the maintenance has been done by volunteer. It is very good to see the well kept green trees and the feeling of tranquility is so precious whilst you're there. The red/orange pagoda at the centre of the garden, the museum, souvenir shop, fountain restaurant and toilet are provided. by the way, the huge stone inside the garden is real, heard it is few thousands years of age. take MTR to Diamond Hill to reach here. worth visit.

Feng Shui. Quiet sanctuary. Stop off en route to . . . wherever else you are going. Very beautiful, calm and serene even though it is an actual working nunnery. Beautifully landscaped gardens take you through a series of equally beautiful smaller courtyards. Toilets and gift shop. Too serene for a café but near to local amenities - take a bottle of water and a camera!

Magnificent. A quiet get away from the hustle bustle of Hong Kong. Take the train ride to Diamond Hill. The garden is a five minute walk from the train station and entry is free. The gardens are gorgeous... so Chinese and picturesque..... Everywhere you turn, you will have picture perfect views.... make sure you bring your camera....we thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this garden.... over the bridge you reach the lovely nunnery which is also worth a visit.

World class garden right in the middle of the city.. A world heritage garden site we found just by accident.Lovely example of Asian garden and old historic garden bldgs.Free and easy access, just finding the place might be challenging, .....but worth it just for the solitude in a hectic city.
Beautiful garden. Very peacefull place in the crowded city of HK. You can find precious presents for friends and family in the garden shop. À place we really loved.
gorgeous. A Stunning Escape from the bustling city. The Nan Lian Garden might have even been my favourite outing of all in Hong Kong

Serenity. What a beautiful, serene place in the midst of the hustle & bustle of Hong Kong. To step away from the fast paced life outside the garden walls & into this temple of nature was a treat that we really enjoyed. Thank you for caring so lovingly for this space, & for sharing it with us.

Free, beautiful, quiet, large garden in the middle of busy streets. Definitely worth a visit - close to MTR station, and free entrance. Beautiful scenery, nice lakes, plants, rock formations, etc. Nice respite from the busy streets!

should travel. Nan Lian Garden scenic garden is meticulously landscaped over an area in which every hill, rock, body of water, plant and timber structure has been placed according to specific rules and methods. Traveler should go

Relaxing!. Pro tips:The vegetarian restaurant in the park is closed in the afternoon (3-6) on weekdays. It's located UNDER a waterfall so definitely try to go if you can.On Wednesdays, the little museum exhibit at one site is also free.Nan Lian gardens is a beautifully maintained garden of tree and rock displays connected by a flowing series of paths. With no entry fee and located just a few minutes walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station, it is definitely worth a visit. Make sure to also stop at Chi Lin Nunnery (which is just up some stairs off the main path) in addition to the several other points of interest you'll find on the map. The park is designed in such a way as to reduce external noise and makes a very peaceful setting so if you listen to music like me - take your earplugs out for this one :)
Ever so beautiful. Double up your visit to these beautiful gardens with lovely surroundings with a visit to the Nunnery just across the road and a very easy walk from the local underground station.

Grade average. Nan Lian Garden is next to Chi Lin Nunnery. The grade is also average. There is an expensive veggie restaurant inside the Garden. You can tour Chi Lin Nunnery, Nan Lian Garden together and then walk about 10 mins to the nearby Diamond Hill Shopping Mall for food. Remember : do not go in the hot summer afternoon, there is little shelter in the garden.

A World Apart. Hong Kong is a very busy city similar to New York. In all of the rushing from place to place - it was nice to step into the Nan Lian Gardens to catch ones breath. The Gardens are absolutely stunning in beauty. There are also a lot of exhibits that tell more about the history of Hong Kong and the culture. Well worth the stop!!!!

Unexpected beauty. Exit C Diamond Hill MTR and simply follow the signs. We reached about 1.20pm. We were initially doubtful of what this garden could offer us as a simple glance after the entrance did not prove anything really significant about this place. The magic begins when you passed a small gate (looks like Japanese Torii gate). It was well maintained. The gardeners happened to be trimming the grass, flowers etc. The place was not too crowded and offered a really conducive and serene environment for a short walk. I would say this is a must visit if you are visiting HK. Furthermore it is free of charge!

A calm serene oasis. Catch the MTR to Diamond Hill and just walk across the road to the gardens. This truly is an oasis in the midst of a large urban residential area. The gardens have been beautifully planned and are situated next to the Chi Lin Nunnery which you can also visit. Definitely worth a visit.

Worth the detour!. A little away from the main HK Island and Tsim Sha Tsui tourist hot-spots, but well worth a visit, and easy to get to by the MTR and public transport.
We enjoyed walking round the garden and visiting the Nunnery attached to it.

Pretty, but too artificial. . At first glance, the gardens and grounds of the nan lian gargen are very pretty. But on closer inspection, everything starts to feel overly artificial. Too much effort has been put into making everything perfect, and nature shouldn't have to be "perfect".
Worth a look if visiting the nunnery opposite, but don't go out of your way for it otherwise.

A perfect getaway from the hustle and bustle. It was nice to have a few hours away from the normal hustle and bustle of Hong Kong , the garden is lovely, and well worth the effort if you have a few hours to spare. Graduation and wedding party's are not allowed so it is very peaceful, and a lot bigger than I thought it would be, you can easily spend a couple of hours here, en route to or from somewhere. My daughter in law said that if she lived in Hong Kong she would come here every day, and write poetry! Also if you go into the nearby shopping mall, give the toilets near Starbucks a try, they are the nicest public toilets I have ever visited, a real credit to the ladies who keep them sparkling.

So peaceful and not crowded. Agree with other reviewers, easy to get to, free and very beautiful. The fish were enormous and the trees were amazing. We also visited the nunnery. Easy to get around. Makes for a pleasant change from the noise. Very delicious lunch at the vegetarian restaurant.Try the vegetarian dumplings. I could have just had these. Fresh and Light with a hint of ginger. The Souvenir shops were reasonable priced and had some interesting selections. I purchased a Bamboo hair clip and 2 hand made paper writing books, something I have not seen elsewhere in HK. And if yiu want to shop there is an enormous shopping centre next door, even had a Marks and Spence and H&M. It had a Watson Pharmacy which was exactly what I was looking for.

Relaxing place in crowded Hong Kong. The thing I like the most about this garden is the quiet atmosphere and the relaxing feeling you have while you walk through its many little roads. I think it is the perfect place if you want to escape from the crowd of the city and spend time by yourself. In the garden you can enjoy a pleasant and relaxing walk with chilling Chinese music on the background , admiring the rocks gallery or having lunch at the vegetarian restaurant inside it. It is very easy to get to this garden, you just have to take the MTR until Diamond Hills and then follow the directions- it takes just 3 minutes walking. If you are in Hong Kong you shall absolutely visit it to experience the traditional Chinese gardens atmosphere!

Gorgeous gardens, children not very welcome. These gardens were easy to find, we travelled by MTR. The gardens are pristine and gorgeous. To see a traditional garden like this was beautiful. The only issue we had were the caretakers following us and glaring at our children when they skipped or ran a few steps, stepped off a path onto a rock or spoke loudly. They were just excited children they really didn't act in-appropriately. I would still recommend families with young children visit the gardens because they are well worth it but be prepared for some angry looks and gestures.

An oasis amidst urban HK. Serene, clean, tranquil and FREE! Perfect place to stop by after days and nights of shopping. The garden is easily accessible via the MTR (get off at Diamond Hill) and the location is surprisingly under a fly-over. Check out the vegetarian restaurant or get a quick snack (and some take away souvenirs) from the small cafe located after the windmills.

Beautiful. Truly a place that makes you feel you are in the old world China. A serene park complete with soothing Chinese music on the background, one would enjoy a relaxing stroll in this park. Even though it was just several meters away from a busy mall and the Diamond Hill station, it was surprisingly serene in this area. After a visit to this garden, go through the exit, right beside it you will find the stairs going up the footbridge and through the Chi Lin Nunnery, another amazing place to see. Both a must-visit!

picture perfect. We stopped by at the garden on our last day and we are not disappointed. After spending days and nights in the busy attractions in hongkong we finally found a perfect peaceful and tranquil place. The garden is wonderful with lush vegetations. I am not into plants and trees but when i saw the place it was just relaxing.

Quick add-on. I was at the nunnery cross the street so I stopped in. Yes, it's pretty and tranquil and free. However, it is looks too unreal to me. Many of the tree branches are held in perfect place by wires, about half the paths were closed off, and even the grass and rocks seemed fake. It's worth stopping by if you're in the neighborhood but don't make a special trip.
A very pleasant afternoon. It was a wonderful place to visit. Allowed you to escape from the frantic pace of Hong Kong. The grounds are well maintained. Overall, it was tranquil and relaxing

An oasis in an urban jungle .... As a Landscape Architect, I could not pass up on visiting this site ... it is such an inviting respite beset with lovely gardens, interesting wood structures & wonderful settings. A "must do" if you visit Hong Kong.
Beautiful. A beautiful haven in the city. A lovely place to visit with the family or with a loved one. A relaxing experience.

Wow- Excellent Garden. This is one of the top half dozen must see sights in Hong Kong. Free admsision. this lovely garden is mostly level with beautiful views, a lovely lake with trees, plants, and buildings around it. Get the map with the description of the buildings and the sites so you know what you are viewing. It is lovely. Also don't miss the gift shop. We found very reasonably priced items we didn't see elsewhere. The end of the garden is "attached" to the nunnery, which is also a top site.
Kyoto? NO... is HK. The gold pagoda and and the bright orange bridge in the garden, makes me think I am Kyoto. This place is the just next to Chi Lin Nunnery.

nice food. Located in Diamond Hill’ Nan Lian Garden can be called a public park also built in the style of the Tang dynasty. There are exhibitions for timber architecture.I strongly recommend you to try the vegetarian restaurant and have tea in their special teahouse.

Tranquil gardens in the city. Easy to reach these peaceful Chinese-style gardens but a bit too man-made for me. I prefer the real ancient relics that are to be found out in the New Territories. The gift shop was very good, though, and there are excellent washing facitlites and a restaurant. Interesting to see but, if on a short trip to the colony, there are other better places to visit.

Visit when you need some tranquility.... I agree with other reviewers... visit this place after 2-3 days of the hub-bub of Hong Kong and Kowloon. Only then will you really enjoy the peace and tranquility of these beautiful gardens. I was surprised how close this garden was located to major transportation arteries (raised highways, etc...), yet seemed so isolated and peaceful. The gardens really have a beautiful sense of proportionality and display the art of Feng shui. There is a sense of "zen" serenity here. My wife and I walked around here for an hour and came out refreshed and calmed. For more mundane needs, there is a vegetarian restaurant, a snack bar and a gift shop.The Garden is within easy reach of the Diamond Hill MRT and is clearly marked after the A2 exit of the station. Just follow the signs.

An amazing garden of a class of its own. I can't think of any reason not to visit this place. It is so beautiful and tranquil and depicts so much culture and classical beauty and is also very conveniently located along the train line ( diamond Hill MTR station. Get out from Exit C and you see a big modern mall. Next to the mall you see signs directing you to the garden). The grounds are very well kept and once you enter the gardens, you just automatically speak a little softer, feel so zen and lighter. The garden is next to Chi Lin Nunnery - another must visit which I will post my review later.

Beautiful place to visit. Opposite the nunnery, it's easy to get to at MTR Diamond Hill. The gardens are spectacular and it's like stepping into another world. The sounds of the city just disappear as soon as you step inside. It's a must place to see.

Gorgeous Chinese garden in middle of big city. It is varied, lots of plantings of trees and grass to transport you to tranquility. The lake has huge koi fish, buildings are also traditional. Hope you can go when not crowded as I did as you get better photos and experience what peace can be found in the heart of a major city. Easy to find off Diamond Hill MTR stop, across street and you're there. Also allow half hour at least to see the Chi Lin Nunnery as they are attached by a bridge. Enjoy!
Beautiful Garden. Must visit when in Hong Kong..beautiful garden,so peaceful,so clean and Free..:) This garden is located at Diamond Hill, beside Plaza Hollywood..recommended, must see..

One of my favorites. Came to this area easily on the MTR. Took stop for diamond hill and exit C2 for the chi lin nunnery. The nan lian garden was even better! So peaceful and serene. Wonderful photo opportunities while escaping the hustle and bustle.

A True Chinese Garden in Full Glory. Absolute must to go here and be part of this incredible garden, with water features, rock formations, beautiful plants and sweeping paths. Very well maintained and free entry. Bring your camera :)
Peaceful. Near the MTR, a great place to wander around, grab a bite to eat, snap a few photos, and escape the overall busy hustle of the major city around.
peaceful place in dynamic city. This is a very nice garden at the middle of crowdy place and high buildings, yet you feel the peace and harmony thanks to the architecture of the place.
oasis. This garden is a stunning oasis in a crowded city. It exudes calm and peace. Well worth a visit. Easy to access via MTR.
Beautiful. Such a beautiful place, traditional styled architecture and some great greenery in east kowloon. Fun time

Breathtaking oasis!. If you have a few days in HK, the Nan Lian Garden is a must see for a quick afternoon visit, a longer stress relieving afternoon, photo op's, or even lunch (there is a great vegetarian restaurant on site)! The Garden is a bit of a ways away from Central HK but is easily reached by Metro or bus. You are sure to be in awe of the beautiful landscaping, large koi, and general sense of serenity in the middle of a bustling city!

Stunning unexpecte beautifu spot in big polluted city!. like a breath of fresh air, this garden really is something special and I reccommed doing as I did and going at twilight for some awesome twilight skyline photo opportunities with silhouettes of connifers and bonsai which is really cool as there isn't much in the way of parks and natural places in the city.I didn't get to see the nunnery.
Beautiful place. A must see in your list. Great location next to the nunnery and it's free too! It's rather small so you will be able to complete it in less than an hour
I love this place. Connected with the Chi Lin Nunnery. Try to visit the Nunnery before as the temple closes the hall early.

Not expecting this!. Easy to reach by train the Chin Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens should be seen together. They are located next to each other and easily accessed by the MTR Diamond Hill station. A great way to spend a morning. Follow the signposted route around the garden and you will see all of it. Great Bonsai trees and lovely Lake with Pagoda.

Nice little peaceful corner.... This garden is located at Diamond Hill right beside Plaza Hollywood. U feel totally different the moment u step in the garden n it feels like all the hustle from the city are blocked out totally. Take a slow stroll around n visit the chi lin nunnery. It's worth a visit to chase away all the stressful city beats.
Highlight of HK!. After elbowing through markets, this beautifully sculpted green space gave the illusion of tranquility in the midst of the urban sprawl. A true delight!

Quiet little garden, beautiful one.. The garden is located near MTR Diamond Hill and Chi Lin Nunnery.No admission fee.There's lot of small trees.It's a clean garden, very relaxing, not so many people when I was there.A little red pagoda on the pond make the garden looks more beautiful.Must visit when in Hong Kong.

Serenity in the middle of HK!. Beautiful oasis, adjacent to the nunnery, with water falls, gardens, petrified wood, interesting rocks ( check out the rock house) and serene vistas of skyscrapers. Two worlds, side by side, old and new.

A Peaceful Oasis. It's quite surprising to find such a peaceful and lovely spot literally right next to busy thoroughfares in Hong Kong. The gardens are very pretty and beautifully kept, with nice, wide walking paths and many different settings to take in. In addition to buildings featuring woodworking, rockery and bonzai tree displays, there is an impressive koi pond. There is also a vegetarian restaurant on site, nestled behind a waterfall (we did not go in but it looks charming), and a tea house. There are easily accessible restroom facilities in a couple of locations on the property, and, typical of Hong Kong, they are spotlessly clean.There is no fee to get in, making it an even more appealing way to spend an hour or two relaxing and taking in the garden's peace and calm. And while you're there be sure to also visit the Chi Lin Nunnery which sits right next door -- there is easy access between the two without need of exiting first.

Pleasant Change. The Garden (connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery, and both worth a visit) is a quiet change from the crowds in most of Hong Kong. Close to an MTR station, and easy to access. The Vegetarian restaurant is located behind a waterfall, and a bit different for lunch.

very pretty little garden. no fee. short walk from dimond hill metro station. very pretty. there is a snack kiosk here and a very expensive vegetarian resturant. we went to the snack kiosk but the food size was tiny so we ended up going back to the nunnery to the vegetarian resturant there as it was more in our budget.

Peaceful Garden. Nice garden to walk around just outside the Diamond Hill MTR. Lots of security guards walking around and watching you. Little tea shop inside but rather expensive to have tea. There is also a curio shop to buy things. Nice waterfall and very peaceful.

Beautiful place. I read somewhere that it was better to come at night, and they were correct. The garden is beautiful at night, and not a lot of people stay after dark so you can take your time going around and taking pictures. It's open till 9, actually, not 7 like some sites say. But the nunnery closes at 4:30pm so you have to go there before then.

Excellent Chinese gardens with the finest collection of unusual rocks and boulders from all over China.. This was a highlight for us. My wife likes gardens and rocks, and this garden "rocks." Also, it's very close, just a block from the MRT stop. You can eat, or snack there, and there are good restrooms spaced conveniently around the garden.

An excellent idea to visit. Calm and tranquil in the midst of the frantic bustle of the city, this place is a must for those who appreciate the beauty of these peaceful gardens; the veggie restaurant was interesting and also worth a visit in itself.Not to be missed when combined with the Chi Lin nunnery adjacent to it
Tranquility. A wonderful tranquill contrast from the hustle and bustle of HK. Interesting variety of plants, trees and rocks. Also, a very good vegetarian restaurant included in the gardens.

Peaceful oasis in a bustling city.. We were surprised to fine such a calm, quiet, and uncrowded green oasis in the middle of Hong Kong. Conveniently located next to the Diamond Hill MTR station, this is a beautiful garden and Buddhist temple that is a pleasure to visit. There is a wonderful vegetarian restaurant on site but it is very popular and reservations are recommended.

outstanding.. The garden is great. I loved it and if u like greenary so will u. It doesnt look natural because it isn't but it is still beautiful. Its connected to chi Lin nunnery. The whole tour will take about 4 hours. They also have a vegetarian restaurant inside. The food was just OK, I'm not a big fan.

A wonderful garden haven. We were recommended to visit Nan Lian and we were not disappointed. The gardens are attached to the Nan Lian Monestry and it gave us a couple of hours relaxation and enjoyment. A short ride to Diamond Hill Station on the MTR from Kowloon or a 20 minute taxi ride.

An oasis of peace. This little gem of a place is a must visit when in Hong Kong. You can easily get to it via the MTR and it's about 4-5 minutes slow walk from the station.When we crossed the road and were greeted by the gates we were not too sure what to make of it as it's just off a busy road. However the further we got into this place though the more we felt calm and relaxed.The garden layout is very beautiful and each way you look you get that little glimpse of old meeting new as behind the temples you can see the towering flats. It is a perfect place to unwind even if there are only a few places to properly sit and take it all in.It is a place where the hustle and bustle of the city is slowly removed and replaced by bird song and gentle music.
Peaceful!. It is opposite the Chi Lin Nunnery Temple so you can come here after visiting there. It is such a great place for relaxing yourself after being chaos in the city.

landscaped leg-workout. A great oasis of green to amble about, right across the pedestrian walkway from the Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautifully landscaped garden areas, with a walkway path all around and a central pond with large fish in them, plus a restaurant (steeply-priced). The other restaurant id behing the 'manmade' waterfall or sheet of water that adds to the charm of the place, although looking slightly fabricated. A great display of the 'all-wood' made-to-scale miniature models of Chinese ancient architecture, is the highlight. The intricate interlocking beams and rafters give an insight into the insides of all those great ancient chinese structures - even for the average 'non-technical' types among us!

Quiet and well designed. The garden is in the middle of town but it I still a nice place to relax and enjoy the peace. Well designed with a temple to visit north of the garden connected by a bridge that goes over the road. Close to a subway station and several restaurants.

"Imitation of nature made by men". That's what they boast in the little tourist brochure and after almost a month in China we already had an overkill of imitation. Still, the garden is beautiful and the little bonsai trees look surreal. It's definately worth the short MTR ride. But there are hardly any benches to sit, you must not sit in the grass and eating or driking is not allowed. So it's not really the place for a relaxed afternoon, as we had hoped. If you come here Sunday afternoon you'll meet a lot of friendly maids from Indonesia and the Philippines and get a glimpse of Hong Kong's unique maid-stuation.

It's a special garden. I visited Nan Lian Garden by coincidence. I was lost while I was looking for Chi Lin Nunnery. I arrived just 45 mins before it closed. It was only at around 7pm, it was dark and I was almost the only person left in the park. I haven't seen any guard at all and I think there were just a couple of people leaving at that time. All I can say is, it was incredible spooky and exciting. There were a lot of different sharp of rocks all over the park and maybe because it was dark, they looked like many different people's faces staring at you all the way. The trees also look scary as well. May be I would not like it so much if I had visited the park during day time or if there were more people. I'm glad that I visited the park when there were no ones at night.Tips: Try to go there alone in winter and arrived there 1/2 an hour before it closed. It would give you a different feeling about the Nan Lian Garden

Nice park in hectic HK. I think I got tipped about this garden from either one of my tourist maps I got in HK or of an information map from MTR. Any ways, if you've set up your base camp in Causeway Bay as I did it is quite a travel to get to this wonderful garden on the Kowloon side, but it is worth it. It is so green and very well kept in what feels like the middle of Hong Kong although geographically you might be on the outskirts. It has a great little golden pavilion in it, but it should be noted that this is a park for walking and not so much for sitting.Next to it you'll find the Chi Lin nunnery that is open for visits as well. Both together is a great experience!
a quiet place in the middle of town. what a beautiful place to walk and meditate in the middle of HK Madness....next to the Nonnery, this garden has the most incredible stone selection ever

Beautiful Garden. You won't regret visit this beautiful garden. Once you inside the garden, you will forget all the busiest area outside. Its very calm and peaceful. Located near MTR Diamond Hill, take exit C2 and follow the signs pointing Nan Liang Garden.
Beautiful little gem - must see. Absolutely beautiful gardens, linked to the Chi Lin nunnery and tucked away in north Kowloon but easy to reach via MTR. Well worth a visit

Not to be missed part II. Adjoining the Nunnery-and flat out gorgeous (see details about lovely sit-down vegetarian Restaurant here with previous review). The two sites are an amazing way to spend a few hours admiring the plant material and landscape artistry.

If you are interested in Tang Dynasty architecture, this is the place for you. Nan Lian Garden is an absolute must. 5min walk from Diamond Hill subway station and you are here without needing to pay any entrance fee. You are in for some very beautiful Tang dynasty architectures, remade of course, all of the finest wood work, joined together without nails and designed by Chinese and Japanese architects who demonstrate their expertise in the best of Tang dynasty tradition. Mind you even in China, original Tany dynasty architectures are rarities, here you have a chance to view some very fine remades of that era. In addition you are also in for the beautiful traditional Chinese garden with ponds, bridges, nicely laid out compounds, bonsai garden. Every stone, every plant are work of art. I like the tranquility of this place and you can linger around and enjoy the serenity for quite a while without being bored. We intended to spend a couple of hours here, but ended up in spending the better part of the day . Don't miss the Chin Lin Nunnery which is adjacent to the park, just every bit as exquisite. You are in for some big surprise.
A good start to get over jet lag. My disabled cousin, wife and I went here on our first day, a truly calming way to get over a long haul flight.
Beautiful & quiet. A beautiful & quiet place to walk around. Adjacent to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Do sit & meditate fro a while whilst listening to the soothing music.
Peace and quiet. So much peace and quiet in the middle of Hong Kong. The gardens are beautiful and we spent over 3 hours in total, I'm really glad we didn't miss this gem.

A hidden gem. I was looking for places to visit that weren't teeming with tourists, and cheap, since Hong Kong is a very expensive place. I came upon Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery while browsing through tripadvisor. Getting there was easy, just hop on the MTR and its about 5 minutes away. The garden is very clean, not too much people around, and no entrance fee! They have beautiful pagodas, bridges, lotus ponds, and bonsai! We spent more than an hour going around and having our pictures taken. Unfortunately I was unable to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery since it closed at 4:30 pm. It is a very beautiful and peaceful place. Highly recommended.

Speechless. Amazing and beautiful serene garden. A complex of nunnery, temple, museums, snack bar, and vegetarian restaurant. They play a peaceful meditation music throughout the garden which created by the monks. Clear mountain like water flows and falls across the garden and gathered in the middle main pond where big Koi fishes live. This garden definitely will stop your clock ticking.

Beautiful garden in HK. Nan Lian Garden is located very close to Diamond Hill MTR. The entry gates may be a bit of old fashioned but once you enter the garden gates, you will fall in love with it. Do make sure to take a map of the gardens as soon as you enter and follow the directions laid out on the path to enjoy the different views and to know more about the architecture. You can cover the garden within an hour but if time permits, do take some time to relax and take in the architecture.

Peaceful pocket of a bustling city. Beautiful garden laid out in traditional east asian style. There is a wide range of flora and fauna, meticulously well kept, worth noting when you walk around the garden. The golden temple and orange bridge provides a nice contrast against the backdrop of grey high rises across the hong kong skyline
beautiful. this garden was including Chi Lin Nunnery, great and enjoy this place. so many perfect spot to grab a pictures. Recommended.
Beautiful Garden in the City. Took the subway from Kawloon Hong Kong , to reach the Temple garden. Very beautiful and nice place to walk and take pictures.Good gifts to buy.

Attach this attraction.... ...to your Chi Lin Nunnery experience. Grounds, buildings and displays were superb.Even the souvenir shop was interesting. Not far from the shop, there was a little café/restaurant which had water cascading down in front of the windows. Worth a look. Toilets in the grounds were spotless.

Peace but not entirely quiet. This is a nice place to visit but I think other reviewers have gone overboard with the praise. It is small and hemmed in on all sides by busy roads so it is never as quiet as the lovely surrounding deserve. And they are lovely but not stunning. If you want to escape the madness of Hong Kong then this place helps but we could never forget where we were.

Tranquil oasis amidst a hectic city. Spend an afternoon wondering around this beautiful garden. You almost forget that you're right in the middle of this big, buzzing, urban metropolis. Nan Lian is an immaculate and charming garden very close to Diamond Hill metro station. There are several little exhibits within the garden, including bonsai trees and also a wooden-roof/joinery exhibit. The brilliantly eye catching golden lakehouse and the vibrant red bridge made for some colourful photos. It's also worth walking up the steps to visit the tranquil Buddhist temple. The only negative is that they seem to be a bit strict about consuming food or drink whilst walking around the garden, so I spent most of the time feeling terrified that I'd be told off by the wardens for taking a sip of water!!!

A beautiful spot in the midst of busy Hong Kong. The Nan Lian gardens are very lovely and have some features that were new to us, e.g., large bougainvillea plants shaped and tiered to form what look like giant bonsai trees. Ancient Chinese landscaping techniques have been used very skillfully in what is quite a new construction. This is definitely worth a visit and very easy to get to on the MTR. The one thing I would suggest is more benches so that visitors can sit and admire the various vistas.

Gorgeous!. Join a visit here onto the Chi Lin Nunnery and your trip will be complete. The gardens here are meticulously looked after and are exceedingly beautiful. It is currently waiting approval to be listed on the UNESCO World heritage list. Worth a visit.

An accidental yet wonderful discovery.. We came across this lovely garden while visiting the nearby shopping mall at Diamond Hill - it is a five minute walk from the shops and the MTR. The 'garden' is a small botanical gardens in the Chinese style with everything trimmed to perfection. There are a number of pagoda type buildings that together with careful choice and positioning of plants and rocks create some beautiful views. There are also two restaurants including a vegetarian one with a window behind a waterfall! In addition there is an interesting architechtural display with models of pagodas as well as a souvenir shop. Overall we were very glad we made this dicovery, we followed it with a visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery which is also very worth a visit.

A simple but enjoyable break from the bustle. The garden is so accessible by MTR and is a haven of peace and tranquillity in the middle of this busy city. Well worth a couple of hours - free entry, too.
