Take time out to wander. Also visit the Chi Lin nunnery. This is a tranquil space with food options and interesting circuit walk, about the history of Chinese gardens/ design. Many interesting bonsai-type trees, pond system and rocks.

Peaceful and beautiful. A beautiful garden with many nice sights and buildings. Water, rock, trees, old buildings, small waterfalls, lakes, zen gardens, a closeby mall, tall modern buildings surrounding the garden, all together. And the Chi Lin Nunnery at the other side of the road. Whether you like photography (like I do) or you prefer just a relaxing time this is your place in Hong Kong. You can get here by metro (Diamond Hill station). The rest is for free... I recommend it!
Serenity. The gardens are comprised of plants, rocks and water. Very serene. Little restaurant's food was good too. Wonderful visit!

Beautiful Gardens. A great little oasis in the middle of Kowloon. This garden is adjacent to a mall, kand of a ying/yang for me. Spend about an hour walking around taking in the sights. The prayer and offering areas were great cultural insights.

Exceeded my expectations. First of all...free entrance! Second, you can take the MTR to Diamond Hill, and after exiting, simply follow the signs to the garden. Easy.We loved Nan Lian. Even though it is not an ancient garden (it was completed in 2006), Nan Lian is just as stunning. It is built in the Tang style, but includes a few modern touches that highlight Hong Kong's geomorphology. (See if you can spot them!) If you have never experienced a Chinese garden before...GO! If you have...GO! Nan Lian offers stunning views around every curve and corner, and an experience of the more peaceful side of Hong Kong.

wonderful scenery. I think I wrote a bit about this on the review on the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery, but this is without doubt the most beautiful place seen in HK and very easy to reach by MTR to Diamond Hill station. Easy to walk through and completely free as well! not overrun by tourists (yet...) 1-2 hours I would say is enough at a leisurely pace as it is not that big and its great location plus generous opening hours mean that it can be slotted into most few day itineraries without difficulty.
One of my FAV spot in Hong Kong. Very peaceful, scenic and not so crowded or packed with tourist, nice garden set up which really calm you down for the busy world.

An oasis in Hing Kong. Nan Lian Gardens were a peaceful, colourful oasis away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong centre and well worth a visit if you are in the city for a few days. The contrast of the colourful Chinese pagodas against the background of skyscrapers make for great photographs. We visited the Nunnery next door on the same morning followed by a superb value for money lunch in the food court at the nearby mall.

A beautiful oasis. Absolutely worth a visit. Easy to get here from the Diamond Hill MTR station. Just follow the signs and after a short walk you'll see the garden. It's so beautiful with flowers, fish in the pond, bonzai-trees and you can tell that every plant is taken good care of. The most remarkable is the view. The garden with temples that gives a feel of ancient times, but the skyscrapers towering behind reminds you that the hustle and bustle of today is just around the corner. This is what Hongkong is all about. The garden is really a feast for the eyes. Free admission but donations can be given at the entrance.
Relaxing place to walk. Nice place to enjy and walk and relax. Located near Diamond Hill mtr. Need to walk around 10 minutes there. There is Hollywood plaza there for people to shop around.

A must seen for tourist. I was walking randomly from the choi hung station and I came across this very pleasant garden. Very nice experience even more if you are just in hk for a couple days. The garden is well designed in a classic Chinese style. This beautiful and peaceful garden will amaze you.

Beautiful Garden. This is the Garden across from the Chi Lin Nunnery. I already reviewed it there but to be brief , the Garden was well designed, had lots to see and the plants in there were beautiful. That day we were lucky to see 3 exhibitons, all free. There's a resturant there that served vegetarian dishes but we didn't have time to stay and try but the menu looked pretty good. Don't miss this Garden.

so peaceful. such a lovely place! a perfect getaway place when you're sick of the crowdedness in the HongKong subway or side walks (basically everywhere in hong kong) It is interesting how such quiet and peaceful place is just right in the middle of the city. It's not a 'Must' go place but I definitely recommend it!

Lovely spot for a change from hectic HK city sights. This was a beautiful garden to photograph, walk and have tea in. The dining room behind waterfall looked beautiful but was not open when we were there so we had coffee in the little cafe and it was very nice. Very clean bathrooms. Gift shop also carried lovely items that were quite reasonable. It was very easy to get to from Diamond Hill subway stop

A perfect place to commune with nature!. Nan Lian Garden is, indeed, a perfect place to commune with nature amidst the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Located in the Diamond Hill area, this ancient classical Chinese Tang Dynasty-inspired garden must be an excellent welcome respite to visitors who are used to seeing Hong Kong as a huge concrete jungle. The atmosphere inside the garden is unbelievably serene and beautiful despite its location, being surrounded by soaring residential towers. The garden is just a walking distance (just a few steps across) from the posh Plaza Hollywood mall, where the nearest MTR Exit is located. The garden is FREE to the public.

An oasis of calm. What a tranquil place to spend some time. The gardens have some of the finest bonsai displays I have ever seen. When I say Bonsai don't think I just mean small, some of these are large, attractive shrubs, beautifully laid out. The fountains etc are well thought out. A lovely place.

Serene and quiet. If you are hustled by the city noise pollution, be here for it will help calm the nerves and make you feel like you are one with nature. Very serene and just alright with composing yourself.

Just go there. This is one of the most beautiful and relaxing places I've ever been to. The garden is not very big, takes about an hour and a half to walk around including the Chi Lin Nunnery, which is just right next to the garden. The garden is planned very carefully, every single patch of grass is planted separately. The trees are amazing. Interestingly, the entire garden and the nunnery sit in the middle of Kowloon and surrounded by 30-floor buildings and highways but I do not remember hearing any noise in the garden. It is also a very well equipped tourist attraction, there is a restaurant, a cafe bar and toilets. There are some exhibitions in there as well. It is very easy to access and there are more gates. One of them is almost at the exit of the Diamond Hill metro station.

Takes your mind off troubles, just enjoy the serenity. Decided to drop by Nan Lian Gardens after visiting Wong Tai Sin since it was only a station away on the Kwun Tong Line. Admission is free and there weren't many people around when I arrived. The garden was generally quiet and air was fresh despite many sources of potential noise just outside the garden, and I was impressed by how the workers maintained the garden, constantly fixing stuff here and there. The garden was filled with lush greenery and a golden pagoda in the middle complete with ancient Chinese architecture, and can I say how much larger it was than it seemed! Everything, from the architecture to the flora and fauna made Nan Lian Gardens a place perfect for a temporary respite from the hustle and bustle of modern HK city life. Music was played and added to the overall serenity of the garden. Just go ahead and appreciate its cultural significance and rich greenery. Nan Lian Gardens can be reached by alighting at Diamond Hill MTR, the exit signs will clearly show Nan Lian Gardens and its simply a stone's throw from the actual place. It was a real pity that I didn't have enough time to visit the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery!

Team with a visit to Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautiful Chinese garden. Well maintained with everything clipped to within an inch of its life. Really enjoyed viewing such a different style of gardening from what I am used to at home in Australia. On Wednesdays the pottery exhibition is free. Entry to garden and all other exhibitions free. 'Amusing' sign at the gates warns visitors that there is no frolicking allowed.'

A real gem off the beaten track. A half hour journey on the subway brings you to the beautiful gardens and pagodas. Adjoining is the chin linn nunnery and both are free. There was also a superb pottery exhibition - which was well worth the 10 HKD.

Amazing garden! A MUST!. The garden us beautiful, although it has only been in the city for about 7 years, it feels ancient and sacred. It was built to show the culture of China to the foreigners and to remind the Chinese of their cultural heritage.It is a place you must not miss, the gardens and the architecture are breathtaking.We would definitely come back.

Beautiful garden. I am sure it will not be on everyone's must do list to visit a garden in Hong Kong. However, the garden blew me away. Located just next Chi Lin Nunnery and just a few minutes' walk from Diamond Hill MTR. The garden is very well maintained and wonderful place to relax and have a walk. The landscapes, buildings and pagoda in the garden are simply beautiful. Highly recommended.

A Sanctuary of Tranquility. Just returned for my second visit to Nan Lian Garden (my previous visit was two years ago). It is so well maintained and a tranquil spot amidst the hustle & bustle of Hong Kong. Bring your camera. Lots of beautiful rocks, landscaping and scenery to photograph. The vegetarian dim sum restaurant is definitely worth trying.

Ten minutes stroll from Diamond Hill MTR. I wish I had made more time than just a morning. Do not be rushed. store up the memories and enjoy. It is regulated with guards/ park keepers to keep it nice but I just wandered around taking my time and many pictures and did not find them intrusive on a warm sunny day.Oh and you can pass a Marks and Spencers on the way back to the station.

Very nice and calming. Take the train to Diamond Hill Station. It is very near to the station. Very good photographic location. There is also a vegetarian shop here that sell vegetarian dishes near the waterfall.

Wow! What a fabulous garden. Never seen anything like it!. We travelled by MTR from Tsim Sha Tsui changing at Mong Kok for the train to Diamond Hill. On exiting the station one faces the Plaza Hollywood. The bus station is on the left hand side. Face right at take the path under the flyover signpost Nan Lian Garden. A short walk to the traffic lights - cross the road and you're at the entrance to the Garden. The pictures posted speak a thousand words. Don't miss this fabulous garden when you visit Hong Kong.

A much needed respite from the hustle and bustle of the city.... Like most places in Hong Kong, very easy to access by MTR. NLG is a very peaceful place to withdraw from the high-octane vibe of HK. I really enjoy my walks in the garden when I need to unplug from the Matrix...this is an ideal setting to be contemplative and just to find some rest for the weary traveler.

Maybe the best Chinese garden. Really, don't miss it! It's just near Diamond Hill MTR station. Extremely beautyful setting - trees, stones and rocks, pagodas, bonsai, temples... If you haven't seen it you'd never understand Hong Kong.

Tranquil and peaceful. Bring your old folks to Nan lian garden if you have the time. Its picturesque and the sound of birds chirping can be heard all around Nan lian garden.Its basically free to visit Nan Lian garden but do note that certain sections do not allow photography.
outstanding. you will never know you are under a motorway flyover>the area is seriously stunning and you must visit this stunning area

Stunning and tranquil. I always love the places that are easy to get to on MTR and that give you a feeling that you aren't in the middle of a huge city. The Nan Lian Garden is amazing because you walk in right under a loud expressway and somehow, the sound all goes away when you get inside. There is a really neat exhibit with wooden models of Chinese temples and they are wonderful to look at. This is a wonderful place for an afternoon break from Hong Kong.

very lovely gardens. Go for the vegetarian restaurant. ITs a little pricey, but the food was nice. The gardens are lovely and you hardly notice they sit right in between major roadways. I really enjoyed the architectural exhibit. The scale models of various chinese temples were incredible. Go across the street to the Nunnery and see the lotus gardens as well.

Nice time among the hustle. Not a long train ride or walk from the train to the gardens. Lots of history. Gardens, temples, and serenity. Designed for tourists but saw locals too. Very friendly staff, some with limited or no English skills. One area has themed exhibits that change. Recommend for a nice few hours break.

a fairy garden. This garden is a must go. its like a heavenly garden for fairies. It is too beautiful to describe in words. Seeing is believing. I went there at 7am and the fresh air is so invigorating that it feels like dragon breath

An oasis in the city. After reading the reviews on tripadvisor we decided to visit the gardens and. We're very pleased. It is small enough to see in less than two hours even if you include the Chin Lin nunnery which is adjacent. The garden has many nice features including a koi pond, pagodas and gorgeous flowers and stones. I did have one huge surprise however. I am a artist and keep a travel sketch book. I was very excited about sketching in the garden but was stopped by two official women and told you need a special permit to paint in the garden. I understand one may need a permit to set up an easel and paint but I think they should be able to tell the difference when one has only a small sketch book and a few pens. This was very disappointing. I would still recommend a visit and can say with certainty you can easily get there by the MTR which is their subway system. No need to take a taxi.

Oasis of peace and serenity. Surrounded by tall buildings and all the business of a Hong Kong neighborhood but once in the garden it is so peaceful. The grounds are impeccably neat and you can see the care to upkeep it. They use a toothbrush to clean the tree trunks. Huge koi fish as well in the ponds. Very easily accessible via Diamond Hill MTR station. Just follow the signs and cross the street. The garden is joined with the Chi Lin Nunnery but if miss where they connect and exit the garden, then you just need to walk towards the left and you will see the overhead connector between the garden and the nunnery. Just cross the street to walk up towards the nunnery. Close by is the Hollywood Plaza. Perfect to have a snack at the Food Republic food court, shop or shop at the supermarket before you head back to your hotel.

Don't Miss This Attraction. My husband and I were in Hong Kong for business for 6 days and were told by friends who have visited before that there was very little to do other than eat and shop…they were VERY wrong.The Nan Lian Garden was a beautiful site nestled in the heart of the city and we were so glad we made it out there. The public transportation options, especially the subway, are very user friendly and we were dropped off right at the corner of the garden.This is a serene spot to spend a couple of hours and a photographers dream with good weather.

Serenity amidst the 21st Century. My sister and I almost decided not to visit Nan Lian Garden, but glad we did! When you enter the garden its tranquil setting quickly removes you from the hustle and bustle that surrounds. We arrived early so there were not too many visitors, allowing us to really enjoy a slow stroll ingesting everything the garden offers. Plan to spend at least an hour or two there. We visited toward the end of the 2013 Chinese New Year, which in addition to the normal landscape and exhibits afforded us the sight of additional Chinese New Year decoration and activities. A definite must see…it’s beautiful, serene and free!

In the middle of the city. In the middle of the city you will find this beautiful garden. Expecially when the weather is sunny an absolute must to go and just sit down and relax. Also visit the monastry that you will find when you walk the bridge. Great to take pictures!

A spot of tranquility. Like stated by other reviewers I visited Nan Lian Garden as part of a visit to Chi Lin Nunnery (and regardless of whether you went to the Nunnery or the garden first, you should visit them both),Nan Lian Garden is stunningly beautiful - especially if you enjoy the classical Chinese garden. The garden almost seems to be on manicure; nothing is left to nature's whim. It's stylized and perfect.But if appreciate this, you won't find any better place than this. It's not particularly big, so if you don't stop to appreciate it, you won't spend more than 30 min. here. But even so - don't miss it.

Amazing trees, flowers, ponds (full relaxing environment) and No Fees. Location very close to Diamond Hill MTR station. Time required to cover Nan Lian Garden 90 mins without any breaks.If you want to still see nice collections of trees, flowers, ponds and precious stone then this is the right place for you. You can easily spend 2 hours with some relaxing time to get energy for any tourist spot of the day. It’s a awesome place to feel the beauty of nature and take few nice pics from photography’s point of view. Its not big park, not crowed and with full of natural beauty and pure air.Tips1. Just come out from MTR exit and then follow the arrow direction in the boards.2. Buy mobile sim card with data package (1 week unlimited data) which would help you to navigate the location in google at anytime. This you can buy right after the immigration counter of HK airport, at the time of arrival. 3. You can go comfortably with baby and stroller, no problem of staircases.

Pretty & Peaceful. Easy to visit after the Chi Lin Nunnery, Nan Lian Garden is pretty and peaceful. Look for the shaded area with stone tables and chairs. Have a seat (if one is available) and enjoy this beautifully landscaped garden.

nice place. It was a nice stroll through the park and the vegetarian restaurant was quite good. However, I have to admit that I was a bit disappointed by this place, perhaps over-hyped by other reviewers. It's not an especially big park and the exhibits and environment, while it's quiet, doesn't really have much to offer than being what it is, a park. I did not find much historical or even cultural significance to the garden, and it's not really a place for family entertainment or fun. So put simply, it's a quiet place, a park, nothing more, nothing less. Great place to stop by if you're in the area or nice place to take a break from shopping at the nearby mall, but it's not even really big enough to sit and read or meditate in the park, so I would not make an effort to come here unless you just happen be in the neighborhood. Not a good place to visit in the summer as it is way too hot, but being an attraction that's completely free of charge, in Hong Kong, that is definitely a plus.

Brillant Garden in the City Center. This was our first stop on a two night stay in Hong Kong. We loved the tranquility of the garden and that it went around in a circle. The grounds well kept and the flowers, scrubs and trees were spectacular. The Verimilion Bridge was wonderful to see with the back drop of the city. It is so easy to get to Diamond Hill on the MTR. The gift shop was also very good and I picked up some Christmas gifts.

garden in the middle of city. we are amazed with the garden.... very beautiful & peaceful and forget that this garden is in the middle of the city... perfect place to take photo and make some relax after exploring very busy Hongkong city

Touristy but still beautiful. I personally preferred this to the Chi Lin Nunnery. It's laid out in a very intuitive manner, which made it easy to stroll through without having to think about the route and whether you're missing out on anything. This left me free to enjoy the (manicured) nature and tranquility of the whole place. I came slightly later in the afternoon, so there weren't as many tourists. Beautiful structures adorn the park, and the setting sun was a beautiful backdrop to many of my photos here.

Stunning beauty in a crowded city. A magnificent traditional garden & water features complimented by traditional buildings.Very relaxing to wander about with the mystical low volume music playing in the background.One cannot believe that this area was only commissioned in 2003 & opened in 2006. the Chi Lin Nunnery which is attached is also highly recommended for a visit.A very short walk from Diamond Hill MTR and should be a must see for anyone slightly interested in gardens/parks/traditional landscape & history. An visit early in the day should avoid most of the tourist groups.

Peaceful escape. Have visited many gardens throughout the world this past year, and I must admit that I was disappointed in this one. The plants were too much alike with very little variation in foliage, colour or variety. This is not to say it is not worthy of a visit - it most definitely is, even if for the peace, tranquility and the break from the city that it gives in an otherwise hectic world.The Bonsai on display were fantastic and appeared very old, but were in need of a trim.

Very nice, many tourists. Make sure to go in the morning to fully enjoy the atmosphere. Considering that this place is in the middle of HK, its super quiet and peaceful. Nice pond with kois. The restaurant seemed to be very nice.

Beautiful & peaceful escape!. Have been to HK many times on holiday however this is the first time i've decided to do some proper sightseeing and I wasn't disappointed! Nan Lian garden is beautiful! Perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of the hong kong markets and city! Very easy to find with plenty of signposts from diamond hill station! We went just as it was beginning to get dark and there were plenty of garden lights and the pagoda lit up and was lovely to look at and walk around! Would've been nice if you could've walked across the bridge and into some of the other pagodas, but definitely worth a visit if you want to see older/more traditional chinese style buildings & bonsai trees! Plus its free!

Chinese Classical Garden. On my way to Sai Kung Town, I decided to visit Nan Lian Garden @ Diamond Hill MTR. The garden has an area of 3.5 hectares. It is designed in the Tang Dynasty-style with hills, water features, trees, rocks and wooden structures. The garden was a joint project of the Chi Lin Nunnery and Hong Kong Government and Hong Kong Stars.

Peace and tea. The peace of this garden hidden amongst the bustle of the city is amazing. Beautiful gardens and buildings and the ceramics exhibition was very interesting. Then we discovered the Tea Room, hidden down a little path. We took our shoes off and entered a tea ceremony from the past. Just wonderful and we spent over an hour drinking different Chinese teas and enjoying little biscuits and really enjoying the calmness of the place. Well worth a visit and allow time for a good stop.

Peace in the middle of Hong Kong. I was actually dragged here by my friend and had no interest in going, and what a total surprise ! After the hustle and bustle of the streets of Hong Kong it was complete peace, the gardens are gorgeous and if you have a picture in your mind of china then these gardens will be it , it's also worth a walk across the road to the nunnery

Lovely oasis in the city. I see several reviews complaining about "you can only go one way", "guards spoiled out visit", "nowhere to sit" – I guess my friend and I visited a different place today, as we experienced one of these things. We were free to wander here and there, back and forth, in and out. There were no signs or staff telling us which way to go, can't sit there, don't do that, etc. Lots of quiet spots to sit and relax, and I believe we could have had a picnic if we'd brought one, people were sitting at stone tables under trees – very peaceful. Beautifully maintained gardens, ponds, buildings, rockery – everything was exquisite. I don't know what people expect of a garden, it's a GARDEN, after all, not an amusement park. A tranquil oasis in the city – I felt it the moment I walked through the gate. Free admission, too!Take the time to enjoy the lovingly prepared food in the Buddhist vegetarian restaurant. All in all a wonderful, peaceful outing in a very crowded and noisy city.

A classical garden in a modern city. This Chinese style garden in the midst of Hong Kong is described in the leaflet as “ Serenity in the mist of urban bustle, ingenious imitation of nature by man.” Access to the main entrance is across the road from the Plaza Hollywood Shopping Complex, nearest Station, Diamond Hill. An elegant carved gate defines the entrance to the 35,000 sq.m garden, entrance is free, collect an English pamphlet from the office just to your left after passing under the carved gate. Arrows indicate the direction to walk to best enjoy the layout of the garden. The trees are trimmed and sculpted into Chinese classical tree shape perfection, the feature rocks are extraordinary. This is not a garden where visitors can loll about on the grass with a picnic but is designed to please the eye and the mind with its perfection. Picture perfect, somehow too perfect as an imitation of nature, however worthwhile to visit nevertheless.

Very Peaceful. I had to find out about this place after reading some tripadvisor reviewers' comments and I enjoy going to places like this. I find it very peaceful and quiet. I was sitting in one of the exhibit building for almost 1 hour and I didn't feel like leaving. It was so relaxing with the cool breeze flowing in from the outside, sweet smell of the garden and the soothing music. I went on a weekday in the afternoon. Not a lot of people. One of guards was very polite and she given me some information about the place. Unfortunately, some of the paths are closed to the public. The restaurant looked interesting with waterfall in front of it. The restaurants and souvenirs' prices were a bit too pricey for my wallet. The place was just clean. The garden, wood and rock exhibits were interesting. The Chi Lin Nunnery is next to this place.

Worst experience ever at a touristic spot. I am a resident of HK hence some of the touristic spots I have noticed for a while highlighted in Tripadvisor but never came around to visit them. One of those places is Nan Lian Garden. This weekend due to limited To Do options with family we decided to give it a try. Getting there was easier than expected. I need to mention I have 2 toddlers and we use scooters when we go out. When we came in the garden, first guard seeing us of course tell us no scooter, which made my young one have a fit as he loves his scooter. we pass this and go other 50m, another guard tells me I cant carry my children on my shoulders!!! Of course my kids started asking for snacks, and as you can imagine you are not allowed to eat inside the garden. All this time one of the guards was around us, not sure if we were looking like trouble or why. We went in and out in 15min top. About the garden itself now. If you ever visited gardens on mainland (which we did in Suzhou and Shanghai) this wont impress you that much, to be honest for us had a little bit of artificial feeling, everything was clean and did not look that natural, even if it was pleasant to the eyes. Huge koi fishes in the pound but also a lot of areas closed for public at least earlier in the morning. Now, as a final recommendation if you want a little of Chinese experience in a modern city like HK and you travel with kids that walk by themselves and don't need snacks you go and try it, other way think twice.

tranquilty. a beautiful and Zen garden in the middle of the city. came here to take pictures and relax. the Gold temple in the middle was verry pretty. should of spend 1-2 hours just relaxing in this garden

Lovely and serene in the midst of the city. This was my favourite place to visit in Hong Kong. I was so impressed with the serenity of the place and the meticulously maintained garden, music, gift shop.

Beautiful gardens away from all the crowds. We read about this on trip advisor and it sounded worth a visit away from the crowds of TST. We had a wet day/misty day so wanted to go somewhere which wasnt all about the views! This was a perfect choice as there were plenty of places to shelter from the showers and it was beautiful in the rain. It's a very new gardens and set very close to some busy roads but even so they have created a very peaceful place to visit. Highly recommended.

Really beautiful ! . Loved it and the nunnery ! First of all- this garden is free. You are following a certain path, which is nice and not confusing. There are hardly any people there. It is the nicest place I've seen apart from the big budha( and again- it is totally free)

The best photo opportunity in Hong Kong!. For quintessentially Chinese pictures this is the place to visit. The pagoda in the middle of the lake complete with red arched bridge is sure to be a talking point when you show friends photographs of your holiday. Arrive early for the best pictures without having to join a queue for the photo opportunity.The gardens are immaculately groomed and even feature a vegetarian restaurant underneath a waterfall.

Have a walk early in the morning. The gates of Nan Lian Garden opens at 7 in the morning. The place is peaceful and it is nice to have a walk here early in the morning. There's only few people visiting this place in the morning so you can take pictures more comfortably, though tripods are not allowed. It is near exit C2 of Diamond Hill Station, you will not get lost as there are signs along the way. Connected to the Garden is Chi Lin Nunnery, which opens at 9am. If you go there early, the Nunnery is closed but you can still see the Lotus ponds.Visit here if you want to have a relaxing stay in the middle of the busy city.
Nice place to walk and photograph. A nice place if you want to just relax and take some nice pictures. It is also nice to see the contrast because of the high builings in the background.

A prison. Many pathways was blocked so you can't get a seat to rest. They only allow you to move on one direction. You can find you are being watching by guards, making you feel like a prison. It is so bad. Furthermore, there is a lot of rules set by the authority, no entry, no food and drink, no seating, no ...., making you nervous. It absolutely not a place for relaxing.

My favorite place in Hong Kong.. The Nan Lian Gardens are beautiful. Don't be confused - they are modern gardens built in 2006. But they are absolutely beautiful and worth the trip. It doesn't hurt that the gardens are right next to the MTR stop and you can walk to the Chi Lin Nunnery via footbridge.

A gem in Hong Kong. When I read about this garden, I was determined to visit it during a long layover on my way back to Cebu. Unfortunately, my skills with buses have always been sketchy at best. I missed my stop, missed the next bus, and to make the long story short, I got lost for the better part of 2 hours. Through sheer determination and the help of GPS on my dying phone, I finally stumbled onto the bridge that joined the Nan Lian garden and Chi Lin nunnery. Imagine a tired, weary, semi-traumatized traveler stumbling onto the serene beauty of Nan Lian garden at 9AM and it felt like I had been saved and literally stumbled into paradise (sorry, but it really did feel that way at the time). It was worth getting lost for.This is one beautiful and large garden with beautiful rocks/boulders dotting the landscape here and there, various ponds filled with large healthy koi fish, large columned halls, and various exhibits. As it was just myself and a handful of tourists and locals that early morning, it felt like I was visiting a secret space at the time. Chinese music played throughout the garden from various speakers positioned discreetly behind rocks and trees.At 10AM, various exhibit rooms open to the public such as the Pottery exhibition (with fee), Chinese Timber Architecture Gallery (free, no pics allowed) which housed impressive miniatures of various Chinese temples, The Rockery (free, pics allowed) which exhibited several bonsai trees near its entrance and hosted several Dahua Yantan Coloured Scholar's rocks. There is also a gift shop, a cafeteria, and a restaurant for hungry guests.This is a beautiful relaxing space and I would recommend this spot to visitors of HK looking to reconnect with nature or those who would enjoy a beautiful traditional Chinese garden. Plan on spending at least 1-2 hours here -- this is one large garden, plus you shouldn't miss the Chi Lin nunnery right across the street.(P.S. Turns out the garden is right across the Diamond Hill MTR station too, so it wasn't really that hard to get to. It's just something with me and buses.)
Picturesque gardens. Love the serene gardens but we went at a busy time. Would love to go when it's quieter but still amazing nonetheless

Serene. This was lovely, and worth the visit. We didn't expect all the rules and you have to keep moving, not exactly a picnic spot, but we absolutely loved this and the lunch at the nunnery. The gardens are incredible and so beautiful to immerse yourself in.

Absolutely Stunning!. This was something we stumbled upon when visiting the Nunnery across the road. It felt like we were off the beaten track a little with no tourists and complete serenity it was bliss to be so close to the city yet complete peace and quiet. I would definitely recommend this as a get away from the city afternoon.

Great little garden. Beautiful spot. A traditional classical Chinese garden built in Tang Dynasty style, plenty of picture ops around the park. It's also adjacent to the Chi Lin Nunnery, a temple and the only building in Hong Kong built in Tang Dynasty style. Come in the late afternoon. The garden looks fantastic at dusk!

Calmness amongst Chaos. I was taken to the garden by a friend and we especially wanted to visit the vegetarian restaurant located within the garden. Both the places did not disappoint. The garden is not huge but it is beautifully set between the concrete jungle. Very well maintained, clean and calm despite the hustle and bustle around. Really nice to visit, sit back and relax and take some good pictures. Also the parking is conveniently located. Definitely worth a visit.

Peaceful. Based on previous reviews, we visited the gardens and found it lovely and peaceful. However, what one of the previous reviewers said is correct. There are a lot of do's and don'ts which can be a bit annoying. I was waiting for my mum sitting on the steps and was told that "you can't sit there". To my question, "why?", I was just told that "you can't sit there". I read that the Hong Kong government is trying to get the gardens to be listed on the World Heritage site. To be honest, it doesn't deserved to be recognised as one.

Beautiful Nan Lian. Absolutely breathtaking. A wonderful experience, superb scenery. Super for an hour or two just wandering around taking in the beautiful surroundings.I would have made the trip from London to Hong Kong just for the day we had at Nan Lian gardens and Nunnery, just beautiful.

A Gem. The Nan Lian Garden is a gem within otherwise hectic and busy Hong Kong. Frankly, it was the highlight of our visit. Everything about this quiet urban Asian garden is wonderful. A must see, and it's free!

A relaxing end to a day. I arrived very late after a day's hectic sightseeing. Everything about the gardens helps you relax as you stroll around. It is beautifully tended and tranquil music plays. The water gardens are lovely. Give yourself an hour and you will be recharged and ready to go again.

A Retreat in the Middle of the City!. Once you are inside the garden, you will not notice that you are next to a highway and lots of buildings and shopping malls around you. The garden was nicely designed and planned, it really is an oasis in the middle of nowhere (nowhere meaning nothing worth looking at around the garden!)We had afternoon tea at the small restaurant inside the garden. Everything was vegetarian but tasted good.
Great quiet visit in a busy city. Worth a stop very near MTR, quiet, well manicured garden . I went early in the morning which added to the seclusion ! Nunnery nearby .
An oasis in a desert.. Surrounded on all sides by overpasses and other busy roads, this was just beautiful. Well worth a trip out on the MTR, with the station just a few minutes walk away.

Nice gardens away from hustle and bustle. Nice gardens to stroll around in the middle of the city! Garden very well kept. We ate at the vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall! Overpriced for Hong Kong standards but for £10 for a set 5 course meal each still cheaper than UK! Be aware restaurant closes at 3pm for lunch we got last orders!

A REAL TREAT. So so pleased that we visited these Gardens (Thanks to those on TA who suggested this as a 'MUST DO in HK'). So tranquil and almost unbelievable that such a haven of peace can exist amidst the business that makes HK so exciting. Goes to show that not everything that's special has to cost money. Be sure and walk through to Chi Lin Nunnery right next door. Another GEM!! Catch the bus to Diamond Hill MTR and the Gardens are right across the street. Too easy!

Nice garden, but a lot of rules. A lot of prohibitions: don't eat, don't drink, don't use tripod, don't feed animals, don't go here, don't climb and so on.Nice to see, but not comfotable to relax inside.

Peaceful - Tranquil Gardens. We have been to Nan Lian Gardens twice now and enjoy the peace and quiet of these beautifully maintained gardens, buildings, waterfalls and ponds........... plenty of 'security' ? people on hand to ensure the peace and quiet is not disturbed. Clean toilets, Gift Shop & basic café round out the enjoyable experience. Note - Some areas are No Photography Zones.

Highly recommended. These gardens are very peaceful and quite beautiful and offer a nice respite from the busy city. This garden is very easy to get to - a short subway ride to Diamond Hill. The Chi Lin Buddhist nunnery is connected and also well worth a visit to see the beautiful Buddhist temples. There is a restaurant in the gardens but we did not eat here. The garden and nunnery are free to visit and are very well maintained - highly recommended.Also, there were not too many visitors when we were there in early October while the rest of Hong Kong was very busy. We spent about 2 or 3 hours at the garden and nunnery.

Beautiful Place. Its a really beautiful place see, its really peaceful and quiet. Its connected to a nunnery which is also wonderful. There are little temples, a lot of bonsais, a small rock museum, etc. I highly recommend it to get out of the busy city and be in a relaxed place. Its also really easy to get there, you only take the MTR until diamond hill station and then you can walk to the place. There is also a mall crossing the street so we had lunch there before getting into the park.

Serenity!. Nestled between the motorway and several high rise buildings, this typical Chinese garden is a great escape for some peace and quiet. The cultivation of the gardens and trees are quite impressive and will keep you grabbing for your camera every step of the way. The journey is a bit "far" out from the city center, but if you're a fan of great landscape, be sure to add Nan Lian to your list. Also, check out the impressive Chi Lin Nunnery opposite the gardens.Check out my blog for photos!http://www.vagabondingheights.com/2013/10/a-new-discovery-new-experience-hong.html

respite from busy city. thanks to tripadvisor we spent the last day of our 8 day trip to Hong Kong in this beautiful garden it is easy to find ,we took a picnic which we were not permitted to eat as the park is pristine and they want to keep it that way ,there is a casual restaurant and a more expensive one. We took lots of photos and relaxed in this tranquil setting ,we were practically the only ones there which made a nice change.While you are there just cross the street and have a look at the Chi Nunnery wonderfully maintained and just as peaceful with lotus ponds

Terrible waste of time. Don't bother the long subway trip to this place, all that awaits you is a fake, empty, hollow garden placed beneath a motorway. The guards prevent you from enjoying anything about this soulless scrap of grass, there is potential for this to be a place of relaxation however it simply turns into stale facade. If this is up there with the best hong kong has to offer then there is no wonder the british gave Hong Kong back.

Must see garden. A very nice garden. Albeit small but very well maintained and nice to see! Easy to get there by MTR. Also went to plaza hollywood to relax afterwards with all the walking. Also must see is the 10,000 Buddha monastery.

A beatiful garden. The attention to detail in cultivating the trees and plants in this city garden is mind boggling. Like everything in Hong Kong the cleanliness and (tranquillity in the garden) order was highly appreciated. One experience a kind of serenity when walking there. We went fairly early in the morning before it became to busy

Disappointed. It is a pleasant garden but nothing wow about it. We meandered around the grounds, the planting is OK, however the vistas are not brilliant and the best part is the pond with a good variety of fish swimming around.

Relaxing place in the middle of busy Hong Kong. Entrance to Nan Lian Garden is free. Upon exit at MTR C2, there are signs to Nan Lian Garden. Just follow the sign and you won't get lost. It's just about 5 minute walk. Perfect Garden. The place is so peaceful, quite, and relaxing. If you have time when you are in Hong Kong, don't miss this place. It's worth the visit.

Hidden Treasure. What a treasure this garden is - sandwiched between freeways and high rises it is a tranquil and beautiful oasis in busy Kowloon. Of course you can't miss the equally beautiful Chi Lin Nunnery as they are side by side. Easy to get to via MTR station Diamond Hill and a very close walk away. A lot of my HK friends didn't know about this garden and are off to see it!

Typically a Chinese Garden. Went here first thing in the morning (around 6-7am). Its a quite place and not hard to find. Its a typical Chinese garden with bonsai. For me the highlight of this garden is the Pavilion and the Zi Wu Bridge (the orange colored bridge). Nothing so special BUT is a place of tranquility. This place is a nice one to visit and if you have spare time. Need not to worry, as the admission is free.
Nan Lian Garden. What a relaxing and tranquil way to end our stay in Hong Kong. Peaceful and beautifully landscaped gardens, really easy to locate from the MTR. Definitely worth a visit
Very peaceful. Beautiful and peaceful gardens in a middle of hectic Diamond Hill. love coming here for few minutes of "me time".

Beautiful Oasis in the City. This garden is so beautiful and peaceful, hard to believ you are in the middle of a hugebusy city. Could have spent a lot more time there just clicking away with the camera. Easy to get to on the MTR and if you follow the directions and take the correct exit you come out just across the road from the garden.

A bit disappointing. It was very pretty but was also a bit of a trek on the MTR to get there. We went in Sept and quite a lot if it was cordoned off so we couldn't see it. It was a good way. To spend an hour if you are in that part of the city but not sure it's worth a special trip as there is so much else to do in HK.

Lovely oasis and easy access. Built on the model of a Tang Dynasty garden this is a lovely place to spend some time. It is quiet and well maintained and very easy to get to from the MTR, essentially right next door.

A beautiful and peaceful place. Its amazing !! I went with my family... Everytime what I did was just clicking pictures of the place.. And every step was just amazing. There is shop and a veggi resto.. Though I went in summers (too hot). I was quite lucky at least I had an extra memory card to click pictures. There is peace, beautiful surrounding, clean and moreover just colorful...
A beautiful escape. This is a hidden gem and totally worth heading to. Bring some drinks and a book and relax in a stunning setting, albeit dwarfed by neighbouring skyscrapers.

Oasis in the City. We visited Nan Lian Garden & Chi Lin Nunnery on our last day in Hong Kong, and together they provided a beautiful and relaxing (and free!) oasis in the busy city. We stopped at the small cafe near the rock garden and had a light and delicious vegetarian meal and a super refreshing dragon fruit blended ice drink -- the perfect stop on a hot Hong Kong afternoon. Recommended!
Beautiful. A stunning find in the middle of a city. The gardens are quite extensive and you will need plenty of memory space on your camera, there is just so much to look at.

Oasis in the middle of Hong Kong. Beautiful gardens in the Middle of Hong Kong. You can easily forget you're in a metropolis and spend a couple hours walking around taking pictures and enjoying the scenery in relative peace and quiet. Definately worth a visit to and best of all, it's free! The nunnery was closed when we visited. Easy to get to. I'm pretty sure that the subway stop was Diamond Hill, just like the address.
An enchanted garden. It is a garden within a city. Very accessible and easy to find by following the signs once you get out of the subway. It is a different way to experience Hongkong.

Very nice. Yes is it very nice and good for moment of relax during the tour.Is it so special for different type of small museum along the rout of garden.Very interesting the ceramic and architecture one

Beautiful. So amazing to see this serene stunning garden and beautiful buildings with a backdrop of huge skyscrapers. i cannot believe i read another reviewer say it is not a must see! It is a relatively small garden but easy to get to on the MRT, it is also just opposite the Chi Lin Nunnery which is also a fascinating place to visit. such a peaceful tranquil place in the centre of this very busy city - awesome. i have some of my most stunning photos from these two places too, the Juxtaposition of the new monochrome skyscrapers and ancient colourful low rise buildings in the same shot - brilliant.

Bring spare camera batteries. This is a pristine setting in the middle of the city (it literally has motorways going all around it) and if you want to get some awesome photos of classic chinese (clean) images, then come here. It's free and is connected by a bridge to the nunnery which is also a photographers dream.

Tranquility in a over populated city. This garden is absolutely stunning. The layout is a masterpiece of zen garden designs. From the perfectly manicured buddhist pines, to the lake filled with koi, the waterfall over the restarant, the windy pathways past unusual rock gardens and the peaceful building on the lake. It is a paradise in a city overcrowded with people. An absolute must see.

Nice morning stroll... It surprising how a park like this is in the center of a busy city. Be sure to go during the early morning for a stroll and breakfast too. There are some bonsai trees and carefully taken cared of plants to see. Also, photo opportunities are abound. You can also drop by the Chi Lin nunnery which is beside this "garden".

Avoid summer months. It is a beautiful treasure in between high risers however avoid summer months as it gets so humid especially inside the garden. Good perspectives for photography, direct entrance to Chi Lin Nunnery. You may have a nice quick walk, take some pictures and visit Chi Lin Nunnery. Cannot be considered as a must visit but dont miss it if you are around the Nunnery.
So So..... 15 mins and done.. If you have been to China -Bejing, what you see here will not fascinate you. All are replica. Can still visit if you have ample of time to spend.

They take life out of the park. Because they don't allow you to sit and enjoy a drink in the park and there are constant watchguards everywhere and they blok a lot of the nice places for walking or relaxing, they have taken the atmosphere and life from the park. We were very dissapointed. The park is nice looking but the management completely destroys any enjoyment this way. I guess they forgot a park is to be enjoyed by the public. It is not a museum of art.

A peaceful retreat hidden away in the city. Nan Lian garden is a beautiful peaceful oasis which is a two minute walk from Diamond Hill. It can be easily accessed from the MTR or buses. Once you come out of the MTR or bus station you will see immediately in front of of you Plaza Hollywood which is busy shopping centre - lure yourself away from the shops and instead of going up the escalator to the plaza stay on street level and follow the directions which are clearly sign posted to Nan Lian Garden. You literally follow the path and cross the road and the gardens are in front of you.On entering the gardens you are greeted with the immaculately kept trees and rock formations which epitomise typical chinese horticulture. Follow the winding garden path and you will be greeted with several interesting features. You will come across a small exhibition of chinese timber architecture which shows amazing models of some of the famous temples around China which have all been made out of timber without using any nails. You will see a beautiful gold Pavillion with a red bridge leading to it which is the centre piece in a large Lotus Pond. There are many such buildings to see and then you will come across a waterfall. Look carefully and you will see that in fact behind this is a restaurant - Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant which serves delicious food at reasonable prices.From the waterfalls, trees and rock formations you will then be led towards the Chi Lin Nunnery - a Buddhist Temple.This classic chinese garden is free to enter. It is very clean and well maintained. There are toilets available, a cafe and vegetarian restaurant should you get hungry. There is also a souvenir shop and plenty of places to sit and rest in the shade.Definitely worth a visit and ensure you take your time taking in the beauty of this serene garden.

Easy to get to. After a long day in the city we took the subway to diamond hill. Just ten minutes. And opposites the station this beautiful garden. Very peaceful. At six the vegetarian restaurant opens. You sit behind the waterfall.
Worth visiting. It was a great experience to see a hidden garden in the city of HK. It's a man made garden with beautiful sculptures and scenic view. Worth a visit. :)

Peace and Quiet in the busy city. This is one of the most amazing placing. The second you walk into the Gardens from the busy city you will feel this calm magical place. The Gardens are extremely beautiful and a great place to visit for any one who loves a bit of photography. The contrast of the greenery inside the gardens walls with the skyscrapers back drop is not to be missed. The temple in side the gardens is also a must.

A fata morgana in Hong Kong. 5 minutes from the MTR station, in the midst of a bustling city lies a tranquil paradise.Wonderful gardens and the pond with the koi fish is extremely zen. Beautiful pagodas and buildings. Free entrance!

Worth a visit. It is just a minute walk from diamond hill station. Turn left then at the stoplight cross the street, its already nan lian garden. Enjoy walking along the garden and feel the ambience, its very peaceful and cool.
Peaceful. A little bit of Heaven in HK! Great place to wander with many great places to take photos. Located next to the Diamond Hill MTR station. Check out the Chi Lin Nunnery across the street.
Gem in the city. This place is like a mixture of traditional and modern scene. I love it here! It's just peaceful here, you'll love it here too!

An oasis of peace and quiet. An authentic Chinese garden, a relief from the noise and rush of the city. Beautiful lake in the middle, and traditional music accompanies you as you walk around. Trees and plants are labelled in English and Chinese. Good shop, selling souvenirs that are better quality than you often get at reasonable prices. It was free entry too for some reason - they just waved us through at the entrance!
Surprise. I was surprised to find such a nice place in the middle of a city. Its quite a nice place for toiurists to unwind take some pics and move forward. Nice place and really well maintained.

Back in 2011. What a beautiful place to just sit and enjoy the peace or wander through the garden's..watching the waterfall and looking at the modern skyline in the background of this old peaceful place in a major city.
Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful and peaceful, close to the MTR. Loved it, very tranquil. Give yourself 2 hours if doing the garden and nunnery.

Beautiful place. Absoltely beautiful park to walk around, no admission fee. Toilets are clean. The adjoining Chi Lin Nunnery is also worth a look, though too bad that photography of the Buddha altars are not permitted. I'd advise to walk around early morning or late afternoon, we did it in the heat and it is not so pleasant than. The view is breathtaking, though!

Lovely traditional Chinese garden nestled in cityscape. The Nan Lian Garden is a traditional-style (though new, est. 2006) Chinese garden, adjacent to the Chi Linn Buddhist Nunnery. It has beautiful rocks, a pond, a waterfall, and a little art gallery. When I visited, the gallery had a fantastic exhibition of Chinese artist Zhao Zhongliang. The guided tour I took was good value: the guide spoke good English, was knowledgeable and answered my questions well.While you're at it, also visit the nunnery and Buddhist temple across the road!

Nan Lian. A great place to get away from the crowds. Set aside a couple of hours to stroll through the garden. We were fortunate enough to catch an exhibition of Chinese embroidery work. There is a restaurant which we didn't try, as well as a coffee shop.

Beautiful garden in the midst of a city. Nan Lian is just next to Chi Lin nunnery. This garden is well maintained and the flora and fuana is carefully planted. There is a vegetarian restaurant located just behind the waterfall. There is also a tea house in the middle of the garden facing the pond. Worth a visit if you are into traditional chinese styled garden.
Oasis close to the City.. My daughter and I visited the Gardens in April. We were there early to beat the heat and the crowds. The gardens are beautiful and well maintained. We enjoyed the stroll.

Well Mantained but..... The garden is very well maintained but the best attractions were barred to visit. you could find all sort of plants and trees. It is a good walking experience within the garden. The Nan Lin Garden management is NOT very active.

so natural!. perfect contrast of seeing high rise buildings from nan lian gardenit was raining when i was there.and that made it so perfect.i cant forget the nature, lakes, and the tea shop here.very peaceful and beautiful!
Best garden in Hong Kong. Visited a few gardens in Hong Kong. This was the best, make sure you visit. The nunnery was closed due to typhoon warning but looked nice from outside

A great Garden with serenity. It is easy to reach by getting down at Diamond Hill MTR Station, exit at Gate C-2 and one will first see Plaza Hollywood. Just walked to the street and follow the signs to get to the Nan Lian Garden which is a short 5 minutes walking distance. It is located just beside the Chi Lin Nunnery at Fung Tak Road. These are technically two different attractions but as they are connected many often treated as one enjoyable experience. The Garden is relatively new (built less than 10 yrs ago) and modeled after Chinese Tang Dynasty landscape design. Beside the garden there is the Timber Architecture Gallery, the Rockery and a Tang Gallery (souvenir shop where one can check out the various books on chinese culture, tea, poetry etc.) whereby visitors can gain much insight into related interest. The Nan Lian Garden has always been considered as the finest garden in HK. We find the garden both large and beautiful, and peaceful to walk around. A good stroll will explain how it has managed to harmonise good garden design with elegance and style. Beyond the garden one can also see the skyline of nearby housing estate in the background.We have been to HK many times but this is our first visit here. We really felt that it is a welcome respite from the hustle/bustle of crowds. Another good tip; Beside being just an overbridge away from Chin Lin Nunnery it is only a station away from the famous Wong Tai Sin Temple and 2 from Kowloon Walled City, both equally interesting to drop by…

Beautiful and peaceful escape from the city. This was one of the highlights of my trip. Really easy to get to -about 5 minutes walking fom Diamond Hill MTR. Even though it's still in the middle of Hong Kong, it felt like I was outside the city. It was so quiet and peaceful. The scenery is absolutely beautiful. Full of ponds, gardens, trees and a beautiful golden pavilion. It's not a huge place, I think I walked through the complex within a half hour. You can also check out the nunnery while nearby. Don't miss out! It was worth the visit!

Beautiful, manageable size trip. It is completely free to enter and is a beautiful space to calm down in the middle of the city. It's not a terribly LARGE garden, so I wouldn't plan on spending more than an hour on it.

Tang dynasty styled Chinese Garden. About 5 minutes walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station. A little gem amongst the urban concretes. There is a very nice Chinese vegetarian dim sum restaurant with a modern twist inside the garden. Well worth a try.
When you need some Silence. This definitely is one of the quietest places in Kowloon. Easy to get to (MTR Diamond Hill) and beautiful.

Worth a trip. Whilst I can understand some of the negative comments, I can honestly say my family and I (sons - 22 and 20, daughter -16) really enjoyed our visit. It made a pleasant change to escape the hub-bub that is HK, yet is situated in a very busy area, although you would not know it once there.The food and drink facilities were a tad basic and pricey but that was not why we were there. Overall I would recommend a visit, just to experience the variety - we took a taxi which is always a cheap option and returned by the tube.Just go with an open mind.

Don't bother. I was expecting something wonderful with a bit of history attached to it. However the gardens were completed in 2006 and have the feel of a Hollywood film set or what you would expect from a Las Vegas casino if went for a Chinese theme. To me the whole thing was characterless with the adjoining nunnery made from Cedar imported from Canada according to the blurb.

Hidden Gem in Hong Kong-tranquil beautiful MUST SEE. What a beautiful garden and pleasant way to spend a afternoon. Its metres away from the Diamond Hill MTR exit and you would never have guessed such a beautiful oasis exists in the centre of a bustling area. The garden are tranquil beautiful, well maintained, the pagoda area & the trees are great photo opportunities. It is so peaceful just walking admiring the plants/shrubbery. There is a rock garden, miniature wooden carving museum, restaurant, art museum, , carps in the pond, - 3-4 hours just go by. A lot of visitors to HK aent even aware of this place. Also connected to this garden is the nunnery and temple next door (this closes early so get there before 4 I think)

Pretty, but.... While undoubtedly pretty, this place has a certain artificial feel I did not particularly enjoy.Nan Lian Park (and the "Nunnery" next to it) has been constructed recently. It is basically a reinterpretation of old Tang dinasty gardens and buildings (8th-10th century), some of them still in place in Shaanxi and elsewhere in China. So, beware, it's not a historic site.After being at the Wang Tai Sin Temple (a few blocks west), which had such a lively, authentic vibe, this place seemed dull and even kind of plastic. Many paths and all bridges were closed for visitors for no aparent reason. And there was some "traditional" music on speakers. (what for? obviously the administration did not feel the place "peaceful" enough) Also Nan Lian park is not friendly for children (and for anyone who enjoys sitting on the grass, picking flowers or walking dogs), since there are many rules for visitors... This increases the phony, unfriendly feel. The guard, while friendly, stared a lot too. Maybe she expected me to be feeding the fish or something...The bottom lines: skip it if you're going deep in Mainland China and visit the real historic stuff there. If you won't leave Hong Kong and want to see something more authentic (less quiet tho), walk a few blocks to Wang Tai Sin.

Pretty Gardens.... It was a wonderful peaceful walk through the pretty gardens even in the rain. The gardens are easy to reach via subway. Viewing the OLD river rock exhibit gave us a little time out of the rain. We then walked over to the nunnery--the two complimented each other well.

Definitely worth a visit!. I loved this little garden. It was raining on the day that we visited, but that only added to the beauty! It was a very nice, peaceful walk through the gardens - that I very much enjoyed. I was on a bit of a budget, so I didn't visit the restaurant inside of the garden, but it was quite beautiful as well!

worth the trip. Easy to go to via the MTR (Diamond Hill station). The place is very clean and it is very quiet in the area. It is adjacent to the Nunnery which is another good place to do some sightseeing. The staff inside are very helpful too. Allot 1 to 2 hours for your stay in Nan Lian Garden.

Peaceful green space in the midst of Hong Kong. Went on a drizzly afternoon, so my husband and I got lunch and waited the weather out at the Plaza Hollywood mall across the street from the garden and nunnery. The landscaping is beautiful, as the many pictures show. It seems like there are barriers preventing people from going to many parts of the garden, keeping you on paths away from the architectural features. The garden is hidden behind tall walls (which are hidden on the inside quite well by the greenery), which serve to block the city noise almost entirely. An easy walk from a green line MTR station; there is a bus stop just outside the entrance as well, but we didn't use that method.

One of the most memorable sightseeing iexperience in Hong Kong. This garden should not be missed.Great place to take some stunning pictures, especially of traditional chinese garden with skyscrapers in the background. The giftshop is especially good. Check out the various books on chinese culture, tea, poetry etc. the books are beautiful and interesting. I doubt you can find any on amazon.The nunnery in the oposite side is just as interesing ad beautiful. Great sites!

Very Well Kept. We spent a couple of hours walking around this garden and we still weren't able to see everything. The grounds are very well maintained and they provide opportunities to stop and rest in the shade or go inside to see some of the additional exhibits. When the sun is out, it can get quite hot so be sure to prepare accordingly. With it's convenient city location and free admission, there is no reason not to make this a stop on the itinerary.
Nice photogenic place with free entry. Things to watch:Timber architectureGreenery and beautiful landescapes.Coloured fishes.waterfront restaurant.
Nice Photogenic place with free entry. Things to watch...Timber architecture....Coloured fish....Greenery and nice landscapes...Have dinner at waterfront chin lin restraurant.

Awesome. It was worth the visit. The plants and trees were beautiful, the 3 elders with us were so amazed with all the trees and even the stones. My 2 kids enjoyed looking at the pond and the man made falls. We took great pictures and even took a few jump shots of the kids. Very accessible, just a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station and entrance is free. Shouldn't be missed when ur in HK.

Calm amidst the bustle. As a frequent visitor to Hong Kong I sometimes struggle to find something new to do, and also something that calms the soul for a while. The Nan Lian Garden fulfilled both these requirements this time. It is easy to get to via 2 MTR lines and well signposted and I loved it! Walking the shaded paths, sitting in small pagodas or arbours, admiring the sculpted trees, carefully chosen significant rocks and ponds with goldfish creates a sense of tranqility not always found in HKG. Combined with the adjacent Nunnery (also gardens), it is easy to while away an hour or two. Don't plan to take a picnic though - no eating or drinking allowed (other than water) and definitely no brawling or Graduation photos ( according to the information brochure that features an amusing list of 'don'ts'.

Very beautiful. This garden is right besides the Chi Lin Nunnery which can both be covered in a short few peaceful hours. Although I usually find gardens and temples a bit action free and boring, this one made for a few nice pictures and filled up a couple of hours I could spare.

Beautiful place, visit it with the Nunnery. The gardens were very well kept. I went on a Saturday but there were few people there. (Could have been the heat!) There were a lot of opportunities for great photos. It's easy to find from the Diamond Hill station. You can look for the signs in the station that tell you which exit to take. The Nunnery is a short walk away from the Garden, so you can easily see both.If you get there while the "Exhibition of Contemporary Chinese Embroidery Works of Suzhou" is still on, it's worth the HK$20 to see it. It's in one of the buildings when you reach an area with tree and benches to the right as you loop through the garden. There are about 25 pieces there. I haven't seen this type of work before and, to be perfectly honest, it was some of the most beautiful art work that I've ever seen.
Feng shui peace in the city. This garden is a marvel. Not very old but gorgeous setting. Check out the large pond with the golden carp.

Beauty & Serenity in the City. This garden is easily overlooked by tourists & locals alike (if you ask them, they may not be familiar w/ it or know how to get there). The garden is so peaceful, impeccably maintained, not crowded, nor commercial in any way. A photographer's dream; a great place to reflect/meditate in quietness. Located near the Plaza Hollywood mall (Diamond Hill MRT stn), if you exit the back door of Lane Crawford store, it's just across the street. Easy walk along the garden paths (w/ few stairs) & is also connected (via bridge) to the Chi Lin Nunnery temple (which closes earlier @ 4pm than the garden @ 9pm). There is so much to see & learn about the plant life as well as the architecture (types of wood & build style using no nails) & rocks (large & small) used. Easily can spend 2 hours leisurely meandering the garden & buildings. There is a beautiful onsite Veg restaurant & tea house (both expensive) & gift shops. You can easily go to the PH mall for affordable refreshment. There are rules to be respectful (no commercial photography, feeding of fish, touching of plants/flowers, nor climbing rocks, etc). That's why this place is an unspoiled gem; best of all: free admission.

"New Surprise". Nan Lian gardens are interesting but somewhat dubious for their authenticity as only created in the last few years. Part of the ongoing "Chinisation" process I suppose. Immaculately maintained

Enjoyed this Garden even after seeing some Japanese Gardens in Japan!. It was very easy finding this place. Once we know the general area where it was, it was easily reached by train. There's a slight walk, but really not a big deal since you need to walk anyway while you are in HK.Note, this was our last leg of our travel after being in a Japan/So Korea cruise. Even after visiting some Japanese Gardens in Japan, glad that we came here as well. Interesting to see the subtle differences between a Japanese and Chinese garden. Both beautiful in their own right!Having the high rises being a backdrop to the temple and the garden was very cool! Great for taking pictures. Snack shop and souvenir shop also available.Note: If you are prone to being bitten by bugs, please spray yourself with Bug-off or something of that sort. My son and I (bugs love us) were bitten by a few bugs.
Awesome Garden. Right outside the train station, less than a 2 minute walk. Beautiful, free and a photographer's paradise!

Quiet-tastic. for those who seek serenity this is the placefor garden and flower enthusiast this is also the placethere are no lines, not many people perfect place to clear your headits one of the best place in hong kong to take a quiet stroll and escape from all the buzz in the city
Just Beautiful. I love this place. It's free. It's clean. A picture haven for all photographers. Down to earth. You can feel a bit of Hong Kong's culture.

Lovely garden. I visited the garden in June 2013. It is really lovely and well taken care off and it has this "peacefulness" about it. It a nice place to just slow down from all the fast-paced stuff generally associated with HK and take in nature and most importantly relax. I definitely recommend it. I caught the train to Diamond Hill and walked the very short distance to get to the garden

Amazing hidden treasure I never knew about. I only discovered this after my friend took me there the very last weekend of my two week stay. I have visited Hong Kong numerous times to visit family and friends over the years and I can't believe I haven't come across this before. I don't know how I have missed it given it ranks quite high on the list of places to visit! It's an amazing hidden treasure juxtaposed against the chaos and tall buildings. Is is located 5 minutes walk from the Diamond Hill MTR. I note from the other reviewer that they had difficulty finding this by taxi (it might be better known as the Chi Lin Nunnery which is connected to the grounds and who maintain the gardens). Directions - take exit C2 which comes up to the entrance of the Holliywood Plaza, turn left and follow outside of the mall and the road around, then cross the road. Enter via the Chi Lin Nunnery. It's spectacular and take the walkway and steps to the Nan Lian Gardens.The grounds are beautiful and serene. It's styled on the Tang dynasty style - with wonderful timber pavilions; buddhist pines; and a huge koi carp pond. The reason for the visit was to try the vegetarian restaurant there which is located under a waterfall feature - the food whilst isn't cheap for Hong Kong prices, is extremely good in quality and flavour. The restaurant stops serving lunch at 2.30pm; after that they offer afternoon tea. I recommend a window seat to take in the views and be warned that there are often long queues! If you have time visit the exhibitions - we saw the exhibition of the contemporary chinese embroidery works of Suzhou. There is an extra fee (free on Wednesdays) but the works are visually spectacular. Visit the Chi Lin Nunnery as you leave. They have four lotus ponds in the courtyard; beautiful wooden doorways and some wonderful buddhist statues in a temple area surrounded by people chanting buddhist mantras which has a lovely calming effect and adds to the atmosphere. Really worth a visit!

Beautiful. Serene. But very very difficult to find.. Firstly to get there from Kowloon station was not an easy feat. Many taxi drivers didn't know and we were about to give up after flagging 10taxis who refused diamond hill citing they simply don't know. After one driver agreed he brought us to some apartment. I had the number of the garden and cabbie called him. It turned out to be right opposite Hollywood plaza. Please mention Hollywood plaza shopping mall to any cabbie to get there. The garden is also linked to chi Lin nunnery. But I reached about 6:30 pm and the orange bridge was closed. Many tiny bridges were closed. The link bridge to chi Lin nunnery was closed as well. So try to go earlier. Before 6:00pm that is. The one solace u get is the serenity of the well manicured garden and its surroundings. They have patrolling police troops who watch people's movement and what they touch. We can't walk on the grass. And u can't feed the koi fish nor can u touch the tree leaves. But u can snap as many pictures u want. There was a Vege shop under a man made waterfall. The minimum price for you to eat is HK120 per person. They will tell u this as you enter in. The food is very tasty and I can taste no msg. They use bean curd and mushroom in all their food. The tea tasted fresh and musty. Overall this shop has good food.With a memory of a beautiful garden and good food i will go here again should I visit HK.
Beautiful garden. Large and spacious, beautifully manicured and best of all free. Added bonus, the Chi Lin Nunnery is across the street. Modeled after a traditional Chinese garden.
Lovely spot. Gardens maintained in careful precision, a big shift from the hustle and bustle of HK. The sprays of mist could not cool down a hot humid day, but it adds to the ambience.

The Garden is so peaceful,. The Garden is so peaceful, well maintained and manicured. I immediately fell in love with the garden once I entered it due to its unbeatable ambiance and beautiful landscape.

Amazing!!!! a must to see in HK!. In the last day in HK I had few hours and following TRIP ADVISOR advice I went to Nan Lian Garden.I was amazed. I spent three hours with my two young boys and a friend. Walking arund, having a drink, buying few small souvenirs. Is a paradise that collides with the city. Is part of the city and its opposite. Represents the city but gives a very different sight.Is a must to see!!!! and not only to see but to feel.

Tranquil spot. It was a beautiful garden, well laid out and very quiet, considering the rush and bustle outside. A welcome respite from the crowds. The Nunnery across the road was OK, but is a recent construction based on old plans, worth a visit.

Beautiful urban oasis. We really enjoyed a stroll around the gardens during our short stay in Hong Kong. It's easily accesible from the metro. There are several nice koi ponds and it's a lovely (and free) respite from the urban congestion. The vegetarian restaurant on site is brilliantly disguised behind a waterfall and serves excellent Chinese food.

The Garden is very well maintained. Many beautiful plants, trees, flowers and a nice waterfall. The Garden is linked to the Chi Lin Nunnery with a few steps which is also very worth visiting. They are very conveniently located.

Take a brake. Nan Lian Garden - close to Diamond Hill MTR station -is a peacefull garden in the heart of the cityStroll there' take pictures,relax hearing the music arround the garden and take a meal at the vegetarian restaurant ( it closes at 15:00 !!).Continue with the MTR one stop to Wong Tai Sin station and see another very very interesting atraction: The Wong Tai Sin Temple
Beautiful. The park is beautiful. Make sure to visit the temple. The sites, sounds, and smells are wonderful. Spend the money to do tea in the tea house or have lunch at the nunnery.

peace in the Heart of town. A well keep secret. A garden to visit and meditate.
A must visit to get away from the usual sites of Hong Kong
Nan Lian. Very easy to reach from the MTR, well signposted. The gardens are beautiful and very peaceful. Recommend you visit.

A place to relax. It´s very easy to get there, you get to the Kwun Tong MTR line and stop at the Diamond Hill station. You just have to walk 3 minutes and you´ll be at the Nan Lian Garden.There´s a cafe and a souvenir store inside the garden.The Nan Lian Garden is very well maintained and it´s a good place to spend a part of the day.
Oasis in the midst of chaos. The gardens are beautiful and the vegetarian meal served in the restaurant is delicious.Best of all, the gardens are free to visit as is the adjacent Po Lin Nunnery

It was worth the trip out on the train ,so peaceful. The gardens were beautiful and the silk embroidery was fantastic.It was so peaceful to walk around and to see the skyline of Hong Kong in the background and we had nice vegetarian lunch at the nunnery over the road,another place to visit is The Temple of the Thousand Buddhas.
Stunning. Well worth a visit? Beautifully maintained gardens. A serene and peaceful spot amongst the bustling city of Hong Kong.
Beautiful. This is actually connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery. It's a beautiful place, meticulously manicured. Great for just walking, relaxing, and visiting with special family and friends.

Lovely, peaceful gardens.. It is worth taking a trip to see these traditional Chinese gardens. There is a restaurant in the the gardens that do afternoon tea. Very basic but nice and they also do other food but it is vegetarian. The gardens are worth going to see. Right across the road is a shopping plaza so when you are finished you can go there. Great for getting a taxi.

Serenely beautiful. This was an unexpected pleasure to find the garden in the middle of the city. It was beautiful and well tended. So serene, that we found ourselves speaking in hushed tones in order to preserve the calm, quiet aura. Access this by taking the metro to the Diamond Hill stop. The garden is well marked, across the street. Note: It was quite humid and hot on the day that we visited. I was grateful that I brought a bottle of water and some tissues. There is a gift shop on the premises, as well as vegetarian restaurant (we did not try) and a buddhist temple. There is no photography at the temple. Exiting the garden, back towards the metro, is a small shopping mall. (In case you need refreshments afterwards.)

No park is like this - one way route!. Even I am a local residence, I don't understand how come there is a park which does not allow people sit on the benches, lean at the rails nor walk any way you like!!! During the time I visited it, visitors MUST walk in ONE way, not the other. Not to say turn around to revisit a corner of the park! This is totally absurd! My son was just 4 years old and so he had to step on the 'barrier' of a traditional door to the exhibition room, and he was immediately ordered by a guard to step down before his other foot stepped on it! Unless you want to see how absurb HK sometimes is, you don't have to visit this park because anyway it is not very 'original' Chinese tradition. It is only a place built within 10 years in HK out of nothing. NO tradition at all!

A relaxing and soothing getaway !. My daughter in law was raving about this scenic attraction. And so we decided to check it out. Lo and behold ... it really is a sight to behold! The garden speaks volumes about eastern culture and its people. It gave us a much needed time to relax and rejuvenate away from shopping malls and the maddening crowd.. to touch base with nature though in a reconstructed perspective !
