Nan Lian Garden was a spiritual experience of some sort! We love it!

Something different. If you think Hong Kong is all go go go, then think again. This hidden oasis in the city is just a short MTR ride and short walk away from the chaos that is outside. This well maintained garden is just perfectly calming. Manicured trees, water features, serene koi in the ponds, as well as the secluded temple.The vegetarian restaurant may be pricey (in HK terms), but you pay for the quality - worth it for the taste, and worth it for the experience to sit behind the waterfall!Just perfect to take you mind off everything and relax.

A Wonderful Oasis. I learned of the Nan Lian Garden and it's attached Buddhist Monastary (Chi Lin Nunnery) through other travel reviews on tripadvisor. I would like to thank those who wrote a review urging me to visit.I made time to visit this wonderful oasis even in the short time I was in Hong Kong (just 2 nights) and I was most definately not disappointed.The gardens and nunnery is well sign posted and easy to find. The MTR system makes it easy to get to from all around the city too. Get on the MTR Kwun Tong Line and get off at Diamond Hill Station (The Hollywood Plaza shopping centre) and follow the signs to the garden. It is about a 2 minute walk around the outside of the shopping centre and across a minor road. The gardens and Nunnery (another attraction in itself) are both free to enter and are excellent. The gardens were quiet and a pleasure to walk around, were very well maintained, tranquil, relaxing and are stunning to look at. The gardens and Nunnery are a great way to spend some time away from the hustle and bustle of the city and get back to nature, even if only for a brief moment in time.There is a small cafe to buy food and drink during the day and also a Vegetarian restaurant located in the gardens themselves (though this wasn't open during my visit).The Nunnery joins the gardens via a well designed walk way and is also worthy of a visit.I could quite easily visit the Nan Lian Garden time and time again on numerous trips to Hong Kong and would recommend it to any one thinking of going to Hong Kong.

Beautiful and serene, well worth a visit!. Very beautiful, clean and serene, must visit! Do check out the waterfall in front of the Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant. There was a rainbow in front of the waterfall that appeared to follow us as we walked past the waterfall... very interesting! Do check out the restaurant for lunch / tea break / dinner, depending on the time of the day. It's a good opportunity to try some delicious food and escape from the heat.
Beautiful!!!. Definitely worth a walk through. A haven in the middle of a bustling metropolis. If you want to see a classic Chinese garden, this is you stop.

Calm amongst chaos!. Easy to get to at Diamond Hill via the MTR underground rail system. I'm not a "garden person" but this place is outstanding. I read on TripAdvisor one rev iew where the writer said he always takes time out of a visit to HK to spend an hour or two in the gardens to just think......and now I know why. This is one of those places you have to experience for yourself. Words don't really do it justice.

Relaxing afternoon. This was a nice relaxing hour or so away from the hassle and bustle of the city. The garden is very well maintained, to the extent that all the plants are so perfectly trimmed they almost look like plastic! Beautiful ponds and waterfalls. Easy to find, catch the MTR to Diamond hill, exit C2 (Hollywood plaza shopping centre). Don't go into shopping centre, instead exit to outside, turn right & walk up hill to next set of lights. Entrance to garden is directly across the road on your right.
Wonderful respite in HK !. Get there early and you will have the place to yourself! The tour groups don't typically arrive until after 9:30am!

Eden. Lost in the middle of Kowloon you will find these oasis. There is also a buddhist nunnery attached to the place. I loved wondering the gardens, learning about traditional Chinese architecture and even eating at the vegetarian restaurant in the place (a true lost in translation moment in HK)

Stunningly Beautiful Garden. Nan Lian Garden, has been described as a hidden gem, I hope that it stays this way, it does now appear on the tourist map from the airport which is worrying. I say worrying because the garden would lose a lot of its charm if it is crowded, or a single tour visits. The layout is inspired, and the buildings within the garden have been very well built in aesthetic terms. The whole combination between path, plants, water and buildings has been very well planned. The garden opened in 2006, so it is still quite new and well maintained.Crossing the bridge to the Nunnery gives you a real spiritual lift. The Buddha statues are amazingly well crafted and the whole layout is very peaceful. An ideal place for some contemplation.
Fantastic place to go and get some serenity in the city. Go in the morning as there was hardly anyone there and it was very peacefull. Check out some of the sights surrounding the gardens as well.

Oasis of tranquility in the heart of the city!. We ventured to the garden on our last morning in Hong Kong. It was a great finish to our visit to this beautiful city. It is easy to find and very close to the subway station. Walk up a few steps and you are in the Chi Lin Nunnery. It is a terrific change of pace and place to catch your breath after the hustle and bustle of the city.

Wonderful Garden. Nan Lian & Chi Lin are the places must see when visit to Hong Kong. These place easy to reach just by walk from MTR Diamond Hill station. The landscape designed are very beautiful and feel peaceful and clean. Don't forgot your camera as this is nice place for photograph.

Wonderful contrast to modern day Hong Kong. Spend some time here to wind down from the frenetic pace of Hong Kong. Music is played which helps to distract from the buzz of traffic . Delightful place to visit within a very short walk from Diamond Hill station. Styled in old fashioned way with manicured gardens and beautiful wooden replicas of temples on exhibition. It took me a little while to adapt to the pace but felt very peaceful when I left. Go to the Chi Lin Nunnery that is attached, pay your respects by bowing 3 times to the buddhas.

One of the best gardens ever. Nan lian & Chi Lin are almost a continuation of each other & a must see, a bit out of the usual travel route but worth it, Diamond Hill station plenty of Buses & Metro rail stop.

peaceful. a lovely place to visit in the morning before the groups arrive.There is excellent toilets and a cafe.The views of the gardens change around every corner. A peaceful and serene garden in the middle of the hustle of Diamond hill

A very neatly maintained Garden.. The Nan Lian Garden at Fengde Road in Hong Kong is an easily approachable, neat and well maintained garden full of greenery. It is at a short 10 minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR Station , exit C-2. Chi Lin nunnery is also located within the Garden and should not be missed when visiting Nan Lian .

An oasis of tranquility in the heart of Hong Kong. Only a few paces away (5 minutes walk at the most) from the Diamond Hill MTR station (exit C2) one can find a really peaceful space that takes you away from the city buzz. A very welcome break to the normal HK life whether a visitor or a resident this public park (free entry) is designed in the style of the Tang dynasty. The plants and trees are beautifully shaped and together with the beautifully designed paths and pavilions provide the perfect environment for an escape from the city rhythm. Do not miss a visit to the adjacent Chi Lin nunnery. The spirituality of the place will complete your overall experience!

Secluded, Serene and worth a visit .... Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery are connected via an overbridge. So, I will write about both together.It is remarkable, how the atmosphere changes dramatically after entering the garden. It is barely 5 mins walk from the MTR exit (get down at Diamond Hill). Very quiet place. On the day I visited, it was misty and drizzling. It added to the effect. There are places where we can sit/relax under trees (and meditate?). I would have liked to stay a bit and relax as opposed to 'sight-see' this place. Eating food is prohibited, for good reason. A short walk on an overbridge gets you to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Another nice place, if you like history and religion. Many religions originated in India. Ditto in case of Buddhism. The term buddha means 'enlightened one'. So, there are technically many Buddha's in history. The one we commonly use the term for is the one from India, specifically, Sakhyamuni Buddha. As with other temples in HK, this place is generous with visitors. Visitors have close access to most things. Can take photos in many places etc. To get the most out of the visit, I suggest reading a bit about the place and Buddhist history.While there is no fee to visit/enter, there seems to be occasional exhibitions that require a fee to see. Fair enough. I visited the "Su Embroidary" exhibition. Liked it. Suggested duration: 2 hours at least.
Lovely Garden. Just a delightful place to visit, peaceful and beautiful. the design has a serene quality hard to imagine in the middle of Kowloon.

An oasis in the heart of suburbia. What a hidden gem! And at no charge as well. The gardens were very well maintained and the bonsai garden blew us away. The Chi Lin nunnery was so tranquil and the vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall was totally unexpected - excellent food and service. We spent an entire afternoon there.
Easy access by MTR to Diamond Hill.
Peaceful. Next to the Chi Lin Nunnery, it's a place of quietness next to the big city. A place to spend hours. Unfortunately it was raining when we went there. But still nice even in the rain.

Tranquil and beautiful. beautiful and peaceful place just a few steps from a very busy shopping mall. It didn't however "blow our mind away", like our travel guide said, but still absolutely worth a visit! It is so tranquil compared to the busy city. The park supervisors are very strict, we weren't even allowed to eat a cookie on a bench.

Chi lin Nunnery and garden. So easy to get to by bus and makes you glad to be alive. Note- no food to be eaten in the grounds but there are 2 eating places. If you like water, bonsai and topiary, this is heaven.

A garden of tranquility and beauty. These gardens nestle into the city miraculously creating an island of peaceful meditation in the most populous and bustling city possible. Visually beautiful, with wonderful birdlife and manicured gardens and temples...gorgeous!
Delightful space. We visited this park and the Chi Lin nunnery on a warm and humid May Day. It is worth the visit and is immaculately cared for and a beautiful space. Would recommend to everyone

Zen Green Garden. If you want to check something during your visit to Hongkong apart from shopping, this garden is a must visit. We went by MTR and got out at Diamond hill station took exit C2. From the exit you can find the direction how to reach the garden, it's only 10 min walk from the station. This gardenis really well managed. Neat and green, trully a Zen in the city. We can find some different shape of chinese gazebo, green trees, and the rocks. It's worth a visit!

A PLACE TO RELAX FOR "FREE". Nan Lian Garden is a nice place to getaway from the fast paced life in Hong Kong. It is located across MTR Diamond Hill Station and Plaza Hollywood. The trees, ponds, stones, flowers and birds were put together beautifully. When we got there, we couldn't stop taking pictures, everything in the garden is just so lovely. Even the background music that's playing compliments the scenery. It is good to visit the garden during the afternoon to early evening so you can see the day and night view of the garden. In the evening the place is enhanced by the spotlights; you'll appreciate the view even more. The Chi Lin Nunnery located right across is worth visiting too. Depending on how much time you have but an hour would be enough to go around the whole place.You can also drop by at Plaza Hollywood. It is a mall with restaurants, cinemas and a wide variety of shops.

Peace and tranquility in a storm of concrete. This is one of the most beautiful gardens in Hong Kong - if not THE most beautiful. It sits amid high-rise buildings and concrete flyovers but once inside the gates, all of that is forgotten as you walk through fantastic gardens and buildings. Very peaceful and not to be missed.
Must see. A must see in hong kong. One of the most amazing gardens ever. Don't think, just go and stay. Even in japan I didn't found anything like this.

beautiful escape from the bustle of Hong Kong. been here a few times now: took my daughter and she loved it.Its a tranquil beautiful place across the raod from the nunnery whcih is very much worth a visit. free to get and wander around the gardens, take in the pavilion and even eat at the restaurant under the waterfall. A very pleasant and relaxed way to while away some time in Hong Kong and recharge the battery. Deecent souvenier shop here too whcih has come in useful for gifts for friends and family

Peace and calm in the city. Great get away from the city. The cable car ride was fantastic even though it was cloudy that day. The views from the car are unbelievable. Go eat at the buddhist monastery if you enjoy simple vegetarian meal.
peaceful. this marvellous garden made me imagine how life might have been in the old china some century ago. you breathe the peace in the air and soon you feel better. recomeded it. born2travel.it

Formal oriental gardens which are a delight.. These gardens are just wonderful to walk around and get a feel for the subtle architecture of an oriental garden. It has the lot - a golden pagoda, colourful bridges, oversized koi carp, lakes, waterfalls, mountainous rocks and of course the plants themselves. Piped oriental music completes the atmosphere as you wander around. A very impressive display unlike any other garden that you would encounter in Europe.
Definately worth a visit. Beautiful tranquil gardens, this was one of the highlights of our trip to Hong Kong, well worth a visit. Easy to get to on the MTR

Finding peace in Hong Kong. Here you can.. It was so peaceful and nice to walk through these gardens, sit under a tree and enjoying looking around and forcing yourself to stay there for a while to absorb the snenery, the overall atmosphere. On the other site is a beautiful wooden replica of a monastery, called Chi Lin Nunnery with a very nice garden.

A haven of tranquility. This garden is a nice break from the concrete jungle that is Hong Kong. The garden is very manicured and there are some pretty buildings and ponds. Im not qualified to say whether this is an authentic Chinese garden or not but it certaily provided a wealth of Chinesey photo opportunities. While there definitly walk across the road to the Chi Lin nunnery.
Average!. I went to see this place on the reccomendation of Trip Advisor members but was disappointed. Nothing much to see and do here. Can be avoided if this place is out of the way
Beautiful. A quiet and beautifully kept oasis. Lovely trees and plants. Take a little time to visit, it's right near the subway station and nice to get away form the hectic pace and city crowds.

If you like tree gardens and stones this is a must. I greatly enjoyed walking through that garden. During our visit in May we were able to observe workers on how they prune the trees back into shape.I also love the contrasting views of the peacefulness and the sky scrapers in the back round. There is a vegetarian restaurant on the premises as well as a cafe place with some snacks and drinks. They will not allow food or drink while walking the park, except water.The Chin Lin Nunnery is located within the garden, there you can also see some bonsai trees.It is easy to get there, Diamond Hill MTR station (exit C2) and from there a short walk, 5 to 10 min. You will find signs pointing you in the right direction just outside of the MTR station.

A haven in the midst of one of the busiest cities in the world. Having been to Hong Kong many times, we decided to visit the Garden and we were absolutely delighted that we did. It is a bit of peace in quiet in a hectic city. The topiary and design of the garden make it w worthwhile visit for admirers of eastern gardens.
Peaceful. See review on Ch Lin Nunnery . Very peaceful and scenic place. Definitely going back! Easy access from the Diamond Hill Station. The bonsai collection is worth seeing as is the Rockery

Tranquil getaway in the city. What a lovely place! Just 5 minutes stroll from the Diamond Hill MRT station, this is the perfect place to unwind from the bustling streets of Hong Kong. Serene and calm, with only birdsong and the sound of running water occasionally breaking the silence. We enjoyed a tasty vegetarian lunch in the nice restaurant before exploring the rest of the beautiful temple complex. A treat for the weary traveller or anyone else searching for some tranquility from the busy city life!
Unexpected sanctuary. A 2 minute walk from Diamond Hill MTR. Great views, peaceful location with a juxtaposed high-rise backdrop.

A tranquil oasis. We visited these gardens and the adjacent nunnery on a wet day, but, armed with an umbrella it was still a beautiful spot. So easy to get to on the main MTR line, it is so peaceful to walk around the gardens,have a vegetarian lunch and relax with the bustle of HK just over the wall. Well worth a visit.

BEAUTIFUL GARDENS. It was a beautiful peaceful tranquil place just outside DIamond Hill MTR station.Easy to get to foilow pink signs when you get off train. Piped music throughout the garden. I like gardening and appreciate this sort of garden.

so enchanting!. The first thing that amazed me about this beautiful place was that we weren't took a charge to get into this place, which is different from Indonesia, that we have to spend an amount of money to buy some ticket to enter ALL the tourist attraction site.

A Peaceful Retreat. During our 3-night stay in Hong Kong,visiting a number of sites and attractions in the area,we arrived one afternoon,away from the hustle and bustle,at 'Nan Lian Garden'.We followed the one-way circular route around the grounds and spent a couple of hours appreciating its timber structures,water ponds,odd-shaped rocks and well laid out gardens with gentle music from hidden speakers set in the ground.They also possess a restaurant for light meals or you can enjoy a coffee etc in the smaller snack-bar.To find the place-take the 'MTR' to 'Diamond Hill station',exit C2 and follow the signs.Well worth a visit and its free entry.

Time out. As far a city gardens go, this is relatively compact but it is beautifully laid out. You will definitely want to take some pictures of the buildings and gardens as they are very much Hong Kong and China. A number of walking paths were cordoned off when we were there without explanation and the tea house did not open until noon so if you go in the morning, no tea house which was disappointing. If you go on a weekend be prepared for crowds and not as much of a "meditative" setting as it could be.Easy to get to on the MTR.As free attractions go, this is a good one.
OK kinda place. Nothing special about this garden, some Chinese architecture & a vegetarian restaurant. If you are in HK for a long period you might visit it, otherwise you can skip it.

Worth the trip and easy to find.. This garden was very well organized and well maintained. There are maps to guide you through the grounds and several breathtaking areas throughout. There are also free exhibits and museums sprinkled throughout to make it educational as well. The Su Embroidery exhibit was particularly breathtaking.

Beautiful garden well worth a visit. We visited this garden and next door nunnery - and really enjoyed it. Well tended, with calming music playing, this is an enjoyable couple of hours. Easy to get to as well with the metro to Diamond Hill. Visit the nunnery as well.
For a relaxing break of the hkg hustle and bustle.. Very beautiful, went there late afternoon. The park plays classical Chinese string music, which gave us a relaxing and calming feel. A must visit.

Nan Lian Loveliness. My daughter and I really enjoyed strolling around this lovely public garden. It's best to go in the front entrance, directly opposite Diamond Hill Station, as there's an info booth with free guides/maps in English to help you make sense of what you're looking at.The main attraction here is the rather surreal luminous yellow Pavillion of Absolute Perfection and the zingy orange Zi-Wu Bridge, surrounded by a lotus laden moat. To our eyes it all looked very 'Wizard of Oz.' Even the trees framing this scene were crooked, which seemed appropriate. It's a very clean park, and there's a small museum exhibiting wooden replica's of beautiful architecture from previous dynasties. Well worth a wander in there.To sit and relax, or pause to plan the rest of your day, I recommend the Banyan tree section of the park. These trees are just amazing - I loved them.It's a really nice park, and combined with the Chi Lin Nunnery next door, I think that visiting these Diamond Hill beauties, offers balance, depth and context to any Hong Kong trip: a must.
WOW. What a great sanctuary in the middle of a bustling city. It is small, but very peaceful and beautiful. It is quite a relaxing place and a beautiful find.

Tranquil Japanese Gardens in Kowloon. A nice spot in the middle of Kowloon. Well laid out Japanese style garden with interesting rocks from China. Plus a gift shop, cafe, vegetarian restaurant and clean toilets! Well worth a look if you want to do something a little different. And it is connected to a Nunnery (a temple) which is also worth looking around. Both are free.Nearby is Diamond Hill MTR and a massive shopping mall if you fancy getting back to real HK!

Stunning!. A great little garden in the centre of a busy city! A very close walk to the Chi Lin Nunnery (you can get to in from the inside of the gardens). Very beautiful with some good photo opportunities!

Pretty. The gardens are lovely. Hong Kong is such a busy cosmopolitan place and I love that you can get tranquil place like this right in the middle of all that. The gardens cover a decent amount of ground space to wander about in. We probably leisurely wandered for a couple of hours here and the Chi Lin Nunnery over the road. The grounds are so well kept and really beautiful foliage and trees all over. Some ponds with fish swimming about, a waterfall here and there and a little museum in the midst of it. Some great photo opportunities here!

A beautiful and peaceful garden to relax in. A beautiful garden surrounded by skyscrapers. The gardens is very well maintained.Amazing ponds and flowers everywhere in a very nice scenery. There is actually two gardens joined together here, the Nan Lian Garden and the Chi Lin Nunnery.This is also a place of worship with buddhist temples.The admission is free.

Another side to Hong Kong. When people think of Hong Kong, they think busy, shopping, business - you dont think, quiet, peaceful, calming. But that is Nan Lian Garden, the garden is very much a Japanese style and very well maintained - when you get tired of the crowds and the shopping, catch the MTR on the Green - Kwun Tung Line to the Diamond Hill station use Exit C2 and go to Nan Lian Garden entry is free. There is a restaurant under a waterfall, you will understand when you see it. But there is also a small cafe, try the vegterian noodles, they are great. Also while you are there go across Fung Tak road to Chi Lin Nunnery - it is beautiful as well.

A serene side of Hong Kong. Over 35,000 square feet in total, this is a highly recommended park made according to a Tang Dynasty style. A place made for reflecting in a peaceful and serene environment, something which is rare in Hong Kong. If you appreciate Bonsai, Koi ponds and traditional Chinese style structures for a picturesque background for your photographs, then Nan Lian Garden is a good choice. The Chi Lin Nunnery sits beside the garden.
Beautiful. Amazing!! It is hard to believe that you are in the middle of Kowloon, it is so peaceful and tranquil

A real gem. A beautiful place to visit. The highlight of my trip. It was very serene and peaceful. The traditional architecture is amazing and the gardens superbly designed. Went in the early evening, and there were only a few others about.While the gardens are free to visit, the tea house is not cheap, but well worth a visit for the service and atmosphere. The food at the vegetarian restaurant is also quite good, and if you can get a seat at the window, has a wonderful view out into the gardens through a waterfall.
Beautiful garden.. This is a very beautiful garden. I really enjoyed it. A few minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR-station. It has it all. Will come back here later.

Peaceful. I like the Park itself - how it was arranged to the tranquility (no mad, noisy crowds here). The only thing is that the Nunnery has a no picture policy for their saints (which I have to respect of course).
Beautiful garden. This is a very beautiful garden of Hong Kong, however a little further away from the centre. Unfortunately it was raining when I was there, so I could not take in its full beauty.

Oasis Garden!. Amidst the hustle and bustle, there still exists a quite and tranquil place where one could relax and communicate with nature! The Garden is so peaceful, well maintained and manicured. I immediately fell in love with the garden once I entered it due to its unbeatable ambiance and beautiful landscape. The Pavilion with a lotus pond, waterfall and a bridge is so mystifying. As if you want to travel back in time and be amongst the ancestors who dominated and experienced the laid back life!Nan Lian Garden is located near MTR Diamond Hill. It's so easy to look for the place since directions can be seen inside the MTR and once you take your Exit. Just a few walk you'll be there at the entrance gate. Chin Lin Nunnery lies within close. Don't forget to check it out. Both are free of charge. All angles are picture perfect so don't forget to bring your camera!

Great Spot. This is opposite the Chi Lin Nunnery. See my review for Chi Lin Nunnery.But for quick note, many areas are restricted especially when they have prayer days and I supposed it was Prayer Day when I visited because I could hear chanting throughout.Don't forget to offer 'oil money' for prayers for either living or deceased family members or friends. Amount of contribution is 'from the heart'.

Very peacefull. One of my favorite places in Hong Kong. The gardens are beautifully done and it makes a peaceful oasis in a busy city. Its very serene to walk around with a huge Koi pond in the middle and a lovely Bonsai display. If you are visiting here also combine it with the Chi Lin Nunnery.We used the metro, Diamond Hill stop and its only a short walk from there to the gardens.
Nice morning walk in Hong Kong. We visited the Nan Lian garden before a meeting, was a nice place to walk, the flora and fauna are worth the stop.

Beautiful Gardens. It really is a beautiful place to go and have a look at. Tucked away from the hustle and bustle, You step into another world. We stopped by on our last day and although we didn't stay for ages we enjoyed a quite walk around. Easy to get to on the mono rail with the Diamond Hill stop just near by. Take your camera and enjoy some pretty sights.

Mesmerizing experience at Nan Lian Garden. Without doubt this is the number one tourist attraction in Hong Kong. The sheer beauty of the bonsai trees and rock structures stunned us in every possible way. The peaceful walk around this garden and the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery was the best thing I had done in a long time.Nan Lian Garden is easily accessible. Simply reach Diamond Hill MTR station and follow the signs. In no time you'll be transferred to a pristine land of natural beauty.

Peaceful and beautiful. Highly recommended for a visit, beautiful, peaceful and a really special place. We took a taxi from our hotel (Harbour Grand Kowloon) but the Gardens can easily be reached by MTR to the Diamond Hill station a very short walk.

Beautiful !. We went there by 7 pm and we saw the beautiful garden decorated by lights and it looked so serene and heavenly ! We ate at the vegetarian restaurant in the park. It was too bland for us.. but the location was terrific - just behind a waterfall and we could enjoy the view while eating.

Just amazing. Reviews just cannot do justice to this gem in the middle of Kowloon. The gardens are stunning. There are also a number of buildings and temples to wander around. As you emerge from the MRT station you just don't know what's treat you are going to encounter. The gardens are pristine and on a par with many I have visited in china and Japan. The wodden buildings are evocative of a time gone by. In time you forget that you are in the middle of a housing estate! The site has very good facilities with wash rooms cafe, classic tea house and restaurant. There is also a gift shop.Around each corner there is an absolute treat.

A not to be missed experience. We have seen the Light Show (Disappointing) Dialogue in the Dark ( an experience) but these gardens are just beautiful and in our view have to be the number one tourist attraction in Hong Kong!It is a place of great beauty with lovely manicured trees and bonsai interspersed with uniquely shaped rocks. If this is not enough there' is a wonderful "Chinese Timber Architecture Gallery" featuring beautiful timber models of Chinese temples which are works of art.Then there is the adjacent "Nunnery" which is truly beautiful. This place is an absolute oasis in a noisy bustling city.It is being considered as a world heritage site. It is unique and beautiful.

Amazing hidden gem!. Not everyone knows about this place so it's like an hidden gem 30 minutes mtr ride from central. Imagine being brought back a thousand years to some ancient chinese garden full of bozais, pagodas and wooden bridges. There is also an amazing little shop where you can buy some natural food and a cafeteria for a cold drink or coffee. Great for adults and kids alike (even if smaller kids don't have too many activities for them and tend to grow restless). Great lakes full of huge colorful fishes. Worth the mtr ride. Enjoy!!!

Peaceful gardens amid Urban Chaos. Beautifully landscaped Japanese-style gardens in Kowloon. Easily accessible via MTR Diamond Hill Station - short, well marked walk - less than five minutes. Gardens and adjacent nunnery are a welcome respite from the urban crush that is HK. Grounds are immaculate and well laid out. Several places to eat and clean WC facilities are available. Note children are expected to behave on the grounds. Absolutely worth several hours to explore and relax.
Beautiful... Nan Lian is a beautiful garden that is well-kept. It is surrounded by skyskrapers, but in the garden you have a quiet Asian scenery. Great to just take a stroll and enjoy the scenery.

Amazing find in the Center of Hong Kong. Beautiful grounds and amazing ponds and flowers. Very nice museum store with reasonable prices for local wares. My wife loved the silk scarves. Of course she never met a scarf she didn't live.
Beautiful Japanese Gardens. Just very pretty to walk around, easy to get to, take subway to Diamond Head and right there when you get off.

A beautiful place to relax and take in the tranquil atmosphere away from the bustling center. This place was one of my favorite places to visit and went there on my first full day in HK. It was most memorable because of it's pristine environment, very well manicured grounds (especially the trees), and neat shrines. This is one place one will want to take their time and enjoy everything within the gardens. It's also very very easy to get to and once getting off the MTR at Diamond Hill, all you have to do is follow the signs and they'll direct you on where to go. It's merely right across the street from the MTR so access is a squeak. Most notably, there is NO FEE to enter and view the gardens.  Truly and awesome place to visit, a must by my recommendation, and a place I will not forget of all the destinations I visited on my trip to the HKSAR.

beauty and tranquillity. The Garden is a small beautiful place where you can hide from Hong Kong speed and noise, enjoy the silence, fresh air, beautiful mini-trees, pagodas and ponds, have some shade on a hot sunny day. In my experience it is never overcrowded, but do not expect solitude, there will always be some locals and tourists taking pictures. Admissions is free. Drinking and eating is forbidden inside.

Beautiful, pristine gardens.. These gardens are absolutely pristine, and people work very hard to ensure they remain that way. There is no eating within the grounds (except inside the restaurant), so don't come under the impression that you can have a picnic here.These gardens are the kind that you take a slow turn about - give yourself an hour or two to wander along the paths, admiring the lovely pagodas and enjoying the tranquility of this lovely green oasis amidst a chaotic, polluted city. There is a lovely exhibit on ancient Chinese temple architecture - unfortunately not in English - and an interesting little nook dedicated to the ancient art of bonsai with some lovely examples.The contrast between the ancient styles of architecture within the gardens and adjacent nunnery/monastery and the super high rise buildings in the background is a wonderful representation of Hong Kong - the fusion of old and new is very prominent.Absolutely worth half a day - and there's always the nearby shopping centre at Diamond Hill which is pretty excellent as well!
Relaxing, beautiful. I can't say much that hasn't been said. Easy to get to, relaxing, and beautiful. The scent of incense nearby. feast for the senses

Tranquil. Take metro to Diamond Hill and take exit C2, it's sign posted anyway. Loved it here, amongst all the chaos of Hong Kong is this little piece of tranquility and Bonsai Trees. I took many lovely photos here and just thoroughly enjoyed the walk around in the piece and quiet. There is also a strictly vegetarian restaurant in the park which is worth a try. If you a group you may have to wait as its very busy, I was dining alone so went straight in, the restaurant sits under the waterfall, I enjoyed the experience. It also leads on to Chi Lin Nunnery. You should definitely put this on your to do list.

Lovely gardens but make sure you eat outside before going in. Super hot day visiting the gardens. It's really nice and peaceful. We bought food at the shops before getting to the gardens but the problem is there are signs everywhere stating you can't eat/drink there.There was a vegetarian restaurant and cafe there. The staff were quite stern with us and said we can't eat outside, and the food you eat in their shops must be vegetarian because it was sacred ground I guess. It was a bit annoying because we had to hide the fact we were eating. Anyways, nice garden, just be prepared food/drink wise before you visit

Great gardens. We travelled to the gardens by MTR as it is only a short walk from Diamond Hill station. The gardens are very well looked after and a very restful place among all the high rise towers. They have some beautiful buildings erected among the manicured gardens and lakes. As we did not get there until approx 11am it became a little busy with all the tour groups going through, so go early.
Beautiful and relaxing. This is a garden that must not be missed. If you are looking for places to relax, this is the one you looking for. A peaceful and calm venue for busy people to wind down.

Worth your time!. There is no particular attraction here, none that is out of this world. But the garden is a place to chill and have dozens of photographs. Plenty of bonsais and Buddhist Pine trees coupled with the high rise buildings in the far background - excellent!Very accessible. Less than 5 mins walk from Diamond Tree MTR station. Do stop by at Hollywood Plaza for some shopping. Its adjoining to the Diamond Hill MTR station.

Nice place. We went there at around 8am before going to disneyland. This place is very relaxing. I love the scenery. Place is very clean. And its free of charge. For those who love photography u should see this place.
Beautiful manicured gardens. Well worth a trip to see these perfect gardens in the middle of such a busy city. It was strange to look up from the tranquil garden to see huge skyscrapers

Perfect Respite. A break from the hussle and bussle. A beautiful garden and a working monastery make this a good place to visit on your second or third day here. Definitely come at lunch time so you can visit the vegitarian restaurant on the grounds. I ordered the set lunch with 5 dishes and they were all different and tasty.

Endless gardens. Beautiful, peaceful gardens across from the Chi Lin Nunnery - the place is huge! We had a wonderful time wandering around the grounds and looking at the phenomenal plants, the waterfalls, the rock features, etc. It would have been easy to miss the gardens, but so glad we didn't - great way to finish off our trip with a little tranquility in a chaotic urban location.

peaceful and quiet respite from the city bussle. can hardly believe you're in HK when in the garden grounds. very peaceful and lovely stroll. be sure to eat at the veggie restaurant in the gardens -- best food in all of HK.

Nice.... There was an artificial feel to it, but as long as you are visiting Chi Lin Nunnery, Nan Lian, which is just next door is worth a look see... the cafe looks nice too, and I got a good book from the shop.
Silence and beauty. This is a fantastic place. Peaceful, quiet, beautiful plants, soft Chinese music, birds chirping, a wonderful architecture. From my point of view a must go!

Quiet place, nice architechture and gardens.. This is a nice quiet place to go to get out of the noise of Hong Kong. I'm not sure I would go out of my way to see it however if your in the area it is a nice walk and it is beautiful.
Amazing!. Garden is clean, beautiful. Various structures break up the nature for those who don't like a lot at once, beautiful views and plants... really well done. Worth seeing!

A beautiful oasis in a bustling city. This has certainly been one of the highlights of HongKong.This lovely peaceful place is a 'must see'. The flowers, rocks and ponds were just lovely to photograph. The layout with its many wooden features is just perfectly thought out. We spent a good couple of hours there just mesmerised by the beauty of it all.
Delicate. This is like a bonzai park of many hectares. Flowers, ponds and goldfish - impeccable, immaculate and peaceful.

Nan Lian Garden. What a wonderful garden in a busy city we spent 3 hours on our last day there it should be on everyone,s list when going to hong Kong.The layout of the garden with wonderful water features the large pagoda ,all the different Bonsai trees also the large carp in the ponds the waterfall .Would love to go back at a different time of the year to see the changes

A nice respite from the noise of Hong Kong. This is a great spot to gain 60 mins of tranquility (or as tranquil as one can get in Hong Kong). The garden is very well maintained with lots of plants and flowers one does not see often in North America.

If you really have nothing to do or you are a garden lover, then it is OK to go here. Though it is near the Diamond Hill MTR station, it is still quite far from Tsim Sha Tsui (around 30 mins). For me, it is not worth my time to go here. A good plase to relax yes, but I didn't go to Hong Kong to relax. The place is beautiful, well maintained, and clean, no question about that, but this is just not for me. I don't think the kids will enjoy the place either. I'll probably enjoy the place if it is just outside our hotel.
Add this to your sight seeing top 5. Beatiful and tranquil in the middle of a concrete jungle. Well worth seeking out the temple is amazing and I have never seen so many intricate bonsai trees.

A beautiful park in the midst of a huge city.. Lots of Bonzai type trees. flowers, and a well kept park. Very clean and tidy. Very helpful staff. Had food to eat and a nice reasonably priced gift shop. Make time to see the Nunnary next door. We took the Metro there and it was a 5-10 minute walk from there

Only if you need to pass some time. We decided to go after reading all the great reviews. We left there wondering how these gardens made it into the top 5 attractions!!! Yes they are clean and tidy. If you want to see Bonsai trees, a couple of nice buildings and lots of goldfish then this is for you. Otherwise don't bother! It took about 20 minutes to go around. It was pleasant but not by any means fantastic. The roof terrace gardens and Nunnery were closed when we got there so maybe this would have made a difference? The nunnery closes every day at 4.30 p.m. so get there before then if that's what you wish to see. We did manage to take pictures of that from the outside which was very nice and the only thing that made it worth the trip in our view.

This is a jewel in the midst of a concrete maze. Lovely, well cared for Chinese garden adorned with precious bonsoi plants! A photographer's paradise!There is also a Nunnery Vegetarian restaurant (not that pricey by HK standards) that I went to twice! Wonderful atmosphere. Check for reservations if in a big group.I would spend two-three hours here! Easily accessible by MTR, stop at the Diamond Head station, go through the mall or ask for directions!

A surprising oasis of calm in a bustling city. Had a day to myself while the boyfriend was working so I decided to go up to Nan Lian Garden and the adjoining monastery. I was very surprised to find a tranquil garden in the middle of busy roads. It was very peaceful to wander around and take a seat for a few moments of thought. The photos of Nan Lian are the few that actually look like I was near China!
Beautiful and peaceful place. This place is not to far from MRT Diamond Hill and it joint with Chi Lin Nunnery you can walk through these two beautiful place.

bonsai trees. i love plants i was amazed by the landscape, those bonsai podocarpus trees around and the stone shape seems aged. and sound of birds around so relaxing. the rashing of water drifting on the man made falls , to sum it all i really enjoy and the place is awesome, fantastic...
100 from 100. It's a breath Takeing Garden ...The atmosfere is very chill and warm we had tea and dim sum a bit price but it's worth it

Beautiful garden. It takes a while to get there but the garden is a real gem in the busy metropolis and it's well taken care of. There are some very nice samples of Chinese architecture and the lake area is simply beautiful.

Well worth a visit . Very easy to get to from metro, well sign posted. Lovely scenery, very tranquil. Definitely visit the tea house while there for tea and dim sum, we had tea and dim sum for average 180-200hkd per person. It may seem expensive but worth the experience!! An extra bonus was the hollywood plaza shopping centre next door!

Pretty Gardens. Good to get away from the bustle of people and traffic. Tranquil and just relaxing to stroll around some landscaped gardens. We ate at the vegetarian restaurant here. The windows had a waterful running over them, setting quite a lovely scene. The food was tasty but the service was a bit bad, they made us pay the bill before we had finished eating. Just because they wanted to close!

Beautiful quiet retreat in downtown Hong Kong. When you need to get away from the crowds and the noise of the city, take refuge here. The grounds are beautiful, peaceful, and although it's only a couple of blocks from a subway stop, it feels like you're miles away.

Nan Lian Garden & Chi Lin Nunnery. This was a wonderful find. Easy to get to on the MTR (Diamond Hill) with clear signs to point the way. Wonderful atmosphere and a very beautiful place. Lots to see and well worth a visit.

Oasis of calm in a frenetic city. My husband and I took several trains on the wonderful MRT to reach Nan Lian Garden. It had been highly recommended on Trip Advisor and we were not disappointed. In an unlikely location surrounded by towering skyscrapers and near the MTR station we found an oasis of quiet and beauty. The gardens are beautiful with water interests and interesting petrified rock formations. The adjoining Nunnery was also beautiful and worth visiting. Don't let the fact that this attraction is off the beaten path outside the center of town dissuade you from visiting.

Nice Escape if You Have the Time. Nan Lian is a beautiful tranquil garden located on the outskirts of HK (Diamond Hill MTR). It provides several photo opportunities and some piece and quiet away from everything.We went around 4-5pm on a weekday, and it was almost empty. The only real negative is the distance. We spent about 30 min in total to get their from the island, and you we only stayed there for about 45 min. I think it would be hard to stay there more than an hour uless you stopped there to eat or take a long rest.In my opinion, if you have the time, take a peek at Nan Lian, Otherwise, I would take the time to find some peace hiking or strolling a beach just as far away.
Top attraction. Great place to relax in the heart of the city. Sort of a Chinese version of Central Park in NY, adapted to Hong Kong!

Nice Garden with Free Admission. A very nice zen garden with ponds, bridges, pagodas and lots of plants. Just make sure when you take pictures, try not to take the tall buildings in the background. It's free admission and very easy to get there. Just take MTR to get to Diamond Hill station.
http://hongkongextras.com/_nan_lian_garden.html
Great break from the hustle and bustle of HK!. Beautifully designed, peaceful park in the middle of HK. Nice way to relax after your other tours and sightseeing. Wonderful and inexpensive gift shop.

Nothing changes; a timeless attraction.. This peaceful attraction is about a 10 minute well signposted stroll from the MTR and the very modern Hollywood Shopping Plaza at Diamond Hill. I had previously visited the garden in January 2012 and this year nothing that I could detect had changed. That is the beauty of this place though. I never cease to be amazed that on entering the garden from underneath the busy flyovers, you enter a haven of peace and tranquility such that one is oblivious to the tower blocks that surround the spot. It is the perfect place to stroll around for 2 to 3 hours and marvel at the many bonzai trees that must be hundreds of years old. There is not much shelter from the sun so if visiting between April and November remember to take a hat and sunscreen.Yes, nothing changes but I will be visiting again next year when I know I will find an oasis of calm and tranquility amidst the brouhaha of a very vibrant city.
Beautiful. Beautiful well maintained garden... lot of photo opportunity. you cant take a tripod for some weird reason

Beautiful garden and interesting exhibition of wood carving models of castles and temples. That was my first time I saw the Buddhist pine tree with its soft and gentle needles. And I liked it. There many beautiful trees and stones in the park, I was really stunned by some of them. I also liked the pounds and the waterfall. The golden pavilion, the red bridge, the bridge pavilion look pretty impressive but they are just a kind of decorations for photo shooters. You cannot come closer and take a look, or touch them – because you would spoil the photo point – that is the explanation from the garden authorities. Very ridiculous one. It is a shame that many paths and buildings in the park are closed for no good reason. Take a look at the exhibition of wood carvings – beautiful models of castles and temples with plenty interesting details. The entry is free. Location – MTR Station “Diamond Hill”. From Nan Lian Garden you can directly proceed to the Chi Lin Nunnery.

Small park next to shopping plaza. Diamond Hill MTR , next to Hollywood shopping plaza, a small park with a pond, shops, cafe/restaurant and a few structures that resemble temples/wats with distinctive Asian touch trees, waterfalls, etc. I recommend visiting at sunset park open till 8 or 9 pm. You get to see it's lit up and it's really makes magic. Take some pictures if your camera allows high ISO values (mine was 12000) and I got some pretty decent ones. Otherwise, it would make a good place to eat an ice–cream on a hot day, but alas, they don't allow food or drinks on the premises.Good luck!

Ok but... Visiting Nan Lian garden was okay, beautiful etc, but it was also a bit tame. Situated in the middle between houses etc, you got the feeling that it was too beautiful to be nature. (which it also is). But still worth a visit..
Beautifull garden in Kowloon. Lovely quiet traditional Chinese garden in Kowloon. Easy to find as it is right beside an MTR station.

Still beautiful but getting crowded. Still a beautiful spot in HK especially earlier in the day. Because it isn't a hidden gem any more it is getting a little more crowded - as everything in HK eventually gets. But if you can go earlier in the day and are willing to deal with other people around it is still a beautiful break from city life.

Beautiful Gardens. Well can I say this Garden is lovely to see as they have spend many man hours to get this place looking so good and the decorations and the way the garden is arranged is so beautiful

Garden oasis. A green oasis in Hong Kong. Recommended to us by a local and definitely worth a visit. A short MTR ride from Central. The garden is very well maintained and the way the trees are trimmed is something to see.
Absolute Tranquility. These gardens are a haven of tranquility in a busy city - absolutely beautifully tended - not a weed in sight - so peacfull.

Nan Liam Garden. Well this is a different place localizated in a busy area of HK, but inside is very calm.It's very easy to reach there by Metro, and the admission is free. If you want to visit there have a very nice restaurante behind the water falls.Is a nice place to visit and near have the nunnery also that you can visit the both and don't take you to long time.

Serene. This was a very serene garden in the middle of Hong Kong. There is not much to do here apart from looking at things, but there are some exhibitions of wood carvings and things like that which are interesting. No rain protection, so make sure that you schedule you visit on a clear day.

Oasis. We have been to Hong Kong on six occasions but yet this was the first time we had visited these gardens. They are just a peaceful oasis in the midst of Kowloon. We were staying in Jordan and wanted to do something for an hour or two so we took the MTR up to Diamond Hil and enjoyed a dander around. They are really easy to find from the MTR station. On a local note we bumped into friends from Northern Ireland whilst we were there - it was slightly surreal. Well worth a visit.

A piece of quiet time in Kowloon.. I always make it a point to visit the gardens upon my visits in Hong Kong. Though not much changes has been done in the park , I still like the quiet stillness the park has to offer , plus it's a nice jump-off point to Chilin Nunnery !
Worth a trip. Manicured but relaxing.... You can relax despite the regimented order of the place, birdsong in the middle of Kowloon !

Tranquility within urban Kowloon!. Nan Lian is a beautiful, peaceful and serene garden in the centre of urban Kowloon and yet you would think you were miles from anywhere. The nearest MTR stop for the garden is Diamond Hill from there it is a well signposted five minute walk. Nan Lian is set in 3.5 hectares of land, there is no charge and I would allow an hour to explore. The garden is open from 7.00am-9.00pm. There are facilities in the garden, a vegetarian restaurant, teahouse and snack shop.Nan Lian is set in Tang Dynasty style with hills, water features, pagodas, water features, trees and rocks, although small it really is quite spectacular. Don't forget to visit the bonsai trees which an added bonus. Make sure you visit Chi Lin Nunnery as well whilst you are in the area.A lovely retreat away from the neon lights of Hong Kong.

A Paradise in the heart of the City!. I have never seen so many gold fishes in a pond . The Garden is very well maintained . Many beautiful plants, trees, flowers and a nice waterfall. The Garden is linked to the Chi Lin Nunnery with a few steps which is also very worth visiting. They are very conveniently located. Get off at Diamond Hill Station, cross a small street and you are at the entrance of the Garden.

Beautiful Nan Lian Garden & Chi Lin Nunnery a great afternoon out. Well worth the visit, a great days outing in beautiful gardens and a very pretty nunnery. I liked the bonsai tree selection especially. Neat lake and temple.Very close to the Diamond Hill MTR station, exit to the east, only 5 mins walk.

a garden below the highways of hongkong. its amazing how this garden just pops out in the middle of the street... when i came here, i was like.. ok they see a vacant lot and just decided to turn it into a garden, voila... well its alright, you'll see plants and more plants.. we can't go closer to the temples because its closed.. well they put a barricade. and the guards are very vigilant, they're everywhere so you'll feel safe. no entrance fee, but you can skip it if you've been to other gardens because you'll probably see the same thing.

best garden i have seen. in the middle of all the excitement of hong kong, lies a beautiful garden that makes you appreciate that everyone needs peace and quiet in their lives. everything is trimmed and cut perfectly. not a single thing out of place. the gold leadf statue in the middle of the garden is a standout. the bridge over the water is also a great spot for tranquillity. allow yourself 2 hours in your busy sight seeing schedule to go to these gardens and really appreciate and admire a beautiful place in hong kong on the Kowloon side.

It's a nice and clean chinese gardens, but rather small. This garden was very clean and nicely designed. But it is a very small area. You'll probably cover this place in 10 minutes. And given that it's rather out of place, i don't think it's really worth coming to this place. I came here because i needed to take a bus from this MTR to Sai Kung, and this place is just beside the MTR. But if you happen to come here, do visit the nunnery beside, which is also very small, but i guess you can take a couple of nice photos there.

Most beautiful and manicured garden in Hong Kong. I love this garden. It is so beautifully landscaped and the place is so well maintained. It looks like an oasis in the concrete jungle. There are lots of photo opportunities there. One would find peace and harmony in there. Enjoy.....

a great escape in busy HK. Nan Lian Gardens is a breath of fresh air in the very busy and crowded HK cityscape. It is very accessible and a short distance from the Diamond Hill MTR Station. Once you exit the station, you will find signs leading to the Gardens making it very easy to find. Make sure you have your camera with you as this will be one a feast for your senses. The beautiful landscapes, finely pruned trees and well manicured gardens are breathtaking. You will think you were in a Japanese garden and forget the noise, rush and pollution of Hongkong. Definitely we must visit.

Stunning, beautiful oasis of serenity in the middle of crazy Hong Kong. I have to say that Nan Lian gardens was one of my highlights of my visit to Hong Kong. It took took two or three metros to get there but was well worth it. The gardens are idylic. Peaceful and had the most beautiful relaxing Chinese meditation music playing throughout. I felt incredibly relaxed, refreshed and recharged after my visit there. There is no charge to enter the gardens so i made sure i made some purchases whilst there. The gardens are an absolute must to visit when in Hong Kong.
must see. a superb botanical gardin, very well maintained with beautiful trees, flowers, traditional style buildings all surrounded by modern HK skyscrappers.

Pretty garden and good restaurant. The garden is attractive and the restaurant is good with reasonably priced vegetarian food. The waterfall there is attractive. It is easy to get to as it is close to the Diamond Hill MTR Station. It is also open in the evenings. The garden is free.

Beautiful Garden in a busy city. You would not beleive that is in Hong Kong where the land is at a premium price. A beatiful setting with penty of trees and accent style buildings etc. Just few steps of the MTR station.

Interesting garden in front of Chi Lin Nunnery. Nice park with lots of Bonsai , ponds and pagodas. Reminds me of Japanese garden. Good place to visit after visiting Chi Lin Nunnery. There are music playing throughout the whole garden. Quite a nice relaxing walk in bustling Hong Kong.

A peaceful garden in the centre of the city. Really liked this oasis of calm in the centre of the city (it has a flyover over part of it!). It manages to be a really tranquil place although it is surrounded by traffic. You can combine with a visit to the Nunnery nearby or indulge in some retail therapy at the shopping mall nearby also.

Worth a visit if you're tired of standing in line for everything else in Hong Kong.. We visited the gardens on our last day before moving on to the airport. It was a very pleasant way to spend the morning. The gardens are very peaceful.

Nice Green Oasis Nestled Amongst Tall Concrete Buildings. For such a compact, high density place, Hong Kong has surprisingly large green tracts. However, most of these places are some distance away from the usual tourist sites. The Nan Lian Garden is one of those exceptions being a 5 minutes stroll from the Diamond Hill MTR. It is compact but a well designed and well tended traditional Chinese garden complete with bonsais, koi ponds, bridges, pagodas and stone sculptures. There is small exhibits, a small cafe and an interesting looking restaurant serving vegetarian food located inside a man made waterfall. When I was there, the cafe was sparsely attended. However, the restaurant was fully booked even though I arrived early prior to noon. It only opens at noon. So make sure you book if you wish to dine there.Diamond Hill MTR station is adjacent to a large shopping center with an air conditioned food court serving a wide variety of regional cuisine. Its a good alternative for meals or snacks if you cannot get into the Nan Ling Garden's restaurant.

Beautiful Oasis in the City. Just off the MTR is this beautiful garden in Kowloon. Explore the peaceful, zen perspective just off a major roadway. And don't miss the stunning nunnery right across the street!

Truly a great oasis in the heart of suburban Hong Kong.. Not to be missed. Along with the Nunnery across the road (use the overhead bridge) this is a wonderful reprieve from the crazy crowds of Hong Kong. Very easy to access via the Diamond Hill MTR station, its right across the road. The shopping mall is well worth a walk around while you are here, not the high end stores of Ocean Terminal and Times Square more a mid range mall, good food hall and cheap cinemas as well.

Japanese Eden. It's amazing how this garden was located somewhere in the middle of a bustling city. The garden itself offers peacefulness and serenity. You will never feel that you are in Hong Kong. I love this garden so much and it's a must visit. Just few minutes walk from the Diamond Hill MTR.
Peaceful.... A little bit of Heaven in HK! Great place to wander with many great places to take photos. Located next to the Diamond Hill MTR station. Check out the Chi Lin Nunnery across the street.
An oasis in the middle of the bustle. You won't believe such a beautiful and peaceful place can be found between elevated highways. Worth the trip to see the garden and the Chi Lin nunnery.

loved it!. Totally amazing. super peaceful. never seen so many bonsais before! slight gripe is the fact that when we were there they closed off quite a few paths. other than that, it was totally amazing to just go to such a relaxing place where you can sit down in nature, just take it all in. bring a book with you and chillax if you like. There's also a vegetarian restaurant and small cafe.

A Hidden Gem. Easy to get to on the MTR as it is opposite the exit at Diamond Hill station. Many people who have lived in HK do not evcen know this great place exists. A beautiful walk around the mature botanic gardens and then into the Nunnery where there are fantastic Bonsai and Buddah temples. The gardens are around a large lake with Koi in them. There is a gift shop and resteraunt in the gardens as well.Fantastic place to visit for locals and tourists alike.

Beautiful Garden in Hong Kong. I just came back from Hong Kong for holiday with my wife and daughter. I browsed in the internet about our destination and I found this garden. Nan Lian Garden is very easy to find. After you alight from MTR Diamond Hill you just follow the sign to Nan Lian Garden. Maybe just 3 minutes walk you will find it. The garden is very well maintained and also very clean. No admission ticket. This garden also connected with Chi Lin Nunnery and just separated with small bridge. One of the weakness from this place is there is no place for snacks and drinks. But to maintained the cleanlines of the garden I think it's better if there is no place for eating. Definitely I will come to this garden again if I have oppotunity to got to Hong Kong.

Beautiful, peaceful, visit at night. Nan Lian Garden is an amazing attraction a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR and the Hollywood Mall. I visited during the day but even better went back at night when the gardens are even more beautiful and peaceful. Explore the exhibit in the museum building -- and the building.And don't miss the Chi Lin Monastery just across the street.

Very Formal Gardens, not my cup of tea. I blame the Rough Guide to HK for building my expectations too high of these gardens. They claim that once you are inside you are magically insulated from the traffic noise and the sight of the surrounding highrise blocks, sorry but neither of these is anywhere near true. The gardens are formally laid out, perfectly manicured and, to my view, a little sterile. There is a nice pond in the centre with a collection of large goldfish and carp but you can't get too close to the pond edge which again I found a bit disappointing. It's a nice walk but personally I found the Chi Lin Nunnery next door more interesting and peaceful.

A bit of serenity. HongKong has got to be one of the most crowded cities in the world. However, we stumbled on to this little piece of serenity in the Diamond Hill area, a very convenient short walk from the MTR station. Going there during the weekdays was nice as I am sure it would have been more crowded over a weekend. Try to get there before lunch time and you should find it a quiet and relaxing walk and a good way to spend about an hour.

Calm in a busy city. This garden is beautiful. A delightful walk takes you around the garden, but if you do not want to walk for ~90 mins then you can simply look at the parts you want. Entry to the garden is free. After you enter you can look at a map in the information booth. The buildings show how wooden temples are constructed which is really fascinating.We visited on a day that it rained and the garden was still amazing. After your visit don't forget to cross the road and go to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Currently the purpose built bridge from the garden to the nunnery is being renovated, so you need to cross the road around level to reach the nunnery. Signs are provided.
Beautiful!. This little garden is definitely worth a visit. The tranquility was most welcome in such a busy city and the landscaping is truly breath-taking.

Great hideaway. Visited the gardens after reading about things to do in 3 days in HK. I agree that it's a must see if you have an hour or two, combining it with the nunnery just across the road. The landscaping is beautiful and you cound even have tea in one of the pavillion but it's rather expensive. I also found the arcitrecture of the wooden buildings very interesting and wonderful. The gift shop offers unique items if you are looking for quality gifts to take home. They have a separate building that houses some temporary exihibition which requires payments. The charge is minimal (around HKD 10/20) but it's free on Wednesdays.
Tranquil space. Free and chilled. A nice space away from the busy areas of HK. Easy to get to via MTR to Diamond Hill. follow signs

Beautiful garden in the city. Quite and serene garden that instantly transports you to another world. There's nothing like this garden, with zen decor and vibrant, bright colours. Great for avid photographers and visitors who just want to get away from it all for a while.
Peaceful place. Liked the atmosphere and calmness. Easy to get to by MTR and next to Chin Li Nunnery so you can combine the two.

Oasis in the city. The Nan Lian Garden is a nice respite from the busy city. It is situated a few minutes walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station, so it is easily accessible and it is free for the most part. There are some paid parts within the garden for the museums, etc. which could peak some people's interest. The garden is not very large, but it could take you a good 45 mins if you are carefully looking at everything and stopping to take pictures, etc. The gift shop has some nice, well priced items, good for souvenirs. It's a different side of Hong Kong, but the garden is well manicured. Don't expect anything too wild! There are some good areas for pictures as well. You can visit the Chi Lin Nunnery right across the street after this.

Nice quite stroll. As everyone says, it is a nice quite stroll in prestine gardens. Not for children though as the guards(they see themselves as guards) will constantly tell them off if you they as much as touch a plant and we all know how children like to walk nicely down the middle of a path. Only high spot for them was to look at the fish in the surgically clean pond. Would have been nice if there was a little more information about the plants. Gets it's Very good rating as this is one of the best parks in the city, and a place to "get away from the hussle", but it is just a pretty park and quiet walk. Use this is an add on for the Nunnery next door.

Beauty and the bustle. Nice garden with an interesting contrast of old and new surroundings. The highlight was the nunnery which is overlooking the garden, But also i really liked some of the fauna on display. The garden isn't very big and is still busy even during winter, The garden would be a nice retreat though for locals just to relax and escape the city. Definitely worth a visit, Quite far away if staying on HK island but accessible via metro.

Great vegetarian meal. Great oasis in the middle of busy HK. There is a vegetarian restaurant inside the garden that is very popular with the locals. The restaurant is located behind a waterfall, and the dining room has a big window to see the water. Ordered one set lunch and other entrees. Fresh food and very delicious. Great attentive service.

Well worth a trip on the metro. Nan Lian Garden is next to the Chi Lin Nunnery, so two attractions for the price of one but as they are both free, the only cost is a metro ticket, which in Hong Kong isn't very much. Short walk from the metro to the garden. I visited on a Wednesday, it was very quiet. Very peaceful, very relaxing, if you are short of time (I was on a short cruise stop) it is well worth it, even if you can only afford an hour.

Relaxing!. The weather was really nice when I went there and it was on a weekday so there weren't a lot of people. It was really a nice place, totally relaxing. When I entered the place I was listening to my iPod, but later on I noticed that it was better to listen to the music they were playing. The exhibits are free of entrance on Wednesdays. And yeah, bring your cameras!!!

Quiet and peaceful.... Well the garden is supposed to be quiet and peaceful, but unfortunately I went on a weekend afternoon, and it's just full of mainland tourists who had a tendency to talk really loudly and spoil the peaceful atmosphere. That's not the fault of the garden, so I'm still giving a positive review of it despite me not being able to enjoy my walk.Do avoid weekends afternoons. I'm sure mornings would have been better.

Peaceful and beautiful. A very lovely stroll with many photo ops. Doesn't take too much time and is a great thing to do for free to see traditional gardens. Even on a drizzly day, we enjoyed it. Restaurants also there!
Relaxing little stroll. A nice walk around this well maintained and worked on little garden in the middle of Hong Kong. Worth a look if you have a few spare hours.
Surrounded by greenery and lake. I spent time for this place around an hour walking and really enjoy a nice view during our first visit in HK such a wonderful day for us.

Fantastic break from the city rush. Wonderful park to escape from the city noise, full with trees and birds, such a wonderful way to get away from the city crowds. walking there was such a pleasure for the soul straggling for a piece and calm. The park entrance is free of charge, of course, to get there you just need to take of on the Diamond Hiil station (Green line Kwun Tong, it took 13 HK dollars to get there from the Causeway Bay station), and then - it would be easy to find it, there are signs everywhere - Nan Lian Garden, would be hard to be lost, believe me.

Charming park in middle of crazy city. What a wonderful and charming park this was! All in the middle of a bustling metropolis. Very serene, quiet and reflective place to visit. You can walk around the ponds and enjoy the peace and quiet to get away from the crowds. Can't say enough good things about this gorgeous park!

Good for a morning stroll. Great way to kill time before you leave for your flight. Ambiance here is very different from the busy Mongkok. The garden is well maintained. Perfect for a morning stroll with your family or friends.

A good place to unwind. It was lovely to be there on a crisp morning in November. A nice place to reflect and meditate with the soft background music. Very beautiful landscapping with bonsai plants, rocks, and elegant wooden architecture. Sit around the park and listen to the birds chirping. To go there, stop at the MTR Diamond Hill Station Exit C2, follow the signs and walk for around five minutes.

Very relaxing spot. Visited here during a stopover in November. {Using the MTR its the Diamond Hill station on the Green Line}Not a huge attraction but very well put together and well worth a visit if in Hong Kong. Nearby metro stop is only 5 minutes walk away. As you walk into Nan Lian Gardens you could also cross the road and continue onto the Chi Lin Nunnery which is only another 5 minutes further on. There is a restaurant under the waterfall that we did not go into. Overall a nice way to pass an hour, stop off and read a book etc...

Tranquility in a busy city. It was very easy to get to - you should combine the Nunnery to this journey as they're basically connected. There was maintenance work going on so you should take the exit near the Rock Museum and walk across the road where you'll see the entrance to the Nunnery up the steps.The park was incredibly relaxing and beautiful.
Beautiful and tranquil. As good as other reviewers say it is. Very beautiful and tranquil all in the middle of HK. It is across the street from Chi Lin Nunnery and I recommend visiting both.

Wow. It s a must visit. Located in the bang centre of Town, is easy to get to. Take the metro to the diamond hill station and it is a 2 minute walk from there. Lovely bonsai creations. There is a museum of rocks, a souvenir shop, a coffee shop and an art gallery where exibhitions are held.

Very quiet and relaxing. . Just a short walk from Diamond Hill MTR Station, a very nice garden awaits. There are a pavilions to take pictures in, a seemly high end tea house, a vegetarian restaurant, souvenir shop, snack shop and a rock shop (you didn't hear this wrong). Currently they are renovating a bridge that connects the Park to the nunnery across the road. It's expected to complete on the 5th December. Do go as a couple for a very good experience.
Stunning. A photographer's dream with the mountains in the background, sky scrapers, chinese pagodas, waterfall, huge rocks, ponds, red bridges - an oasis of calm and beauty in this mega city.

Fantastic Bonsai in a peaceful setting. No food or drink allowed so do not plan on bringing a lunch to sit and eat. The gardens is mostly bonsai, some look 100 yrs old. There is an exhibit of many famous building in fine wood showing how they built them all without using a nail. We did eat at the vegetarion

Nothing spectacular... Its just a garden, pretty small. If you have extra time and are looking for something free, you could go here. But it's not something you should go out of your way to visit, unless you've never seen parks and gardens before. It is a nice scenery change compared to rest of the Hong Kong, peaceful and quiet. There are no places to sit in the park, there is a lot of security making sure you don't sit. So all you can do is take one round and leave. I think there is cafe though.
amazing!. highly recommend going to this area. its just the most beautiful place in the most busiest place in hong kong. it is well catered and kept.
Lovely garden, worth the trip. The garden is beautiful and very serene. Worth the visit if you have the time. If you're there make sure to also pay a visit to the nunnery which is very close

A beautiful setting in the heart of Kowloon. The garden is laid out in such a way that you follow a one way route. Along the way you can stop off to visit a museum dedicated to Chinese wooden architecture, enjoy bonsai trees, a rockery, enjoy a snack amongst other things. When I was there one of the buildings was housing a lovely exhibition of painted chinese porcelain too. A very relaxing pace to visit.

Peaceful & Tranquil Gardens. Peaceful, tranquil & beautiful gardens. Entry is free. Worth the effort of going if you have the time. Spent over an hour walking around the gardens.MTR to Diamond Hill, exit c. Walk up a slight hill beside the shopping mall.Cross the road at the lights and you are there.

Lovely break from a extremely busy city. The Nan Lian Gardens are a delight. Almost the moment you enter the gardens you feel relaxed and calm after the chaos of Hong Kong. What an oasis of beauty in the heart of this amazing city. There is also a delightful vegetarian restaurant in the garden.Do yourself a favour and go to the gardens to recharge.
Nice garden. It was okay. Nothing to travel for, but the garden was really a pretty sight and has lots of bonsai trees, so if you like gardens and have time you could go and see it.
Perfect peace. Very calming; peaceful, tranquil space. Beautiful bonsai... Many photographers.....Interesting display of building styles - amazing examples of beautiful old building.

A traditional highlight in Hongkong. It was a free attraction that we woud like to visit, it worth for value, the pure pond surround by beautiful & green garden made this place like a heaven and the behind was the buildings make it as a secret garden.

Wow, It's Even Free!. This is a beautiful (if slightly regimented) garden, but it's free and is well worth the visit (especially combined with a visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery). There's also a cafe near the end of the walking route that has some tasty and interesting snacks (including ones to go).

Wow!. We loved Nan Lian Garden. Plenty of beautiful photo ops for photographers. We spent a few hours here just looking around. We took the MTR subway to Diamond Hill, exit C, the just followed the signs. Truly beautiful.

exquisite views. these gardens are truly enchanting. the place is well-maintained and the sights soothe your senses. the moment we entered the gardens, we were all mesmerized by the exquisite beauty of the place. it's an experience not to be missed if you're visiting kowloon. it's very accessible by mtr, just a stone's throw from diamond hill station. entrance is free.

Such a beautiful place in a busy Hong Kong. We visit this garden and the Nunnery every time that we are in Hong Kong. It is very peaceful and well kept. One of the better sites in the area. It is a "don't miss".

Lovely peaceful gardens. Well worth a visit, the gardens as well as the architectural modelling of how the earlier buildings (1000 AD) were put together are very interesting. A peaceful oasis, beautifully maintained.

Very Pretty Garden, easy to get to.. The garden was very pretty and very easy to get to...about one block from the MTR. The nunnery is right across the streeet. Visiting both in a morning is very easy to do and quiet relaxing...although you are surrounded by a highway, roads, and high rise condos. If you focus on the gardens, the world around you just melts away.
Hidden Garden in the City. Another hidden gem! You can get great pictures of the city + tradition all in one shot here. I would definitely recommend coming here if you are in HK.

Serene attraction in the middle of chaos. Opted to go here on our last day of vacation in HK.
This attraction made me appreciate HK more. After going through the bustling crowd in MTR, this location is a breather.
Located in the middle of a city, Nan Lian is a place to be when you want a sweet escape.

Amazing, must see. Stray from the normal path and go see this amazing, awe-inspiring place, which will transport you back in time. Incredible architecture, spectacular landscape, beautiful buildings. Truly an oasis in the middle of the big city.

2 hours relaxing amidst a hectic town. Although it is all brand new (build in 1997) a gives a good impression of typical Chinese traditional park landscaping. I cannot decide for myself whether I consider it fake or not, this is just the way Chinese do these things. Combined with The Chi Lin nunnery it is definitely worth a trip, you can spend some 2 hours in a very quiet and relaxing environment in the middle of this hectic city. If you choose to have lunch or diner at the vegetarian restaurant in the gardens, you may add an enjoyable hour to that trip (note for lunch a minimum spend of 85 HKD applies - for diner it is even higher)

Beautifully maintained Chinese garden. Definitely one of the nicest free attractions in Hong Kong. Very easy to get to (right next to MTR station) and extremely well maintained.
Not a particularly large place, but plenty to see and a very pleasurable way to spend an hour or so, including the nunnery across the road.

A beautiful Tang-style oriental garden. One of my favourite places in Hongkong to take the overseas friends to, especially the ones who are keen to experience Oriental places. Hongkong is very modern with high-rises and neon lights but this place is a little oasis in the centre of a busy city. Relatively new garden and still getting established but has become a very important tourist destination. I would have rated it a five star place but for the touristy environment.
