Not all the places in the garden are open to the visitors but there are enough to spend a couple of hours in. The lotus pond is gorgeous and so is the Blue pond with Koi fish..so beautifully landscaped with rocks and waterfalls.I like to eat at the vegetarian cafe- don't go for the set-menu but choose your own dishes. If not very hungry one can pick up a snack or a fresh juice from the snack shop or the Chinese tea-house.The garden is 7 minutes walk from the Diamond Hill Mtr..easy to reach as there are enough directions signs to the garden. One can even go to the Chi Lin Nunnery from here and spend half an hour there...again Tang style buildings..very calm and serene.

Unbelievably peaceful for being so close to a major road. I visited on a very sunny day after a visit to the Chi Linn Nunnery, I was amazed at how peaceful it was given its proximity to a major road. It was a lovely place to sit and read in the sun for a while.

A delightful garden but tried too hard. I know it is a nice garden in HK and it is relatively new and young. But it lacks direction and control in building it's own character and soul. They can take a lesson from the established gardens in Japan. It gave an impression of trying too hard and placing too many items in the limited space. Visitors can't access many features in the garden like the arched bridge, pagoda in the lake, some paths etc.A great garden should be more accessable for visitors. But don't take it as negatives, it is still worth your trouble to find time and effort to visit this garden. The vegetarian restaurant in the garden is actually very good but you just have to order your own dishes but not the set lunch menu. We pay over HK$300 for this excellent lunch for 2 persons, the set lunch menu is about HK$100 per person. Do try it and you won't be disappointed. Enjoy!

Extremely serene and calm oriental style garden. It looks very much like gardens in Japan, but as you walk further in it connects to Chi Lin Nunnery, which is very unique. I suggest to visit the garden in early morning as there are less visitors and you can enjoy the scene and also you might bump into gardeners sculpturing trees in the garden. Very.

Picture perfect... And free!. Beautifully maintained and pruned, this quiet oasis in the chaos of Kowloon is well worth a visit. There is piped-in music in some areas, beautiful vistas in others... Pagodas, waterfalls, artistic rocks... It's all a delight!

Oasis in heart of HK. This little (free) gem is well worth the MTR ride, where it is nestled between skyscrapers but feels as if it is another world, or at least Japan. Pretty cool even on a very hot day because of all the water features, especially the waterfall over the restaurant. Many of the walkways were closed off, though, and prices in the gift shop (mostly Japanese items) were VERY high. Vegetarian restaurant quite refreshing and good; however they really need a picture menu because there was no way to make a selection from the description and some were fairly tasteless/textureless.

Beautiful garden, very disappointing restaurant.. Beautiful tranquil garden park, just a couple of minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR staion and across the road from Chi Lin Nunnery. The mid size bonsai trees really impressed.The vegetarian restaurant at the far end of the garden behind the waterfall seemed like the perfect place for lunch. Unfortunately not - we had the set price menu and 3 of the 5 dishes were just different shapes and colour of very slimy tofu pretending to be beef, pork and chicken; in half reasonabale sauces, though lacking any real flavour. Would put off any would-be vegetarian for life! Avoid and take a lunch box - from a good veggie cafe if that's your thing!Such a shame because the location behind the waterfall is lovely.

An accidental find.. We only walked through this garden on our way to our REAL destination. I don't even particularly like Chinese gardens. But this is beautifully groomed, with mists coming up from the water and dragonflies darting about and a fine little pagoda. It's a great place to photograph and you even have room to put out your tripod without getting crushed by crowds or yelled at by security. The bathrooms have to be the cleanest and largest I've seen in Hong Kong too.
Beautiful gardens. So beautiful - definitely worth the visit. But don't sit in the gardens. The staff don't like it and will try and move you on!

Not your typical Hong Kong destination.. This place is really nice. There aren't many tourists when we went there. The place is really serene, clean, and just plain lovely. Tripods are not allowed though... so someone in the group is always going to have to play the photographer. Since I was going there with my two sisters and my parents, it was a great way for them to see the other side of Hong Kong not just shopping and busy streets filled with tourists. There is a small shop there where you can buy souvenirs. And right across the garden is a nunnery another must see place! Talk about hitting 2 birds with one stone. ;)
Photo ops here!. Agree with recent posters....a wonderful find in a busy city. Highly recommend for all travelers except those with small children that aren't able to keep the peace.

Lush and Serene. On a sunday in HK, I decided to skip shopping and the usual bustling downtown, and opted to visit Nan Lian Garden. It was beautiful, serene and just a nice place to wander around. It's just a short walk away from Diamond Hill MTR, so finding the place is not a problem. This is a nice side of HongKong that one must see. It's a nice contrast of traditional Asian versus the modern HK outside. And while you're at it, cross over to Chi Lin Nunnery across the street to complete the whole meditative experience.
Surpise in the City. Go there ... MTR Diamond Hill, short walk away. Beautiful gardens you will be pleasantly surprised !

A little oasis from the concrete jungle. What a lovely garden and a real treat to experience a recreated traditional Chinese setting. Take your cameras as you will be sure to take lots of photographs!

Wow Just Stunning. These gardens are superb, a must see during your holiday to Hong Kong. Step out of the hustle and bustle of the city into this serene peaceful oasis. The grounds are immaculately maintained and they have a small cafe. You will be enchanted, a special place to visit.

Beautiful and free. Well worth the MTR trip out there, and you can do the Nunnery at the same time.The garden itself is gorgeous and there's no entry fee. Somehow that just makes it more tranquil, though there is a souvenir shop at the end.I do recommend stopping at the tea house before you leave. It's not cheap but it's well worth it for the experience.
Beautiful. Stunning gardens, really easy to find, lead on to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Lovely day out. And they play relaxing music for you!

Oasis in the middle of the city. Looks a bit like a Japanese garden and together with the Shilin Nunnery it's worth taking the subway to there (Diamond Hill) and have a relaxed visit of this place. Best of all: It's free!

A serene oasis in the heart of Hong Kong. My wife and I were looking for a vegetarian restaurant, and found Chi Lin Vegetarian - located inside Nan Lian Garden. It is about 15-20 minutes on the MTR from Tsim Sha Tsui or Central. You will have to switch lines as well, but it is well worth the ride. A very short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR stop (less than 2 minutes walk), you walk into this magical urban oasis: surrounded by sky scrapers and highways, Nan Lian Garden is such a serene, beautiful place, it makes you forget you are in the middle of one of the most congested places on earth. This Buddhist garden is full of beautiful groomed trees, set next to amazing rocks, which seemed to have been carefully selected and brought in over the years. We visited only during the evening: the garden looks absolutely magical lit at night. I also recommend the Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant there. It is very basic vegetarian Chinese food, but the service is excellent, and the prices are cheap. A well worth trip.
Oasis of Pleasure. Easy access from Diamond Hill station and they the quietness of the garden made it seems a world away from the bustle of Kowloon.

A slice of Heaven. Iftis so ard to believe that this garden is in the middle of a very bustling city. Walking throughout the garden was so peaceful and serene and beautifully maintained. This garden is something that the people of HK should be very proud of.
Peace in the city. Beautiful gardens, full of bonsai type trees. Lovely Chinese pagodas and ponds. Quiet and serene! Only a 5 minute walk from the subway, and well signposted.

Peaceful garden in middle of city. If you have time to spare then make your way to the Nan Lian Garden, it's a small park in the middle of 3 flyovers and is on the tube network, signposted from the station exits. Once you enter the gate you forget you are in the middle of a big city, I spent a lovely hr or two wandering around the garden and soaking up the peaceful atmosphere.

Haven of Rest. It was located at the Diamon Hill MTR station exit C. I was surprised by the structure and the architectural of this garden. Everything was carefully planned and details were highly thought through. Beautiful scenery, good photos shoot, tranquil and peaceful. You won't get disappointed. Free entry. I was so happy that I have a chance to visit this beautiful and lovely garden. Sureley I will visit again if next time come to Hong Kong again.
Hidden gem. We loved these gardens but it is very hot out in the open. Remember to pack your hat, sunscreen and water. It was easy to get to and right across the road from the nunnery.

tiny oasis. absolutely loved Nan Lian Gardens, very easy to get to. just follow the signs after you get off Diamond Hill metro exit. we walked around a couple of times just to let it all in. combine it with the nunnery next door makes a great escape from the crowds

quiet walk. Another quiet green space in the middle of chaotic city life. Rather busy when there as it was a holiday. I liked the fact there was ample space for people with disabilities, including wheelchair bound, assharingbof natural spaces is important. Rather disappointed we could not eat at the restaurant - missed lunch period, but the water features were interesting and the Koi were huge. Do this when you need a respite from the hectic pace of the city.
it was a dream. it was quiet.it has alot of beautiful trees<bonsai> it was a near the mtr and near the shopping mall.

A beautiful oasis in the middle of the tower blocks. This is my first visit to the Nan Lian Garden, when I last visited Diamond Hill, about 20 years ago this area was just full of factories. The garden is absolutely beautiful, full of the most amazing vistas, trees, ponds and buildings. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to find tranquility. It is only a very short stroll from Diamond Hill MTR about a 3 minute walk.

Perfect. Easy to get to via diamond hill mtr station. Magnificent gardens. The workmanship cannot be faulted. Beautiful background music gave this place a lovely atmosphere. Well done to all and it is free.

Tranquility in the busy city. This is a beautiful garden, a must-see in HK. It's incredible how such a peaceful place can exist in a busy city. Take a nice stroll through the garden to see the beautiful side of chinese heritage.

Gem in the Middle of the City. Almost missed going here, but luckily tripadvisor recommended it, and its definitely worthwhile. Missed this on my first trip to Hong Kong, glad I found it on the second trip. It offers a nice view into some more traditional Chinese architecture and buildings. The koi pond is great, and set in the middle of the city, its a great break. They also sell tea and little snacks.

a quiet garden surrounded by the skyscrapers. Very groomed garden with bonsai style trees and a lake with fishesDon't go there if you are looking for shadow and relief from the heatOverall was really hot probably due to the brick paved roads and this prevented me to enjoy the peace of the gardenStrange contrast between the garden and the skyscrapers and highways surrounding it

Another Free Attraction in Hong Kong. This tranquil public park is located two steps from the Chi Lin Nunnery, also built in Tang Dynasty style over 3.5 acres of land. There is a museum that host a permanent exhibit of potted plants and wood structure. There is also a tea house and a vegetarian restaurant. There is a pagoda and small water falls and lakes. The plants and trees are spectacular. Once again, if you go in a week day, it is very quiet. According to the lcoal, this place is packed during the weekend.

SERENITY. Ah the Serenity! After leaving the wife and kids asleep in the hotel (they went the previous day without me), I caught the MTR to Diamond hill at 7am. After a short stroll I'm hit with these wonderful gardens. I was the only person visiting the gardens apart from a few walkers and a security guard or two. It was one of my favorite parts of HK and I felt like I had it all to myself.Then across the road to the nunnery (although some parts were closed until 10am) for some more photos and back to TST station on the MTR and back in time for breakfast with the family.. what a great day to start the day. FANTASTIC

Beautiful!. It was a nice change from the hustle and bustle of the city. The gardens were beautiful and were a great photo oppotunity. We were able to get to them easily through the subway system. It was even free.

Stunning & Peaceful. Wow! What more can I say! If you want beauty, serenity and traditional Chinese culture in the heart of a city - this is the place to go! A worthwhile visit, and only a few meters from the Diamond Hill MTR station. The quietest place we visited (in terms of people numbers) in HK, which was a welcome break. Right next to Chi Lin Nunnery, which is amazing!! Entrance is free.
An oasis of calm. You wouldn't believe this place was in the middle of a very busy city. It's calm, quiet and simply beautiful.It's a must see in Hong Kong and free
Pretty. We hoped to eat lunch in this pretty garden but couldn't take food in! Interesting to see though and nice break from the rat race!

Lovely gardens. The gardens were off the beaten track but well worth a visit. Every area was well cared for and well layed out. There were attendants in each area of the gardens making sure you did not eat, drink or sit in on the walls, which would have been disrespctable to these lovely gardens.

Beautiful and relaxing!!. Beautiful garden with lots of miniature trees and plants (bonsai). Great landscaping and a great place to take photographs. Near to Plaza Hollywood where you can find a food court with great food.
Peaceful. A circular stroll through a garden with unusual rocks and a carp pond next to a traditional building. Very well done and cared for.
A city oasis.. A beautiful garden set a little out of the central area - easy to get to on the MTR. It's a little escape from the hustle and bustle from the city.

The quietest place in HK. This is absolutely the most peaceful place in the city. Well designed, facilities (also for disabled people), rest areas, friendly security staff. It's worth a visit, especially if never been to any other Chinese style garden. Very close to MTR Diamond Hill (Exit C), free of charge.

A Delightful Oasis. This was my 2nd visit to the gardens - having been there some 4 years ago. They are quite small but very very pleasant. They are just across the road from a large shopping centre. Very easy to get to by the MTR - go to the Diamond Hill station and look out for the signposts to the Nan Lian Gardens.   There is a very nice souvenir shop there with lots of reasonably priced things. All in all, well worth a visit

Nan lian garden a gem. After reading the reviews, we took the kids for a visit to nan lian garden. It was easy to get there by mtr. Just stop at diamond hill station. Just a short 5 minutes walk next to the station. The garden is very well maintained. It is so green amongst the lush of tall buildings surrounding the area. We loved the traditional building, pagoda, exhibition sites. There is also a vegetarian restaurant there if you like Chinese vegetarian. Cost hk 98 per person in a set of 5 dishes. Definitely recommendable to families or any tourists. The chi Lin monastery is just next to the garden and a must see. Best, no entrance fees. We loved this place.
Wonderful place!. This is a quite smaller beautiful area in the huge city of hongkong, I would like to recommend it to my friends and colleagues!

A very nice place. We got to Nan Lian on our last day in Hongkong, I can't believe how I was amazed with the landscape.. It was very beautiful and so peaceful... so near to MTR, just take the Diamond Hill Station and follow the sign. Surely you will be enjoy the area as I did. =)

Peaceful and Beautiful. Lovely garden and easy to reach on the MTR. Some very beautiful elements and peaceful. Perhaps not quite what I expected as I have been to many gardens and botanical gardens across the world. This is well laid out but lacks a variety of botanical plants and is very repeitive - not a bad thing but was not what was expected. Would certainly encourage people to go as a lovely site.
worth the visit. a small piece of heaven in the midst of a bustling city. Would recommend that this be on your list of things to see

A relaxing atmosphere. If you are visiting Hong Kong and you need to take a break from the crowded and noisy tourist attractions it has to offer, just hop on the MTR Kwun Tong line and get off at Diamond Hill. Take exit 2 and follow the signs until you get to Nan Lian Garden. It was late afternoon when we visited. After walking all day, we were exhausted. But once inside the garden, the serene atmosphere totally gets into you. Almost immediately, we felt relaxed despite the hot weather. The wonderful landscape features ornamental trees and water features. Sitting at the rest areas, you can just stare at the wonderful sight all day. It was a simple but wonderful experience.

Defnitely A Worth While Excursion. The Nan Lian Garden is defnitely a great trip to consider if you are wanting an escape from the crazy, busy city of Hong Kong. The gardens are amazinging manicured and the view of the towering apartments from the garden area is quite impressive. There is also a vegiterian restaurant within the garden which is very popular with both tourists and the locals. I must admit the food was not my favourite as it is quite bland and different especially if you are not used that type of food, however the setting was great. I would also suggest trying to book a table before going, as it is very popular and you may find yourself waiting in a long line for quite some time.
Beautiful green garden. Come to visit Nan Lian garden for 2 times, it was great, good place for meditation, escape from the busy Hongkong!
Highly recommended. A serene garden in the middle ofwide roads and high apartments.Just so beautiful and impressive.Note no food allowed

It's OK... would rave about it.. It's peaceful and well maintained.. well actually immaculately well maintained gardens, but not worth the hassle of getting there. Takes about 1hr from the Island. Kinda confusing getting there and the fact that there is a highway.. well 2 of them right above the garden takes away some of the 'serenity' from the experience. Lantau etc is far better.

Speechless………. It’s not a typically public garden where you can lay down in the grass with your picnic basket, bring your pets and let your children playing and running. It’s a garden where actually they keep all the property inside and reserve it well. Inside there are museum, pagoda, mini pond and of course the garden itself. Entrance is free and it’s extremely clean. Security is there to remain you about all the rules & regulation. But so far I must say that this is the best garden I’ve ever been. I see there’s a connecting entrance to Chi Lin Nunnery, but it closed, so you have to go outside and cross the road to reach this nunnery. Make sure you visit both.

Peaceful oasis. HK is busy and noisy - so this garden was like an oasis. Winding paths, pergodas set in the middle of ponds with koi swimming around. It was a very pleasant and relaxing way to spend an hour.

Tranquility in midst of busy city. I have seen this place on TV many years ago but have no idea what's its name. Only during the planning of this trip that I managed to.The garden's design is Chinese oriented with back ground music at low volume to let you feel relax. we went there on a rainy day under a cold weather, but it did not deter us from enjoying the scenic walk in the park. It was not a big park and if you are in a rush, you can complete the whole round in 15 minutes. But a place like this? You need to walk slowly.One memorable site in the garden is a gallery displaying different rock. You may ask what so special with rocks? There were rocks resembling certain objects or people, there were rocks with surface as if it was a painting. the Gallery even give each rocks a name so that you can understand why it is there.Other than the rock gallery, there is also a gallery displaying Banzai. However, I am not really into miniature trees and won't understand much of it.Overall, it is really great visiting this place, especially after a hectic rush to Hong Kong on the day before, it does allow you to let go of the stress.

Worth a visit. Well worth a visit this little oasis of a garden is surrounded by the concrete flyovers and tower blocks of hong kong yet it is an oasis of peace tranquility beautiful plants koy carp. Although some of the walkways were closed it was lovely to walk around the garden see the koy and bonsai trees there are a couple of lovely tasteful Chinese shops and my top tip would be to go to the cafe/ restaurant that is behind the waterfall sit in the window and look out from inside the waterfall while having a jasmin tea.

So calm. This retreat from the hubub of the city is perfect!... in every way.
It is one of my favorite this to do in Hong Kong.
Make sure you make reservations at their Vegetarian Restaurant for lunch.
The rock formations that they have transported to this location will take your breath away. You will be wondering how they did it.

Nice landscape!. This place is good for photo-taking. It is easily accessible from Diamond Hill MTR.
We visited the Garden at around 3 to 4 pm and there wasn't much crowd.
Very relaxing, a hidden gem in the city.. Not so enjoyable on a very hot day, not much shade. Very very beautiful though and very well maintained.

laid back hong kong. A peaceful place in hong kong, away from the popular tourist destination. Soft music piped in to create a meditating atmosphere all over the place. So many bonsai plants beautifully maintained. The sight of calm waters and cascading falls is breathtaking.

Romance and relax. I went there with my boyfriend and had a great time in this 100% feng seui garden! It's also very close to other attractions such as Wong Tai Sin and the nunnery, so you can plan a whole afternoon discovering Hong Kong's side behind the skyscrapers!

Wonderful peacefull place in the middle of busy Hong Kong. My local friend took me here and I loved it! Wonderfull trees, lovely water, peacefull area... Nice little museums and a shop with chinese handicrafts.

Nice & Peaceful. This is a nice and peaceful garden with beautiful trees and running water. They even have soft music playing as you walk through. Although they seemed to be doing some construction with a few areas closed off, it was still a nice stroll through a lush green area.

Beautiful Gardens of serenity. The serenity, the meticulous gardens, the Vegetarian restaurant It was so easy for my husband ( disabled ) to walk with his walker around the gardens and they have a real sense of the WOW! factor. Everything very well signposted, spotless, and beautiful, from the lotus ponds to the Nunnery to the Golden Pagoda and in particular the magnificently sculptured trees. East to reach from Shatin by MTR or the 89 'bus from Royal Park Hotel ( outside the door!)

Wonderful. What a fantastically tranquil and beautiful garden this is. The garden is wonderful and we had tea in the Tea House which was a great experience and would thoroughly recommend it. At first the prices looked a little off putting but for the 4 of us we choose different teas. had some dim sum and cookies and it came to approx HK55. The ceremony and ritual of the tea was great and my 2 teenage children thought it was fab! Well worth a visit

A must see. We have been to Hong Kong several times but have never been to the gardens until this trip. What a gem amongst the jungle! It was awesome and there is no admission charge. Make sure you bring your camera as there are multiple photo opportunities. At the end of the leasurly one hour walk is a good souvineers shop and rather pricy restuarant. At the exit there is another not to be missed attraction called the "Nunnery". It is also free of charge. Getting to the gardens is easy. Just go to the Diamond Hill train station then follow the signs. The gardens are less than a minutes walk from the station exit. Make sure you go or you will miss a beautiful part of Hong Kong.

Beautiful. Even I went there on the day that the weather is bad, raining all day, but it was not a problem to discover beautiful flowers and trees around the garden. Staffs there were still working under the rain. Great job!

Beautiful, but too much pavement.. Hong Kong can be very warm during the summer months. For some reason, it feels about 10-15 degrees hotter in this garden than it does anywhere else in Hong Kong. The second I walked through the gates, I began sweating profusely. Then I realized that the type of pavement used in the garden actually absorbed heat and was radiating up off of the ground. After about 10 minutes, it was overwhelming. We ended up leaving within 30 minutes. If the weather cooperates, this would be a lovely place to relax.
A beautiful place - must visit!. Very close to the MTR so easy to get to and a beautiful place to spend a couple of hours walking around and enjoying the tranquillity of the gardens

Great oasis from the crazy city. So pretty! If the city is making you crazy, go here.There is a tea house inside the gardens. We tried it and it was a very nice experience but it is a bit expensive - everyone has to pay for a tea serving which was something like $25US and you cannot take photos - they will run to your table to say no photos inside. Not really sure why...So, my reco is to pick different types of teas and do one or two tea servings (about 8 -10 cups of tea per), enjoy it and then ask for the rest in little "take away" bags so you can bring it home and have the tea later or give it as gifts.

Beauty and peace in the heart of Hong Kong. No, really!. This is a stunningly beautiful place. The planting and architectural features are picture perfect. The ponds and fish provide a serene atmosphere. This is such a well kept garden, it is hard to believe. And somehow it is FREE! Add to this that it is easy to get to (Diamond Hill MTR), and that very few tourists seem to bother visiting, you have a wonderful retreat from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. There are lovely bonsai trees, temple and pagoda style buildings, and calming koi. There is gentle meditative Chinese music played to ensure whatever cares you had when you entered, are lost as you stroll around.Wednesday is a pretty good day to visit since any exhibitions in the garden are free to enter. We saw some amazing ceramic painting. Bring your camera, because there are so many pretty vistas, you'll want to capture them all to show your friends and family!

Excellent sanctuary of peace in the city. Quick access to the Nan Lian Gardens from the Diamond Hill MTR Station on the Kwun Tong line makes visiting this site a no-brainer. Beautifully restored gardens are recreated in the Tang dynasty form. Even though we visited in swelteringly humid and hot mid-July, we found the stroll around the gardens pleasant and beautiful. Proximity across the street from the Chi Lin Nunnery is very convenient.
Nunnery Garden. Located next to the Chi Lin nunnery the gardens are a delight of orderly colour, quiet & relaxing in the midst of HK's urban clamour

Go During the Week. I visited in early August and it was unbelievably hot. The trees provide some shade and it was definitely worth it. Great photo ops. Maybe even the oft sought after computer wallpaper photo. There is music playing, which you would think would be cheesy, but it was actually kind of soothing. There is a veggie restaurant and it had nice views, although I did not eat there. Getting here is super easy and very well signed as soon as you step off the train at the Diamond Hill station. Free entrance as well. There is a huge mall here too, so that could always be a stop for some AC and bottled water after your stroll around the park (Starbuck's too!). I went during the week (Wednesday) and I only ran into three other people. Visit the Nunnery after (they are connected and the garden guides you around to end at the foot of the temple) for beautiful woodwork and some shade.

A Lovely few hours. Went in July, when it was very hot and humid , but once in the Nan Lian Gardens, the walk around was very pleasant. They are very beautiful. Cross the road and visit the Buddhist Nunnery, another lovely sit. Both these attractions have free entry.
Veggie Heaven. Beautiful surroundings in the middle of HongKong. Delicious and healthy! Meat eaters will not be disappointed . Make a day of it, touring the Chi Lun nunnery gardens .

Peaceful oasis. Very beautiful and well kept Gardens next to Diamond Hill MTR station. Nice and quiet. Very odd contrast with the high tenement blocks and flyover next to it!
If you are into Koi, then they have some amazing specimens. Also an exhibit on how temples were built without nails, but we were lost with the exhibits!

lovely garden.... we visited nan lian garden. one of my friends had been here before and said that its a lovely place to go with your family. he was right . its a nice place. specially in the evening its great. it was nice to go there. we had a great time
Worth a visit.. took in this place as part of a private tour - it was a most peacful and relaxing place to see....
Superb. Maintained to perfection.....Probably the best Chinese style garden I've ever seen.

Beautiful. Lovely Chinese architecture, everything was very beautiful. The garden was so peaceful - it was a great place to relax. It wasn't crowded with tourists, and was very well maintained. I'll never forget this visit!

A beautiful gem. What a delight to find this beautiful garden, well signposted from Diamond Hill MTR we went from a frenetic hustle and bustle, to peace and calm in a matter of minutes.A beautiful well kept garden with some wonderful displays of Bonzai trees.Would recommend that if you have a spare couple of hours while in HK visit this oasis of calm.

Simply Amazing to find a Calm Place like this in this Bustling City!. We visited this place as a group of five people (four Hong Kongers and me) in spring. Luckily we enjoyed beautiful weather, so the pictures we took are really colorful and show the shiny golden surfaces very well.The whole place is free of charge, and it's amazing what you get for it. From as much as I understood, the little round golden temple in the middle of the little lake is based on Japanese architecture and is called the "Temple of Perfection." When we went there, you couldn't get really close to the pavilion since it was barred of with a rope, but it still made for great pictures when you stood on the path in front of it. The other buildings are made of really dark wood, and since it is a special Tang Dynasty building style, there are absolutely no nails or screws used to fasten the planks to each other. It is like a special intertwining building style. You can take pictures from the outside of the buildings, but on the inside taking photos is not allowed.Make sure you bring a good camera though, especially when it's a sunny day. You will get amazing pictures that last for a lifetime as the place offers so many good photo spots. Just one word of advice: Eating is not allowed throughout the garden (I tried to slip a little pastille into my mouth and immediately there was a security guard beside me,) so try to save that up for the little lunch place there or after you get out of the garden premises.All in all I really loved the trip there, also visiting the Chi Lin Nunnery close by. Go there if you get a chance - it's free, is beautiful, and you can get a whole lot of new insights and great pictures!
" Little Paradise". This one of the prettiest garden we have ever seen. Very clean, beautiful and FREE. May be better than Japanese garden in San Fransisco, CA. Just amazing!
City Respite. Great garden. Wonderfully planned and maintained. Not crowded with tourists. Architecture is beautiful, especially the models of buildings.
no screws!. the epitome of chinese architecture... absolutely not a single screw used in constructing the buildings of such grandeur... what can i say...amazing!

Unexpected. When i saw garden, i thought it will be a lame visit. It turned up to be a relaxing, peaceful and beautiful experience.
There's a nice, elegant and colorful green/flowers spaces with souple of lakes and couple of old chinese houses. This is coupled with a soft chinese music.
I really enjoyed it

Overrated attraction. Having read the reviews, I 'd looked forward to our visit to Nan Lian gardens. I was fairly disappointed as it turned out to be quite an ordinary garden. The traditional Chinese instrumental music in the background, enhanced the visit, but I reckon this attraction is way overrated particularly when one has seen the Summer Palace and Beihai Park in Beijing or Jardin de Luxembourg and des Tuileries in Paris.
Peace and Serenity in a Busy Metropolis. The polution, noise and throngs of people in Hong KOng were left behind as you walked through the gates into this little garden paradise.
Hard not to feel tranquil here. Well worth the MTR journey here. Do not miss it.A peaceful oasis in a bustling city.
Serene. Beautiful gardens in the heart of the city. Well worth a wander.
AMAZING!! Highlight of trip to Hong Kong. DO NOT MISS if you love chinese/japanese gardens. A lovely way to spend 2 hrs in a bustling, hot city.
A tranquil city garden.. A must after visiting the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery. The gardeners keep the park in perfect condition making a visit an absolute joy.

Peaceful. Nan Lian Garden, opened on 15th November 2006, is a Tang-style landscaped Chinese garden of classical elegance based on the blueprint of the famous Jiangshouju Garden in Shanxi Province. It was jointly developed by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department of the Hong Kong SAR Government and the Chi Lin Nunnery. Funding for the infrastructure was mainly provided by the government. Some costs were also donated by Chi Lin which was entrusted with exclusive responsibility for the planning, design and construction of the whole garden which covers an area of 35,000 sq meters.

Beautiful garden attached to nunnery. Calm and peaceful garden in the middle of city with no entrance fee. What other reviewers are failing to mention is that it is attached to the nunnery and temple which has several huge Buddha statues. The various shrines were incredible and a very impressive expression of faith. Of course, because it is a place of prayer, you cannot take photos but it is well worth the trip and a great use of two hours. When we left, my husband commented on how relaxed he felt after visiting the gardens and temple.
Pretty little garden. It was quiet, serene and pretty. It's not very big and will not take you long to walk thru. I was glad it's next to the Chi Lin Nunnery for a little added adventure.

A Beautiful Zen like garden with serene atmosphere right in the smack of the city. The place is amazingly beautiful.located in the Diamond Hill near the MTR
Tang-style garden with a very good landscaping. The ornamental rocks formations
is awesome. A Zen like and serene atmosphere and the area is photograph worthy.
I love how hongkong maximize their space..creating a beautiful garden
right in the smack of the city..Love It!

Abolsutely loved it, a highlight of our trip. It is a beautifully laid out garden, with so many different features; very old bonsai trees and so many of them, water falls, lily ponds, beautiful, old chinese architecure and many other features. It is lovingly looked after and well preserved and a serene and quiet place to just enjoy nature and the artistry and passion of the Chinese landscapers and gardeners. Aboslutely beautiful. Even my husband (who only went because he didn't want me to go on my own) loved it. We were there for nearly two hours. It's a definite must see!

Nice place to relax.... An excellent garden, considering being in the congested Hong Kong... though this garden is situated in the Kowloon area. If you like relaxing scenery or just want to escape from the hustle and bustle of the city, you can spend a couple of hours here, just walking through the garden paths. There is a tea house and a restaurant within the garden, as well as a few small exhibition galleries that might be of interest to some. Go across the street and visit the Chi Lin nunnery if you interested in the Chinese temples and architecture.If you've had enough of all the crowded streets and shopping malls, congested MTR etc, this is definitely a place worth visiting.

Baby and baby stroler friendly. Easy to get to from the MTR station, no steep roads to push the stroler ( as u will find at Hong Kong park). Beautiful and calm place, with relaxing music playing, garden route just long enough to see the whole garden in 40 min in a slow pace.. Vegetarian restaurant and tea house available so as a cafe. Cute souvenir shop, 1 temporarily exibition ( incredible porcelain painting for 20$) and 2 free permanent exhibitions - chinese arquiteture and stones). All of them with great AC for refreshment. Friendly staff. Incredible Chi li nunnery accessible with a lift if u have a stroler.This park is much more nice than the Hong kong park. We didnt use any nursery or changing station for the baby, we rather feed and change her nappies at the nursery in the mall just outside the MTR station...

Just a very normal nice garden. Nice little garden which i round it up in 2mins. I bet you've been to something similar in your lifetime before. Its quiet thou right smack in Hong Kong city~Can pass if you are not visiting the neighbouring Chi Lin Nunnery.

Finally, something that makes me go WOW in Hong Kong. Situated a little off the usual Mongkok/Kowloon area is Nan Lian Garden. A peaceful and quiet area in this hectic little city. Traditional chinese music is played in the background as you stroll through the park. Makes you wonder if you are really in Hong Kong, what more, right beside a huge shopping mall which is bustling with activity. Highly recommended for anyone who has an afternoon to spare.
Very nice relaxing Garden. Very nice, relaxing garden hidden in the town, with temporary art exhibition

Brilliant Oasis in the heart of HK. This is so worth a visit if you are exploring HK. An oasis of calm in the hubbub that is the city, an hour relaxing in this gorgeous, well-kept garden will refresh you nicely.There are tables and chairs (in the shade) if you want to bring lunch in and eat it here, I wish I had!Must see place in HK! great for photography too.
lovely tranquil gardens. this is well worth a visit, a serene place among a chaotic and busy metropolis

Absolutely beautiful.... If you want to escape from the hustle n bustle of the city then this is your place...entry is FREE and public transport within handy walking distance...You don't need to be a gardener to really appreciate how beautiful and serene this place truly is...

Peaceful. It's not a huge garden, but it is very peaceful and serene to be there in contrast to the usual hustle and bustle that is Hong Kong. You will only need an hour or two to go through it, but it's definitely worth it. It's a great place for shutterbugs as well. Bonus: It's free!
Nanlian gardens,HK. Simply superb..a quet place with hectic noisy surroundings..Chinlin Nannery nearby is a must visit too

Juxtaposition of an urban jungle and pristine garden.. This park is well worth a visit. It's an oasis in the city. The plants are so well kept some appear to be fake, and when you walk around it seems as if the buzz of the city falls away.
Easy to get to and free entry, worth a visit if your tired of shopping.

Niuseful quiet outing to fill a day. An oasis of calm away from the usual HK. Beautiful and interesting architecture... But not much else.... so good if you are trying to fill part of your day with a quiet outing and an interesting break from sightseeing.
peaceful walk. Don't miss this place when in hong kong. It's very relaxing to walk through the park. It's worth spending a few hours here.

Beautiful and very interesting. We visited the garden and the nearby nunnery (monastery) on a Sunday afternoon. We found the garden to be very beautiful and relaxing (as it is planned to be). I did get spoken to about not falling asleep on a park bench (I was jet lagged), so don't try that. But it was a very pleasant, easy walk and close to a metro stop (Diamond Hill). There are some decent quick food options in the metro station, btw, but not in the park.
clean and green!. nice introduction to the architecture technology of the chinese which is very impressive
Nice Walk. It was a nice walk and didn't take up the whole day so that was good too since there is lots to see in HongKong

Beautiful garden in the middle of high rise buildings. This garden is beautifully landscaped and it is a nice break from the city. They have a few little places with snacks and a restaurant too. Make sure to combine it with a walk up to chi Lin nunnery too
Nice Park. Nice park. This is a must for photography buffs and such. A nice place to chill out if you're waiting for the check in time (:D) or just want to see a spectacular architecture.

how did they do it!!!?. it's amazing to get a sense of the chinese architecture that was used back in ancient times as not even a nail was used in constructing the magnificent structures... gotta say i am very very impressed and in awe of the chinese
Gorgeous gardens. The quality of the gardens with lotus ponds and bridges were quite a surprise for us in the middle of high rises. Do not miss a visit to these spectacular gardens.

A green area in a jungle of concrete. The gardens are a nice break from the concrete jungle of the city and are remarkedly uncrowded when you just need to get away. They are somewhat small and not worth the trip for just the gardens so plan on combining with another activity in the area - there are lots!

Great place!. A green place at the center of the city.
This is one of the must visit place in HK.

Wonderful Blend of Past & Present. A great stop and fun place to photograph. The garden is beautiful and is a great break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Great place to take a quiet, relaxing stroll and take some neat photographs. I loved the contrast of the city sky scrapers in the background of the zen-inspired, very natural gardens. Leave ample time to see the gardens so you have plenty of time to just relax and take it all in (especially if you'd also like the see the adjacent nunnery). I spent 1 1/2 hrs there and wish I'd had more time.
best park I have seen. beautiful rocks and plants. very well kept. Very clean.

Tranquil Garden. I had read about the gardens before we arrived in Hong Kong and, because our schedule was full, the gardens were a low priority. We went to the gardens in between seeing other things but it was a pity we didn't make the gardens a higher priority. We got there just before closing time and so our visit was a bit rushed. However a short visit was better than no visit at all. The gardens are a pleasant, tranquil place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. It is just a pity about all the high rise buildings that stick up into view while walking around the garden. I have seen gardens in Hangzhou, Suzhou, Shanghai, Tokyo, Kyoto and Kanazawa and this garden is at least as good as any of them.

Beautiful and calming. Absolutely beautiful and calming gardens adjacent to the Chi Lin Nunnery. Even going on a very heavy rainfall day, one cannot help but love this garden.Make it a must see on your visit to Hong Kong..
A Garden lovers paradise. This is across the road form the Nunnery and most people consider them one and the same. The Temple is beautiful.

nice garden, but quite new also. its a nice garden, but seems a bit new and artificial. Having seen this type of gardens in Suzhou. Shanghai, Tokyo, Kyoto etc. I find it nice, but nothing special, perhaps except for the back drop of high rises just behind it.

Put this at the top. Easy to get to via MTR, relaxing and inspirational, stroll, don't rush. Relax in the shade on a hot day. Practice mindfulness with every step you take, with every sound you hear, and simple be there.

Wonderful garden. Nan Lian Garden is a public garden located at Diamond Hill, Kowloon, Hong Kong. In the garden, I can see hills, rocks, waters, plants and some ancient looking buildings in the classical style of Tang Dynasty. It's all arranged in a really beautiful way. Some of the buildings are designed in a traditional Chinese way, where no nails were used and it's all fixed a special interlock system. Very clever. It's a really nice to chill out and escape the bustling streets
A little beauty. Arrived to a ugly shopping mall and overhead motorway so was not expecting much. Couldn't have bee more wrong. Totally tranquil lovely gardens and fantastic buildings

Worth seeing. This is an amazing garden and nunnery surrounded by concrete roads, overpasses and yet another shopping centre. It is serene, a welcome retreat on a hot steamy day. Makes you want to take 5. Make sure you visit the temple and lotus garden areas, so beautifully peaceful.
garden in the city. peace and tranquility amidst the buzz! worth it!! i really love this place =)
JoH883. This is one of the most beautiful gardens I have ever seen! Absolutely manicured lawns and plants, elegant crystal clear fish ponds. A gardener's paradise!

Fantastic day trip!. We loved Nan Lian Gardens. The area is very peaceful and the buildings are just beautiful. Much nicer than some of the other 'must do' visits, and it has a lovely little vegetarian restaurant - I'd recommend the afternoon tea!

Still worth it even when its's pouring rain.. Nan Lian Garden was very lovely, it was a pitty that it was pouring rain when we visited here. That didn't stop me from going in. Im glad i did, this place was so peaceful and pretty. It's nice to have a garden like this in the middle of a big city :)

peaceful amid the city chaos. This was a very peaceful place that stretched on for ages. It is clean, the bonsai are gorgeous and it is hard to believe you are in Hong Kong! A beautiful spot to escape the heat.

Beautiful in the rain. So this past Sunday we decided to head over to Nan Lian Garden to have some vegetarian food at the restaurant located inside the garden on the northeastern corner. We booked that morning and were given a waterfall window seat. Just absolute gorgeous view as we sat behind a man-made waterfall. Although we were inside in air con comfort so could not hear the pounding of the falls on the black rocks at the bottom or the rush of waterover the edge, it was still a beautiful view. There are two seatings for lunch 11:30 and 1:15 on Sundays. We were in the second seating and the place was probably 85% full. They have two set menus for people so it is easy to order. We decided to go ala carte instead since there were so many different dishes to try. Too bad a handful of dishes on the menu were not available. The food was tasty but after awhile they all seem to have the same flavour. The four of us spent about $155 each - food was good not great. Service was quick and prompt. Seating was beautiful.After luch the rains came down and we waiteduntil it subsided before venturing into the gardens. After the rains a thin fog enveloped the gardens, making for an unforgetable afternoon. Give the uncertain weather we did not venture across the street to visit the nunnery. Wished we had brought umbrellas as it is very peaceful in the rain. We will definitely come back.

Just another garden.... Yes, It is pretty...but so is other park such as Kowloon park or hong kong park. The only advantage is next to the chi Lin nunnery. The big disadvantage: this is not family friendly park. Do not expect to see playground or fish pond. You are not even allowed to eat or drink inside the park though there are several place to sit down. You can only eat at the canteen area. Worth a visit if only you hv an afternoon to kill and travel all the way to diamond hill and wanna see the nunnery as well. Or u can go here in the morning and go to sai Kung in the afternoon. There is a direct bus from diamond hill to sai Kung.
A Different Side of Hong Kong. This is a very beautiful park with a great zen atmosphere. After 3 days of amusement parks and shopping, this was a perfect respite before heading off to the airport.

A Beautiful Garden in the city. This is a peaceful garden to walk around. There were not a lot of people so there were totally quiet spots. It was nicely landscaped and planted. Also the Chi Lin Nunnery is well worth a visit

Loved this place!. We absolutely loved Nan Lian Garden! This was our first stop during our week in HK and it didn’t disappoint. If it wasn’t for our jam packed itinerary, we would have gone back for another visit. Doing it all over again, we would have saved it as a mid-week retreat from the busy city.
Peaceful Haven in the middle of Hong Kong. Beautiful park with many traditional buildings and shrubs

Calm amidst the bustle. Extremely nice and a pretty place. Easily accessible via MTR by getting down from Diamond Hill station. The garden itself and the museum housing replicas of Chinese temples, the different display halls with stone formations, etc are all so nicely planned. A tip for photographers, tri pods are not allowed! Din't know it coz I din't read the brochure before entering and learned the hard way, nothing unpleasant though! Visit is beat teamed with a visit to the Chin Li nunneryThere is a veggie restaurant and the food is good but slightly expensive. (Visited with mom, there is no such option here! - admins)

Serene Garden. Very surprise to find a beautiful garden in the midst of a concrete jungle. This place is good for people who like laid back attractions. Nice place to visit and picture pretty. But this attraction is good only for one shot , doubt I will go back again but for bonsai enthusiasts , it might be a different story, this place got lots of them and all labelled.

Wow. Everything here were immaculate, from the trees (some are over 1000 years old) that were pruned perfectly, to the beautiful natural stones that compliments the gardens and the beautifully clean Koi Carp Pond, all were absolutely beautiful.You will find lots of staff at hand to talk to who are more than happy to chat to you about everything from the trees to the available facilities, they all spoke English and all seemed genuinely passionate about being there.You need to visit this garden, such beauty and skillful pruning of all the trees and plants. Well worth a visit.

Very easy to get to-nice for a quick stroll. The garden is very beautiful and seems to be very Japanese inspired. There are quite a few paths that take you though the garden and while inside the park you really feel as if you are completely outside the city. You will probably only need about an hour to visit the park- but they did have a very interesting vegetarian restaurant that I wish I had tried. They offered set menus at a reasonable price. There are also some small galleries throughout the park which I did not enter because, while the entrance price was low, I was not interested in the items they were showing (ceramic vases and such). They also had a nice cafe that served only vegetarian/natural foods which was really nice to see. They also has some amazingly clean bathrooms :)

Nice gardens in the middle of the city. Pretty destination with beautiful deity statues. You can travel there by bus if you're feeling adventurous, otherwise take a cab. Better to visit during the cooler months because there is no shade to escape the crazy heat of summer.

Peaceful and nice scenery. It was a surprise to me that such a serene place was nestled in the middle of the city. Quite near the station and arrows lead you from the station to the garden. Best to go there in the morning before loads of buses arrive and the tour groups ruin your photos.

Beautiful, serene....and touristy. Without a doubt, this is a beautiful and serene oasis in the middle of the chaos of Hong Kong. You can walk the whole garden and nunnery in less than an hour -- the space is relatively small -- but you could also pass part of a day there just relaxing. There is quite a lovely traditional-style tea room too, where you exchange your shoes for slippers at the door, and where each table has an element to heat a kettle of water and a slotted porcelain tray with a drain underneath where you can pour out the hot water from heating your pot and cup. Having said that, this place is VERY touristy as gardens like this go. You are not free to just roam around anywhere or sit yourself on a rock by the water, as you can at other Asian gardens I've visited. There are barriers everywhere to keep you on a prescribed route and there are signs telling you to stay off various areas. Come to think of it, I don't recall seeing many, if any, benches to sit on either. There are a lot of security keeping an eye on things, and an awful lot of money-making features for a relatively small garden (to be fair, the garden itself is free). There's an art gallery, the aforementioned tea room, and a fairly large souvenir shop. I didn't see the vegetarian restaurant, but I gather that's tucked in there somewhere too.One other minor complaint: when I was there, the smell of sewage from the public bathrooms was actually wafting into the garden in places, which ruins the effect somewhat.I still give the garden four stars, because it's hard not to love a beautiful and serene Asian garden like this. However, I am from Vancouver, were I used to frequent Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Park and the Nitobe Garden. Both of those are more like "working gardens," where you are welcome to lie on the grass or sit on a rock by the water and read a book or generally enjoy the surroundings as you would any other public park. The Nan Lian felt a bit "look but don't touch" for my liking.

peace and quiet in the urban jungle. We saw some reviews of this place in tripadvisor and decided to visit on our second trip to Hong Kong. This place is simply fantastic, not only is it accessible (walkable from diamond hill MRT station) you can hardly find any place so peaceful and quiet in Hong Kong like this. Don’t forget to visit the temple beside the garden too. If you are tired of all the shopping in Hong Kong, you will definitely love this place.
Tranquility!! in central HK. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill, and the gardens are only a short walk. Very peaceful, well maintained gardens with an excellent vegetarian restaurant

Peace in Hong Kong. These gardens and the adjacent nunnery are a "must see" destination. The gardens are beautifully maintained and laid out and the Buddhist temple is lovely - unfortunately there was no guide book in English which would have been helpful to explain some of the features of the garden. Easily reached from Diamond Hill MTR station. The restaurant behind the waterfall did not open until lunch time so we did not visit it which we would have liked to do. Bathrooms were spotlessly clean.

Fabulous stunning garden and temple. Loved everything about it; took tons of photos, great models, great bridges, wonderful plants, superb rocks and the temple with its bouganvillae and lily pond was superb.
Tranquility. Beautifully maintained. On our visit several areas had restricted access.

gorgeous, tranquil, calm. gorgeous city garden with a Buddhist temple across the bridge, highly recommend if you are looking for tranquility and greenery in Hong Kong, a pleasant vegeatarian restaurant behind the waterfall too.
Interesting city garden. It's good place to visit after hot day to breath fresh air and relax.
Relaxing. We had trouble finding the entrance but once in the gardens were beautiful. We had gone at lunch time and brought a sack lunch, however, eating is not allowed in the several "picnic" areas.

Beautiful Gardens. A good place to gather your thoughts as it is such a peaceful and tranquil place.
Beautiful gardens., really wouldn't expect this in the middle of such a busy city.

Oasis. This place was unbelievable in so much that it was so tranquil and so beautiful yet surrounded by high rise buildings and fast roads but you would so not know they existed once you enter the gardens. It is certainly a "must see" you can spend a whole day there and it is so tranquil....just do it you wont regret it!
Peace and Quiet. Easy to get to via MTR, quiet, beautiful surroundings, uncrowded. No one trying to sell you souvenirs.

amazing! a must see. Nan Lian Garden is an amazing place to visit while in HK. located in the heart of the city among sky scrappers and a restless city life, the garden is an oasis of peace and nature. Incredibly well maintained, it's a glance on the traditional chinese landscaping that almost makes you think you're in another time. Free entrance.
Incredible: dont miss it. incredibly weel kept garden. Nicest place I've seen on China
Peaceful oasis. Peaceful setting with carefully manicured gardens.
Very nice. Very nice gardens. They are near Chin Lin Nunnery - and together they are a great half day away from the noise and crowds of Kowloon...
Modern Garden. A modern garden with easy MTR links. Well worth a stroll with the nunnnery across the road and a good shopping centre.

Peace. Until you look up, it's hard to remember that you're in a beautiful garden in the middle of a big, cosmopolitan city. It's surrounded by skyscrapers and has a fairly new mall across the street but these gardens shouldn't be missed. They are beautifully manicured and there's music playing throughout that will remind you of a spa. Combine this with a visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery across the street.

Not crowded and beautiful. The garden is a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station. Signs are clearly marked all along the way. It is beautifully landscaped and there are some special crafts in the giftshop. The nunnery is attached so if you are interested you can also visit that on the same trip.There seems to be parts of the garden that are roped off that seem to me would make it nicer for visitors. The two times I went the pagoda and and a bridge area could not be accessed and I wasn't sure why. Maybe this is not all the time and I caught it at a bad time. I wouldn't travel out of my way if your time is short in Hong Kong. Kowloon park and even Sha Tin Park, which are near other tourist attractions have beautifully landscaped gardens and ponds that are just as good. They also have places for kids, Nan Lian would have bored my children.
Very nice & peaceful. High rises in background ruined view, but gardens were beautiful in & of themselves.
A beautiful Chinese garden. This garden is set underneath a busy road system yet it is so peaceful and quiet. The closest MTR station is Diamond hill about 12HK dollars.

Quietness exists!. A oasis of peace in the middle of a bustling city. Perfectly maintained garden with the typical elements of a traditional Chinese garden. Good vegetarian restaurant under a waterfall, nice place for a different lunch and to bring visitors!

kind of boring. I'd say this attraction really isn't so interesting unless you have a particular interest in traditional Chinese landscaping and gardens. If you're interested in the vegetarian restaurant, make sure to check the hours - we were there during the middle of the day when they were closed. It is a very tranquil place, so if' you're needing a break from the rest of the craziness of HK, this could be it.

Fantastic gardens. Beautifully maintained.. This is a must visit in Hong Kong. It exceeded any expectations we may have had. There are some great photo opportunities in the gardens and it is a tranquil spot in Hong Kong. Found it not to be crowded when made the visit.
Oasis in the middle of a big city. The Gardens are so serene with beautiful landscaping, which is very well maintained
Unexpected Oasis in the middle of a middle class neighborhood. This place is so unexpected.. stop by the actual monastery to hear the nuns chanting
Worth a visit. Easy to access from the MTR and a definite alternative to the other attractions in Hong Kong

Must visit. I am not really into gardens etc. but this place was beautiful. Got some great photos here and it was nice and relaxing. Temple next door is also worth a visit and afterwards (or to break up the day during shopping) there is good shopping at Plaza Hollywood.

This is where the city stops. MTR to Diamond Station and basically cross the road. A very well kept, serene and functional garden that is another "must see" if you have a couple of spare hours in Hong Kong.

Quiet time. It is worth a visit for an hour just to have some quiet time away from the city noises. It is a well manicured garden which is relaxing to wander through. I enjoyed photographing the gardens with the city backdrop, an interesting contrast. The toilets are clean here! Take the MTR to the Diamond Hill station with a 5 minute walk from the Hollywood shopping plaza.

A gem in the city. It is a specially designed Buddhist garden and is very well managed. Easily accessible by public transport, eg MTRC. Don't miss the vegetarian restaurant inside the garden at affordable prices.
Very peaceful place. I wish I had more time to just sit and relax here. Very calm and quiet, apart for some cars just out side the walls.

Hidden Treasure in the Middle of the City. A lovely scenery that gives you calm and peaceful feeling. You need at least 1-2 hours to enjoy this romantic and relaxing oasis in the center of Diamond Hill. Great place to walk around in the early morning. One of the most beautiful garden I've seen. A must for a first timer in Hong Kong.

Beautiful attraction in the middle of the big city. If this is your first time visit of the city you should defiantly spare half a day to visit the nan-lian gardens.The colorful gardens are decorated with ancient chinese building style, a waterfall with a restaurant behind it and many unique trees, flowers and so on. There's a marked route which take you all around the garden.Getting to the gardens is easy, just take the subway and there's a 200 walk from the station.Also near the gardens there's the huge Hollywood mall you should drop by before or after seeing the gardens (even for a quick meal).

Very Nice Surprise. Visited the gardens late in the afternoon and was pleasently surprised at the beauty and immaculate care. Very calming and quiet........amidst the life of Hong Kong. An easy short ride on the MTR to Diamond Hill and you are there. The gardens for my visit were not crowded at all which was very nice to not have to fight any crowds to enjoy the views. Enjoyed this very much and recommend it to anyone interested in gardens and Asian structures!
Good place but too far from the center. Very small one with beautiul small lake & the temple. But ... I think you should not waste time on a trip.

A hidden gem. Surrounding of the garden is like any ordinary area of Hong Kong. But once you get inside, it is surprisingly quiet and tranquil, due to the specially constructed panels blocking the noise from traffic outside. Set up of this garden is Chinese/Japanese Zen style, all along the trail you hear light music of qin (Chinese ancient musical instrument) which really cleanses your mind. I was surprised to find that this elegantly designed and maintained garden is run by the government but not privately owned. It is free to the public. Inside there is a vegetarian restaurant which serves fine dim sum, good food but expensive. There is free guided tour in Chinese, English, maybe Japanese and booking is needed, they are volunteers so need to check for availability before going.

Serenity in the midst of Kowloon Madness!. This is such a beautiful, serene Chinese-style garden. Attached to the nunnery, it is an absolute pleasure to just walk around and bask in all it's positive vibrations. They have a vegetarian restaurant too (not been there, but it's by a waterfall!), and a very nice pond with these giant, colorful fish. Plenty of places to sit around and read or meditate, and a lovely place to take pictures. They often have some sort of historic art exhibit going on, too. Strongly recommended if you'd like a break from busy city life.

Nan Lian Gardens and Chi Lin Nunnery. We had a lovely visit to the gardens, Nunnery and restaurant. It was a very humid day and it was so nice to spend time in the tranquil gardens. We enjoyed a beautiful meal in the restaurant. We spent about 3 hours there including lunch. very easy to get to from Diamond Hill MTR, all well sign posted. Lovely day out in beautiful HK.

Beautiful, peaceful spot at Diamond Hill. This beautiful garden was about 5 minutes walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station. Entrance is free and you can follow a well defined path to see a wonderful Tang inspired garden design. Trees, rocks, a Koi fish pond and bridges surround a stunning pagoda in the middle of the garden. A water wheel, pond and waterfall sit next to a tea house which opens at 12 noon and overlooks the pond.There is a rockery displaying different types of rocks and steps take you up to a lotus garden that is connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery.

An escape from the city!. After a short trip from TST on the MTR you land in a garden that you think should belong in China from 500 years ago! It was beautiful and the temples were great amongst the skyscraper skyline - my kids said they were the same as in Kung Fu Panda!

Chinese garden of classical elegance. It is an amazing garden amidst all the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. You will find an atmosphere conducive to serenity and tranquility, an ambience in which you can enjoy moments of leisure and peace of mind. It's just about 5 mins walk from Diamond hill station. There is also a vegetarian restaurant serving varieties of Chinese food...It is a must try!!. The nunnery is built according to Chinese architecture and its simply brilliant. The entrance is free

An Incredible Experience - And It's Free. The weather prohibited our original plans. Using Tripadvisor, we located this beautiful garden spot, right in the heart of this bustling city. Every branch, every blade of grass is perfectly trimmed. The peaceful setting is a picture perfect example of the Asian art of landscape. It could not be more enjoyable.
A relaxing oasis. A lovely garden, beautifully tended, wonderfu bonsais and the opportunity to get away from the bustle of Hong Kong. It is easy to get to, opposite the MRT and a shopping centre.

Calm and peaceful place amid the buzz in HK. Visit the temple, learn about the various figures in Buddhism. It is highly awe inspiring yet calming. After that, visit the gardens. A nice place to rest for a while before moving on to other parts of HK.
Great place in a Huge City. We loved it. Went mid day and it wasn't busy at all. We took public transport and it was really easy to find. One of more beautiful places of the city.
So beautiful. It transports you from the busy city we walked around it in the rain. AMAZING

Bonsai treasure. I had read reviews of the garden and was not sure what to expect. We took to MTR to Daimond Hill and its a short 7 mins walk from the station. As you enter the garden you realise its a big park and would easily take about 2-3 hours to make the most of the garden. We followed the trail. It was interesting to see some miniature wooden replica's of famous Asian palaces, temples. The design and effect was excellent. We walked through various types of trees and plants and the attractions amazed the kids. They asked a lot of questions and I was glad they were learning. The other side of the park is the temple however it gets closed around 4 pm so we did not get a chance to visit to temple. There is no entry charges and the garden is well maintained. Its probably the biggest collection of bonsai plants / trees that I have seen. A must go.
Hidden gem. Beautiful hidden gem in Hong Kong. Lovely surroundings. Also, a nunnery on the premises.

Peaceful attraction at a busy district. If you like flowers and chinese ancient architecture, then it is a must go for Nan Lian Garden, alight at Diamond Hill MTR and you cant get lost. Rmb to bring a camera and charge it before you go Nan Lian!

Peace in the middle of bustling Hong Kong. We jumped on the MTR out to Diamond Hill station (on the Green Line) and visited the Chi Lin Nunnery – a large wooden building housing Buddhist nuns – and some beautiful gardens (Nan Lian Garden). Very peaceful and nice to get some quiet time in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong city.

Serenity, pease and harmony. Very peacful and quiet garden. Perfectly preserved from the busy neighbouhoods. I was very impressed by the clean and perfectly shape alleys and vegetation. It's all fenghsui and traditional. you feek like experiencing a walk on the old traditional Hong Kong with respect and peace. Amazing golden pagode and scenery from the top of the garden. Best time to visit is at 4 or 5pm when sun's less powerfull. Perfect place to take photos and rest.

Unexpected tranquility amongst a busy road system. Firstly, the useful stuff (hopefully)...Getting there: take the MTR to Diamond Hill and exit C2. You exit at the shopping mall. Hang a left as you come out, cross the road on your right at the first pedestrian crossing (about 30m up the road), and you're there. The 5 minute from MTR to garden estimate includes the time it takes you to walk from the platform out of the station in my opinion. Try to go at a time when it's likely to be quiet. I went on a Monday at lunchtime, and it was relatively empty then. However, I can see that the tranquility of the place would be lost if it was full of lots of people. A couple of tour groups were arriving as I was leaving and already it was getting more noisy. The monastery is really part of the same site. To get there you just follow the sign up to the lotus garden and you're there. All in all, I was there for about 1.5 hours (garden and monastery), though I didn't stop for tea or anything. Do take a look at the gift shop too. It's not quite as full of the usual tat that other gift shops attached to tourist attractions are. Well worth a visit here even if just to escape the busy city for a short while. And the allegedly 'surly' staff that a few folk have mentioned aren't so bad if you just smile at them and say hi! They are not asking anything unreasonable of you to keep off the grass, not climb on anything etc. There are clearly a lot of people putting a lot of work into keeping this place lovely, so a little respect for that goes a long way (and don't forget that this place is free, so remember you're a visitor, not a 'customer' here). Just a word of warning to some of the ladies - the toilet facilities available here (near the exit) are the squatting kind. They are very clean, but if that puts you off, then there are other public toilets over by the shopping mall/MTR. There are lifts here for disabled guests, but not well signposted and I can't see how someone in a wheelchair would get over the steps up into the monastery/nunnery too, so worth checking beforehand.
Nature meets skyscrapers. Very relaxing place. From the outside, you wouldn't expect that it would be that beautiful. Away from the hussle and bustle of the metro.
Place of serenity and tranquility. An eye opener.. Highly recommend for those who love scenic spots and photography. An amazing experience.

It's a must to visit. I've been to Hong Kong several times but this is my first visits to Nan Lian Garden. Just about 6 stops for MTR from Tim Sha Tsui station.You will have a peaceful moment in Hong Kong.Also, you can across the road to visit Chi Lin Nunnery.Good to be there. Will be there again
Peaceful place. Just went there on visit to Chi Lin nunnery. Affordable gifts in the little shop there.

Serene place in the middle of a concrete jungle. A nice ethnic Chinese park, a rarity in Hong Kong. Can spend an hour or so walking around, taking photos. Mall nearby to keep the family occupied. If you come to Hong Kong looking for a piece of China, this is your place.

A peaceful haven in the middle of the city. We visited early in the day after arriving in Hong Kong and it was lovely to wander around in the sunshine before it got busy. A very pleasant way to while away an hour or two and very easy to get to.
Peace in the middle of a big city!. Gorgeous grounds to stroll though. Peaceful! And right next to a subway stop. Also part of the Chi Lin Nunnery.

Beautiful Park. The park is amazing but you need to be on your best behaviour as their security is extremely strict (which is understandable), the place is extremely neat and tidy (so no touching of the fauna/flora), walk only on designated paths. Our group felt like we were watched from every corner and the minute we did something wrong (like veered off the path or touched a rock, etc), we were reprimanded for. A lovely place to take photos and have a chill out from the hastle and bustle of HKG life on the streets
Very serene. Beautiful calm spot in the city...to walk and sit. We also took tea in the tea house. Well worth the visit.
A quiet respite in a fast-paced city. Loved the quiet of the Garden - a real respite in a very hectic city. Very interesting and beautiful. Worth the trip!

Immaculate precision!. These gardens are stunning. We watched gardens pruning the trees with tiny shears and trimming roots of bedding plants with scissors. The Lunar Reflecting lake with Coy is so pretty and the waterfalls and water wheel a pleasant surprise. A bonus was the Cave Art exhibition-amazing!

Pretty Japanese Kyoto-like Gardens in Hong Kong. Easy to get to from Diamond Hill mtr station (follow signs for Hollywood Plaza exit/or Nan Lian Gardens exit) Only about a 5 min walk from the station and it's free! There is a small museum inside of it that has special exhibitions and displays and you may pay an extra charge to see it. The gardens are pretty and they play some traditional Japanese music that you can hear while you wander through the gardens. There is a nice vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall (for tea breaks or lunch sets,etc) and there is also a small gift shop as well as a small snack shop for a tea break near the end. The Chi Lin Nunnery is connected to the gardens, so it is nice to see that as well when you go. It has a very peaceful atmosphere.

Very quiet and peaceful in a very busy city - and different. Loads of Chinese gardens and pools and models of very old Chinese Monasteriesi etc - well worth it if you like gardens and this one is different. Free too

Quiet spot amid busy Hong Kong. Love this spot of quiet amid the busy atmosphere of Hong Kong. It's a great place to walk around in to relax. It's not so far from the MTR so it's easily accessible. Staff/security is friendly too. A must visit.

A welcome escape from the hectic city pace. It certainly is a serene environment, and quite a surprise given its well within the environs of busy Hong Kong. Somewhat dissapointed that apart from the perimeter walk, most of the park ( the central areas ) were roped off and we were confined to distant views. But nevertheless worth an hour or so and not too difficult to access. Just a 10 minute ride on the MRT from Tsim Sha Tsoi.
Beautiful and calming. I didn't plan on visiting the Garden, but I'm really happy I did. You can't help but leave with a sense of peace and tranquility.

A oasis of tranquillity .... Loved these nicely laid gardens and the tranquil atmosphere, very different from the buzz that goes around outside the walls!
Definitely worth a visit if you in HK for more than 1 day.
A must. A wonderful and serene garden, such a welcome escape from the hustle and bustle of HK.

An unexpected oasis amongst the skyscrapers. A bit out of the way and involves a long-ish MTR trip but a great tranquil and very beautiful place to spend half an hour or so. There is a nice souvenir shop onsite.
Lovely Chinese Garden. Give yourself a break from the busy Hong Kong here at Nan Lian Garden. Enjoy the trees, flowers, Koi fish pond, and clean air.
"Worth Visiting". Hong Kong a bit of a concrete jungle in parts so nice to view some gardens.

Tranquility in the noise of Hong Kong. A visit to the Nan Lian Garden and the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery is well worthwhile. It is a short and well signposted walk from Diamond Hill MTR. The garden is based on classical Chinese garden designs and is beautifully laid out. A meandering path takes you through the gardens and leads you to the wide footbridge to the nunnery, which has a Zen like calm. You should allow at least an hour to see both sights.Eating out in that part of Hong Kong can be a challenge if you don't speak Cantonese. Diamond Hill MTR is underneath a mall called Hollywood Plaza. On the third floor of the mall there is an excellent restuarant called Chao and Hak. It serves Chiu Chow food and has menus printed in English

A retreat from Hong Kong's business buzz and shopping madness. Opposite Chi Lin Nunnery, I really enjoyed going here due to obvious contrast it has with Hong Kong's skyscrapers, busy MTR stations, and huge shopping malls.

A place where one can easily and happily lose himself/herself in tranquil beauty and harmony!. Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden  -  Where one can easily and happily lose himself/herself in tranquil beauty and harmony! A wonderful place for foreign and Chinese tourists alike to enjoy several relaxing hours or a day in; not to mention that it's a locals' favorite! - Free admission and handicapped friendly.- Located in Kowloon, right by the Diamond Hills MTR Station/Bus Terminal and the popular western Hollywood Shopping Plaza. LONG VERSION- This attraction actually consists of two main areas, separately only by a very short overpasswith elevator access.1.
