Nan Lian Garden- This amazingly charming garden park, full of exotic flowers, trees and brushes; large rock-like petrified woods; a huge pond with koy fish; beautiful winding paths for relaxing strolls... along with several fun and educational exhibits, will make visitors keep coming back! - It also has a tea house, gift shop café, a vegetarian diner by the waterfall mill (for lunch/dinner), and a muti-purpose exhibition/performance hall. Some Free Exhibits in Nan Lian Garden- Scale models of legendary Chinese buildings, including one in the Forbitten City; detail displays of the architectural and structral elements.- Large collections of exotic bonsai plants, and strange rocks and boulders.There are also special paid exhibits and occasional musical performances by famed artists as well.Whenever in Hong Kong, my wife and I always come to enjoy ourselves here. This time, we were very fortunate to be able to take in a delightful "Erhu" (Chinese Violin) musical performance by a famous Chinese lady musician in its performance hall in the Nan Lian Garden.2. Chi Lin Nunnery: It has magnificent temples (reportedly built without any nails!); vast, charming courtyards with relaxing gardens and ponds; and buddhists' (recorded) soothing chanting permeating in the air, along with people quietly paying respects, some with burning incense sticks in front of buhddas and Lohans...!For better descriptionof their incredible beauty, click the links: (a) Nan Lian Garden:http://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/things-to-do/images/nan-lian-garden-tour.pdf(b) Chi Lin Nunnery:http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chi_Lin_NunneryAdditional Info:  The Hollywood Shopping Plaza- This huge, very popular, modern Hollywood Plaza above the MTR subway and bus terminal offers numerous Chinese and western styled restaurants and cafés, a cinema, and a variety of shops. Peterskis, Feb 2012

A serene gem to find in the middle of the city. A relaxing atmosphere in the middle of busy Hong Kong, this place is perfect for having a relaxing walk after a busy tour around the island. It is also a great place for photo shoots.

As my husband said - "ok, this doesn't stink". I wish he would use more eloquent language, but you get the idea - the garden was really beautiful and it was a wonderful experience. Though he resisted going, he loved it. I am sorry that many of the paths were closed the day of our visit - but what we saw was really moving and spectacular. So great to see the juxtaposition of the tall buildings behind and the oasis within.The landscapes and the buildings were classic. There was an exhibit of wooden buildings and the joinery used to assemble the buildings. Really impressive, even for the layman.There was also a temporary exhibit of watercolors by a woman who has spent a lot of time in some Buddha caves in the northwest of China - they are really impressive and beautiful. She has done some really exceptional work.

very beautifull & relaxing place. A few steps from the mtr station; there are those beautifull gardens; that are connected to a monastery up stairs. The expeience there is perfect with the wonderful sounds that are heard around.

Wow, what a great job of landscaping. Took a morning off from the bustle of TST and went to Nan Lian Garden and LOVED it !!! Take the time and go here for a wonderful retreat from noise and crowds. Bring your camera !!!

The trees are tagged it is informative and gorgeous. It was such a pleasant walk for me and my husband to be at Nan Lian Garden.
I can only congratulate the whole team working on the beauty of this place!
Dont' Miss. This beauty of a place. Make sure you eat at the Vegetarian Rest.

Great choice for siteseeing in HK!. I took the MTR (subway) from Hong Kong Island out to Nan Lian Gardens after seeing it on the cover of an airline magazine that peaked my interest. The garden itself is really accessible from MTR - it's just up the block and across the road. It was peaceful walking through the garden, though I recommend going in the cooler seasons (Oct-Mar) to avoid extreme heat. Right next to Nan Lian is the Chi Lin Nunnery, which is also worth seeing. There is a tea room inside if you get hungry or thirsty. Figure this trip will take you a half day, but definitely worth it!
Wondrful. We explored this garden with our children aged 8 and 10. It's stunning and you can also visit the Nunnery garden next door.It was a 10 min cab from Mong Kok
Peaceful. A nice pit stop off of Diamond Hill. A quiet, peaceful stroll in the heart of a bustling city. The rock/bonsai garden was interesting but the highlight was the Chi Lin Monastery.
Peace in the city. Off the beaten track so very tranquil. Lots of photo material here.
Very impressive. The gardens were most interesting with their amazing trees, rocks and lake. Nunnery was interesting as well.
everything because i am a green thumb. liked every thing if i can put it all down it would be reprinted into a novel

Worth making the trip for. Nice park of landscaped gardens providing a lovely haven away from the hustle and bustle of HK. Located a stone's throw from Diamond Hill MTR and clearly signposted from the exit.
Make a point of popping into the Chi Lin Nunnery opposite, the temples are astonishing.

Nan Lian was our favorite spot in Hong Kong. Beautiful grounds with Zen influenced style. We liked it so much that we went back on a second visit. It is right next to the Chi Lin monastery and both locations are free of entry cost. We found the garden's gift gallery to have some of the best souvenir/gift items in terms of uniquenesss, price, and quality.

awesome place to relax in the middle of the busy city. the best place to relax within the Hongkong city.well maintained place surrounded by trees & flowering plants.Has enough resting places along the walking track.one souvenir shop inside the garden to buy (not so costly).One Buddha temple with Lotus pond one must visit (unfortunately photography is not allowed there).one fish pond along the track with many colorful fishes .the garden is so near to the Diamond hill MRT station.the Hollywood plaza is near the MRT exit.Free entry & also they provide free brochure with details of the garden.good place to spend time both for adults&kids.
Nice Garden in New Territories. Excellent staff and very clean - beautiful old trees.

out of the way location, lovely gardens. it was hard to get here because our guide book did not have a very good set of directions, but the gardens were lovely and an interesting counterpoint to all the chaos and bustle of HK.

Absolutely Stunning. Words can not even begin to describe this garden - look at the photos and you'll probably agree. Very easy to get to; take the green subway to Diamond Hill and follow the directions to the garden. It's less than a five minute walk outside the subway station, free to visit and very accessible.

A different Hong Kong!. I love the peace and serenity in the garden. Well, it takes some time to get there, but it's worth it! The bonsai, the rocks, even the structure of the nunnery and garden itself is worth the visit!

Great!. This one is a totally pleasant surprise in Hong Kong as it isn't even listed in my guidebook (Fodor's) at all. However, I came to visit Chi Lin Nunnery and I've heard about this Nan Lian Garden across it and you can't miss it if you are coming from the MTR.It has become one of my favourite spots in HK. Very pretty landscaping, although many paths were closed when I visited. They also have a very nice restaurant where I had a quick snack just to rest from all the day's walking. Highly recommended!

Spectacular Gardens. I visited the Nan Lian Gardens during a recent trip to Hong Kong. It is directly across the street from the Chi Lin Nunnery, and I highly recommend visiting both. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill and follow the signs to the Gardens.The gardens are not huge, but meticulously cared for. There is a nice walking path through the gardens and a vegetarian cafeteria within the gardens. There is also a huge koi pond that I could have stayed and watched all day. Some of the koi are just huge!Near the entrance to the gardens there is a red bridge that leads to a red and gold pagoda, which is stunning set against the green gardens and cityscape. You can easily do the gardens in a hour, but i could have stayed all day!

I think that Nan Lian Garden is No. 1 attraction in Hong Kong. Beautiful, peaceful place, no crowds - exactly what you will desperately need after several hours walk in Kowloong. Admission is free. Don't miss it!

Must see. Lovely garden, close to metro. First time we had been to HK, didn't have opportunity to visit . Must combine with Chi Lin Nunnery just across the street. Allow several hours for the combined visit. Very relaxing. Don't rush through

Chinese Gardens. Beautiful garden in Kowloon, with a small lake and water features, in old Chinese style. Very beautiful, a haven in a busy area where you can relax for an hour. Take the MTR, but you then need to take a taxi as it's quite a long way from the nearest station.
Amazing gardens in the middle of a busy junction!. Beautiful tranquil gardens right next to the Nunnery and beside the MRT. We had lunch in the restaurant which was very good vegetarian fare.
great. loved it - relaxing oasis in the busy hum of Honk Kong

The most beautiful spot in Hong Kong is also a free visit. We try to visit both the Nan Lian Gardens and nearby Chi Lin Nunnery at least twice a year in order to escape the bustle of the city, relax and enjoy a couple of hours in the peaceful confines of these two beautiful attractions. Our last visit was this past weekend. It seems visits here never grow tiring. One can easily spend hours strolling, enjoying and taking pictures of the excellently maintained grounds and well manicured plants, shrubs, bonsai, trees, ponds and buildings. Exiting Diamond Hill MTR station, below the Plaza Hollywood shopping mall, you are three minutes walk from the most beautiful spot in Hong Kong, the Nan Lian Garden (free entry).Within the Nan Lian grounds, the walking trail is just wonderful, calm and a feast for the eyes in regard to garden landscaping. There are two impressive ponds, first a shallow pond with a beautiful pagoda that is just serene when the sky conditions are favourable, allowing a blue background for your pictures. The other a large pond with a sizable deck for spectators to watch and admire the beautiful koy fish that swim these waters. There is also an interesting stone room with large boulders, polished by years of resting in riverbeds. Additionally, there is a very good bonzai garden area with some attractive specimen to view and photograph. Further, there is also a vegetarian restaurant, called Chi Lin Vegetarian that is very good, a kiosk that served fair priced dumplings and other veggie snacks and drinks as well as a souvenir shop as well as bathrooms located within the Nan Lian Garden facilities. Once you've had your fill of the Chi Lin Gardens, which usually takes us about 90-120 minutes, you can walk over a bridge and visit the equally impressive Chi Lin Monastery. Combined, these are two of our top temple & monastery experiences in Hong Kong and one of our very favourite places to visit in all of Hong Kong.

Surprisingly Peaceful. Easy to find and a fantastic place to spend the morning. We were very lucky in that it was bright sunny day. It is surrounded by a very busy road but you dont really notice it. The gardens are very well laid out with a lovely waterwheel and waterfall along with a pagoda with carp ponds. There is a fantastic gift shop with some beautiful things in there to buy. The vegetarian restaurant was pretty full when we went to eat but we got seated very quickly and the fixed menu lunch was tasty and different. With some fabulous pickled mushrooms as a nibble plate could have eated a larger amout of those. Have look at the arial photography that is in the grounds as it gives an overview of how the gardens fit into the local landscape. There is a bridge that connects to the Chi Lin Nunnery and I have reviewed that (the Nunnery) separately.
Oasis in centre of Hong Kong. Really lovely spot with everything in beautitul condition. Lovely cafe. Its a most if in Hong Kong

relaxing at the heart of the busy city. you wouldn't expect that there is a place like this in the heart of a very busy place. You will feel very relax and the place is VERY VERY NICE. Lots of trees and rock formation. You will enjoy visiting this place. It's worth the visit!

Beautiful. I thought the miniature wooden models were very beatiful, and the actual park was very nice and quaint. It is adjacent to the nunnery, and the tour of these two areas was the highlight of my trip.
a real surprise in the city. Connected to the Chi Lin Nunnery, it's beautifully set-out with some great places to take a rest or have a meal.

Meh, just a nice Chinese garden ... Good vego restaurant though.. Suppose this place is worth checking out. A nice break away from the intensity of the city.
Bansai trees, old bridges and stuff ... No big deal.
The highlight is a great little vegetarian restaurant tucked in behind a warerfall up the back of the gardens.

Beautiful and compact!. This is absolutely a beautiful, tranquil garden to stroll and comtemplate. There is a single Chinese instrument playing unobtrusively in the background, and visitors are respectful of the meditative atmosphere of the grounds. Around the bend of the central golden temple, in the distance is a sign that ironically reads "the Hollywood Plaza", in striking contrast to the natural beauty and wonder of this jewel of a Chinese garden! A little out of the way, but well worth a visit!

Amazingly peaceful. A very pleasant interlude in the middle of a very busy and hectic city. The gardens were very interesting, well tended and very quiet given the site.Would recommend for anyone intested in gardens, nature and a bit of peace and quiet

A quiet break. Attached to the nunnery temple this bonsai garden has a promenade around a small lake stocked with large koi carps. A beautiful and tranquil stroll will take you to an art exhibition hall, an display of Chinese architecture, a restaurant inside a windmill with water cascading down the window, an ancient rock display and bonsai everywhere. You can also see bonsai being created. There is a tea room where you can sample the best of Chinese tea.
Enjoyed it. Next to the Nunnery, lovely landscaped garden, peaceful amidst bustle of city.

Beautiful Garden--hidden gem!. I discovered this place by accident after gettign off the Diamond Hill MTR station. My intended place was to the beach in which i had to take a shuttle from Diamond hill. It was getting too late, so i decided to see if there were any places to go. After browsing the shops upstairs (hollywood plaza)..i saw a sign for the "temple"/ the nan lian garden. So i found it to be only a block away...The garden is very tranquil and beautiful. There were very few visitorswhen i went. Soothing instrumental music was playing.There is no admission to the garden but if you want to visit some of t he museum/gallery, there is a fee for that. There are vegetarian restaurants inside the premises, and they aren't cheap. I spent 1-1.5 hours here taking pictures and strolling. i arrived upstairs to the nunnery right when they were closing.I recommend this garen if you have more than 3 days in HK and have spare time to explore more.
Excellent retreat from the busyness of Hong Kong. Only a few steps away from Plaza Hollywood at Diamond Hill, this is an exceptionally well-kept Chinese-style garden. Lots of great places for photos.

An oasis in the city. I have looked forward to see this place and finaly I got my behind on the MTR. And what a reward!It seems strict with all the rules and regulations but the garden is realy a pearl in the city!Spend half a day there just relaxing.

A Perfect setting for a Hong Kong afternoon. Close to the Nunnery and the Diamond Hill metro, this garden was also free to visit and simply stunning. Beautifully kempt. Trees, reflecting ponds, a water wheel, koi, a couple of striking red bridges right out of a tourist magazine, a great gift shop, and rock garden made this a special visit. There is a little handout in English and other languages, be sure to grab one of those before you start your tour. I probably took 80 photos while I was there. A wonderful afternoon.

Charming. A nice and charming place for having a walk in nature and peace.Not easy to go there by car, even Taxi drivers doesn't exactly know where it is.There is a new temple there, very well designed, and a great park with Rocks of different properties, shapes and outlooks are arranged and placed in groups or in isolation, matching and enhancing other features elements and the specific environ.

Beautiful garden, great vegetarian restaurant. This garden, a modern interpretation of Tang dynasty design principles, is one of Hong Kong's underrated gems. Considering that it's only a few years old, the plantings are remarkably mature (I'm sure they were brought in at great cost and effort) and provide welcome shade during intense summer heat. A restaurant at the eastern end provides vegetarian dim sum, prepared by the nuns at the adjacent Chi Lin nunnery. Well worth a visit, especially for visitors who will not have a chance to visit the mainland.

Find the time. This is one of the most peaceful and tranquil places imaginable and this fact is emphasised by it's location in the midst of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.We caught the MTR (wish we had a rail service as clean and efficient as this in Melborne) from Kowloon to Diamond Hill and had no trouble finding the place. And what a reward it was,Beautiful walkways through glorious gardens, rockeries, historic structures and ponds -just magnificent!And we noticed that everyone (including ourselves) is less rushed and just a little more personable while there too. I guess this is the whole point. Even if only for a couple of hours, find the time,
Must see on your trip to HK. A really nice tranquil spot in the middle of a busy city

Beautiful oasis. The garden is a bit away from the traditional tourist area, but easily accessible from the metro. It's beautifully maintained, offering some relief from the hustle and bustle of the city. You can eat there, but bring cash, as they don't accept credit cards.

Really taking care of every plants and stone!. Just next to Chi Lin Nunnery, a lots of expensive plants and stone, the management spent a lot in taking care of every plants and stones. A must visit place.

What a beautiful place, nestled amidst the HK hustle..... Take the MTR to Diamond Hill - it's a short 'well signed' walk up the road to Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery. What a beautiful, immaculate, tranquil garden to wander through, away from the busy streets of HK. The gardens are kept perfectly. It is amazing to experience such a peaceful place surrounded by tall buildings. The gardens connect to Chi Lin Nunnery, making it super easy to visit both. There is no entry fee.There is a small gift shop and cafe, however, the reason I keep returning to Nan Lian Garden is to eat at the Chi Lin Vegetarian Restaurant! The food is AMAZING! The restaurant can get really busy during peak season, it may be worthwhile making a reservation. There's a minimum spend per head but it's nothing major, approx. HKD85 from memory. There are lunch and dinner sets or there is an a la carte menu. I have tried something different on each occasion and have loved every dish. I HIGHLY recommend the entire experience.For shoppers like myself that are scared of withdrawal symptoms.... there is a big shopping centre - Plaza Hollywood - right at the MTR exit - that you can visit on the way back to the MTR! (You can't miss it....)

An unexpected gem!. This place is beautiful, surprising and just plain lovely! I like gardens and arboretums, but even if I didn't, I would have enjoyed this place just as much. There are ponds, waterfalls, bonsai paths, rock formations (a rockery where you can sit on the prehistoric rocks). It is pretty, interesting and a nice respite from the hustle and bustle of Central or the business of shopping on Kowloon! I could return to this site, so that says a lot since I am not easily impressed with anything. Note: I read all previous reviews and went to this venue by myself. I did not get lost (a first for me) and I felt completely safe (single woman, westerner).  Make sure you have extra batteries with you and do try to eat in the restaurant; it was too crowded by the time I got hungry and I think they stop serving their Vegatarian fare at 2pm.

Lovely gardens for flora and fauna. Nan Lian Gardens is a nice attraction to visit. The gardens are lovely and there is plenty of different types of flora and fauna to see as well and rocks if that is your thing. I would avoid the restaurant as its quite exspensive. You should be able to see this and tye ajoining Chi Lin Nunnery in half a day.

Lovely garden in the heart of the city. An oasis in the middle of the city. A perfectly laid out garden- very tranquil. I love visiting this garden in rain or sun. A short walk from the tube. Small cafe and bigger restaurant (not tried). A lovely shop- expensive but some original things- as well as some smaller items at lower cost - quality in a city with so much rubbish on sale. Adjoins the nunneries with lovely lotus flower ponds. All free.

Such rest in the middle of Hong Kong. It was so wonderful to be somewhere nice and quiet, and to hear bird song, after running around a very busy Hong Kong for a few days. The gardens are not big but they are pretty (even if you cannot visit all areas) and it is not swamped with people. The tea house offers a wonderful tea experience (not cheap though - 150HK$ per person) but well worth it and serves a lovely vegetarian dim sum and sweet buns to go with it.

oasis in an urban jungle. This gem of a garden is nestled among traffic overpasses, a shopping mall and residential high rises. It is an easy walk from the Diamond Hill metro station, on the way to Chi Lin Nunnery. It is beautifully landscaped with many of the trees and shrubs carefuly labelled and it is dotted with small museums and traditional buildings - a great place to spend an hour or two whether you're a gardener , a geology enthusiast or just looking for a respite from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. There is a gift shop , so shoppers do not go into complete withdrawal.... and when you get tired or thirsty, there is a nice tea shop.

HK Hidden Gem, fantastic garden linked to Chi Lin Nunnery. The Nan Lian Garden is a wonderful, free attraction in the Diamond Hill area. This is actually the first of the two attractions that you visit after exiting the Diamond Hill MTR under Hollywood Plaza shopping mall. Combined with Chi Lin Nunnery, the Nan Lian Garden is our second favorite temple/garden attraction in Hong Kong, just slightly less favored than the 10,000 buddha monastery in Sha Tin. The gardens are immaculately maintained and look like something out of an old Japanese or Chinese storybook. We visit several times a year just to sit and enjoy the garden area. It is such a treasure to be had in the chaotic bustle of every day Hong Kong. There is a nice pond with a small temple surrounded by many bonzais that we particularly like. There is also a man-made waterfall with a vegetarian restaurant concealed behind it. The place becomes very picturesque when we have good air quality days. They sometimes have exhibitions at Nan Lian, they are usually cheap, HK$20 per person or so. We enjoyed the free River Stone exhibit the last time we were there. We enthusiastically recommend the Nan Lian Garden along with a further visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery just across the road, directly linked to the Nan Lian Garden. Combined they make a top 10 attraction in Hong Kong in our opinion. While you are in this area, you can visit the interesting Wong Tai Sin Temple just one MTR stop away (Wong Tai Sin MTR). It is a worthy stop if you enjoy temple visits as well.

Perfect way to spend a lazy afternoon. Combine this with a trip to the Nunnery and you can spend a good few hours here. It's very easy to get to, get the MTR to Diamond Hill and the signage is very good from there. It's free to enter both the nunnery and gardens. It's a peaceful, heavenly oasis in the middle of the city. I was really surprised to at how lovely it was (except for the brightly painted bridge - I won't spoil the surprise!)

Relaxing and spiritual. We had Nan Lian Garden on our itinerary from the start, we wanted our Hong Kong trip to have some cultural attractions , and this was selected from the start by my wife. The Garden is easy to get to, take the MTR to Diamond Hill, exit C2. very simple. The entrance isn't grand, it's actually quite modest, with a small sign starting it's Nan Lian Garden on the front. The garden is designed in a way that, you follow the path one way only. You pass many types of "Hills" we were looking forward to Fragrance Hill, but there was not flowers currently blooming, so there was no fragrance. which was okay, because the ambiounce of the park was more than sufficent without the flowers. We even observed some Monks visiting the park also, which was pretty cool.As we made our way though the park we ended up at the Nunnery also, where we observed a more spirital place. There were many Buddhas, but you are forbidden from taking photos of the Buddhas. It would be easy enough to sneak a photo if you felt like you had to, but we wanted to respect the spirituality of the nunnery. There are descriptions of the Buddhas if you are not aware of them, or the stories behind them. which we found interesting to read, and raced on, to finished reading the rest. This is a must see for anyone who want's culture, and a bit of chinese heritage in their visit. i'd also reccommend this to anyone looking for a relaxing, quiet place to go sight seeing. But, maybe leave the children at home.. this really isn't a child friendly place, unless they have either a love for nature, or are interested in buddism.

Place of peace. Lovely garden. The entrance dint seem to impress, but as we proceeded inside, we were awestruck. Had never seen the various kinds of trees, liitle lakes, falls and few places to eat as well. The best part was the models of temples and monastries. They were a real treat to the eye. ITs a pity they dont allow photography of these models :( Its a big place, so one must keep alomst 2 hours in hand to fully explore adn enjoy the place. Children would love it too !!!

Peaceful visit - worthwhile!. Visiting the Nan Lian Gardens goes hand in hand with visiting the Chi Lin Nunnery - they are at the same place pretty much. Both are free to enter and both offer peace and serenity which is a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.Getting there is easy thanks to the MTR. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill, use the C2 exit. At the top of the 2nd lot of esculators turn right, prior to entering the shopping centre. Nan Lian Garden is directly over the road but you have to walk up to the top of the road and use the pedestrian crossing to get to the entrance.You can spend half a day here if you wish. There is a cafe on site which has a limited but adequate menu and you cant eat outside the cafe so finish what would like to eat before you leave. It was a privilege to visit here, we very much enjoyed walking around here.

Beautiful Oasis in a Crowded City. Although it was hot and humid it was worth the diversion to see this exquisite Garden.It is free and in some pavilions there is no photos allowed. However, it is a snappers dream for the rest of the gardens.It is a minimalist’s layout, very typical of Asian gardens and there is such beauty in a simple rock with a green tree or fir surrounded by concentric circles imbedded delicately in the stones.There are miniature wood buildings in a pavilion (no photos allowed) of extensive well-known buildings from history. There is a pavilion devoted to large random shaped rocks (no touching but photos allowed) that have been polished to a mirror reflection and as simple as it looks, again the beauty is amazing.In the middle is a golden pagoda surrounded by water, greenery and striking red arched bridges. I took so many photos it was embarrassing. Lucky it is a digital camera.The whole walk can take about 30-45 mins at a leisurely pace. There is a vegetarian restaurant on site overlooking the area as well as a souvenir shop that has very reasonably priced things.I try to buy from these places as the money usually goes back into the attraction and I bought several small quality items to take back to family.You can also buy snacks and chocolates as well.This shop is attached to the Nunnery (another review).Take the MTR to Diamond hill, and before going up to the shopping mall turn right.I followed directions from a very helpful TA review and it was exactly right!Take the time if you love gardens and also see the Nunnery next door, it is so worth the trip.

An incredible place to unwind within the hustle and bustle of Kowloon. I have the whole day to spend before checking in for my almost mid-night flight and decided to do more sightseeing and shopping. I saw a beautiful picture of the Nan Lian Garden inside the HK Visitors Guide. It's located within easy reach via MTR, Diamond Hill exit. It was mid-morning when I arrived and there were just a handful of people. I enjoyed a leisurely walk admiring an immaculate landscape, beautiful pagoda, rocks so unique but most of all, being in a calm and quiet environment. Next door is the Chi Lin Nunnery, a place for Buddhist worship, a large lotus garden, pond, buddhist temples and pagodas. Both are incredible places to unwind.
